[ was, Re: Bob Grumman's list poetic schools / Is Langpo acadomina ]

Mark P. --

To what extent is the influence of the New Yorker "responsible for"
(used advisedly) the "Ashbery is okay" phenomenon, I wonder?

The number of poets whose work appears in the New Yorker is (I think)
pretty small -- and of those whom that magazine publishes, there are a
select handful whose poems tend to appear again & again thru the
years (including several I like a lot -- e.g., Ashbery, Mewin, Simic).

The New Yorker's role / status in broad American culture is, it could
be argued, unique.  For one thing, it has (if I'm not mistaken) far and
away the vastest circulation of ANY "serious literary" publication in
the country (or -- heck -- the world);  & it's a weekly = Ubiquitous.

Acceptance by that mag as one of a few dozen whose poems they'll
oftentimes carry upwards of half a dozen times per year, seems a seal
of approval for a fairly broad & influential hub of the culture.

There are (naturally) *many* other elements in the Ashbery-in-America
phenom -- one being (simply) the long tenure of his contribution.
Heck, even Ginsberg gets flower petals, eventually.  As I understand
it (I wasn't around in those days), for a long time, Ashbery was
severely criticized & ridiculed & deemed something of a laughingstock
(rather as John Cage was -- or for that matter, Phillip Glass till
at least the mid-'80s) in highbrow circles.  Eventually, the court
jester gets a cabinet post, natch: the stone that's rejected (but
establishes a strong name), becomes the corner stone.  If you're part
of the dialogue, doesn't matter too much if the press is good or bad.

As said, just a thought (or thought & a half).

best,
d.i.

Date:         Wed, 9 Jul 1997 19:23:00 -0500
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         "Pritchett,Pat @Silverplume" <pritchpa@SILVERPLUME.IIX.COM>
Subject:      Re: Naropa readings
MIME-version: 1.0
Content-type: TEXT/PLAIN

Last Friday, if memory serves:

Keith Abbott opened the evening with several short stories. These were
straightforward realistic narratives, frequently funny, somewhat ribald, and
tinged with a careful attitude of pathos toward the inevitability of aging
and the lot of the working class. "Three things my Irish father instilled in
me: a fear of the dark, an eternal mistrust of politicians, and a deep
respect for the fishy things in the ocean." The best of these pieces was
"Sayonara, Adios, Goodnight:" a seemingly biographical account of Abbott's
glory days as a high school football player in Washington and his singular
encounter with "the man who put death inside me," Clarence Clancy Williams,
a freight train of a running back who later went pro and who for sixty
minutes on an autumn night more than 20 years ago pounded the knowledge of
mortality painfully deep into Abbott's bones.

A very pregnant Wang Ping read next. Her coolly enamelled accounts of life
as a child in China during the Cultural Revolution only served to increase
the strange horror of hearing how her mother, for instance, was driven
through the city streets by teenage Red Guards in a humiliating show of
public punishment. "We are nothing but grains and yet all we think of is to
crush one another - what is the matter with us?" In another story - the
theme again revolving around heartbreak, loss and exile - she demonstrated
how the imagination has the power to reshape reality simply by the writing
of stories. I don't do it justice - it was both funnier and more poignant
than I get across. Her last piece was the somewhat too long "8000 Miles of
Clouds & Rain" - an elegy for Allen Ginsberg centering on her work as a
translator for Allen at a conference of Chinese poets. A paean to New York
City as the exile's paradise, it recounted how AG flew into a rage when the
Chinese poets opined that things were getting better in Tibet and his
subsequent apology : "Sorry to yell for Buddha."

Lorenzo Thomas closed the evening with a marvellously warm and expansive
reading of new poems - I hope to be collected somewhere soon. From "Morning
Raga:" "while you were sleeping undoubtedly some tragedy occured - but
somewhere someone is singing." The best title of the night: "The Sadness of
Space Exploration," which Lorenzo confessed to having stolen from a
student's essay. Though brimming with easy humor, Thomas's reading of life
is a deeply moral and compassionate one. One poem, "An Education," described
listening to Mingus through the ajar back entrance of the Five Spot.
"Hollandaise Salsa" recalled a trip to Amsterdam with fellow poet Ricardo
Sanchez. Typical of his generous range of thought and emotion, it was both a
critique of colonialism and a postcard of nostalgic wanderlust familiar to
anyone who's ever been homesick while abroad: "salsa leaking out the windows
of the lost lost in their dreaming - feels like home." A smattering of other
lines scribbled in haste: "the heart a speedbag for emotions." "You're not
alone as you think. That would be impossible. But God is not a pinch
hitter." (Recalls Delmore Schwartz's famous line: "existentialism means
nobody else can take a bath for you"). "We have decided everyone has a
problem - that's our idea of equality."

From:         "Aldon L. Nielsen" <anielsen@EMAIL.SJSU.EDU>
Subject:      Re: Acadominatrix
In-Reply-To:  <Pine.HPP.3.96.970710095639.28315B-100000@serv4.law.emory.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0

My problem with "acadmoninant" is unrelated to whether it is thought to be
a compliment or a pejorative -- Seemed to me such a term should either
mean a poetry dominated by academics (or by the academic) -- or a poetry
that is dominant in the academy -- Clearly neither is true of any
iteration of LANPO one might care to describe ("My favorite definition
still the one offered nearly a deacde ago by Ron Silliman, to the effect
that a language poet is anyone who has evern been accused of being a
language poet) --

The MIT is to whatever as Buffalo is to the rest won't work for anybody
familiar with academic pecking orders --

and it certainly does make a difference which vantage point one chooses
from which to view the academy -- I suppose LANPO might appear
acadmoninant to anybody visiting Buffalo for a weekend (though it didn't
to me) -- but out where the vast majority of teaching is done in this
country things couldn't look more different --

____
as to how the pcking order maintains itself impeccably, I here reproduce a
letter recently received from a West Coast academy -- since I already have
a good job I am able to find this amusing:

Dear Dr. Nielsen:

I am sorry to have taken so long to inform you about the status of our
search for a full professor.  The search continues, and I am writing to
ask whether you still wish to be considered for the position.  You are one
of a dozen applicants remaining on our list, so I hope you are still
interested.  In the Fall MLA Job Information List we will advertise the
position again, but we are opening the search to associate professors.  We
hope to compile a short list by the end of the calendar year.


___
I told them that, while it would certainly be interesting to be part of
such an unusual process, I would decline.

______

part of the problem I've seen in the recent discussions of "which came
first" regarding "theory" and certain theoreticllay inclined poetries has
been the foreshortened perspective -- take a gander at this:

"there is no world of objects which antedates the experiences of any
individual.  All perceptual objects . . . are integrations of contact and
distance experience, achieved through a process which began as practical
or organic and became theoretical when the practical act was inhibited."

This is not a Francophone academic writing -- It was published in 1945,
and today's whiz kid award goes to the first listomaniac to identify the
American philospher whose position is here described --

I don't know about the hypothesis that the Nyer has "mainstreamed" or
"ok'd" Ashbery, mainly because, with a few exceptions, Ashbery being one,
the Nyer's poetry editor sucks.  I don't know of a repectable magazine
that publishes a higher percentage of truly vapid poems - somehow Tina
Brown has managed to update/upgrade the rest of the mag without bringing
the poetry along for the ride.  I'd rather see a years worth of poems by
Tupac in there than what they're currently dishing out.  So, yeah, I
suppose it lends a certain respectability to Ashbery among a certain
constituency, but not among many poets or serious poetry readers.   -m.

On Thu, 10 Jul 1997, Douglas Barbour wrote:

> I do know this: more big publishers publish books on
> contemporary theory than publish books of contemporary poetry...
>

I hope some people on the list can provide more info about publishing.  It
is my understanding that print runs of academic texts are "typically" 500
copies and that those runs almost never sell out.  If a theoreticl text
does "take off" it usually means it is being adopted for classroom use at
a goodly number of schools - that's the market, yes, for theoretical texts
(and for most "literary" texts as well)?  This is, perhaps, why you see
all sorts of theoretical collections coming out all the time, including
texts of "primary" works with secondary criticism (I'm thinking here of
the series that's out that provides different theoretical readings of
literary works, e.g. *Heart of Darkness* collected with feminist, New
Historical, Decon, Psych readings of it) - as authors and publishers try
and keep current and sell books for class adoption. Now contemporary
poetry - I don't know who the target audience would be for a "big
publisher"??  Sheesh, don't Romance Novels, self-help books, New Age
books, horror books ...  sell a zillion times more than than contemporary
poetry and contemporary theory combined?

I guess the big question is what do we learn when we compare publishing
trends?  What does it mean that Stephen King sells so many books and has
so many films made from his books - btw, I use the phrase "so many books"
with caution.  To be a best seller in this country how many books do you
have to sell?  It's a very small number, compared to the population, yes?

Date:         Thu, 10 Jul 1997 14:14:24 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Jacques Debrot <JDEBROT@AOL.COM>
Subject:      Re: Langpo and the academy

Of course Language writing is as much an argument against (de Man) as it is a
collusion with poststructuralism (say, in the work of Althusser).  Moreover,
it strikes me that the term "academic poetry" as an implied or explicit
description of Language writing is  pejorative and/or confusing given its
already strong association with New Critical poetry. Nor does the prevalance
of certain aspects of critical theory on American campuses necessarily
translate into the dominance - or even the acceptance - of a specific
poststructuralist aestheic practice - either that explored in various ways by
the Language school, or any other.

Date:         Thu, 10 Jul 1997 13:50:03 +0000
Reply-To:     ARCHAMBEAU@LFC.EDU
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Robert Archambeau <ARCHAMBEAU@LFC.EDU>
Organization: Lake Forest College
Subject:      White Male Hegemonist Club
MIME-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit

I was settling into the vast expanse of my customary brown leather couch
in the White Male Hegemonist's Club yesterday, looking forward to a
night of port wine and cigars with some of the regulars (George Bush,
Donald Trump, John Hollander, Seamus Heaney, George Bowering, Charles
Bernstein, Iggy Pop, Gore Vidal, Robert Bork, and others of that ilk and
kidney), and I happened to glance up at the gilt-framed oil portraits of
past members of our club, all fine chaps, really "our sort" -- Nelson
Rockefeller, George Orwell, Jack Kerouac, General Patton, Elvis, Charlie
Chaplain, Sir Stephen Spender, Ringo Starr -- and I thought to myself
(just as the butler showed up with the evening papers and lit my cigar)
I thought wistfully to myself, you know, Archambeau old bean, maybe we
are all a bit too much alike, maybe, just maybe, we ought to let a few
others join, for a change.  And just then the door burst down and the
angry crowds were upon us.

--
Robert Archambeau
Department of English
Lake Forest College
Lake Forest, IL 60045
http://www.lfc.edu/~archamb/

See: behind bullet-proof glass, the ruby slippers sparkle.
We do not know the limits of their powers.
We suspect that these limits may not exist.
 --Salman Rushdie

>a compliment or a pejorative -- Seemed to me such a term should either
>mean a poetry dominated by academics (or by the academic) -- or a poetry
>that is dominant in the academy -- Clearly neither is true of any
>iteration of LANPO one might care to describe ("My favorite definition
>still the one offered nearly a deacde ago by Ron Silliman, to the effect
>that a language poet is anyone who has evern been accused of being a
>language poet) --

>familiar with academic pecking orders --
>

>acadmoninant to anybody visiting Buffalo for a weekend (though it didn't
>to me) -- but out where the vast majority of teaching is done in this
>country things couldn't look more different --
>
>____

>letter recently received from a West Coast academy -- since I already have
>a good job I am able to find this amusing:
>
>Dear Dr. Nielsen:
>
>I am sorry to have taken so long to inform you about the status of our
>search for a full professor.  The search continues, and I am writing to
>ask whether you still wish to be considered for the position.  You are one
>of a dozen applicants remaining on our list, so I hope you are still
>interested.  In the Fall MLA Job Information List we will advertise the

>hope to compile a short list by the end of the calendar year.

>such an unusual process, I would decline.
>

>

>individual.  All perceptual objects . . . are integrations of contact and
>distance experience, achieved through a process which began as practical
>or organic and became theoretical when the practical act was inhibited."
>
>This is not a Francophone academic writing -- It was published in 1945,
>and today's whiz kid award goes to the first listomaniac to identify the
>American philospher whose position is here described --

Date:         Thu, 10 Jul 1997 15:27:49 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Mark Wallace <mdw@GWIS2.CIRC.GWU.EDU>
Subject:      Hank Lazer's OPPOSING POETRIES and "academic ideas"
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

        Seeing Hank Lazer's name appear on the poetics list several times
yesterday reminds me that I've been curious about the fact that though
there's been a lot of recent discussion about Bob Perelman's THE
MARGINALIZATION OF POETRY, I haven't seen much talk about Hank's double
volume of criticism on language poetry and related matters, OPPOSING
POETRIES. It makes, I think, for a crucial read on the subject that's come
up recently about the relation between language poetry and the academy,
and language poetry and theory. I've read no recent volume of criticism
that seems to me as SPECIFIC as Hank's book about the differences between
the academic "network" (if you will) and the "network" (loosely and not)
of poets associated with language poetry. While it is fairly
clearly targeted towards an academic context, OPPOSING POETRIES insists on
the DIFFERENCES that are at stake in making a place for language poetry
inside the academic world (and not solely there, of course). I think he
also delineates pretty carefully where language poetry is related to
literary theory, and where it differs from it--he shows why language
poetry can by no means be reduced to "literary theory by some other
means."

        In any case, I don't think one ought to be too quick to collapse
distinctions between terms such as "academic discourse," "literary
theory," "language poetry" and the like. There are many types of discourse
that are not literary theory. There are many types of literary theory
which are not academic discourse. Neither one of them refers to a single
kind of activity anyway, and all of them produce some
interesting books, and perhaps more often less interesting ones. "Language
poetry" itself intersects with both these possibilities--there are some
academic books about it, there are some "language poets" who took a lot
from French literary theory, and others who took less from it. Actually
I've seen some "language poets" be rather xenophobically American, at
least in conversation, far more likely to put forward Stein or Williams
than Derrida.

        I find myself fairly skeptical about claims that this
or that theory, this or that school of poetry, can be called in any simple
sense "dominant in the academy." My own sense is that the disciplinary
strategies by which academic departments and careers are shaped, ALWAYS
these days takes precedence over any particular "literary" or
"theoretical" approach--most approaches sooner or later get some piece of
the bureaucratic distribution of the department, and that's where it
stops. What's dominant is MONEY and BUREAUCRATIC organization,
and while there are many fine theorists and poets who work in academic
contexts, the specifics of what they think are much less important to
university organization than the fact that the organization can seem to
"cover" and "have an expert in" as many "relevant" areas as possible. The
traditional Milton scholar may have disdain for the new scholar of
subaltern studies, and the new scholar of subaltern studies may find the
old Milton scholar intolerably hegemonic. But they are both still dealing
with IDEAS, whereas the bureaucracy that they are a part of has only a
secondary concern (if that) with IDEAS. What a university bureaucracy
cares about is the organization of those ideas in ways that make financial
"sense" as they see it. Ideas are the commodity that the university sells.
It is the SELLING that is dominant. When something no longer appears to
sell to enough people, it will disappear sooner or later from the academic
marketplace. How many universities no longer have a classics department,
for instance, or teach even a single class in how to read ancient Greek?
And if you think you're sticking around because your own discourse is more
crucial than those, I'm not sure you don't have a big surprise coming.

        In short, I'm not sure I don't find this stuff about "dominant
academic ideas" almost to be a kind of whimsical nostalgia for a world
that never existed in the first place. The only dominant ideas I'm aware
of have very little to do with literature at all.

        Mark Wallace

of confusion, and anxiety that leaves me sleepless. I am well aware of

Date:         Thu, 10 Jul 1997 14:40:00 -0500

Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         "Pritchett,Pat @Silverplume" <pritchpa@SILVERPLUME.IIX.COM>
Subject:      Re: Readings, Shmeadings
MIME-version: 1.0
Content-type: TEXT/PLAIN

Stop me if you heard this one before...

Tuesday at Naropa:

Cassandra Terman began the evening by reading from her work and I have to
confess that I was not as drawn to her poetry as much as I've been to that
of others in this series. Her poems worked in the vein of personal
observation of the world - that is to say, they tended to *be about*
something, rather than *being* something in themselves. Given that, they
offered some nuanced attentions to both the natural world and the quotidian
moods of the psyche. "What a blessing to be stripped of the burden of
meaning..." "We travel in a language of syllables and antelopes..."

Kristen Prevallet (who gets my vote for coolest shoes of the Summer Writing
Program) read next from _Perturbation, My Sister_, a re-collaging of a Max
Ernst collage the title of which unfortunately escapes me now. "Magnificent
parrots that will die at the sight of light..." Though I'm unfamiliar with
the original, what impressed me about these poems was the way in which
Prevallet stood Ernst's obviously wild surreal collages on their head to
effect sleights-of-hand that were not only playful and fecund, but full of
sly amusements. Ernst's obessions became Prevallet's comedies (and perhaps
vice-versa as well). "To connect the project of building to the possibility
of touching the sky." "Lead, Glass, Poppy" was her take on the apocalypse as
a media event, recombining images of news stories that ranged from warfare,
archeaology, cult suicide, suburban child murders and the history of
displacement - "Pick this up and explode."

Lisa Jarnot closed the evening and may be fairly said, I think, to have
caused a real stir, at least judging from various comments overheard
afterwards. (Could Naropa be the Cannes of the poetry circuit? O Marcello, O
papparazi, where are you?) Jarnot read from _Some Other Kind of Mission_ and
from newer work. Her poems defy easy excerpting since their procedures are
so concerned with repetition, overlap and a kind of echolalia. The method is
both encyclopedic (seemingly) and precise, which is to say, exclusionary. A
poetry of disjunction, cagey wit, and circular rhythms, in which perception
is a conjoining of disruptions and clarity is conferred through a series of
confusions.  (That's what I scribbled in my notebook anyway...) All of this
delivered in a lowkey, unemphatic, sometimes deadpan pitch that at times
took on the characteristics, the hue (and rue) of a litany of the obtuse and
recalcitrant *things* (read: words) with which we stock our lives. Dazzling.
=========================================================================

From:         Matthias Regan <regan@CHEM.NWU.EDU>
Subject:      Re: Langpo and the ory
In-Reply-To:  <v01540b01afea4606cf86@[129.128.238.37]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

I am sorting through these various postings about theory and language
poetry and wishing I could respond at greater length and also more
specifically.

Jordan: thank you for your response, I wish I had in front of me. I think
your solution -- to ask one or more poets from a list of excellent ones is
the way to go. Ideally I'd ask all those poets and then ask a bunch of
theorists as well and see where their answers overlap.
        I'm not surprised Jonathan Culler hasn't read Olsen, Creeley, if only
because such study of contemporary  poets must itself be symptomatic of
postmodern tendencies in thought. Is it a response to a "surplus of
signifiers" that we (I, at least) feel compelled to scurry about
investigating the work of contemporary (or very near contemporary) writers?
Has post-industrial capitalism encouraged us to forget the past to such a
degree? Perhaps not: I don't know! Right from the start I was always most
interested in contemporary writers.
        Its interesting to me that people keep bringing up Derrida (Douglas B.
mentions him, and others have in postings earlier this week--is he being
used as a signifier for a larger group of theorists or are people referring
specifically to his work, and if so which essays, which books? (I confess,
I've read relatively little by Derrida, which might be why I am about to
potentially undervalue his influence on Langpo.)
        I would guess that for many of the US poets of the 50's - 70's (Black
Mountain School, New York School, da Beats) much of the critical work got
into the bloodstream through a previous generation (half generation) of
poets (Williams, Pound, who get their theory direct from the novelists and
poets who generated the historical conditions from which Tel Qel (sp?)
sprang) and painters (I'm thinking of the O'hara connection, Motherwell et
al.).
        Then in the 70's - 90's, I'd reckon, but I'm guessing, you start to get a
lot more poets with PhD's and much more directly influenced by literary
theory. Most of the influence was no doubt pretty reactionary, but that
seems to have been a peculiarity of US academics at least since 1913, if
not since the Adams & Jefferson tapes.

Jacques Debrot writes:

"Of course Language writing is as much an argument against (de Man) as it is a
collusion with poststructuralism (say, in the work of Althusser).... Nor
does the prevalence of certain aspects of critical theory on American
campuses necessarily translate into the dominance - or even the acceptance
- of a specific
poststructuralist aestheic practice - either that explored in various ways by
the Language school, or any other."

        Totally true. And perhaps a case can be made for de Man being more
influential--though probably less directly than poststructuralists--on
contemporary poets in general...?
        I have focused on poststructuralism because at the heart of my query is a
desire to see how and where structuralist linguistic theory translates into
poetry--is adopted by the poets themselves.
        Nor does the predominance of some theory necessarily translate into a
certain practice--but does it translate into any practice at all? And whose
practice? And how directly thought-out is it?

Matthias

Comments: To: "David R. Israel" <davidi@MAIL.WIZARD.NET>

The appearance of the acceptance of the marginal (i.e. the threatening) by
the mainstream often falls under the heading of "neutralization by
assimilation" or as James Agee put it "the emasculation of acceptance" but
since Dodie Bellamy rightly pointed out the gender bias of that term, call
it instead "the defanging of acceptance."

Tina Brown has certainly affected a turnaround at The New Yorker, mainly by
pumping up the number of fashion ads and filling its pages with English
writers, but as I understand it, the magazine still operates at an annual
deficit of $10 million. Charles Bernstein addresses some of the economic
dynamics at work in America's various poetry cultures in his essay "How
Poetry Works." (May be where I got that ten mill figure...).  I agree with
Michael Magee about the egregiousness of poetry Alice Quinn publishes,
though I remain a shamelessly devoted reader of the mag. We can't look to
Tina Brown to push the poetic envelope.  I don't see the New Yorker
occupying any position of cultural centrality - those days are closing fast
 - except in its editors minds.  And I don't think "broadness" can be equated
with "influential," David - just the opposite. Only look at the cartoons -
they're rife with "mene, mene, tekel, uparshin" (sic) -  this is urban East
Coast culture, ironically and anxiously aware of its impending dissolution.

in love with the rhetoric of apocalypse,
Patrick Pritchett
 ----------
From: David R. Israel
To: POETICS
Subject: instance of Ashbery
Date: Thursday, July 10, 1997 3:17PM



To what extent is the influence of the New Yorker "responsible for"
(used advisedly) the "Ashbery is okay" phenomenon, I wonder?

The number of poets whose work appears in the New Yorker is (I think)
pretty small -- and of those whom that magazine publishes, there are a
select handful whose poems tend to appear again & again thru the
years (including several I like a lot -- e.g., Ashbery, Mewin, Simic).

The New Yorker's role / status in broad American culture is, it could
be argued, unique.  For one thing, it has (if I'm not mistaken) far and
away the vastest circulation of ANY "serious literary" publication in
the country (or -- heck -- the world);  & it's a weekly = Ubiquitous.

Acceptance by that mag as one of a few dozen whose poems they'll
oftentimes carry upwards of half a dozen times per year, seems a seal
of approval for a fairly broad & influential hub of the culture.

There are (naturally) *many* other elements in the Ashbery-in-America
phenom -- one being (simply) the long tenure of his contribution.
Heck, even Ginsberg gets flower petals, eventually.  As I understand
it (I wasn't around in those days), for a long time, Ashbery was
severely criticized & ridiculed & deemed something of a laughingstock
(rather as John Cage was -- or for that matter, Phillip Glass till
at least the mid-'80s) in highbrow circles.  Eventually, the court
jester gets a cabinet post, natch: the stone that's rejected (but
establishes a strong name), becomes the corner stone.  If you're part
of the dialogue, doesn't matter too much if the press is good or bad.

As said, just a thought (or thought & a half).

best,
d.i.

Jim Murray and Brett St. Louis

Subject:      Re: The practical act
In-Reply-To:  <Pine.GSO.3.95.970710090553.14285D-100000@zeus.sjsu.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Dear Dr. Nielsen:

I think Whitehead is British, not American, but if he's not, I vote for
him. Unless it was Dewey. Henry would know.

I certainly applaud the notion of "perceptual objects" (and thereby the
external world) only "[becoming] theoretical when the practical act was
inhibited."

It's the tendency of certain aspects of "Cultural Studies" to deny the
existence of an external world in toto that troubles my sleep.

Now, who said this?

"We all talk about poetry so abstractly because we all tend to be
indifferent poets. At bottom the esthetic phenomenon is quite simple: all
one needs in order to be a poet is the ability to have a lively action
going on before one continually, to live surrounded by hosts of spirits."

Also a philosopher, not American. Prizes in the eye of the beholder.

Subject:      Re: Langpo and the academy

On Thu, 10 Jul 1997, Jacques Debrot wrote:

  Moreover,
> it strikes me that the term "academic poetry" as an implied or explicit
> description of Language writing is  pejorative and/or confusing given its
> already strong association with New Critical poetry.

What is the antecedent of the pronoun "its" in this sentence?

Are you saying that the "already strong association" is, in fact, valid?

The question are tangle. What is at stake in pursuing the
"language"/"theory" rapport? Is this a historical probing? Have we moved
so far after the fact of the moment that we can now begin tracing
influences, genealogies, royalties? I don't know (everything always feels
like its just beginning when you're late, until you realize the
reconnaisance (spp) your doing is really only archive work --then you fix
a cold juice drink). Is it important to set in stone, ink, eggwhite, the
exact dates, matches and teams? Was Sartre responsible for Action
Painting? Did Wittgenstein cause Joseph Kosuth? James, Stein? Maybe I'm
muddling it here, but the notion that language writing is indebted to or
engendered by French philosophy feels restrictive, -ted, -ting. Everybody
is around
         by the same tray of books. Everybody

is on the clock. Why are similarities, preoccupations (and not to diminish
the intent of the authors involved, WHAT ABOUT ZEITGEIST, oh) triggers,
paper tigers, and not                       time shares (I admit, I'm apt
to reduce distintions to friviolity, perks, where is raul ruiz?? we're on
to re-runs.)
 Theory is important.
  Poetry is more important (to me).
Sometimes they meet and hold hands
for a movie.

What kinds of questions are asking? ANd for what reasons?

jittery,

Bennett.

                     &c.

The Newyorker has never been urban eastcoast culture. Founded by a guy who
was insecure about being from Kansas, it's always been centered in the
fantasy culture of similar immigrants from points west with deprived
childhoods. For many years its standards of selection have been whatever
fits neatly between ads for stores on Madison Avenue without distracting
attention too much from those ads.
New York has always been about clamorous ethnic cultures. When the fleet of
the future James II appropriated it from the Dutch there were already 18
languages in daily use. This reality rarely gets the attention of the
Newyorker, except, perhaps, in snotty little pieces in The Talk of the Town;
it certainly has little influence on the rag's own cultural attitudes.
Ashberry's acceptance I think stems from two things: his Hamptons style,
subject-matter and diffidence and his currency in the higher-priced
precincts of the art world. Another way of saying he walks the walk and goes
to the right parties. None of which takes away one iota from his often
splendid poetry.

From:         Mark Weiss <junction@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Re: instance of Ashbery
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Music survives because musicians enjoy playing it, find it challenging, and
pass it on to their students in the conservatories. We have Bach's music
because Brahms and his friends, against popular opposition, played it, and
it never stopped being taught. Glass has made no inroads into the
conservatories and virtually no one plays his music except his own ensemble.
I have it in confidence from members of same who must remain nameless that
they only play it because it's a gig.
Non-minimalist composers (I hung out with a lot of composers in NY) speak of
Riley and Reich with respect; I've never heard the same in regard to Glass.
Most consider him a pious fraud. Admittedly this is anecdotal.
Myself, I always assume that there's value out there until I'm flattened
with boredom--maybe I have to learn an idiom before I can hear its virtues.
So I sat through, in person and on disk, Einstein, Satyagraha, The
Photographer, and Koyanasquatchi (only partially intentional misspelling)
before I decided to stop punishing myself. It was harmonically and
rhythmically uninteresting, consistently mannered, formulaic and predictable.
On this last (I'll refrain from another attempt at creative spelling) an
interesting story. My kid saw the film when he was about twenty, loved it,
loved the music. So he got the album. He was genuinely mystified that when
he listened without the visuals none of what he had thought was there was.
He realized that it was background music. Try the experiment with any of the
above-named efforts.
Also interesting--when the music is performed in concert (non-dramatic
settings) one recognizes few members of the audience from concerts of
non-minimalist non-top 40 western music. I would guess that few would have
any idea who Elliot Carter is.
The world is full of wallpaper music, even among "classics"--lots of 19th
century ballet music, for instance, that survives only because dancers and
audiences like the choreography. Myself, I like wallpaper music at noisy
parties or in elevators. If I plunk down the cost of concert-hall tickets
and what I get is likeable noise I feel like I've been had.
I don't like "likeable" poetry, either. If there's no challenge, nothing new
to be learned, I don't go back for more.
Is it clear that I don't like his music?

From:         James Finnegan <JforJames@AOL.COM>
Subject:      Re: Bob Grumman's list poetic schools / Is Langpo acadomina

In a message dated 97-07-10 19:07:17 EDT, you write:

>For instance, is
>John Ashbery really mainstream?  When exactly did he become so?  Does
>calling his work mainstream reflect on the nature of the writing qua
>writing, or merely on the fact that he has managed to make a good
>name for himself and to become accepted in (the perceived)
>establishment?

When he was feted by the Academy of American Poets and such
like organizations he became mainstream. The writing itself lags
behind and is certainly not mainstream per se. But Ashberyesque
has certainly been adopted by enuf younger writers, adapted to
their own purposes, to have become part of the flow rather than an
obscure eddy. And when a poet publishes with a certain press,
with a certain initial print run, he/she becomes mainstream like it
or not. Success causes the cache of avant-garde to fade very quickly.
If everybody's reading him/her, how can he she expect to hold much
interest for the serious few.

Finnegan

Date:         Thu, 10 Jul 1997 22:12:13 -0400
Reply-To:     BobGrumman@nut-n-but.net
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Bob Grumman <BobGrumman@NUT-N-BUT.NET>
Subject:      Re: Schools of Poetry and Acadominance
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Guess I have to post one more message about my list of schools, and
acadominance.  All I'll say about the latter is that I never did not
claim that my impression of language poetry's acadominance was more than
an impression.  It now looks to me like whether the impression's valid
or not will have to await the judgement of posterity.  I suspect no one
knows enough now to say for sure.  And there are so many angles of view
on the question.  Lang po certainly has SOME kind of cultural status
that APR poetry doesn't have--sorta like art films versus Hollywood
fare.

Oh, and I want to thank Mark Presjnar for his good friendly letter about
his possible harshness about my take on acadominance.  As I back-
channeled him, it's impossible to avoid occasionally saying things
not-quite-exactly-as-intended, or worse (and, yow, have we seen examples
of that on this list!)  I, for instance, am now annoyed with MYSELF for
denigrating APR poetry in my effort to defend myself from the charge of
denigrating language poetry.  This when I asked, "Who takes APR poetry
seriously?"  Well, actually, *I* do--that is, I take the best poetry of
that sort seriously as poetry--since it's as good as ANY poetry.  I do
look down on APR, the magazine, though, not for the poetry it publishes
so much as for the poetry it ignores.

As for my list of poetry schools, David Israel made some interesting
points about it.  He's about convinced me that linking individual poets
to particular schools is too tricky to be practical (though I made a
point of stating that many poets belong to two or more schools).  About
Ashbery, here's another of my very unsupported impressions (because I
don't know either poet's work that well): Ashbery and Graham are
modernists in the jump-cut poetry school founded mainly by Pound and
Eliot, particularly with Eliot's "Wasteland."  They are thus very
mainstream.  Or maybe they've pushed jump-cut poetry sufficiently to
merit being called "neo-jump-cut" poets.  Or "hyper-jump-cut."  I would
include in their school many poets called language poets who collage
texts, which is a way of jump-cutting as opposed to doing what language
poetry does (in my view--see below).  Although the textual collagists
seem much more craft-extending than Ashbery--and, certianly, than
Graham.

Anyhow, I think David put his finger on many of the difficulties of
trying to work up an effective list of poetry schools.  In naming
schools, my criteria were scattered and unsystematic--because the list
is a typology, not a taxonomy--and more to generate discussion than to
attain definitiveness of any sort.  A school on my list might be based
on status and other extra-literary qualities but in my formal taxonomy I
try to be objective (which I'm still backward enough to believe
possible) and work out my kinds of poetries based on what they
concretely are and/or do as words on paper (or in speech).  Language
poetry, by my definition, then is simply poetry that significantly
breaks conventional grammatical norms--to significant expressive effect.
I couldn't care less how Marxist, for example, a given lang poet is or
not provided he messes around with grammar.  And considerations of
what's mainstream or not are outside my taxonomy, as well as what's
good/bad.

So, maybe in a month--if I have the courage--instead of posting an
updated version of my schools of poetry, I'll try my taxonomy on the
group.  I'll bet you can't wait.
                                                       --Bob G.

Date:         Fri, 11 Jul 1997 01:09:19 +0000

From:         Joseph Zitt <jzitt@HUMANSYSTEMS.COM>
Organization: HumanSystems
Subject:      Re: instance of Ashbery
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Mark Weiss wrote:

> Glass has made no inroads into the
> conservatories and virtually no one plays his music except his own
> ensemble.

As I understand it, he hasn't published his scores for performance
(except a very few) so that if people want to hear his material live
(as, is obvious from his touring grosses, many do), they have to
bring in his ensemble to do it. A smart financial move.

> I have it in confidence from members of same who must remain nameless
> that they only play it because it's a gig.

That's their problem.

> Non-minimalist composers (I hung out with a lot of composers in NY)
> speak of
> Riley and Reich with respect; I've never heard the same in regard to
> Glass.
> Most consider him a pious fraud. Admittedly this is anecdotal.

The ones with whom I hung out in New York (granted this was a decade
age) were, indeed, quite bitter at Glass. It usually boiled down to
his having figured out how to make a living at it.

> It was harmonically and
> rhythmically uninteresting, consistently mannered, formulaic and
> predictable.

I have heard the convincing theory that one finds most interesting
the music whose changes that person can predict, at the level at
which the person chooses to listen, about half the time. If you're
listening to Glass expecting it to move harmonically and rhythmically
as much other music does, you will be disappointed. Much of Glass's
early work moves most interestingly on the note-to-note level and
at the level of changes of rhythmic pattern.

If trying to sing along with the quick vocal patterns in "Einstein on
the Beach" doesn't cure one of finding it rhythmically uninteresting,
I would be surprised to hear that person claim to find rhythmic
interest in anything.

> On this last (I'll refrain from another attempt at creative spelling)
> an
> interesting story. My kid saw the film when he was about twenty, loved
> it,
> loved the music. So he got the album. He was genuinely mystified that
> when
> he listened without the visuals none of what he had thought was there
> was.
> He realized that it was background music. Try the experiment with any
> of the
> above-named efforts.

I honestly don't know what you mean by this. To the extent that I do,
it does not correlate at all with my own experience.

> Also interesting--when the music is performed in concert (non-dramatic
> settings) one recognizes few members of the audience from concerts of
> non-minimalist non-top 40 western music. I would guess that few would
> have any idea who Elliot Carter is.

Yup. And there's little crossover between fans of Metallica and Roberta
Flack. You point is...?

> If I plunk down the cost of concert-hall tickets
> and what I get is likeable noise I feel like I've been had.
> I don't like "likeable" poetry, either. If there's no challenge,
> nothing new to be learned, I don't go back for more.

Some of us don't demand that every experience slap us upside the
head. I've done music that confused and bored everyone, poetry
that inspired audiences to run away in tears, and theatre that
terrified the viewers. Been there, done that. I now like having
audiences who find what I do pleasant.

Your attitude is that of someone who would send a restaurant
dinner back because nothing tasted odd.

> Is it clear that I don't like his music?

Gee, I woulda never guessed!

Date:         Fri, 11 Jul 1997 16:11:54 +1000
Reply-To:     jtranter@sydpcug.org.au
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         John Tranter <jtranter@SYDPCUG.ORG.AU>
Subject:      The New Yorker and O'Hara
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

I don't usually post my poems to the list, but this one seemed apposite
to the Ashbery / New Yorker discussion. Attribution: it first appeared
in print late last year in the Times Literary Supplement (UK).

John Tranter :  The Green Buick

          'You remained for me a green Buick of sighs, o Gladstone!'
                                                              - Frank
O'Hara, 'Second Avenue'

I'm off, he said. He shrugged on a soft dark
overcoat, and wrapped a check scarf around his neck.
He stuffed his sighs into the Buick
ignoring the way the late afternoon cloud-light
glittered along the strips of chrome and gold trim.
A few spots of rain glistened on the metallic
lemon-green paint shine but somehow not on the
actual paint. "What is it with the New Yorker," he said,
as he heaved his old suitcase into the back seat -
he had the white canvas top down,
the car was full of junk - "that the writing
has to agree with the faux-naïf cover art,
as well as the advertisements for English raincoats
and cruises to the Bahamas? You'd think
one humiliation would be enough! Look at it,"
he said. He looked around for the last time.
We're talking New York circa 1960,
the Apple just beginning to go
bad at the core. "As for the San Fran-fucking-
Cisco Renaissance," he grunted,
"the whole boatload of sensitive bullshit - "
he thumped the flank of the car with his hand,
and it was like jolting a slide projector:
in his brain a magazine clunked to the right, then
slithered left, and dropped a fresh splash of colour
in the slot - he could see the Buick already swaying
over the wooden planks above the swollen river
and then down the track to his childhood home -
"ah, the blue gloom under the trees," he said,
"the neon burning outside the motel
in a halo of rain sparks - ecstasy!"

END

Great story--Which I think could be told many times over about lots of
people like Culler, who I encountered a bit when I was working in the
Cornell libraries in the early '80s....He is indeed a perfect (but highly
representative) example of this ghettoization.  Pick up most publications
that reflect what the Academy thinks is going on in literchur, and you
really won't find any awareness of contemporary poetry..(..some awareness
of rather bland workshop verse, of course, but none of *contemporary*
poetry in Stein's sense..)

Mark P.
atlanta

On Thu, 10 Jul 1997, Douglas Barbour wrote:

> I am reminded by the discussion of LangPo & the academy, & Jordan Davis's
> last post, of a visit to the U of A some years ago by that great
> interpreter of deconstruction, Jonathan Culler, who was giving lectures on
> poetry, but only poetry of the Romantic period, with an occasional
> reference to TS Eliot. They were brilliant lectures except for the fact
> that they seemed totally unaware of the contemporary & recent poetry that
> seemed to me most open to his thinking. So I asked him why he (& others of
> his ilk in the Eastern US universities deep into Derrida et.al.) had
> nothing to say about those poets (I said then) whose work so fitted into
> their theorizing such as Charles Olson, Robert Creeley, etc (I wasnt then
> all that aware of the LangPoets by name, & also thought he would at least
> know the names I mentioned -- but he did not!). He had no answer for me,
> then, & I'm not sure he would now. So perhaps the question is which *parts*
> of the academy, or even which academies, are paying attention to the new
> (recently so) poetics. I do know this: more big publishers publish books on
> contemporary theory than publish books of contemporary poetry...

I think you're right about the New Yorker, altho' to some extent it's
integrated with other institutions (anthologies, etc.) in determining What
Is Acceptable..It is certainly a major cultural presence; I remember a
co-worker many years ago; before working with me in a Michigan library she
had been a proof-reader at Encyclopedia Britannica in Chicgo.  She
recounted how her supervisor there worked passionately on poems....And
never sent them anywhere except the New Yorker.  His only goal in his life
as a poet was to be published in the New Yorker!  That suggests that this
is a publication with an interesting and resonant role in our culture!

I'm sure you must be right about there being *some* dismissal and ridicule
for Ashbery early on...How much I wonder?  Still, I don't think the elder
statesman, if-you-hang-around-long-enough factor is that strong in his
case...Larry Eigner hasn't gotten that kind of broad endorsement and
anthologization; Coolidge, Palmer and S. Howe all began publishing in the
last few years of the '60s, right?  That's 27 years at a minimum, and the
mainstream isn't throwing too many roses...

Mark

On Thu, 10 Jul 1997, David R. Israel wrote:

> [ was, Re: Bob Grumman's list poetic schools / Is Langpo acadomina ]
>
> Mark P. --
>
> To what extent is the influence of the New Yorker "responsible for"
> (used advisedly) the "Ashbery is okay" phenomenon, I wonder?
>
> The number of poets whose work appears in the New Yorker is (I think)
> pretty small -- and of those whom that magazine publishes, there are a
> select handful whose poems tend to appear again & again thru the
> years (including several I like a lot -- e.g., Ashbery, Mewin, Simic).
>
> The New Yorker's role / status in broad American culture is, it could
> be argued, unique.  For one thing, it has (if I'm not mistaken) far and
> away the vastest circulation of ANY "serious literary" publication in
> the country (or -- heck -- the world);  & it's a weekly = Ubiquitous.
>
> Acceptance by that mag as one of a few dozen whose poems they'll
> oftentimes carry upwards of half a dozen times per year, seems a seal
> of approval for a fairly broad & influential hub of the culture.
>
> There are (naturally) *many* other elements in the Ashbery-in-America
> phenom -- one being (simply) the long tenure of his contribution.
> Heck, even Ginsberg gets flower petals, eventually.  As I understand
> it (I wasn't around in those days), for a long time, Ashbery was
> severely criticized & ridiculed & deemed something of a laughingstock
> (rather as John Cage was -- or for that matter, Phillip Glass till
> at least the mid-'80s) in highbrow circles.  Eventually, the court
> jester gets a cabinet post, natch: the stone that's rejected (but
> establishes a strong name), becomes the corner stone.  If you're part
> of the dialogue, doesn't matter too much if the press is good or bad.
>
> As said, just a thought (or thought & a half).
>

Excellent post, and I agree with everything therein...

I hope I made it clear in my previous posts that my main objection to

On Thu, 10 Jul 1997, Aldon L. Nielsen wrote:

> My problem with "acadmoninant" is unrelated to whether it is thought to be
> a compliment or a pejorative -- Seemed to me such a term should either
> mean a poetry dominated by academics (or by the academic) -- or a poetry
> that is dominant in the academy -- Clearly neither is true of any
> iteration of LANPO one might care to describe ("My favorite definition
> still the one offered nearly a deacde ago by Ron Silliman, to the effect
> that a language poet is anyone who has evern been accused of being a
> language poet) --
>
> The MIT is to whatever as Buffalo is to the rest won't work for anybody
> familiar with academic pecking orders --
>
> and it certainly does make a difference which vantage point one chooses
> from which to view the academy -- I suppose LANPO might appear
> acadmoninant to anybody visiting Buffalo for a weekend (though it didn't
> to me) -- but out where the vast majority of teaching is done in this
> country things couldn't look more different --
>
> ____
> as to how the pcking order maintains itself impeccably, I here reproduce a
> letter recently received from a West Coast academy -- since I already have
> a good job I am able to find this amusing:
>
> Dear Dr. Nielsen:
>
> I am sorry to have taken so long to inform you about the status of our
> search for a full professor.  The search continues, and I am writing to
> ask whether you still wish to be considered for the position.  You are one
> of a dozen applicants remaining on our list, so I hope you are still
> interested.  In the Fall MLA Job Information List we will advertise the
> position again, but we are opening the search to associate professors.  We
> hope to compile a short list by the end of the calendar year.
>
>
> ___
> I told them that, while it would certainly be interesting to be part of
> such an unusual process, I would decline.
>
> ______
>
> part of the problem I've seen in the recent discussions of "which came
> first" regarding "theory" and certain theoreticllay inclined poetries has
> been the foreshortened perspective -- take a gander at this:
>
> "there is no world of objects which antedates the experiences of any
> individual.  All perceptual objects . . . are integrations of contact and
> distance experience, achieved through a process which began as practical
> or organic and became theoretical when the practical act was inhibited."
>
> This is not a Francophone academic writing -- It was published in 1945,
> and today's whiz kid award goes to the first listomaniac to identify the
> American philospher whose position is here described --

Subject:      Cash Moves
In-Reply-To:  <Pine.SOL.3.93.970710144755.19870B-100000@gwis2.circ.gwu.edu>

I can't agree enough with Mark Wallace here. To speak from my
experience, as it were, UVa (both open and closed to both "theory" and
"experimental poetry" --mainly closed, actually) allows a certain amount
of showroom exposure to a wide variety of idea-baubles, but even the
university's best efforts to ingratiate its students and faculty with a
range of "discursive possibilities" winds up feeling like a buffet-table
at the MLA. I know this sounds snide, possibly too reactive, but the
extreme pluralism (or mask thereof) necessitated by state funding and
stodgy boards of visitors is almost enough, enough almost to push me into
a soft-collar career in data analysis. THe shouts of "dominant" this and
"entrenched" that make for loopy cocktail games, but are they more than
diversions? It all passes soon, it's a matter of juggling, navigation,
profit margins, blind-buying, commerce servers --The musak and prosac of
customer relations. Know your markets. Locution, locution, locution. This
is not to say that some ideas aren't "better" than others, or more useful,
or more accepted, or more suffered (I am not so tipsy yet Jordan), but,
you know,                    When
                                Rorty
                        enters
                                the lecture hall
        I am certain I hear
                                                the cappacino call.


                          "Shhhh.
                                Many things are about to be said

                   and do they all concern you."




On Thu, 10 Jul 1997, Mark Wallace wrote:

>         I find myself fairly skeptical about claims that this
> or that theory, this or that school of poetry, can be called in any simple
> sense "dominant in the academy." My own sense is that the disciplinary
> strategies by which academic departments and careers are shaped, ALWAYS
> these days takes precedence over any particular "literary" or
> "theoretical" approach--most approaches sooner or later get some piece of
> the bureaucratic distribution of the department, and that's where it
> stops. What's dominant is MONEY and BUREAUCRATIC organization,
> and while there are many fine theorists and poets who work in academic
> contexts, the specifics of what they think are much less important to
> university organization than the fact that the organization can seem to
> "cover" and "have an expert in" as many "relevant" areas as possible. The
> traditional Milton scholar may have disdain for the new scholar of
> subaltern studies, and the new scholar of subaltern studies may find the
> old Milton scholar intolerably hegemonic. But they are both still dealing
> with IDEAS, whereas the bureaucracy that they are a part of has only a
> secondary concern (if that) with IDEAS. What a university bureaucracy
> cares about is the organization of those ideas in ways that make financial
> "sense" as they see it. Ideas are the commodity that the university sells.
> It is the SELLING that is dominant. When something no longer appears to
> sell to enough people, it will disappear sooner or later from the academic
> marketplace. How many universities no longer have a classics department,
> for instance, or teach even a single class in how to read ancient Greek?
> And if you think you're sticking around because your own discourse is more
> crucial than those, I'm not sure you don't have a big surprise coming.
>
>         In short, I'm not sure I don't find this stuff about "dominant
> academic ideas" almost to be a kind of whimsical nostalgia for a world
> that never existed in the first place. The only dominant ideas I'm aware
> of have very little to do with literature at all.
>
>         Mark Wallace
>

perhaps (all-too-)handy perjorative.  There may be some bias in
evidence, but if I'm not mistaken, the journal is a bit more catholic
in its inclusions than recent references might lead one to suppose.

Mark --

the idea that Ashbery's influence is everywhere is one I come across a
lot, and am befuddled by, as well. You have to extend the idea of Ashbery
out far enough to include J Graham, J Tate, and who else? to give it any
credence. The language of influence is crowded with hard hard c's. If
Ashbery really has that much influence, why aren't things (why
isn't the influenced poetry) _better_?

Influence epidemic,
J

Re:
>
>the idea that Ashbery's influence is everywhere is one I come across a
>lot, and am befuddled by, as well. You have to extend the idea of Ashbery
>out far enough to include J Graham, J Tate, and who else? to give it any
>credence. The language of influence is crowded with hard hard c's. If
>Ashbery really has that much influence, why aren't things (why
>isn't the influenced poetry) _better_?
>
>Influence epidemic,
>J

I think some people see Ashbery's influence in any poem that "doesn't make
sense."  But I agree that when you get down to specifics -- in whose work
is the direct influence of Ashbery's strategems (indicated I suppose by
things like receding antecedents, shifting subject matter, falsely amicable
diction, or non-referential syntax) directly and consciously assimilated --
you probably wouldn't come up with a very long list of names.  Maybe John
Yau?  Maybe Dean Young or Donald Revell? More than one poet has told me
that when they look to their bookshelves for poetry that will drive/inspire
them to hit the keyboard or legal pad, Ashbery's are the last ones they'd
select, regardless of how much they might otherwise like and appreciate his
work.

-- FM

We may choose to disagree without assuming that the other is incapable of
understanding.  I go to music with open ears. For the record, I don't assume
that people who like Glass' music are shallow or stupid. I do wonder how
well-informed they are. For instance, Glass' rhythms are not particularly
difficult or complex and it's hard to imagine how anyone could think so who
knew 20th century music.
It's possible that my composer-friends are consumed by bitterness. Maybe I
just haven't noticed.
Yup, I like art that surprises and challenges me--I prefer Pollock to his
teacher Benton (but check out the latter's surprising early abstractions),
Rothenberg (Susan) to Alex Katz (but check out the small early collages),
Zukofsky to Edgar Lee Masters. Maybe that's like preferring rotten food. I
apply to music the same criteria I apply to the other arts--it's what comes
naturally to me.
But I tire of talking about myself. I expected the brickbats. Let it be
known that one member of the list is not a Glass fan, and let it rest at that.

Date:         Fri, 11 Jul 1997 12:19:00 -0500
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         "Pritchett,Pat @Silverplume" <pritchpa@SILVERPLUME.IIX.COM>
Subject:      Re: Last night at Naropa...
MIME-version: 1.0
Content-type: TEXT/PLAIN

... was the last night of the Summer Writing Program's reading series, held
in true showbiz tradition within the "friendly confines" of the Fox Theater
on University Hill.

Unfortunately, I arrived late (didn't check my ticket for the starting time)
and so missed both Bobbie Louise Hawkins and Anselm Hollo reading from their
work and entered in the midst of a fierce oratorical performance by Michelle
Clinton, whom I'd last heard at the now defunct Chatterton's on Vermont in
LA.  The vivid sense of anger and the flamboyant embattled rhetoric against
persecution and violence to women were still there, but I felt a certain
tendentiousness at work also, and a failure to engage language to its
fullest extent - a decision, clearly, on Clinton's part, to eschew the
stilletto for an instrument with heavier impact. It led to me to think of
several things, among them, Camus' line "To be classic is to repeat oneself.
 And to know how to repeat oneself." Was Clinton doing the latter? Also, how
is her poetry more political (or less) than say, Bernstein's "The Kiwi Bird
in the Kiwi Tree?" I'm not sure - but I found myself agonizing over the
problematized interface between protest and poetry. This turned out to be
something of a leitmotif for the evening.

Next, Anne Waldman and Andrew Schelling performed a spirited and engaging
duet, accompanied by Mark Miller on flute and Steven Taylor on one of Allen
Ginsberg's harmoniums, of some poem-tales from their translations from the
Pali Canon, _Songs of the Sons and Daughters of the Buddha_.  Rendered in a
fresh, contemporary idiom, these pieces were nevertheless curious, to say
the least, as they mainly concerned themselves with exhortations against the
wiles of the flesh and grim repudiations of the body. A strange grafting of
newer Buddhistic teaching with obviously older material that derived from a
tradition of moralizing folktales.

Steven Taylor took the stage and sang in dulcet voice a stunning setting of
Blake's "London."

Stan Brakhage -  looking something like a Mennonite - fairly hopped onto the
stage in a delightful display of joie de vivre following this, and gave a
wonderful homage to the 20th Century American epic poem - Williams, Pound,
Zukofsky, Stein, Dorn and HD - how their works provided an essential fuel
for his own work, all by way of introducing Ronald Johnson.

In a hoarse voice, Johnson read from _Ark_: Spire for LZ, describing how he
had already written it when he heard the news of Zukofsky's death and how
that then changed the poem, made it more serious. He also read one of the
Ramparts, and closed with Arches for Stan Brakhage.  To say more than this
would be gilding the lily, I'm afraid. Suffice it to say, it was great to
see and hear one of the greatest poets in the land. Johnson closed real
trouper-style, saying his book was on sale in the lobby (I hope he sold them
all!) then raised his bottle of Bud in salute.

Diane di Prima read next. First, "Gestapo Poem." Then two elegies for
Ginsberg - funny and moving - "no more unlooked for and unused poetry
advice." She closed with a long reading of section from her work in progress
_Lola_.  It was difficult to get from these snippets a clear sense of this
book-length poem, whose main concerns were with the epic scale of prehistory
and the mythic evocation of the feminine.

Ed Sanders closed the evening, his reading prefaced by some fidgeting with
gizmos. He read the closing portion of *his* book-length poem _1968_. This
narrative work was long on prose-like exposition and short on the lyrical,
but fascinating as an anecdotal document (The Fugs on tour in Chicago, Ed
calling Daley a motherfucker to a pissed off crowd who expected to see
Wilson Pickett instead, the suicide of DA Levy, manning the trenches in
Chicago with Ginsberg) The work carries - and tries to expunge - a deep
anger from that time over government betrayal, government-issued death. As
with Clinton's work, but in a different way of course, I felt a sharp
disparity between the effort to engage political awareness and the cost this
affected on the poem's engagement with language. Not good or bad - but
differing greatly from my own concerns. Ed then led us in a corny, good
spirited sing-a-long "America at Peace,"  then read a lovely lyric poem -
"the weight of the world is love who can deny it?" and closed with a duet
with Steven Taylor - more songs of Blake with segues into contemporary
political issues and some charming, amusing variants of "New Amazing Grace."


whew! .... our revels now are ended. Thanks for listening.

Patrick Pritchett

Mark, I like what you say here. Though I venture to add that it's only
someone from Kansas longing to escape his Kansas-ness who could be more New
Yorker than thou. The New York of the New Yorker is a metropolitan cultural
wish-fulfillment, much in the same way that the Hollywood created by Jewish
immigrants was more American than America (see Neal Gabler's fine book _An
Empire of Their Own: How the Jews Invented Hollywood_).
 ----------
From: Mark Weiss
To: POETICS
Subject: Re: instance of Ashbery
Date: Thursday, July 10, 1997 8:11PM


The Newyorker has never been urban eastcoast culture. Founded by a guy who
was insecure about being from Kansas, it's always been centered in the
fantasy culture of similar immigrants from points west with deprived
childhoods. For many years its standards of selection have been whatever
fits neatly between ads for stores on Madison Avenue without distracting
attention too much from those ads.
New York has always been about clamorous ethnic cultures. When the fleet of
the future James II appropriated it from the Dutch there were already 18
languages in daily use. This reality rarely gets the attention of the
Newyorker, except, perhaps, in snotty little pieces in The Talk of the Town;
it certainly has little influence on the rag's own cultural attitudes.
Ashberry's acceptance I think stems from two things: his Hamptons style,
subject-matter and diffidence and his currency in the higher-priced
precincts of the art world. Another way of saying he walks the walk and goes
to the right parties. None of which takes away one iota from his often
splendid poetry.

Absolutely. For native New Yorkers like me (as opposed to a lot of other
native New Yorkers, I guess), and perhaps especially for those of us living
in exile, the fantasy New York has always been an issue--a lot of folks come
in with little or no committment to the lived place of the vast majority.
Even O'Hara, whose work I love, gets to me this way (few of the New York
School poets were in fact New Yorkers).

Subject:      Re: after Ashbery

On Fri, 11 Jul 1997, David R. Israel wrote:

> Also: (re: nomenclature & generalization):  Much mention has been
> made of so-called "APR style" or the "APR school."  Said journal
> does, incidentally, publish the likes of Ann Lauterbach, John Yau,
> Leslie Scalapino, Robert Creeley, Michael Palmer (I think?), Carol
> Maso (if memory serves), Armand Schwerner, and a good number of
> others whose writing likely isn't exactly of the sort intended by the
> perhaps (all-too-)handy perjorative.  There may be some bias in
> evidence, but if I'm not mistaken, the journal is a bit more catholic
> in its inclusions than recent references might lead one to suppose.


Well--yes, this has always been an interesting issue.  Years ago I was
puzzled as to why the classic founder/polemicists of LangPo and other
counterstream tendencies made APR their whipping-entity, and not say the
venerable Poetry.  One reason is that Poetry seems to've been in decline
in influence since I was a wee lad in the 1960s, and another is the
specific history of APR, which was founded in a way that linked it
historically to the MFA-granting poetry workshop/writing program movement.
It specifically marketed itself to the writing-workshop milieu, and so
many feel that it has helped to perpetuate the blandest free-verse
stylings, which often come out of that milieu.  I'd readily agree about
the counterstream poets they've published over the years.  I haven't
bothered to pick it up for about three years, but before that saw it
pretty regularly for eons--and your list of interesting poets could be
extended;  I remember fine if small bits of Barbara Guest and Susan Howe.
But many folks just feel that the counterstream appearances are pretty
infrequent and minor compared to the overwhelming volume of mediocre
dreck.

The other point, which I've never seen mentioned, but which I suspect is
important, is that APR is just *so* visible and widely available, and so
much *intends* to be a popular/populist tabloid presence, that it's bound
to be a primarily target, if you have criticisms of the poetry
establishment.  Its very character makes it a potent influence, capable of
perpetuating dominant (ahem) trends; and I believe it *has* functioned to
perpetuate dominant trends, most of 'em pretty bad...But yes for most of
us it isn't an black-and-white issue.  I've always publicly praised them
for what openings and support they've given otherstreams...

Mark P
atlanta

Hi, (apologies again for cross-posting)

i've had a couple of requests to cite examples of what i'm getting at under
neologism.

I'd been thinking about something like this from P. Inman's 'Red Shift':


'the outfielder broke stride the more i spoke / bottle allowing

 a red minus. deadener put to people / leam mound, drut aniline

 / rrung lipstick / bloodied shire total ago / boswell's

 shut ink, number bodied mesa / hairline upholstery / brogue

 flim (period any mere) / based minuet diminished to a city'


-   or of this from Maggie O'Sullivan's 'States of Emergency' (difficult to
render accurately here  -  so, a translation from 'Busk, Pierce'):

'Jagged Pebble Song.
 Unlawful
 Cliffs
 Will, where no Cliffs be.

 woundlark.
 moochpennybreeze.


                           O
                      how the filthy
                        Keepsakes
                    Truckle Back Tripling
                          Ash.
                     Ink, launjer, red on leash,
                           BLOOD.
                    Crooked Swatch(ish,yellow) -----
                         Fling Flaunden
                           Sheenies
                    Quick Poppy Tie of Axe
                          Drumcut strip strung twists
                                    brooch
                                       &
                        pen Funerary tabletter, armistice,
                                     Drown!


Keep
Geographies.'

-  or Charles Bernstein's 'AZOOT D'PUUND' from 'Poetic Justice':

'iz wurry ray aZoOt de puund in reducey ap crrRisLe
 ehk nugkinj sJuxYY senshl.'

-  or the language of 'marks' and versions of 'marks' intended to be
sounded in Bob Cobbing and Lawrence Upton's 'Domestic Ambient Noise' series
(which there's no possibility of including a quotation from here  -
hmmmm).

I'm also thinking of instances of nation - language and dialect spellings
as also 'new' turns of phrase or words taking on 'new' functions.

Yes, we know about transrational 'traditions' and the romance of 'coining'
a word or a term. Many neologisms develop out of social interaction  -  I'm
thinking of how inflection turned 'bad' or 'wicked' into 'good' and so on.

Such instances pepper our poetries in these times. Why? What drives them?
What are the political and cultural imperatives at work?

love and love
cris

Cris

Your posting is thoughtful and provacative...

Clearly you're right to ask, what are the cultural and political
imperatives at work (in neologic word/sound creation)?  I think there are
probably almost as many answers as there are examples which cd. extend
your list.  And most of 'em (the examples and the answers) interesting and
important...

As a strongly sound-oriented poet myself, for whom meaning and weight
arise out of musical verbalization, I believe that (usually coexistent in
any given instance with more focused motives) there is the following
rather basic imperative:

In our moment a shaking up or loosening up of language-use is a good (or
rather, an urgently needed) thing. We're confronted with a literary world
most of which still has problems reading a little Gertrude Stein.  And
they've had long enough to assimilate her!  Shaking up the very identity
of words shocks the language. It wounds complacency and linguistic
transparency.  It (among other things) suggests to a reader: you can do
these things to language!  Neither the police nor god strike you dead if
you do 'em!  Language is an ocean with an almost endless number of
directions in which you can swim (till voices wake you, and....)

Mark P.

From:         Jordan Davis <jdavis@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      No New York
In-Reply-To:  <199707111804.LAA25126@iceland.it.earthlink.net>

New York is anybody's who wants to fight for it. Wanna fight? That the New
York School came from Boston, Cincinnati, Tulsa, Rochester (NY),
Providence, Chicago, Passaic, Bolinas, Needles, Lynn, says _this_ -- New
York is (was) a place where people felt comfortable enough to pursue
anonymity with all their might. Some of the early ones fleeing fame were
too slow to get away from it -- O'Hara (the stars of track and field are
beautiful people) became a legend even -- but now the New York school moves
quickly enough to ensure that no one will ever hear of it again.

Viva Huh?
J

Date:         Fri, 11 Jul 1997 12:28:36 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>

From:         Franklin Bruno <bruno@HUMNET.UCLA.EDU>
Subject:      acadominance & langpo
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

I think I agree with the several people who have said that 'acadominant' is
an inappropriate term for Langpo, given that other 'schools' have more
academic capital and will continue to for some time.  (Do you have any idea
how -strange- it was when Jed Rasula showed up to teach in my senior year?)
I think a better case might be made for 'acadominated,' if you buy the line
that the practice 'fits' well with the kinds of theory that have come to
prominence in humanities departments in the last two decades.  I myself
-don't- buy this line, as it supposes that the antecedents for Langpo are
mostly European theorists rather than a line of (largely) American
poet/critics (i.e. Stein, Coolidge, Creeley).
But maybe 'acadominated,' though equally contestable, is closer to what
Grunman was getting at in the first place.

fjb

From:         Franklin Bruno <bruno@HUMNET.UCLA.EDU>
Subject:      ashbery/dewey
Mime-Version: 1.0

I was gonna guess Dewey on that quote too, but '45 seems a little late...
'No objects' seems an overly easy line to take--saying there aren't any
still requires (at least for a philosopher) an account of why we all seem to
see them.

It might be interesting to know when JA's first -New Yorker- publications were;
before "Self-Portrait In a Convex Mirror" and the forthcoming awards, or after?
As for walking the walk, going to the right parties, and having currency in
the non-lit artworld, it might be argued that Ashbery's been in it for the
long haul and probably had a quiet hand (quieter than O'Hara's) in -making-
that the walk, and those the right parties.  Lastly, Kenneth Koch
hypothesized somewhere (APR?) recently that Ashbery 'got away with' a lot of
things because of his tone (and elevated syntax), which fools people on
first reading into thinking they're reading something a lot more traditional
than it is.  Koch was specifically talking about humor, but the same might
be said about several aspects of Ashbery's work (shifting pronouns and
difficulty of establishing a referent, for example).

And the worst thing about the initials DB are how phallic they look in
lowercase.

not the sharpest tool in the shed,
fjb

From:         "L. MacMahon and T.R. Healy" <Suantrai@IOL.IE>
Subject:      Re: re  -  'neologism'?
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

cris

due to repeated attempts to eliminate sign language among deaf people in
Ireland, to take only one country, the language is in a huge state of flux.
Dialects can be grouped in terms of age: youth, middle-aged, elderly people
may use different ones.  There are men's signs, women's signs, Catholic
signs, Protestant signs.  In many cases there is no consensus as to the
"correct" sign for say some new gadget or trend.  One response to this is a
form of neologism in which a sign is introduced at the start of a section of
articulation and its denotation is fingerspelled.  After this introduction
the sign is used without the spelling support.  The life of such neologisms
may be only as long as the interaction.

Randolph Healy



At 14:38 11/07/97 -0400, you wrote:
>Cris
>
>Your posting is thoughtful and provacative...

>Clearly you're right to ask, what are the cultural and political
>imperatives at work (in neologic word/sound creation)?  I think there are
>probably almost as many answers as there are examples which cd. extend
>your list.  And most of 'em (the examples and the answers) interesting and
>important...
>
>As a strongly sound-oriented poet myself, for whom meaning and weight
>arise out of musical verbalization, I believe that (usually coexistent in
>any given instance with more focused motives) there is the following
>rather basic imperative:
>
>In our moment a shaking up or loosening up of language-use is a good (or
>rather, an urgently needed) thing. We're confronted with a literary world
>most of which still has problems reading a little Gertrude Stein.  And
>they've had long enough to assimilate her!  Shaking up the very identity
>of words shocks the language. It wounds complacency and linguistic
>transparency.  It (among other things) suggests to a reader: you can do
>these things to language!  Neither the police nor god strike you dead if
>you do 'em!  Language is an ocean with an almost endless number of
>directions in which you can swim (till voices wake you, and....)
>
>Mark P.
