        As a chief question-asker I have to say the more I've considered it these
last few days the more I find myself sharing your feeling of suspicion. I
guess the way I would phrase my initial question, to make it less
suspcious, would be: "There seems to be a general assumption (is there such
an assumption?) that many of those poets "accused" of language poetry have
been strongly influenced, compared to their non-langpo brethren, by
linguistic, social, political --philosophy. There appear many
correspondences, to use THAT word. To what degree can this be said to be
true?"
        One of the consequences of some of the theoretical work in question is an
understanding that perhaps both the poets and the theorists should be
viewed primarily as responding to the same social circumstances--rather
than directly to each other. Well, I agree with this. BUT I'm looking for
names because I've often heard assumed this affinity, poets and theories,
but have very rarely seen--I say rarely, by no means never--a poet
acknowledge specific insight into any of these theories, let alone describe
how her poetry was in response to theoretical work. Knowing this would help
suggest possible avenues of study, if only because at the least it would be
reassuring to know that so-&-so hand't read such-&-such and so the apparent
association must come with reactions to cultural climes.        At best would be
an instance where a poet or theorist could report how she CHANGED this or
that work by interpreting it.
        As for studying the present, that is difficult.

        Matthias

Date:         Wed, 9 Jul 1997 12:23:41 -0700

Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Charles Alexander <chax@THERIVER.COM>
Subject:      Re: re  -  'neologism'?
In-Reply-To:  <868645368.1329217.0@slang.demon.co.uk>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

>Such instances pepper our poetries in these times. Why? What drives them?
>What are the political and cultural imperatives at work?

I imagine these imperatives are as multiple as the people doing such work.
When such creep or storm into my own work, they are sometimes in part the
attempt to say the unsayable. They are sometimes a protest against
normative language restrictions, they are sometimes a barbarian yawp, they
are sometimes based on existing words, either breaking down into component
sounds/parts, or in process of forming such sounds/parts, on their way to
becoming whole and recognizable words. Sometimes they are simply there for
the physical joy of throat and lips and tongue and cheeks and mind of
pronouncing the unfamiliar -- related to the pleasure I get in reading Old
English aloud. Sometimes the intention is much more specific and musical --
precise consonants and vowels to move the music. And in most instances the
motivations are quite mixed.

charles

Date:         Wed, 9 Jul 1997 12:29:02 -0700

From:         Charles Alexander <chax@THERIVER.COM>
Subject:      Re: ashbery/dewey
In-Reply-To:  <3C463C05219@113hum9.humnet.ucla.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

>And the worst thing about the initials DB are how phallic they look in
>lowercase.

why is this the worst?

I can vouch for the truth that lower-case "d" and "b" are often confused by
hand typesetters. They are close to each other in the conventional type
drawer (called "California job case"), and they are reversed from right to
left. I was told, when I first learned letterpress printing, that the
phrase "Mind your p's and q's" came from typesetters, and that it was
originally "Mind your p's and q's and b's and d's."

But the b's and d's of this list obviously aren't minding anyone. Well,
nevermind.

charles

All of these have been discussed on this list at one time or another during
the past couple of years, although perhaps not at great length. Still, I
should think that if you post thoughts or questions or issues concerning
them here, you will definitely get responses.

about, including the complete introduction from, Carolyn Burke's bio of Loy.

but it's not exactly full of critical information.

There are some other bits on Loy on the web, too. I haven't searched the
web for Niedecker and Riding.

Not exactly a found POEM, but reprinted below is the text of a message I
recieved from another E-mail list, X-ACTLY as it appeared. That other list
has nothing to do with poetry. I like the form, though, with lines and
multiple beginnings and a whispy but not nostalgic ending. Names
abbreviated to protect innocence:

...> points, while a woman who does loses 20. I may have the number wrong, but
...> not the formula.
<snip>
...> ...K____
...> ~~~~~~~~~~End_Text~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
...>
...>    always thought that
...>    a happy person tends
...>    to live longer than a
...>    sad or depressed bod...
...
...My reply is:
...I'm not sure what you mean by this.  Nor how it is connected:  seriously,
...really.  (Obliqueness seems more a feature of modernism, as does
...earnestness and cynicism.  I should know.  But this is not a criticism,
...I'm just unsure what you mean.)
...
...K____
~~~~~~~~~~End_Text~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~& My Reply is:
        hello there comrade,

        just a different emphasis
        on the word gay

        the reply above was in
        response to the use of
        the word gay designating
        a particular sexuality

        u c i tend to comment
        when asked how i am
        feeling that i am rather
        gay today

        meaning happy and
        joyful...

        now i wonder if being happy
        helps to increase on

Thanks, Pat Pritchett, for yet another reading-report from the Buddhist Big
Top. When I read these reports, I feel as though I _am_ you. I am sure my
response to these various readers would be almost identical--if only that
they _have_ been, in former years of reading-going. I am puzzled about one
thing, tho, & that is Ed Sanders' gizmos that he fiddled with before
reading. Are these Whi.He.My.Ma Gizmos, or Tibetan Buddhist Gizmos, or
Gizmos fetched from Woodstock? More on the Gizmos, please.  David

++++++++++++

Ever since I read that, during Clinton's visit to Tony Blair, the pair
agreed that class war was an out-of-date concern for today's voters, I have
wanted only to wage it. Even though I can create the maker of a poem out of
my own head (& gizmos) simply by reading his/her poem, perversely I would
like to see a lot more analysis or leastwise good gossip on the class (not
the 'class') of our poets, starting with, since he's been so much in our
news lately, the highly 'classy' John Ashbery. Did he, for isntance, attend
a one-gender boarding school? Did he go there on a scholarship? Did he play
rugger, or soccer, while there? Stuff like that. (I havent yet read  a l l
the posts with his name in the header; if this has begun to be covered
already, so much the better.)

I agree with someone who remarked that the poetry in the New Yorker has
gotten "better" of late. I just wonder, given the world those ads speak
of/to, how far this improvement can possibly go?

David

Date:         Fri, 11 Jul 1997 21:58:00 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Jacques Debrot <JDEBROT@AOL.COM>
Subject:      Re: acadominance & langpo

It almost goes without saying that the origins of Language writing are
over-determined:  Stein, Zukofsky, theory, minimalist/conceptual art, the
Peace movement, etc, etc.  But now that Language writing's phase as an active
literary movement has passed (as Mark Wallace, Mark Du Charme and others have
recently pointed out in various magazines), the more interesting question
seems to me, what next?  Or rather, in what context (and for what purposes)
are experimentalist poets now using the disjunctive and non-self-expressivist
techniques innovated by Language writing?  These are forms I myself prefer,
but given that no technique is inherently radical, what motivates their use
today?
=========================================================================

Here's a strange autobiographical fact about Mr Ashbery.

As a teenager he made a lot of money and became quite famous as a "quiz
kid" on radio, answering questions about art history. Apparently he
made a lot of money, got to travel back and forth across the US in a
luxury Pullman, famous gallery directors and art connoisseurs would tip
their hats to him in hotel lobbies (well, I'm embroidering a little
..) and so forth.

How about that?

Subject:      Re: No New York
In-Reply-To:  <l03020900afebf7cd7f04@[152.171.226.63]>

As not a New Yorker who is usually taken for a New Yorker, I want to
applaud Jordan. (I'm not a midwesterner either though I've spent time
there, I don't want to revive Maria's thread about Minnesota except to
quote Berrigan quoting K Koch that "it must be awfully lonely to be the
only surrealist at the University of Minnesota" and to add that,
nevertheless, there they are.)

The idea that the only valid "new yorkers" are the various immigrants
from offshore, and not the immigrants from the midwest -- who came as
often as not in search of a place where they could be sexually free as
opposed to seeking more money -- seems reductive, cruel and irrelevant.
Yes, the ethnic communities are part of the vibrant etc etc life of New
York, and New York is more than Soho, but the people from Kansas left
Kansas.

Would you exclude Melville from New York?

There is a lower-middle class native New York presence in the city that
resents (not without reason) the upper middle class arrivistes from other
parts of the US via elite schools.  But who makes the art?  Who consumes
the art?  Who cares about the art?  The ethnic neighborhoods are
important for nurturing art, because they are environments where you can
pursue your anonymity.

I stand with Jordan.
=========================================================================
Date:         Sat, 12 Jul 1997 00:15:28 -0700

From:         Mark Weiss <junction@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Re: No New York
Mime-Version: 1.0

Hey, this aint a war, or even a serious disagreement. I think what I said
was that "the upper middle class arrivistes from other parts of the US via
elite schools," as you call them, often don't seriously engage with the city
as understood by the rest of the population--it remains an escape and a
playground, and all those ethnics a form of exotic stage-dressing. I think
this is often true of O'Hara, whose work, let me repeat, I love. But it, and
the work of other voluntary internal migrants, often has the feel of
expatriate literature--breathlessly excited, but not fully grounded in
place. This can be a virtue, but something is also lost.
It's not, of course, always the case. I think it matters with what social
class the newcomer identifies. Literally graphic examples--two superb
etchers, both New Yorkers by adoption, one , John Sloan, depicts the life of
early 20th century New York workers and lower middle class with profound
sympathy, zero condescension, and apparently total identification, the
other, Martin Lewis, focuses on flappers. Sloan's line is as unkempt as his
subjects, who visibly have to deal with such things as New York's stifling
summers in the days before air conditioning. Lewis' golden girls float above
all that, and the elegance of his line mirrors the immunity to everyday
burdens of his subjects. His few explorations of Sloan's New York are
unconvincing.
"But who makes the art?  Who consumes the art?  Who cares about the art?"
Well, me, for one, and a lot of other natives, and a lot of denizens of
ethnic neighborhoods. I can supply a list if you need it.
Melville, by the way, spent his childhood, until his father's death, in New
York city, if I'm not mistaken. But early 19th century migrations in and out
of New York were considerably less formative, or liberating, for writers
than they became at the end of the century, after New York had grown
several-fold and become a world-city, thus radically differentiating itself
from a lot of other American locales.

From:         rsillima@IX.NETCOM.COM
Subject:      APR, Poultry, etc.
Comments: To: poetics@UBVM.cc.buffalo.edu
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

You're absolutely correct with regards APR's focus on the writing workshop
as a central location. In an important fashion, APR is a creation of the
literary engines of the 1960s, which of course was the context in which
Langpo (or, as Al would have it, Lanpo, which I rather like) first grew up.
Poetry, the mag, is a phenomenon from an entirely different era. I don't
know what the current numbers are, but throughout much of the 1970s and
'80s, APR had a distribution in the 25,000 range in comparison with
Poetry's 12,000. Actually, Poetry's circulation climbed substantially once
Henry Rago died and they stopped publishing the likes of Olson, Zukofsky,
Duncan and Ronald Johnson. The journal has never been "stronger," but it's
still an expression of an earlier era.

(Spicer's poems "For Poetry" in Book of Magazine Verse are aimed at Rago's
liberalism, not the neovictorian aesthetic that came later. Spicer seems to
have dismissed aesthetic/cultural reactionaries out of hand, saving his
wrath for those who attempted to build bridges. Viz the poem to Ginsberg.)

The token inclusion of a Charles Bernstein or Ann Lauterbach in APR has
always seemed to me exactly that--a mechanism by which a highly partisan
publication can then pretend to be "representative."  Another major
irritant in APR, during its early years at least, was its appropriation of
that name, AMERICAN Poetry Review, rather than say, Open Poetry (or
whatever). In the aftermath of Vietnam, people where hypersensitive to the
implications of naming (Vietnamization, after all, had involved genocide of
Vietnamese people). To use the national adjective both manipulatively and
uncritically in the way that APR does is an index of thinking that is as
sloppy as it is cynical.

[When I first got here to Philadelphia, I interviewed a young woman for a
job at my company who had previously worked as a "screener" for APR. She
had not read contemporary poetry of any sort before she obtained the work
study position, nor did she intend to once she left it. ]

Interestingly, neither Berg nor Vogelsang have used APR as a foundation for
any larger socio-aesthetic moves. They're as marginalized as anyone.

Afterthough on Ashbery (example of the non-marginal). I've always read
Self-Portrait and the books that immediately followed that as being the
most unrelievedly vicious satires on Establishment Verse (with a conscious
model in mind, what used to be the typical "Wesleyan" book of the 1960s,
one long poem and 12-20 short pieces). I've always been amazed that these
were taken up by the very people he was satirizing, almost as if they
couldn't see the parody. In this sense, Ashbery is our own Ern Malley.

Ron




On Fri, 11 Jul 1997, David R. Israel wrote:

> Also: (re: nomenclature & generalization):  Much mention has been
> made of so-called "APR style" or the "APR school."  Said journal
> does, incidentally, publish the likes of Ann Lauterbach, John Yau,
> Leslie Scalapino, Robert Creeley, Michael Palmer (I think?), Carol
> Maso (if memory serves), Armand Schwerner, and a good number of
> others whose writing likely isn't exactly of the sort intended by the
> perhaps (all-too-)handy perjorative.  There may be some bias in
> evidence, but if I'm not mistaken, the journal is a bit more catholic
> in its inclusions than recent references might lead one to suppose.


Well--yes, this has always been an interesting issue.  Years ago I was
puzzled as to why the classic founder/polemicists of LangPo and other
counterstream tendencies made APR their whipping-entity, and not say the
venerable Poetry.  One reason is that Poetry seems to've been in decline
in influence since I was a wee lad in the 1960s, and another is the
specific history of APR, which was founded in a way that linked it
historically to the MFA-granting poetry workshop/writing program movement.
It specifically marketed itself to the writing-workshop milieu, and so
many feel that it has helped to perpetuate the blandest free-verse
stylings, which often come out of that milieu.  I'd readily agree about
the counterstream poets they've published over the years.  I haven't
bothered to pick it up for about three years, but before that saw it
pretty regularly for eons--and your list of interesting poets could be
extended;  I remember fine if small bits of Barbara Guest and Susan Howe.
But many folks just feel that the counterstream appearances are pretty
infrequent and minor compared to the overwhelming volume of mediocre
dreck.

The other point, which I've never seen mentioned, but which I suspect is
important, is that APR is just *so* visible and widely available, and so
much *intends* to be a popular/populist tabloid presence, that it's bound
to be a primarily target, if you have criticisms of the poetry
establishment.  Its very character makes it a potent influence, capable of
perpetuating dominant (ahem) trends; and I believe it *has* functioned to
perpetuate dominant trends, most of 'em pretty bad...But yes for most of
us it isn't an black-and-white issue.  I've always publicly praised them
for what openings and support they've given otherstreams...

Mark P
atlanta

Subject:      Re: re  -  'neologism'?
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Hi,

thanks Charles for that:
>I imagine these imperatives are as multiple as the people doing such work.
>When such creep or storm into my own work, they are sometimes in part the
>attempt to say the unsayable. They are sometimes a protest against
>normative language restrictions, they are sometimes a barbarian yawp, they
>are sometimes based on existing words, either breaking down into component
>sounds/parts, or in process of forming such sounds/parts, on their way to
>becoming whole and recognizable words. Sometimes they are simply there for
>the physical joy of throat and lips and tongue and cheeks and mind of
>pronouncing the unfamiliar -- related to the pleasure I get in reading Old
>English aloud. Sometimes the intention is much more specific and musical --
>precise consonants and vowels to move the music. And in most instances the
>motivations are quite mixed.

that would be much of my own experience. Of course there are the seemingly
'accurate' word compounds forged by editing fudges and cut paste on the
processor and the fumble finger inventions that jerk a line onwards. I need
to gut into my bath, I'll be book. Such are the nuts and bolts of facture
in our workshops. Then there's the moment at which a decision is taken to
leave these neologisms in the writing that is sent out of the house. At
those moments are the political and cultural imperatives at play. An
'attempt to say the unsayable' or / an expression of 'protest at normative
language restrictions' might simply generate an expletive or reach for a
conventionalising expression of it - instead the same generates a word that
others might recognise the impulse behind but which has specificities. It
only takes one other to begin to employ such specificities for Saussure's
brow to begin sweating mighty strange.
Yes, such specificities are often context-specific within the music of a
ludic phrase.

Aren't such instances of the 'unsayable' highly revealing? What would we
want to discuss that we don't have the words for? What do they tell us
about our cultural parameters as pre-scribed and inscribed by language?

As Randolph points out in may cases the 'neologism' may only be a long as
the interaction (as true for 'reading' as 'signing'). Some constructions
though in contemporary poetry, 'if not them, how come?', are in themselves
signs, active indexical components within the artifice we speak and ride.
Many of the stumbling blocks we cruise present questions that require
applications of 'similar' navigational devices. Lang - po has period
trademarks that are integral both to its community formations and their
applications  -  as witness much of the discussion on this list.

There was a sereies of exchanges recently on british poets about words for
silence and of how the subtle varieties of silence in other cultures and
older regional dialects has become represented in contemporary usage by
'silence'. There are many many examples of similar vernacular
impoverishments within English(es) that moderarate our 'conversations'.
What lies behind my raising of this 'neologistical' issue is a need to   -
go the other way. To, as Mark Prejsnar put it, 'wound(s) complacency and
linguistic transparency'. Mechanisms for generating this skaning (?) sorry
shaking up are a nub we wittle at, poetry is often that residue.
Contemporary poetries often seem to offer markers as to the lack of
language. That's their sheen.

but that's the flip side of what of what i'm raising, yuo're being ironic
there i take it
>    you might want to conside thhe range poems where i think it appears
>in a pure form for me.  there is no intent here (i hope) to do much more

Ed Sanders had but one gizmo on stage in Boulder (not counting the VCR he
was using to record himself for replay on his cable access show back
home), so we didn't get to hear him play his musical tie, or his
electronic fingers, or any of his other other gizmatic wonders.  What he
did have with him was a small sampler which alloewd him to use prerecorded
accompaniment for one of his songs -- I think experts in the filed refer
to this sampler as an Ashbery --

________

When I heard of the joint Clinton/Blair declaration of the end of the
class war, I couldn't help thinking of Stalin! -- Once Stalin had
consolidated his regime, the "Soviet" government declared that the
classes no longer existed and hence the class war had come to an end (and,
hence no further need for workers to create their own organizations, like,
say, Soviets and unions) -- The oft repeated claim than everyone in
America IS middle-class serves a similar, though admittedly a tad less
deadly, function --

PROGRAM NOTES FOR cine16 FILM FESTIVAL'S July 17 program at  the
downstairs Speakeasy in the Agenda Restaurant & Lounge, downtown San
Jose,  Thursday at 7:30 pm.  Admission is always free.  Smoking &
drinking permitted and encouraged to maintain the bohemian veneer.

July 17: Cinematic Masters of Science and Math

Imagine a school in which: the woodshop teacher turns the shop into his
own private furniture store, trading passing grades for student "slave
labor" in the manufacture of pieces which he takes away for home use or
sale; the metal shop instructor issues an 'F' grade to a student for a
project in which he had worked for months, saying "you couldn't have
done this"; an English teacher is arrested for selling dope to her
students; the head of boys Physical Education pulls out a camera and
snaps dozens of boys in the shower; a science instructor angrily hurls
part of a science experiment at the head of a student seated at the rear
of the classroom. This, my friends, is not the plot of some wacky summer
film. Nope, it's the school I attended, Dartmouth Jr. High, which still
sits staring blankly at the traffic on Blossom Hill Road. And right, you
guessed it, I'm the kid who nearly got nailed by the ballistic science
experiment gone wrong. Perhaps it was the unintentionally errant arms of
science teachers like Mr. Hays that caused thousands of kids to turn off
to the sciences, aided and abetted by perhaps the lack of a proper
background in child learning theory, by uninspired teaching materials,
and the use of boring, really awful science films.=20

You know the type: the didactic black and white Coronets, the terribly
narrated Moody Institute films with the religious message --- ("them
bugs ain't as smart as the creator") --- at the end of every film, and
all the others with their paste-and-glue graphical representations of
mitosis, amoebae, and paramecia. I'm telling you this story as an
introduction to tonight's program, which features science and math films
that are so phenomenally good that anyone could be enchanted. There may
be no way to adequately count the number of young minds saved by Bruce
Russell, Thomas Stanton, Norman & Marjorie Bean, David & Peter Boulton,
and Bruce & Katherine Cornwell, who made science and math films
engaging, fun, intellectually stimulating, and artistically beautiful.
These films truly created an educational revolution, are magnificent
films for people of any age, and will be a real eye-opener for cine16
viewers who graduated from high school prior to 1980.=20

Tonight's films include:

'Imaging the Hidden World: the Light Microscope' 1984, d. Bruce Russell.
It's difficult to pick a Russell film, because they're all good. This
film shows how the filmmaker sets up the 'scope, light, and filters to
make his visually arresting films.

'Crystals: Flowers of the Mineral Kingdom' 1983, d. Thomas Stanton.
Stanton's film of rapidly expanding colorful crystalline growths is
reminiscent of a quote attributed to Salvador Dali', who once said "I
don't take acid, I am acid"

'Carnivorous Plants 1979, d. Thomas Stanton. A Blue Ribbon award winner
at the American Film Festival. Insidious.

'Fungi' 1983, p. David & Peter Boulton. Neat slo-mo shots of slowly
spreading destructive growths. Boulton-Hawker Films were made in
Britain, distributed by Benchmark. Exceptional.

'Spiders -- Backyard Science' 1978', p. Norman & Marjorie Bean. OK, a
film for elementary kids, complete with friendly narrator... except that
these horrifying images will scare the bejesus out of them! Extreme
color close-ups of nightmarish clarity.=20

'Congruent Triangles' 1976, d. Bruce & Katharine Cornwell. Abstract
design, post-bop jazz , and Klee-like animation make a showpiece out of
a seemingly mundane subject.=20

'Insect Parasitism: the Alder Woodwasp' 1968, p. Gerald Thompson & E.R.
Skinner. The wasp drills a hole in a log, deposits its eggs, then four
different kinds of bugs use its developing offspring for all sorts of
things. Incredible cinematography, docs in labcoats. A fascinating film.

Jacques Debrot wrote:
"It almost goes without saying that the origins of Language writing are
over-determined:  Stein, Zukofsky, theory, minimalist/conceptual art, the
Peace movement, etc, etc.  But now that Language writing's phase as an active
literary movement has passed (as Mark Wallace, Mark Du Charme and others have
recently pointed out in various magazines), the more interesting question
seems to me, what next?  Or rather, in what context (and for what purposes)
are experimentalist poets now using the disjunctive and non-self-expressivist
techniques innovated by Language writing?  These are forms I myself prefer,
but given that no technique is inherently radical, what motivates their use
today?"

Subject:      Explanation, Final, Theory/Writing
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

==


Losing Track


At the age of 25 I decided I want to write philosophy. To write a text
implies working through domains without guideposts, recuperating older
strata, looking up through the dissemination of the wide world's in-
formation. Part of me believed that I was writing the world itself,
that a secret would manifest its bones, and with that would come pow-
er.

Never earthly, the power would equate knowledge with interstitial
longings, and hence with a triumphant mastery of death. Space and time
were not far behind.

I could never listen to music with pleasure because of textual ab-
sence; instead, music became a dialog I abandoned after a furious
wager with high-speed sound. Music took far too much for granted,
lending itself to pure jouissance. I would head towards video, film,
writing, and always writing - writing which could describe the world
in a singularity, the compression of everything into - not only the
symbolic, but also a token such as V, a set-theoretical universe.

Once V was announced, it was criss-crossed by rules which in fact
exhausted V: V was nothing but the domain of those rules, Godel not-
withstanding. The rules of the real of course prove much more intract-
able; in fact, they may not be rules (which are top-down) at all, so
much as part-objects, bottom-up operations with superstructural mani-
festations that take on the appearance of relative simplicity. The
unsolvable n-body problems are good examples.

Eventually, I became certain I had nothing to contribute on this level
- that is, to the concrete progress produced by science and technology
- for example, solutions or heuristics for fundamental particle the-
ory. I was too undisciplined, too resistant, for that.

Instead, I became concerned with the interrelationship among these
abstract systems and consciousness, the interstices of structures,
bodies, minds, and the symbolic, plateaued throughout by an imagin-
ary. Such was the case that _muck_ necessarily surfaced in this in-
vestigation, a muck that created _discomfort_ among those workers on
the surface who took the mines for granted.

My work has been in the mines, in the shafts, across the occasional
surface irruption. It explores the depths, not recursively, but with a
sense of ennui, longing, and the depths are not infinite, just as the
symbolic is not an infinite concatenation of broken strings.

More like a Sierpinski Sponge imagined without the recursion, depths
are unfounded, unfounding, and as I am fond of saying, unaccountable,
and unaccounted-for: hence, an other. And more than or to this, I am
also fond of saying that they generate and reflect _the neurotic style
of the world,_ a style necessarily repetitive, obsessive, scarred and
sutured, a style which has always already effaced itself, just as
language as the appearance of each and every determination.

Thus the neurotic, not schizz, may have a hold or grasp on the world,
just as the paranoid comprehends sociobiology in its entirety.

In relation to everything here, there is institutionalization, the
conundrum of institutions. Wild theory is incomprehensible in the face
of the propriety of regulated reference, footnotes, and a dedication
to reasoned argument. I would argue, wildly and unsuccessfully, that
this reasoned argument always already precludes, firewalls, forecloses
the _muck,_ which is not just a matter of a psychoanalytical and/or
rational approach, but also a seeping, oozing, within and without the
discomfort of the (borderlined) reader. In this regard, the muck-text
is as much performative, process, as it is discursive formation. And
in this regard, it remains difficult to translate, suitcase.

On the other hand, it is easy to descend or ascent to a superstruct-
ural surface that purports, through skimming (surfing) to present a
laissez-faire chaotic mapping of nomadic chains, in lieu of comprehen-
sion. And it is easy for me to fool myself that something has been
accomplished, beyond the demonstration of a new command, application,
or Net phenomenon: And if anything salvages these texts, it's the
embarrassment, shame, dirtiness, muck, psychotic flirtations, that
refuse to let go, after the command, application, or Net phenomenon
has been deciphered.

When I began years ago, I developed the notion of two regimes, the
construct and the experiential. The former was external to temporal
systems, and an idealized graph of equivalences or transforms; the
latter was messy, carried motility within it, and problematized the
very nodes and vectors that created the appearances of entities and
processes. The two modes intersected in what I later called state or
process-oriented graphs. Within this scheme, wild theory is, of
course, experiential; traditional discursive formations, on the other
hand, appear as-if-grounded in the construct. Thus an ideal academic
discourse might be considered a database, allowing the recuperation of
argument, revisitation rights/rites, and footnoting allowing the dis-
course to partake of others observing the same protocols. While this
constructs a language-practice ultimately based on the Enlightenment
(or for that matter Euclid), it also precludes both the problematic of
reception (beyond reception-theory) and those very cognitive proces-
ses that grant the text its semantics in the first place.

So that, by harboring texts within the experiential as primary (as my
texts attempt), grounds and reasoned discourse are instead problemati-
zed - not in favor of anarchic feeling - but in terms of those tradi-
tionally analytic part-objects (such as this text to some extent) that
appear within them.

This certainly reduces the necessity of grounds for 'em. *

* And also unfortunately reduces the community of readers, who are no
longer guided by those tokens of footnote/reference/etc. that I have
referenced here, and that provide the ability to cross-translate, as
well as reaffirm a foreclosed but relatively friendly academe. _This_
work, instead, is wounded, refusing to heal, apparently establishing
no discourse, critique; and in this sense, it is a corpse of work, not
corpus. Later, a corpse will give birth to new forms of life; now, it
is an uncomfortable object in the room, leaking onto the table, spil-
ling onto the floor.

Subject:      Re: The language of influence

Ashbery's winning the Yale Younger Poets over O'Hara is in some ways
proleptic of his later, and strangely wide, appeal, isn't it?  It's
interesting, by the way, to read Harold Bloom on Ashbery.  Bloom dismisses
the New York School connection as well as the obvious European influences:
Apollinaire, Reverdy, Roussel, Michaux, Cendars, and de Chirico, and reads
Ashbery instead (not altogether falsely) as a direct descendant of the line:
Emerson-Stevens. It's Bloom's reading of Ashbery that's been the decisive one
in terms of Ashbery's legitimation by the academy.

From:         Rebecca Weldon <rcweldon@LOXINFO.CO.TH>
Subject:      Inner Poetics
Mime-Version: 1.0

David, thanks for the references.

I've been on vacation with the kids and returned yesterday to 283 messages!
It took me awhile to plow through.  By the way, your message was listed
around 24 hours before mine.  Interesting phenomenon, that, the response
arriving first.

Gus Blaisdell made the statement in the letter attached to Gnomonology that
there is no archaeology of the spirit, yet, poetry is exactly that.  It is a
science of language which reveals the assemblage of life (to quote McCord).
What little understanding I have of the intricacies of translating from the
Chinese suggests that Lao Tse / Chuang Tzu used the language to the same
effect, that is to plumb the spirit in an active way, ie. to make us think
about ourselves from inside in contrast to a strictly social perspective.

The dynamic interaction of personal poetics with the social interface of
life has characterised human thought since who knows when.  It is
responsible for the arts as well as the sciences or, perhaps we might say,
the science of art and the art of science.  Both are products of process,
it's just that methods of the former are rather poorly understood by the
latter. (By the way, McCord's list brought Cassirer to mind and his
discussion of Plato, Poetics and the State is very interesting, when read
with Chuang Tzu, Confucius and the Empire in mind. See:Cassirer, The Myth of
the State).

I agree that Tagore falls into the same special category, mystic or not.
There is something so very the essence of the sub-continent in his work.
The lyric form can be a means of cognition, to paraphrase Cassirer via
McCord and, in this sense, the evocative power of mantras, sutras, etc. have
a place.  But then, anything can have a place in poetry if it's what makes
up the poet; the quibbling comes when the reader gets involved: silent
flowers could not possibly speak, much less in color. But there it is; they
did speak to the poet, although one could ask whether the poetry spoke to
anyone else (Wittgenstein's observations on conscious and unconscious
thought in the Blue book are interesting in this respect).

The notes concerning Sanscrit took me back to the books, ie. Snyder's use of
the word "ayang" (which does not seem to be Sanscrit, someone please correct
me if I am wrong, I did my studies in French and sometimes have trouble with
transcriptions).  Perhaps because the alphabet fully represented all the
sounds of the language, it was used successfully to translitterate many
Asian languages and a concept is sometimes pronounced several ways, ex:
ahimsa, ahingsa.  Thai owes a particular debt to it, since it enriched the
language with words for cultural and religious concepts and activities not
previously known and gave it an alphabet, through the medium of Pali (our
equivalents being Greek and Latin).  However, it does not deal with tone
based poetics which are an unusual feature of the Thai language.  While
Sanscrit may be translitterated, it is difficult to do so with Thai, Chinese
or other tonal languages. The effect would be ludicrous. One wouldn't know
if the word meant dog, horse or come/come dog be my horse/horse come be my
dog.  Of course, if that's the intention...

I'm getting long here.  Human languages have been going through process and
synthesis through time with poets and poetry at the cutting edge, to say
nothing of their effects from translation.  When there is something
important to say/show/observe about human beings, poets express it before
and better than anyone else precisely because they are archaeologists of the
spirit. It doesn't surprise me that some of us are well remembered.
Finally, in reference to the tenor of recent exchanges, a day of thought (or
three months) before response might clarify, distill and enrich.
=========================================================================

From:         rsillima@IX.NETCOM.COM
Subject:      The New Sentence
Comments: To: poetics@UBVM.cc.buffalo.edu
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

>------------------------------
>
>Date:    Sat, 12 Jul 1997 19:54:24 -0700
>From:    Mark Weiss <junction@EARTHLINK.NET>
>Subject: Re: acadominance & langpo
>
>What's "the new sentence" (and what do you have to be guilty of to get it)?
>
It's a talk I gave sometime around 1980 (Bob Perelman, who hosted it, could
date it more exactly--he & Francie brought their newborn son Max to the
event, age 7 days, same son who is now about to head off to Yale). I was
trying to distinguish all the prose that was sprouting up among the langpo
from what little had been done previously by way of the prose poem. It cited
Williams' Kora in Hell as a precedent and spent a lot of time looking at
Stein's critical distinctions between sentences and paragraphs. At the
conclusion it listed seven characteristic qualities of the new sentence:

1) The paragraph organizes the sentences;
2) The paragraph is a unit of quantity, not logic or argument;
3) Sentence length is a unit of measure;
4) Sentence structure is altered for torque, or increased
polysemy/ambiguity;
5) Syllogistic movement is: (a) limited; (b) controlled;
6) Primary syllogistic movement is between the preceding and following
sentences;
7) Secondary syllogistic movment is toward the paragraph as a whole, or the
total work;
8) The limiting of syllogistic movement keeps the reader's attention at or
very close to the level of language, that is, most often at the sentence
level or below.

By "syllogistic movement" I was trying to show the structural underpinnings
what tends to naturalized as "reference."

The talk became the title piece for my first collection of critical writing.

Ron

consciously puts ashbery smack in descent of rimbaud: rhetorically
wringing the neck of certain particular logical relations and conventional
congruities of imagery. (p. 15)


tom orange

Reading (a week later) this Monday post from Dave Baptiste Chirot --

>  The issue of naming is intriguing--when Grumman gives an area a
> name--does it open up an area overlooked?  Or does naming things fix
> them--the intellect delighting in boundary to paraphrase Emerson in
> "The Poet".  Or does Grumman's approach, by playing among the
> tensions involved in naming, does it not perhaps open up one's own
> desire for naming and fear of it? Language as vehicular (Emerson
> again) or fugitive is ever in movement, so the best one can hope for
> is some kind of indication of directions.  Whether or not one even
> keeps and uses the name Grumman provides, his main work is done in
> indicating those directions.

All this reminds of a question that has surfaced, amid various doubts
& equivocations anent the "acadomino theory" moniker (so to say) --

namely, how might Bob (or others) view the radical tautology of
calling LangPo "LangPo"?

(This follows, more or less, in the tradition of *not* calling a spade a
"metallo-earth-reconfigurational handheld equipage moiety" -- both
possibilities [i.e., the latter, or, in the alternatives, calling it,
admittedly more prosaically, "a spade"] presumably falling within the
"what it is" school of naming, but with some diff.)

Hey, just a thought.

cheers,
d.i.

Jacques Debrot wrote:

> Or rather, in what context (and for what purposes)
>are experimentalist poets now using the disjunctive and non-self-expressivist
>techniques innovated by Language writing?  These are forms I myself prefer,
>but given that no technique is inherently radical, what motivates their use
>today?

I think this question is an important one to be asking, but it may be that
there's a fallacy hidden here--that of assuming that a technique's
'radical'-ness is the source of its validity.  I think that even in the
langpo 'moment,' whenever it was and supposing it's ended, the constant
attention that its practitioners drew to its antecedents, its place in a
tradition, served the purpose of making the techniques at least -seem-
fruitful beyond their oppositional status.  As I think many would contend
they are.

fjb

Date:         Sun, 13 Jul 1997 12:35:59 -0700

Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Mark Weiss <junction@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Re: exceptions

>>-breathlessly excited, but not fully grounded in
>>place.
>
>Are these mutually exclusive?
>
>

Since I, not Bennet, characterized O'Hara's stance towards NY as above, I'll
take responsibility, altho I'm not sure what your letter as a whole is asking.
Of course their not necessarily mutually exclusive, but they are in O'Hara's
work, and this separation gives rise, I think, to some of the virtues of
same. Let me use an analogy. At a certain point in my expatriate time in
France I realized that I would never "know" the language because, while my
French had the historical depth that reading affords, the cultural referents
of daily life of my French age-mates (I hate the word "cohort"--it sounds
too much like a Roman soldier) and those of the previous generation learned
by them at the kitchen table--snatches of popular song, advertizing slogans,
the commercial history of this or that corner (what was there before the
bakery, who the baker was, how the neighborhood's changed, and the language
attached to that), obsolete slang, echoes of the spoken and body language of
popular entertainers, etc., would be forever largely beyond my reach. As
well, the personal historical past of the language--the baby talk of my
generation, the adolescent jive my agemates had spoken and forgotten--shared
language experience--were also largely unattainable. Even if I learned
enough to mimic these, the affect behind the usage would be different.
Similarly, O'Hara writes as if his New York exists in an eternal present or
near-present, and he seems to skate (and skate marvelously) on one of the
city's shinier surfaces. Which is by no means to imply that he was shallow.
In fact, we can contrast him with Blackburn, who joined his mother in
Greenwich Village, which was then a traditional Italian neighborhood with a
few artists of limited means, when he was eleven, fresh out of a childhood
in rural Vermont. As a mature poet he knows O'Hara's New York, but he's also
aware of a much more complex city. And I think he's often emotionally and
intellectually shallower than O'Hara, certainly rarely (except perhaps in
the journals) reaches the depth of the Odes.
Why is this important to American poets beyond my parochial New York sense?
Simon Schuchat is certainly right that New York has been a haven for those
whose cultural roots are none too pleasant, and not just gays from less
forgiving places, but for artists in general. The expatriate life does offer
its large compensations in personal freedom, and many, including the artists
in all media who landed there in the fifties and sixties, have exploited
that freedom to all of our benefit. But New York is also a metropolitan area
of 22 million--the largest in the English-speaking world and home to maybe
8% of Americans. Note, I speak about the metro area--Ginsberg, in Passaic,
is within that net, and the kids I worked with in Lynbrook and Perth Amboy
were not unlike the kids in white ethnic neighborhoods in the five boroughs,
and they got into Manhattan and out of their neighborhood-centered worlds
about as rarely as their city agemates.
What I'm trying to say is that New York, culturally very different from much
of the rest of the country, is the largest American environment--it's not
just an escape from another country or culture. The American mythmakers,
confusing, on purpose, I think, two words, place the "heartland" in the
"hinterland," as if we've all somehow failed to embrace our true destiny as
virtuous Iowa farmers. To the extent that America is my subject or the
ground of my work I'd better be prepared to understand, in all its
complexity, the urban heartland.
So, I love O'Hara's breathless excitement, hope that my own comes across
from time to time in my own verse, I know there's more to O'Hara than that,
and I don't think that he's particularly grounded in place in New York.
=========================================================================

Actually Rod, Bennett Simpson (me) didn't write the below phrase. Someone
did --I remember reading it-- but it wasn't me. I wrote...hmm. Excitement
and groundless places (we love you!) are definitely not mutually
exclusive. They often go hand in hand, often have little to do with each
other. To raise an old question (but one I never understand), What is
place in poetry anyway, say, the places of O'Hara's poems, or Berrigan's?
I'm not talking about "geographic" St. Mark's places, or studios, or
avenues, but a place that, when attributed by generalists, is often
metaphysical (fine) or idealized. New York. Is this a place?
Distinguishable without streetsigns?

The real v. non-real (imagined). I don't like this dichotomy either. I try
not to be a pedant. I have only figments of axes to grind. But sometimes
something seizes me, bad grad school, greener grass, and --whoa-
everything is allegory.

Bennett

information with your submission: name address phone e-mail.

_Fourteen Hills: The SFSU Review_ is published twice yearly by the
Creative Writing Department at San Francisco State University. We are
proud to announce that Mary Gaitskill's story "Comfort", published in
the Fall 1995 issue, has received an O. Henry Award, and Kolin Ohi's "A
Backward Glance" from Spring 1996 and Stephen Beachy's "Shapes" from
Fall 1996 will both appear in _The Best American Gay Fiction 1997_.

The Holmes Awards will honor two emerging writers published in _Fourteen
Hills_ during the academic year ("emerging" defined as not yet having
yet published a book-length work at the time of publication) with a cash
prize of $250. The Editor-in-Chief will choose from work published in
the Fall and Spring issues--one poem to receive the Holmes Award in
Poetry, and one essay, short-story, or dramatic work to receive the
Holmes Award in Prose.

Ern Malley poems in his journal "Angry Penguins" was named Detective Vogelsang.

Date:         Mon, 14 Jul 1997 14:57:18 +1000
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         John Tranter <jtranter@SYDPCUG.ORG.AU>
Subject:      John, Frank and Wystan.
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Jacques Debrot said in a recent post:

"Ashbery's winning the Yale Younger Poets over O'Hara is in some ways
proleptic of his later, and strangely wide, appeal, isn't it? "

Ashbery himself has mentioned this incident in a radio interview (with the
present writer, broadcast in Australia in 1988). W.H.Auden had been asked to
judge the prize that year (1956) and had sent back all the entries forwarded
to him by the committee with the opinion that none was worthy of the prize.

Frank O'Hara heard of this and sent his own MS directly to Auden, along with
a MS by his friend John Ashbery. Auden liked both, and gave the prize to
Ashbery. (Naturally, given that the early Ashbery was much more like Auden
than O'Hara ever was.)  John Ashbery said "Frank gave my book a good review,
which was very generous of him, under the circumstances."

John Ashbery also said the book ("Some Trees") was a terrible flop, taking
more than eight years to sell out its eight hundred copies. He said that
partly because the book was such a disaster, he felt he had no public to
speak of, and therefore might as well write whatever he liked; thus the
violent disjunctions of "The Tennis Court Oath."

So good luck follows bad.

  39 Short St, Balmain NSW 2041, Australia

>Actually I was only attempting to clean George up a little.  He had been
>so overcome by his readings in Bukowski that he was quite soggy,
>
>Rachel L.

Now, come on. I think it's time certain members of this list woke up and
started reading Bukowski with the intelligence this great Canadian poet
deserves. Also, it is about time that some scholar out there paid attention
to Mr Bukowski's sources. If you can read "Puking at the Post Office"
without recalling "Self-Portrait in a Convex Mirror," you have not been
reading carefully enough. I used to drink a bit with Chuck, and whenever he
reached a certain degree of poetic intoxication, brought on, as I recall,
by some very good Okanagan chablis, he would begin to recite from "The
Tennis Court Oath," except he always called it "The Race Track Oath" for
some reason.

Reply-To:     Mark Prejsnar <mprejsn@law.emory.edu>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Mark Prejsnar <mprejsn@LAW.EMORY.EDU>
Subject:      Re: acadominance & langpo
In-Reply-To:  <970711215759_-625877444@emout05.mail.aol.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

On Fri, 11 Jul 1997, Jacques Debrot wrote:

> It almost goes without saying that the origins of Language writing are
> over-determined:  Stein, Zukofsky, theory, minimalist/conceptual art, the
> Peace movement, etc, etc.  But now that Language writing's phase as an active
> literary movement has passed (as Mark Wallace, Mark Du Charme and others have
> recently pointed out in various magazines), the more interesting question
> seems to me, what next?  Or rather, in what context (and for what purposes)
> are experimentalist poets now using the disjunctive and non-self-expressivist
> techniques innovated by Language writing?  These are forms I myself prefer,
> but given that no technique is inherently radical, what motivates their use
> today?
>

Jacques--

I would argue that much of what LPers have pointed out in their theory,
is (for me) still a set of very active issues....How to blast apart the
congealed ice of mainstream reading practices and publishing forms, for
instance.  And that that project is bound up with a profoundly left
political set of concerns.  (Again, as so often, I return to the fact that
the *hidden secret*, at least apparently to most people, (but like most
hidden secrets it's right there out in the open) with regard to LangPo
theory is: it's huge debt to *Brecht*...but also its creative *extension*
of Brecht; for instance combining him with Stein/Zuke/Ez to begin a
synthesis involving both ideas of a public art and ideas of the
physicality of language as an active medium.)

I have sympathy with your feeling that there is much more, beyond what's
been done, for younger poets to reach toward.  But: 1. to just abstractly
shrug off what was done in the 70s and 80s could risk being just
fashion-mangering; 2. if there's any truth or utility to a given group of
theoretical insights ya gotta go *thru* them to get to your next step, and
neither go around 'em, nor retreat back from them...

regards,
Mark P.
atlanta

Date:         Mon, 14 Jul 1997 14:26:06 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Mark Wallace <mdw@GWIS2.CIRC.GWU.EDU>
Subject:      feeling "dumbed down"
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

        Thanks to Rod Smith for asking some clarifying questions about my
recent post. Of course I think, as Rod rightly points out, that there are
substantive differences between all sorts of poetic perspectives and
academic specialities, and that those differences are important. And I too
would like, for instance, if it was possible at the universities where I
teach to have even a single course in any kind of "postmodern" innovative
poetry, when the closest these universities get is one two-sememster
course in "American Poetry" that sometimes, but rarely, reaches Ashbery.
And it would be nice also to feel more room in creative writing courses to
introduce "experimental" techniques, however defined--and I do introduce
such techniques whenever I can.

        But the question is, matters to whom? And the answer is, well, you
and me, and other people interested in literature. But to the academic
environment at large, or to the bureaucracy of the university itself? I'm
quite sure that the president, say, of either one of these universities
really could care less WHAT points of view are taught in the English
department. Why, you can even be a communist, burn flags and stuff.
Would the bureaucracy object to a course on language poetry every year?
Not at all--they'd even let you go ahead and have several, as long as the
department itself could still cover basic "requirements" such as
composition and survey courses, etc. Try to teach ONLY language poetry and
then you might have a battle.

        So it depends on what one means by 'acdominant'--what professors
in English departments think about literature? What they are doing to meet
or change bureaucratic requirements? What books are published, and who
has the biggest literary reputation? Then yes, clearly some viewpoints
have more "dominance" than others, although that itself is not cut
and dried. In my experience, most professors in English departments aren't
even having enough conversation to agree or disagree with each other at
all--they haven't read the same texts, and don't want to waste much time
talking because they've got careers to defend, and in some cases (not
enough unfortunately), ideas that they want to pursue. Usually, the most
in-depth coversation they have is about whether there's a "field" that
they need to cover that the university will fund a teaching line for, one
that has enough social cache to now need to be "covered."

        But isn't such specialization itself an ideology? And isn't that
specialization ideology itself wedded to to the ideological limits of any
notion of coverage? Also yes. But the fact of the matter is that any
subject can be fit into the academic system that this ideology supports.
Indeed I don't think it will be too long before language poetry DOES get
taught at American universities. Already one of the schools where I teach
has a regular undergraduate course in Postcolonial Literature. Is that a
good thing? Yes. Does it change the content of what is "covered"? Again
yes, a little. Does it change the organization of the university system,
in some kind of "trickle down" phenomena in which more university
bureaucrats have awareness about issues of racism, awareness that they
act on? Well, perhaps yes, but
now I'm starting to feel skeptical. Has the ideology that states that
"coverage" is the point, and that experts "cover" fields, been changed?
Not one bit.

        So, what's at stake in an English department for "language
poetry," or any other "field" that can be delimated by a name, is whether
it gets its piece of the "coverage." And THEN
literary politics matter--and yes, there are still so many professors who
haven't even heard of Language poetry that they are unlikely to want it
taught. So there's one battle. And the other
thing at stake is whose books about literature will get published--will we
have 15 books about language poetry this year, as opposed to 7 or so last
year? At what point will those numbers crest and begin to go down?

        So yes, in one sense the debate matters. You can read Ron Silliman
in a few courses in the United States; probably you can't read Bob Grumman
in any such courses. Of course, I know that's wrong, actually--in the
graduate/undergraduate course I taught on Modern American Poetry last
fall, I DID teach Bob Grumman's VERY STRAYNGE BOOK, but did not teach Ron
at all (sorry, Ron, I'll "cover" you next time, love what you're doing,
etc). So Bob, there's 35 students for you who know more about you than
they do about Ron. And then, too, it's harder to read about Ron than it is
about T.S. Eliot, although if I had to place a bet, I would say that Ron
MIGHT be starting to give Robert Lowell a run for his money, in terms of
how many academic books/articles mention his name in 1996-7. If that's
true, great. I'm all for it. If not, let's work on it.

        I don't mean to devalue the differences between theories of poetry
(especially in terms of what gets taught in creative writing at the
present moment) but it's hard for me sometimes to get that worked up about
it. Language poets WILL get their courses, and WILL get their books. Bob
Grumman WILL be taught somewhere, some time (again). Yes, T.S. Eliot has
the drop
on both of them--that may or may not change. But even if it did, all it
would mean would be that Bob or Ron or whoever would be better read and
better known in a world that looks pretty much like it does already. And
somebody down the line might say "I'm tired of this canonical Bob Grumman"
and whoosh, down he'd go too. There's NOTHING in the academic system to
prevent that from happening. But there is a great deal in the academic
system that prevents anything MORE than that from happening.

        Perhaps, for instance, some facts about the "acodominance" of
language poetry at that bastion of poetry radicalism, UBuffalo, might
help my argument? In a department with, say, 30-40 professors, how many
language poets are there? Two, if you count Susan Howe, which many will
and many will not. Two. It's actually impressive that there's more than
one. But you can be COMPLETELY certain that there will never be five.
There probably will never be three. It's "covered" already, so who would
fund it? At the two universities where I teach,
how many poets there are specifically associated with language poetry?
Well, me, actually. Some people have taken to calling me "that
language poet Mark Wallace." Except I'm not a language poet, although I
might as well be as far as almost everyone there is concerned. Actually,
since I'm an adjunct, with the exception of maybe five or six people
there's no one at those schools who knows anything about my poetry at all.
If I keep plugging away, one day more of them might. What I'm trying to
figure out is how much that will matter.

        So I agree with Rod Smith that the substance of these issues
matters. I
especially feel it in terms of creative writing where, yes, as Ron
Silliman points
out, a "conservative" approach to poetic form receives the most resources
and highest profile. But I also think that too much concentration on these
issues avoids the fact that literature has very little significance
elsewhere in this
society. We can argue about who should be "covered" in classes, but I
think that equal focus needs to be placed on the discplinary practices of
university bureaucracies, and the way we can tie into those bureaucracies,
often without even being conscious of it. And it's hard for me not to
think that there, the idea of "dominant" LITERARY ideas would be at best a
mystery, and at worst laughable, unless we were talking about Stephen
King, who makes enough cash that he might actually donate some.


Mark Wallace

On Fri, 11 Jul 1997, Fred Muratori wrote:

? More than one poet has told me that when they look to their bookshelves
for poetry that will drive/inspire them to hit the keyboard or legal pad,
Ashbery's are the last ones they'd select, regardless of how much they
might otherwise like and appreciate his work.


THAT'S an interesting question, isn't it? Not "what poets do you like?" or
even "what poets do you read?" but what poets actually DRIVE you to the
notebook, word processor, etc?

An old friend once told me that when he felt blocked, he would read Rilke
and Frank O'Hara -- simultaneously (or nearly) -- and that he hadn't known
it to fail yet.

Or perhaps there's not such an easy transference from anyone. Anyone have
any thoughts about this?
=========================================================================
Date:         Mon, 14 Jul 1997 18:21:26 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         David Israel <DISRAEL@SKGF.COM>
Subject:      Re: The language of influence

Fred Muratori:  << More than one poet has told me that when they look
to their bookshelves for poetry that will drive/inspire them to hit the
keyboard or legal pad, Ashbery's are the last ones they'd select >>


and Joe Safdie  << THAT'S an interesting question, isn't it? Not "what
poets do you like?" or even "what poets do you read?" but what poets
actually DRIVE you to the notebook, word processor, etc? . . .
Anyone have any thoughts about this? >>

I can report having been (at least once) driven directly to pen & paper by
reading Ashbery (following, in that case, my occasional custom of
inscribing my jottings in the blank pages that one handily finds at the end
of books; -- this is a custom I think I might even venture to suggest  to
others -- at least to those not scandalized by the idea; at some point I
could even go thru my books & note which volumes are so adorned -- a
case study . . . but for not, I'll stick w/ Ashbery.  Well one other: some
DC (?) poet has a little volume entitled *Asbestos*, in which I inscribed
a poem that became the nucleus of a book of poems.  In this case, I can't
say I was enraptured by *Asbestos*, but somehow it did drive me to
writ my own stuff).  As for the Ashbery, was one of his early volumes --
prob. *The Double Dream of Spring*.  I've also been sent, if not directly
to pen or keyboard (?), then certainly to a sense of wanting to repair
thereto, by the opening pages of Ashbery's *Flowchart*.

I can also report being driven to brush & canvas -- by Ashbery's poem
"Hotel Latraemont" [sp?], when it appeared in . . . yup, *The New
Yorker* in 1990 (it subsequently became title poem of a book of JA's).
In those days, I was doing paintings in which I'd inscribe lines from
poems, and was very pleased with that memorable & remarkable one.

(Also did -- incidentally -- a very large [and very incomplete] sequence of
small canvases based on Rilke's *Notebooks of Brigge*.  And,for the
record, I did a large (& finished) canvas inspired by that paper-boat poem
of Tagore's that Steven Marks has lately mentioned liking [in my
paraphrase of it]. . . .)

Have also been driven to ink & paper by [here's a partial list]: George
Oppen, Ann Lauterbach, Tom Mandel, Jane Hirshfield, W.C. Williams,
Charles Wright, Andre Codrescu (whimsical essays, not poetry), Italo
Calvino, Eugenio Montale, *Han Shan in English* (an essay), the film *In
Custody* (abt. a fictional Urdu poet), and -- noteably? -- front pages of
the Wall Street Journal & the Washington Post (several times).

cheers,
d.i.
=========================================================================
Date:         Mon, 14 Jul 1997 18:35:37 -0400
Reply-To:     BobGrumman@nut-n-but.net
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Bob Grumman <BobGrumman@NUT-N-BUT.NET>
Subject:      Re: Acadominance; also an Announcement
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Yikes, I just don't know how to handle this revelation from Mark Wallace
about his teaching my StrayngeBook.  I never expected my off-hand
comment about acadominance to so quickly come home to roost!

One good thing about it: everyone on this list will now have to obey my
command to order a copy of *O!!Zone 97*, an anthology of visual, textual
and visio-textual art edited by Harry Burrus that's just come out.  83
pages of work from 57 artists.  $13 for individuals, $25 for
institutions.  International in scope.  Lots of good stuff by good
people including the list's own Dave Chirot.  Most of the names are new
to me, which I count a good sign, but I saw a few well-known ones (to
people in mail art and related fields, at least) like Ruggero Maggi,
Jurgen O. Olbrich, Hartmut Andrycuk and Clemente Padin.

Anyone interested in Visual Poetry ought to check out Karl Young's Light
& Dust Site, too: he's got a terrific selection of works by Alain Satie,
and has just opened (in honor of Bastille Day) a gallery of works from
KALDRON, this country's longest-running international visual poetry
periodical (to my knowledge).  Several really fine pieces by people like
Marilyn R. Rosenberg, Carol Stetser, Shohachiro Takahashi--and (speaking
of flow-chart poetry a while back) a collaboration between Miekal And,
Liz Was and Michael Helsem that is part flow-chart, part circuit
diagram, many parts who-knows-what--and all parts fascinating.  I have a
piece in the KALDRON collection, too, an acadominant one--and maybe
that's not so facetious, for it's an homage to none other than Will
Shakespeare!

                                                  Bob G.

> (Also did -- incidentally -- a very large [and very incomplete] sequence of
> small canvases based on Rilke's *Notebooks of Brigge*.  And,for the
> record, I did a large (& finished) canvas inspired by that paper-boat poem
> of Tagore's that Steven Marks has lately mentioned liking [in my
> paraphrase of it]. . . .)
>
> Have also been driven to ink & paper by [here's a partial list]: George
> Oppen, Ann Lauterbach, Tom Mandel, Jane Hirshfield, W.C. Williams,
> Charles Wright, Andre Codrescu (whimsical essays, not poetry), Italo
> Calvino, Eugenio Montale, *Han Shan in English* (an essay), the film *In
> Custody* (abt. a fictional Urdu poet), and -- noteably? -- front pages of
> the Wall Street Journal & the Washington Post (several times).
>
> cheers,
> d.i.
>

Subject:      Brecht
Comments: To: poetics@UBVM.cc.buffalo.edu

Mark,

Brecht is how you get from Shklovsky to Benjamin, the concepts of ostranenie
and alienation being virtually identical. I didn't really start to read him
much myself, other than the plays, until the 1978 when I was part of a
Marxist Study Group led by the Che of theory himself, Bruce Boone, in SF, in
which he introduced BB's critical work. Also involved were Steve Benson, Bob
Gluck and Kathleen Fraser.

From:    Mark Prejsnar <mprejsn@LAW.EMORY.EDU>
Subject: Re: acadominance & langpo

Again, as so often, I return to the fact that the *hidden secret*, at least
apparently to most people, (but like most hidden secrets it's right there
out in the open) with regard to LangPo theory is: it's huge debt to
*Brecht*...but also its creative *extension* of Brecht; for instance
combining him with Stein/Zuke/Ez to begin a synthesis involving both ideas
of a public art and ideas of the physicality of language as an active
medium.)

----------------------

Ron, again:

Mark W,

I'm glad to see that you've finally unveiled the role of Bob Grumman in
acadominance. It's about time that we see some explication of the Grumman
Gruppe in print (tho I've heard people attempt to connect the work to that
of LA poet-actor Harry Northrup Jr, into something they call Northrup-
Grumman, but that's another tale).

Ron

Date:         Tue, 15 Jul 1997 12:26:37 GMT
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Sherry Brennan <sab5@PSU.EDU>
Subject:      Central Pennsylvania poetry reading
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

I don't know if there's anyone in Harrisburg or the surrounding area on this
list, but thought I'd post the following:

The New Poetry in Reading Series is hosting a reading by C.S. Giscombe
and Kenneth A. McClane this Saturday, July 19, 8 p.m. at Svoboda's Books.
Svoboda's is at 227 W. Beaver Ave in downtown State College.  Both Giscombe
and McClane will be reading from forthcoming books.

McClane, W.E.B. Du Bois Professor of Literature at Cornell, is a poet and
essayist.  He has published 7 books of poetry, a book of essays, _Walls_,
and has another book of essays forthcoming.  His essay on James Baldwin in
_Walls_ is really marvelous, and I hear he is a great reader.

Cecil Giscombe is here at Penn State this summer as a Minority Summer
Scholar.  Giscombe is a poet with several books, most recently _Here_
(Dalkey Archive), and _Two Sections from Giscombe Road_ (Leave  Books).  He
is currently working on a prose book (although I heard some of this read a
few weeks ago, and I'd contend that it's prose poetry).  It is loosely
historical, based on the life of John Giscome, a West Indian "miner &
explorer" who settled in British Columbia in the 19th century.  Giscombe's
work is mellifluous and quite beautiful.

If anyone would like more information, directions, e-mail me at
sab5@psu.edu.  Thanks.

Sherry Brennan

Subject:      Re: Neologism / (gravy trail)

Mark Weiss initiates a neo-neolo. thread:

> insaucience--what happens when you fall in the gravy.

how about:
souciety:  whom one's with, when is in company w/ the sauced

also, the recent appearance of Raymond Carver's name (on Maria
Damon's fiction-writer roster) recalls Caver's utterance (after he was
diagnosed w/ terminal cancer) to the effect that he was grateful to
have been able to have so happy a final decade (or thereabouts) of
life (in wake of more troublous years) -- and that indeed, he regarded
the whole personal epoch as "gravy" --

an expression that (with rather different spin) our freshman-year
chemistry professor used for such information as the brood of premeds
needn't consider directly relevant to an upcoming quiz --

also recalling Wavy Gravy of 60s fame --

also skirting around borders of the "grave" & "gravity" of gravy --

what to make of it? . . .

groovy for 60s, gravy for 90s? gravitas for 00s? . . .

sauce for the goose, gravy for the gander . . . ?

d.i.

Date:         Tue, 15 Jul 1997 10:39:50 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         David Bromige <dcmb@METRO.NET>
Subject:      brecht/poetry/sf/'74
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

one grain of rice along this Influence Trail :  a poem I wrote in response
to BB's "Grosser Dankchoral"-- with which I found myself substantially in
agreement, but which, in its use of the idea of heaven in stanza 3,(though
not in stanza 4), appears in contradiction with itself...

 _After Brecht_

Be thankful it's this dark.
Nobody knows what you're up to.
What if they did--
who's to say its wrong.

Anything we want to do,
as long as we can find the energy,
we do it.  That's how come
it's getting darker all the time.

What if some dark night
they do you in.  No last moments
marred by the injustice of it all.
I don't know who to thank.


(this was in _Tight Corners_, Black Sparrow, 1974).

Yes, I recall much discussion of _ostrananie_ during the talks & workshops
of the late 70s, which Ron S is correct to hook up with BB's estrangement
of audience, which could have gone further were he not such "a man of the
people", in whom "the tree of heaven" still grew. I'm not complaining -- to
whom complain? I think Brecht is amazing. "Is the enemy still making
movements in your rear?" ( Btw, Bob Grumman's mention of the "Reverse
Bowering Initial Syndrome" puts me in mind of Bob Grenier, who did a
wonderful translation of a one-act play of BB's sometime in late 70s/early
80s which appeared where, Ron? _Jimmy & Lucy's House of K_ ? )

+++++++++++++

On a probably related subject,"How to Bower", I say to Rachel, whose fund
of what used to be called when I went to school, General Knowledge, puts
her close to the top of the class or at it, "Well, you would say that,
wouldn't you?"

That being Mandy Rice-Davies' most famous line in the Profumo Trial. (One
more grain in the Mandy Rice-Davies Trail.)

++++++++++++++

Theologism : behave-y trail.


+++++++++++++++

Henry James, Steve Martin, John Dos Passos, Stephen Wright, Evelyn Waugh,
Bernard Miles, Scott Fitzgerald, Robin Williams, Malcolm Lowry, Richard
Pryor.

David

From:         "Pritchett,Pat @Silverplume" <pritchpa@SILVERPLUME.IIX.COM>
Subject:      Re: what about Rickles?
Comments: To: Maria Damon <damon001@MAROON.TC.UMN.EDU>
MIME-version: 1.0
Content-type: TEXT/PLAIN

What? No Don Rickles? Whattsamatta with you hockey pucks? But seriously,
folks - only last night as we watched him on Letterman, my wife remarked:
"I've hated that man for 40 years." Then we noticed how age had mellowed him
 - indeed, he had to make a visible effort to work himself up into what was
only a mild fit of bellicose indignation. I've always found him incredibly
obnoxious - but he's a superb  technician of the joke in matters of
delivery, timing, improvising and above all, at reading the audience's
degree of self-loathing - which wld make him an interesting case study,
perhaps. The poetics of self-degradation. Of course, this would apply to
many comics and not a few poets (Berryman, Lowell, perhaps Crane?). I
_still_ haven't read your piece on Lenny Bruce, Maria -  do you deal with
this much?

Patrick Pritchett

Date:         Tue, 15 Jul 1997 17:33:14 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Mark Weiss <junction@EARTHLINK.NET>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

The following came to me from a friend who's always looking out for my
interests. I don't know his source. I thought I'd pass it along, as it's
damned close to poetry.



The following announcements actually appeared in various church bulletins:

 1. Thursday night - Potluck supper.  Prayer and medication to follow.

 2.  Remember in prayer the many who are sick of our church and community.

 3.  For those of you who have children and don't know it, we have a nursery
downstairs.

 4.  The rosebud on the alter this morning is to announce the birth of
David Alan Belzer, the sin of Rev. and Mrs. Julius Belzer.

 5.  This afternoon there will be a meeting in the South and North ends of
the church.  Children will be baptized at both ends.

 6.  Tuesday at 4:00 PM there will be an ice cream social.  All ladies giving
milk will please come early.

 7.  Wednesday the ladies liturgy will meet.  Mrs. Johnson will sing "Put me
in my little bed" accompanied by the pastor.

 8.  Thursday at 5:00 PM there will be a meeting of the Little Mothers Club.
All ladies wishing to be "Little Mothers" will meet with the Pastor in his
study.

 9.  This being Easter Sunday, we will ask Mrs. Lewis to come foreward and lay
an egg on the alter.

 10.  Next Sunday a special collection will be taken to defray the cost of the
new carpet.  All those wishing  to do something on the new carpet will come
foreward and do so.

 11.  The ladies of the church have cast off clothing of every kind. They can
be seen in the church basement Saturday.

 12.  A bean supper will be held on Tuesday evening in the church hall. Music
will follow.

 13.  At the evening service tonight, the sermon topic will be "What is
Hell?"  Come early and listen to our choir practice.
=========================================================================

uh...sort of, but not the extent that albert goldman does, in Ladies and
Gentlemen, Lenny Bruce!, which is a bit creepy in that regard, reveling in
Bruce's abjection and other forms of hyperbole (referring to Jews as "the
most despised race in history" etc) aiming, i guess, for a sort of
titillating voyeuristic pathos. i'm totally into the pathos i must admit,
tho i hope not the titillation, and a few folks have complained about my
paper that it's more tragic than funny. it may still be up at the
postmodern culture website.

i find this whole discussion kind of strange because the concept of, looking
for inspiration when you need to write. i either create or i dont. if i have
to force it out i dont think its worth doing (poetry that is. other writing
deadlines like reviews are another method). yes, i like a lot of writers,
but as for going to my book shelf so i can write a poem, that seems an alien
concept, forcing inspiration.
