Other books are EX-LAX to me. I don't know what I'd do without someone
else's better lines and/or their examples. It's not exactly forcing
inspiration so much as conceeding the fact that inspiration isn't always
desirable, available. Tough, true poets. Often inspiration is a con
anyway, a magic wand a hare too short. And beyond this, just because a
book is "inspirational" or "compelling" or whatever doesn't mean it'll get
words flowing. These are books that make one want to write, while the
actual writing is still another thing. THen again, I've no problem with
sampling.

Bennett.

Date:         Wed, 16 Jul 1997 01:54:49 -0600

From:         Hugh Steinberg <hsteinberg@GRIN.NET>
Subject:      Re: influential writers
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Dan writes:

>i find this whole discussion kind of strange because the concept of, looking
>for inspiration when you need to write. i either create or i dont. if i have
>to force it out i dont think its worth doing (poetry that is. other writing
>deadlines like reviews are another method). yes, i like a lot of writers,
>but as for going to my book shelf so i can write a poem, that seems an alien
>concept, forcing inspiration.

I approach my bookshelf more as a resource, like a refrigerator, than as
means for forcing inspiration (books as ingredients, sure; books as meals
or snacks, but of course; as laxatives? feh!).  Since I primarily work in
collage, I literally devour texts, and so long as the language is
interesting I'm not all too picky.  I got a lot of poems out of a found
text, "German Spies at Bay," a rather jingoistic book from the 1920's
extolling the heroism of British counterespionage during WWI.  Also, a lot
of bad art inspires me, as it makes me question what can be done better.

As for comfort food:  Kafka (the short stories), Borges (especially his
collaboration with Adolfo Bioy Casares as H. Bustos Domecq), Bilge Karasu,
Jabes, Barthes, Foucault, Kristeva, Cixous, this great book of essays on
music by Al Young, "Drowning in the Sea of Love," Eduardo Galeano,
Cordwainer Smith, Alison Deming, Mrabet.  Jean Cocteau's films, also Mel
Brooks and even though he's an increasingly loathsome creep, Woody Allen.

Hugh Steinberg

Acodominants of the world unite,

To: nwuphil@libertynet.org
From: nwuphil@philadelphia.libertynet.org
Subject: organizing academics

Dear folks:

This is a new initiative coming from the Michigan folks.  If you're an
academic writer or know some academic writers, you might consider contacting
the SE Michigan Local.

John

>
>* * *
>
>FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
>
>Southeast Michigan Local of National Writers Union
>Receives $1,000 Grant to Organize Academic Writers
>
>       Ann Arbor, Michigan, June 24,1997--The Southeast Michigan local of the
>National Writers Union, UAW local 1981 (SEM-NWU) has received a $1,000
grant
>from the National Writers Union to begin an Academic Writers Organizing
>Campaign. The announcement was made at the National Writers Union Delegates
>Assembly in Philadelphia on Sunday June 22. Co-chairs Ken Wachsberger, from
>Ann Arbor, and Amy Rose, from Detroit, wrote the proposal and presented it
>at the Assembly.
>
>       The main purposes of the campaign will be to study publishing
conditions of
>academic writers in the Southeast Michigan area and to develop a "Code of
>Conduct for Academic Writers and Publishers." The initial focus will be on
>Eastern Michigan University, Michigan State University, University of
>Michigan, and Wayne State University,
>
>       According to Rose, a former college professor and now a freelance
>instructional writer, the grant is recognition on the part of the union's
>national leadership that economic and working conditions for academics are
>getting steadily worse. "Faculty often work for years without getting into
>the better-paying tenure track," she notes. "They have no job security and
>few or no benefits. Publishing is still a professional necessity. However,
>it is increasingly also an economic necessity. Unfortunately, and often out
>of ignorance or fear, academic writers give away all their publishing
>rights. Many, for instance, let book publishers steal away their copyrights
>because contracts are written by publishers' lawyers and academic writers
>don't assert their rights to retain them."
>
>       Wachsberger, a long-time author, journalist, and editor, has been a
leader
>of the five-year effort by the Michigan Federation of Teachers & School
>Related Personnel to unionize lecturers at Eastern Michigan University,
>where he teaches writing. He sees a natural alliance between the campus
>teachers' unions and the NWU's Academic Writers Organizing Campaign. "The
>teachers' unions all represent academics when it comes to issues such as
>tenure, class schedules, and grievances in the workplace. But they are
>largely unknowledgeable about the publishing world. Academic writers who
>have grievances with their publishers can turn to the NWU, where Grievance
>Officers have won members over a million dollars in grievance awards. In
>addition, the newly created Publishers' Rights Clearinghouse is helping
>writers earn their rightful royalties for articles and poems that appear
>first in print and then are reprinted without permission of their authors."
>
>       Representatives of SEM-NWU will be meeting with academics at the four
>universities in coming weeks to listen to their concerns and begin laying
>the groundwork for the study.
>
>       The National Writers Union was formed in 1981 to represent freelance
>writers in all genres, including fiction, poetry, academic writing,
>technical writing, screen writing, and journalism. The NWU was chartered in
>1983, affiliated with the UAW in 1992, and now has almost 5,000 members.
>
>        For interviews or more information, please call Ken Wachsberger at
>(313) 971-3868 or Amy Rose at (313) 882-5183.
>
>
>
>
John Feffer
National Writers Union
Philadelphia Local
519 S. Melville St.
Philadelphia, PA  19143
215-386-5538
nwuphil@libertynet.org
http://www.libertynet.org/~nwuphil

Poets who drive me to write:

Bill Corbett
Jimmy Schuyler
Rae Armantrout
Bob Perelman
Lyn Hejinian
David Bromige
Charles Bernstein

I've been reading Corbett's Selected for the past several weeks and it's a
wonderful, amazing book. Why haven't they named the English Dept at Harvard
after the man?

In a completely different vein, I go back to my parents, Whalen, Duncan,
Olson, Spicer, Ginsberg, Creeley, Eigner, Blackburn and to my grandparents,
Ez, Gertrude, Louis, and William Carlos....

Comics:
Lenny Bruce (only entertainer that both my mother and I paid to see, tho at
different times). I can still do most of Father Flotski's Triumph by memory.
Lord Buckley
Andy Kaufman
George Bowering

Novelists:
Sterne
Pynchon
Joyce
My twins and I are reading Finnegans Wake at the moment. It's the perfect
book for five year old boys, all puzzle.
Faulkner (esp. the real stuff, not the recycled versions a la Alice Walker)
Hemingway (again, prefer the original to The English Patient)
Beckett (again, prefer the original to Carole Maso's Ava)
Langston Hughes
Michael Gold's Jews without Money
Philip K Dick, Bruce Sterling, Chip Delaney

Date:         Wed, 16 Jul 1997 07:01:48 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         David Israel <DISRAEL@SKGF.COM>
Subject:      Re: influential writers

Dan Raphael Dlugonski remarks:

<< i find this whole discussion kind of strange because the concept of,
looking for inspiration when you need to write. i either create or i dont. if
i have to force it out i dont think its worth doing (poetry that is. other
writing deadlines like reviews are another method). yes, i like a lot of
writers, but as for going to my book shelf so i can write a poem, that
seems an alien concept, forcing inspiration. >>

Actually, I think that many of us were describing a relationship between
reading & writing a bit more loosely than that of repairing to books for
the "purpose" of "causing" ourselves to be "interested" or "inspired" in
writing ourselves.  For exaample, when I said that I had written some
things in the wake of reading Ashbery (et al.), this is an after-the-fact
observation -- i.e., that while in the act of reading his words, I found
(willy-nilly!) myself inclined to write -- and the impulse / impetus to
write happened to be of sufficient strength that I actually dragged the pen
across the page.

I.e., the question can sound like "where do you turn, when you want to
cause yourself to feel like writing?" -- but I think many of us translated
this into "under what circumstances [of having read things] have you
retrospectively noted that you have felt more inclined to write something
[presumably under the "influence" of the thing(s) you were reading]?"

d.i.

ensemble wouldn't let them air their sketch idea during the show but were
gracious enough to let them play it over the credits, at which point the
scene cuts to the two of them in full body frog suits splashing
spasmodically in a kiddy pool while playing banjos: that's it.

a book I might have mentioned myself.  Last week, though--speaking of

which I first thought to pass on to you-all, as a curiosity, then
thought not (since opinions expressed are not necessarily, as they say,
those of your correspondent, and who knows, in this pixel-bath, whether

"Gertrude Stein: A Literary Idiot"

by Michael Gold

first published in _The New Masses_

Gertrude Stein recently returned to America after an absence of many
years. In Paris, where she lived as a forbidding priestess of a
strange literary cult, Gertrude Stein accumulated a salon frequented by
some of the outstanding names of the modern art world and
acquired the reputation of a literary freak. People either gaped at her
published writings, or laughed at her incomprehensible literary
epigrams- "a rose is a rose is a rose."

She was looked upon by those who believed in her as the greatest
revolutionist in the history of contemporary literature, and by
those who scoffed as the perpetrator of a gigantic literary hoax.

As it happens, neither of the two opinions is wholly correct. Her
"revolution" resembles a literary putsch, and if her writing is "a
hoax" nevertheless she earnestly believes in it.

In essence, what Gertrude Stein's work represents is an example of the
most extreme subjectivism of the contemporary bourgeois
artist, and a reflection of the ideological anarchy into which the whole
of bourgeois literature has fallen.

What was it that Gertrude Stein set out to do with literature? When one
reads her work it appears to resemble the monotonous
gibberings of paranoiacs in the private wards of asylums. It appears to
be a deliberate irrationality, a deliberate infantilism.
However, the woman's not insane, but possessed of a strong, clear,
shrewd mind. She was an excellent medical student, a brilliant
psychologist, and in her more "popular" writings one sees evidence of
wit and some wisdom.

And yet her works read like the literature of the students of padded
cells in Matteawan.

Example: "I see the moon and the moon sees me. God bless the moon and
God bless me and this you see remember me. In this
way one fifth of the bananas were bought."

The above is supposed to be a description of how Gertrude Stein feels
when she sees Matisse, the French modernist painter. It
doesn't make sense. But this is precisely what it is supposed to do- not
"make sense" in the normal meaning of the term.

.. The generation of artists of which Gertrude Stein is the most erratic
figure arduously set out not to "make sense" in their literature.
They believed that the instincts of man were superior to the reasonings
of the rational mind. They believed in intuition as a higher
form of learning and knowledge. Therefore, many of them wrote only about
what they dreamed, dream literature. Others practised
a kind of "automatic writing" where they would sit for hours scribbling
the random, subconscious itchings of their souls. They
abandoned themselves to the mystic irrationalities of their spirits in
order to create works of art which would be expressions of the
timeless soul of man, etc. The result unfortunately revealed their souls
as astonishingly childish or imbecile.

The literary insanity of Gertrude Stein is a deliberate insanity which
arises out of a false conception of the nature of art and of the
function of language.

A leisure class, which exists on the labor of others, which has no
function to perform in society except the clipping of investment
coupons, develops ills and neuroses. It suffers perpetually from
boredom. Their life is stale to them. Tasteless, inane, because it has
no meaning. They seek new sensations, new adventures constantly in order
to give themselves feelings.

The same process took place with the artists of the leisure class.
Literature also bored them. They tried to suck out of it new
sensations, new adventures.

They destroyed the common use of language. Normal ways of using words
bored them. They wished to use words in a new,
sensational fashion. They twisted grammar, syntax. They went in for
primitive emotions, primitive art. Blood, violent death, dope
dreams, soul-writhings, became the themes of their works.

In Gertrude Stein, art became a personal pleasure, a private hobby, a
vice. She did not care to communicate because essentially
there was nothing to communicate. She had no responsibility except to
her own inordinate cravings. She became the priestess of a
cult with strange literary rites, with mystical secrets.

In this light, one can see that to Gertrude Stein and to the other
artists like her, art exists in the vacuum of a private income. In order
to pursue the kind of art, in order to be the kind of artist Gertrude
Stein is, it is necessary to live in that kind of society which will
permit one to have a private income from wealthy parents or sound
investments. With this as a basis, you can write as you please.
You can destroy language, mutilate grammar, rave or rant in the name of
the higher knowledge. Nobody will disturb you. And in
time perhaps you can impress or intimidate a certain number of critics
and win a kind of reputation.

Gertrude Stein has won the reputation. She returns home to America after
an absence of thirty-one years to find herself an object of
curious respect by book clubs and lecture societies, and front page news
for the newspapers.

Which seems to me to be proof that with enough money and enough
persistence a madman can convince a world of his sanity.
Gertrude Stein appears to have convinced America that she is a genius.

But Marxists refuse to be impressed with her own opinion of herself.
They see in the work of Gertrude Stein extreme symptoms of
the decay of capitalist culture. They view her work as the complete
attempt to annihilate all relations between the artist and the
society in which he lives.

They see in her work the same kind of orgy and spiritual abandon that
marks the life of the whole leisure class.

What else does her work resemble more than the midnight revels of a
stockbroker throwing a pent-house party for a few intimate
friends? Would it be possible to have either of these symptoms of
degeneration except in a society divided into classes? Is there not
an "idle art" just as there is an "idle rich"? Both do nothing but
cultivate the insanity of their own desires, both cultivate strange
indulgences. The literary idiocy of Gertrude Stein only reflects the
madness of the whole system of capitalist values. It is part of the
signs of doom that are written largely everywhere on the walls of
bourgeois society.
=========================================================================

Hi everyone, it's Kevin Killian.  Still reeling from the assassination of
Gianni Versace and now the newscasters are saying it might be Andrew
Cunanan who killed him.

Anyway yesterday I was reading "USA Today" and saw the article about the UK
poet Murray Lachlan Young with the "face of Daniel Day Lewis" and the "hair
of Jim Morrison" and how his various poetic contracts amount to
$2,000,000.00 (translated to US money).  Is anyone on the Poetics List
familiar with this man's work?  Please fill me in.

Also was drawn to USA Today's coverage of the new memoir by Erik Estrada,
"My Road from Harlem to Hollywood."  I guess in the book Erik Estrada is
kind of tough on his former partner on "CHiPs," Larry Wilcox.  "Asked about
Erik Estrada's recollections of their 'CHiPs' days in "My Road from Harlem
to Hollywood," former castmate Larry Wilcox, now head of a TV production
company and a software company called MediaCore, replied via electronic
mail.  Here is an excerpt:

"To respond to Erik's perceptions would be a litany of material on
philosophy and morals combined with what Jacques Derrida refers to as the
malady of subjective perception."  Only those perhaps who ever saw an
episode of "CHiPs" will understand my shock, the way my eyes bugged out of
my head while reading this.  And it goes on and on.

I've been out of touch with the Poetics List lately and in an awful slump
but did want to second Bennett Simpson's recommendation of Dennis Cooper's
new novel "Guide" which I enjoyed no end.  Actually Bennett Simpson feels
less enthusiastic about this book than I do: "I started it this week and
it's not inspiring, not titilllllllating, obliquely critical, kinda
nauseating and very far from my reality (does this make me a stump?). The
dustjacket is calling him the new Genet. Well, huh. The characters are
boring (but maybe not as much as they're supposed to be). I do like some
of the stylistic tics however. Flatness going places."  Some other books I
have liked lately are biographies, Helen Sheehy's book on Eva Le Gallienne,
Margot Peters' life of May Sarton, John Felstiner's "Paul Celan: Poet,
Survivor, Jew," and Hertzel Weinstat & Bert Wechsler's book "Dear Rogue,"
the life of the US baritone Lawrence Tibbett.  (Although it has a dreadful
opening line: "Most of us, when our course is run, deserve the anonymity of
the grave.  Not so Lawrence Tibbett . . .")  Jackson Benson's life of
Wallace Stegner is horrible.  One other book I read at Naropa was Mary
Butts' novel "Armed with Madness."  This one I give 5 stars.  I meant to
post here my diary of what it was like to spend a week at Naropa but every
sentence I wrote sounded just like Mary Butts.  So there's influence for
you!  Or, maybe, the "malady of subjective perception."

Thanks, everyone.

From:         James Finnegan <JforJames@AOL.COM>
Subject:      Re: Bronk v. Ashbery
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=unknown-8bit
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

The yoking of Bronk to Ashbery I find odd. I think their
sensibilities are worlds apart. First there is the simple matter
of length. Bronk’s poems are shorter, quirky & pithy.
Ashbery's longwinded, multi-layered, digressive. Bronk has an
oblique and perverse approach to his subject; often his work
seems to be an argument with the world. (I’m reminded here
of a recorded interview in which I don’t think Bronk agreed
with a single assertion the interviewer made about his poetry.)
The Ashbery poem is often evasive, opaque--the poem is much
less an explanation than an desultory exploration. Anyway,
these are just a few of my random musings on their poetries.

Finnegan

George: that's unfair. Canucks have their comedians too: still alive (we
think): Lucien Bouchard, Jean Chretien, Mike Harris, Preston Manning (who
sat at the feet of another great comedian in the US [I realize this list
really confuses most of the poetics readers] -- then House Majority leader,
oops, but I cant think of his name only his appearance as a small bomb in
doonesbury), my own provincial premier Ralph Klein, GB's own provincial
premier, Glenn Clark.

Prose writers: Oh I'm so happy kali tal mentioned delany, russ, & such
like, as I have a whole bunch of sf writers I'd mention: a few include
those two, Ursula K Le Guin, Brian Aldiss, Iain M Banks, Alfred Bester,
John Crowley, Gwyneth Jones, & many others, but not all as 'influences,'
since some are fairly recent discoveries; rather, as with George again,
that I read them for pleasure.

I have certainly been indebted on some level or other to many of those
already named, but again the canuck connection comes to bear: gosh, George
Bowering is there; Leonard Cohen, Timothy Findlay, Robert Kroetsch, Daphne
Marlatt, bpNichol (for everything), Michael Ondaatje, Audrey Thomas, + the
famous ones. Just for beginners.

Guy Davenport as both critic & fiction writer ever since i first discovered him.

This is an impossible question, of course. What do we mean 'influenced'? I
pick the hearts & brains of every new interesting text I read.... Dont you?

Sun & Moon Press once again has several new
titles just published, which we are willing to
offer members of the Poetics List for a 20%
discount.

DRA-- by Stacey Levine.

Levine won the PEN-West Award for fiction for
her first book, the 1993 collection of stories,
MY HORSE AND OTHER STORIES. She's a young and
very talented writer, living in Seattle, but soon
be teaching at Illinois State University in Normal
next year (she's a temporary replacement for David
Foster Wallace). This new work, her first longer
fiction, is an incredible dystopia, in which the
title character inhabits a drab and reary world of
utter dread. Through a Kafka-like lens Levine
explores how the meek and sane are made mad in a
society that demands choices that only lead to less
and less individual choice and control.  Paperback
$11.95.

EVERYTHING THAT RISES MUST CONVERGE, by John Jesurun

Influenced by Hitchock, Gertrude Stein, The Wooster
Group, and Richard Foreman, John Jesurun began to
produce his own theatrical pieces in the early 1980s
His legendary, fifty-episode theater piece, CHANG IN A
VOID MOON, began performances in 1982-1983 as 36 half-
hour installments. CHANG was followed by other pieces,
DOG'S EYE VIEW at La Mama, and NUMBER MINUS ONE at the
Performing Garage, as well as several others.
   EVERYTHING THAT RISES MUST CONVERGE was first performed
at the Walker Arts Center in minneapolis and then at the
Kitchen in New York, and his one of his major theater
pieces.
   Jesurun was awarded a MacArthur grant in 1996 for his
dramatic writings.  Paperback $11.95


THE CAPTAIN OF THE BUTTERFLIES, by Cees Nooteboom

Nooteboom is currently one of the major fiction writers
and poets in Europe, and has been suggested several times
for a Nobel Prize. His fictions, published by Harcourt,
Brace, have received great attention in the US. And he
recently published a personal travel book about Spain to
great review attention
   THE CAPTAIN OF THE BUTTERFLIES is the first publication
in English of a large selection of his poetry. The result
is a wonderful writing of enery and wit, in which surrealist-
like images are presented in dialogue in precise, realistic
language.  Paperback $11.95


THE LIBRARY OF THOMAS RIVKA, by Martin Nakell

Well known in the Los Angeles poetry scene, Martin Nakell
has toured the US several times, and is now touring Europe.
THE LIBRARY OF THOMAS RIVKA is a short fiction exploring
various ideas, philosophical and pratical, about an entire
library of books--how to classify them, how to order them,
their bindings, their markings, and what their being within
the same library means, how they "communicate" with one
another. Suggesting other such fictions by figures from
JK Huysmans to Jorge Luis Borges, this book is an absurdly
humorous work.  Paperback $11.95

THE BOOK OF WHO ARE WAS, by Benjamin Hollander

San Francisco poet Bejamin Holland negotiates a past and
present with poets such as Paul Celan, Edmond Jabes, and
Anne-Marie Albiach in the projection of "memory on stage."
Recognizing poetry as a theatrical field, a performance
so to speak, THE BOOK OF WHO ARE WAS contemplates the
process of poetic creation in which it is actually the
reader's or spectator's memory that is projected upon the
stage or text. A must for anyone interested in contemporary
poetry.  Paperback $10.95

Order through my E-mail djmess@sunmoon.com
or from Sun & Moon Press, 6026 Wilshire Boulevard
Los Angeles, CA 90036

If you would like a special summer sale catalogue,
please also E-mail us.

Douglas Messerli

What comedians do  people find inspiring?What comedians do people find
inspiring?What comedians do people find inspiring?What comedians do people

        I all honesty & innocence I protest: Inspiration is one thing--& I
don't doubt the urge to take pen in hand might come from a particularly good
comedy routine--but do you really find all the comedians mentioned so far
*funny*? JESUS!! I mean I like to think I have at least a LIVELY if not KEEN
sense of humor, but none of that standup mainstream hollywood culture crap
makes me laugh!
        OKOK I can see Chaplin & Keaton, for the intellectual elegance, but
that televised slapshhtk just doesn't come off. And those interminable
"sarcastic" gambling-hall clowns--O they tick me off! Standup latenite
talkshowhost reactionary crap!

        Bob & Ray - yes I remember them from one quiet season on public
radio in New Hampshire -- I guess I thought that was sorta funny.
        And I confess the friendship between Lamont & Sanford can inspire a
chuckle. And Carol O'Connor, who, by the by, is quite a Joyce scholar, &
friendly, so I've heard, with Richard Ellman...

        I worked on a production by the Trinity Players in Dublin, doing
"Endgame" & have never laughed so consitently, loudly, at such length, with
such spirit, or so honestly in my life, night after night. Guts split. Every
*single* line of "Endgame", "Waiting for Godot" and the novels of the
Trilogy can get a laugh.

Fictionalists: Cervantes, Sterne, Gogol, Dostoevsky, Poe, Crane, Woolfe, my
great granduncle Allan Paton, Cather,  O'Connor (Flannery this time),
Baldwin, Banks (_Affliction_, _Hamilton Stark_)...

Allegorists: Bunyan, McCarthy (_Suttree_ & before), Antin

When writing poems & I need a break & to spark new words I inevitably turn
to: Milton, Rimbaud, Creeley, Walcott, Jordan or Brusenbrugge (spelled from
a poor memory)


When writing, I always listen to: McCoy Tyner, particularly "African
Village," "The Greeting," "Song for My Lady," "Ebony Queen," "Sahara,"
"Smitty's Place"...

Often inspired by Werner Herzog's movies. I can't watch any of those without
writing about them for days afterward. "Before the Rain" was very
inspirational as well; and Cassavettes' (spelled from a poor memory) "Shadows"
=========================================================================

From:         Michael Magee <mmagee@DEPT.ENGLISH.UPENN.EDU>
Subject:      Stein & Gold
In-Reply-To:  <33CCBCCE.1150@concentric.net> from "Rachel Loden" at Jul 16,
              97 05:21:34 am
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Thoughts on the Gold piece on Stein: it would be interesting to hear what
Gold might say about William James - just another bored capitilist?
Probably not b/c Gold seems to have that love historically common in
Marxists, the love of science & scientific method, of technology, almost
in spite of themselves - Gold shows it in his incredulity toward Stein's
past: what? she was a physician, a psychologist, and she's come to this?
In fact, Stein, it seems to me, always considered her work highly
applicable, highly "pragmatic" in the Jamesian fashion; believed in its
ability to influence and stretch the social fabric, which is to say,
believed in the connection  btwn linguistic and social flexibility.  Of
course Gold's having none of it:

"But Marxists refuse to be impressed with her own opinion of herself.
They see in the work of Gertrude Stein extreme symptoms of
the decay of capitalist culture. They view her work as the complete
attempt to annihilate all relations between the artist and the
society in which he lives."

This is the crossroads at which Jameson sits himself down, right?  Except
he has to be a good deal more sophisticated than Gold, post
post-structuralism, in dealing w/ the function of language-games in
culture.  Anyway, thanks for posting this, very interesting.  -m.

At 1:54 AM -0600 7/16/97, Hugh Steinberg wrote:

>I approach my bookshelf more as a resource, like a refrigerator, than as
>means for forcing inspiration (books as ingredients, sure; books as meals
>or snacks, but of course; as laxatives? feh!).  Since I primarily work in
>collage, I literally devour texts, and so long as the language is
>interesting I'm not all too picky.  I got a lot of poems out of a found
>text, "German Spies at Bay," a rather jingoistic book from the 1920's
>extolling the heroism of British counterespionage during WWI.  Also, a lot
>of bad art inspires me, as it makes me question what can be done better.

See me nodding and nodding in agreement.  This week's writing for me:  it
started with a response to the Jorie Graham article in the New Yorker,
trying to examine a close observation of the physical world and the impulse
to take that to preciousness, now to undercut the preciousness, then
there's AMC's playing of the Johnny Weismuller Tarzan movies which excite
me to no end, in particular this week _Tarzan and His Mate_ and _Tarzan
Finds a Child_, and then there's this marvelous book I got out of the
Naropa library which I just mailed back yesterday:  _Autobiography of a
Schizophrenic Girl_, one of those books that's so great you want to
memorize it.

When Dennis Cooper briefly taught private writing workshops in Los Angeles,
one of his students told me that Dennis' workshop was very much about
influence and his take on it was to go with what really strikes *you* (be
it your favorite rock album, whatever) rather than what is held to be
Acceptable influences.  This is one area in which Kevin K. has been most
influencial on me--the spirit of adventure in which Doris Day is just as
valid an influence as Walter Benjamin.

Dodie

Matthias --

I sympathize with your apprehension vis a vis comedians. But I think
really very funny comedy (Jarry? at least some of the comics listed here
over the past couple days?) is as strong a solvent of one's grimy limits
as any poetry -- which is not to propose that poetry isn't allowed to be
funny; on the contrary, it seems something like a tenet of the poetry in
this list's collective consciousness that _laughter indicates perception_.
Of course once you recognize _that_, it's even more of a battle to keep
from being _jokey_, which is as far from funny as you can get, though the
two are in practice usually undistinguished.

But I think a disdain for "mainstream" humor may safely be assumed here?
Jordan

Date:         Wed, 16 Jul 1997 13:58:38 -0500

Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         GROBERTS@BINAH.CC.BRANDEIS.EDU
Subject:      novelists and comics
MIME-version: 1.0
Content-type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII

Dickens, Conrad, and Beckett usually divert me to write poetry.  The great
variety of their sentence-shapes and their impeccable timing can get me going
for a piece of scrap paper and something to write with.  I wish Stein's prose
would do same.  Sometimes Joyce does.

As for the comics, I'm afraid that I was a sucker for the brilliant marketing
idea of the Marvel Universe elaborated by Jack Kirby, Stan Lee, and their
descendents in the superhero genre, like John Byrne.  Tie-ins, cameos,
cross-overs, origin stories, serial plots, operatic mythology, graphical and
typographical stylistics: it all kept me buying, collecting, assembling the
ephemera into my own hand-picked coherence.  It later sent me looking to George
Herriman, Walt Kelly, and Winsor McCay in reproduction, which set me wondering
in earnest about the difference between a comic strip and a comic book.  My
most intense experience of language as a kid during the 1970s was provided by the
lay-out of words in the boxes, polygons, and ellipses of comics.  No wonder
pomo seems so strangely familiar.  Buy on!

Gary R

>Actually, I think that many of us were describing a relationship between
>reading & writing a bit more loosely than that of repairing to books for
>the "purpose" of "causing" ourselves to be "interested" or "inspired" in
>writing ourselves.  For exaample, when I said that I had written some
>things in the wake of reading Ashbery (et al.), this is an after-the-fact
>observation -- i.e., that while in the act of reading his words, I found
>(willy-nilly!) myself inclined to write -- and the impulse / impetus to
>write happened to be of sufficient strength that I actually dragged the pen
>across the page.
>
>I.e., the question can sound like "where do you turn, when you want to
>cause yourself to feel like writing?" -- but I think many of us translated
>this into "under what circumstances [of having read things] have you
>retrospectively noted that you have felt more inclined to write something
>[presumably under the "influence" of the thing(s) you were reading]?"
>
>d.i.

Yup. Often, I think, we write in a sort of oblique dialogue with the poetry,
the language, what-have-you, that's already out there. Sometimes Chaucer
talks to me, sometimes I talk to him.

Comments: To: Poetics List <poetics@UBVM.cc.buffalo.edu>

You may have heard this before: the situation is still pretty dire,
however, and I'm forwarding this on behalf of "Friends of the Grolier";
purely on principle, I hate to see any independent close--especially
after losing several fine ones in New York. I'm sure other suggestions
would be welcomed.

---------------------

        You must know The Grolier Bookstore in Cambridge, MA--the ONLY
bookstore in the English speaking world devoted exclusively to poetry
and prose by poets.  Luisa's been the proprietor since 1973, and she is
in urgent need of help, or the Grolier will close in September.  She
must raise $50,000.  Thusfar $40,000 has been raised.  She's not a
non-profit, so as yet, this is not a tax write-off.  If you can help,
here's what we propose:  call Luisa at 1-800-234-POEM and open an account
with her, paying whatever you can in now, and then buying books from that
account after six months or a year.  This means she would benefit from an
advance from you of $100, $200 or whatever amount, large or small, and
you'll get books eventually (unless she goes out of business).  We're
trying to prevent that.  Please call her if you can.  Any amount would be
helpful.  Forward this message to any poets, writers, readers or poetry
supporters you might know...

And thank you so much!

--Carolyn Forche

The essay, "Fossilized Fish and the World of Unknowing: John Ashbery and
William Bronk," by John Ernest (to be found in _The Tribe of John_, edited
by yours truly), is actually about the non-influence of Ashbery on Bronk.
It's a good essay, one with a sense of humor about it.

Susan

From:         David Bromige <dcmb@METRO.NET>
Subject:      humorists
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

this isnt going to be comprehensive. I keep remembering more names as i
continue reading your postings. and yes what is mainstream humor, an
oxymoron? Is it Dana Gioia reading his poem about a kitty in heat, "Come
into the garden, Fred"? Another line I recall : "I'm wearing nothing but my
flea-collar". The slight shock of "Fred" for those oldfashioned enough to
expect "Maud" made me laugh, the first time. The wit of analogy abt
nakedness was okay, too. I guess it is what we are calling "jokey"?  But
it's easy to make me laugh. I even laugh at my own work sometimes. I spent
an evening with John Ashbery taking turns at reading aloud the works of
William MacGonnigal, touted as "the worst poet who ever wrote." It's bathos
at its best.

Evelyn Waugh is funny in a way no one else is (In the earlier novels). I am
a sucker for British humor. Dudley Moore & Peter Cook in "Bedazzled"--the
scene where Cook plays God (atop a pillarbox) to show Moore (who has to run
around the box praising Cooke) just why he (Cooke) got so bored with being
an angel in heaven & chose to become the devil instead. Peter Sellers in
"The Party", in a probably P.I. role as a person from the subcontinent
(India/Pakistan) saying "birdy num-nums" inadvertently over the intercom, &
otherwise making gaffes; or in the Pink Panther movie where he disguises
himself as the Swiss dentist (actually, as Einstein) in order to pull
Herbert Lom's tooth : the nitrous oxide is inhaled by both of them, with
(to me) hilarious result. But is this brit or american humor? it was made
in the usa. So was chaplin.

 American humor is terrific, & I agree with Rachel, early live Steve
Martin--it doesnt get any funnier than that, though it doesnt always hold
up today, probably because Martin's humor was transgressive in a
meta-comedy way, & that has now (thanks in part to Sm's pomo sensibility
showing the way) been caught up with. As for Woody Allen, I know he is
loathed for going "uptown" & for non-applicable-to-comedy reasons, but it
was pretty funny to see him attempt to rob a bank with a misspelled note.

 Has anyone named Mark Twain yet? With a stance like that, he cd come back
today & continue his deconstructions.

Stephen Wright's "it's a small world.........But I wouldn't want to paint
it" shows, like so much of his work, a sound grasp of the use of silence.
Such education in the laconic can readily spill over into poetry.

We Canadians are proud of our comedians--maybe being in yet not of the
American thing makes for good funny commentary. And of course, they had to
move south of the 49th to make it big. (Except for George Bowering).
Perhaps not everyone on this list knows the work of Stephen Leacock.
Sometimes it's a bit arch & labored, but in the classic _Sunshine Sketches
of a Little Town__ you find his (like they say) unique brand of humor in
spades. I'd be interested in backchanneling with anyone who'll attempt an
analysis of its workings. It works in part, I think, by puffing up then
deflating pretensions of the provincial sort (& hey, what arent?)

Henry James is a master of the shaggy dog punchline. Recall in _The
Ambassadors__ when the Pococks are coming, that we are told of Lambert
Strether, who hAd checked for a wire from them the day before only to find
none, that today when he checks there is one, to the effect that they will
shortly be in Paris where he is, "So, if yesterday he had occasion for a
small disappointment, today he had occasion for its opposite" ? (I'm
paraphrasing here). Hmm. Had he been living in england a while when he
wrote that?

Creeley is pretty damn funny--a story (in _The Gold Diggers_ ) that begins
"To work was to pray. He worked" -- or the poem "My wife & I lived all
alone. Contention was our only bone. I fought with her, she fought with me,
& things went on right merrily"...are xtreme instances of the yankee p-o-v
that informs much of his work. But its not only yankee, isnt RC close to
being Irish?

And there's none like the Irish for a good laugh, & I second Matthias
Regan's nomination of Beckett as the funniest author available. His people
are crippled or dying, in incredibly straitened circumstance, echoes
(pre-echoes, uncannily, sometimes) of the displaced persons wandering
europe for years during/after ww 2, & it is always side-splittingly funny.
There's a perpetual undercutting-- witness _Malone Dies__ . And yet never a
feeling that such persons/conditions are being laughed at in a patronizing
way.

Peter Quartermain's paper delivered at the Blaser Conference, on how
laughter returns us to our bodies, has been with me ever since I heard it,
as explanation (& a justification) of & for humor's place in "serious"
literature. I _think_ it's called "Out of the Frying Pan". I dont know if
its been published anywhere yet.

Well thats enough of that. David

Rachel Loden wrote of several great comic moments, including:

> Mike Myers as Dieter, host of "Sprockets";
>Rachel L.

Perhaps the greatest skit in the history of poetry took place on this SNL
setpiece: Dieter introduced "the Great American Poet of the Abyss, Jimmy
Stewart." Dana Carvey came out and read some of those "my loyal dog" poems
that the now-defunct Stewart read on the tonight show (sorry, I can't quote
them from memory, and my copy is not at hand), and then explained to the
rapt Dieter that "I wrote that poem while hitchhiking through South America
with a 14 year old Mexican whore. One morning I woke up in a pool of my own
sick and found out she robbed me. . ."  Suggestions of a darker side to
Jimmy Stewart's poetic persona.

DZ

Jordan writes:

> But I think
>really very funny comedy ...is as strong a solvent of one's grimy limits
>as any poetry -- which is not to propose that poetry isn't allowed to be
>funny;

        I think we mostly agree: as I hope the anecdote about "Endgame" suggests,
I am not trying to make any kind of hi-brow/lo-brow distinction or to
suggest that poetry or any other art form should be hilarious as hell when
desired/required.
        But at the same time I'm not sure the metaphor of poetry as solvent works
for me, except possibly in as much as a solvent allows substances (colors
of paint maybe) to mix--and I suppose that mixture IS a vital aspect of
many jokes. Still I guess I don't think of poetry as providing relief in
specifically that way.

>on the contrary, it seems something like a tenet of the poetry in
>this list's collective consciousness that _laughter indicates perception_.
>Of course once you recognize _that_, it's even more of a battle to keep
>from being _jokey_, which is as far from funny as you can get, though the
>two are in practice usually undistinguished.

        How are you distinguishing them?
        Intention?
        Need? Circumstance?


>But I think a disdain for "mainstream" humor may safely be assumed here?

        On my part, O absolutely. Mainstream at least as it describes Letterman
and George Carlin and "2nd City" and "The Captial Steps". Of course jokes
are mainstream in a different sense--they strike me as one of the few
pervasive & widespread (popular) original bits of "folk culture" left. For
example, I have almost never actually heard people not termed "specialists"
invent songs in response to current events, but I have first-hand heard
jokes materialize "on the street" in response to the same.

        Matthias

Date:         Wed, 16 Jul 1997 22:32:15 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Marott@AOL.COM
Subject:      Where are we in all this?

Friends,

I want to add my two or three cents to Mr. Prejsnar's very interesting post
of the other day about the position of younger poets in respect to the
mainstream and the experimental.  In his post Mr. Prejsnar closes with:

I have sympathy with your feeling that there is much more, beyond what's been
done, for younger poets to reach toward.  But: 1. to just abstractly shrug
off what was done in the 70s and 80s could risk being just fashion-mangering;
2. if there's any truth or utility to a given group of theoretical insights
ya gotta go *thru* them to get to your next step, and neither go around 'em,
nor retreat back from them...

Please forgive me if some of this territory has already been tread upon.
 I've been out of the loop for a few months and only just recently began to
read these posts again.  At any rate, thinking about Mr. Prejsnar's post, I
was re-reading Richard Silberg's article in the June/July 1997 issue of
Poetry Flash in which he suggests that "the center itself is starting to
break up, to shift and slide."  Then he examines some recent work by three
poets-Brenda Hillman, Jane Miller, and Jorie Graham-whom he considers to more
or less represent "the American mainline," using these three as examples of
this supposed shift from center.  Then he ends his essay with this:

As I'm sure you've noticed, all three of these poets are women.  I wanted to
pull in some experimental, mainline-based men to balance this review out, but
I couldn't come up with any.  I was talking it over with Joyce Jenkins,
editor and publisher of these pages [Poetry Flash], and she felt that it's
women today who are doing the feelingful poetic experimenting, that male
experimental poets, whether mainline-based, Language-based, or postmodernists
somewhere 'in between', tend more to be what we could call head poets or
maybe poets of power.  I'm resisting that idea, for obvious reasons, but I'm
having trouble refuting it.  What do you think?

Well, I think that I am a 33 year old male writer who is, I guess, "somewhere
'in between'."  (I'm not really sure though.)  One time, about three or four
years ago, after a reading here in Berkeley I was at a bar with Lyn Hejinian
and some other folks of my generation and I asked to no one in particular,
"Am I a 'language' poet?"  Then, interestingly, Lyn shot back, "Am I?"

At any rate, these many years later, I can decidedly say that I am not a
"laguage" writer.  That would be an impossibility.  I'm too young.  But, I do
come at poetry from the margins, and for as long as I've been writing
experimentally, practically all of my writing career-after doing a stint in
graduate school at UCSD and becoming a member of what Ron Silliman calls "the
San Diego Mafia"-I've been concerned with the issue of audience.  That is,
though I think of myself as an experimental writer, one who cut his writing
teeth on the likes of Barrett Watten, Ron Silliman, and Charles Bernstein, I
want to write poems that, say, my gramma can read and not simply respond to
them by saying either, "That's nice, honey" or worse, "I can't read this.  It
doesn't make sense."

Of late I've been increasingly concerned with this problem of audience,
especially in one particular way that it manifests itself:  the inability of
the mainstream to converse with the experimental.  I've even embarked on a
project of writing a series of volumes of occasional poems, poems written for
particular individuals (mostly non-poets who, I'd guess, would politically
represent the mainstream) on particular occasions (weddings, birthdays,
deaths etc.).  I hope not only that the people for whom I've written these
poems can read them with pleasure, I also hope that poets and editors and
teachers from the center would also be able to.  Some few of you on this list
have, I know, seen or heard some of these poems.  While I think of these
poems as experimental in that they, for the most part, fragment narrative,
eschew representation, mess with conventional syntax, they're written for
real people out there, so there's something in them that makes them, I think,
really mainstream and therefore, I hope, infinitely readable. That is, I hope
the poems, at once, embrace difficulty while also seducing the lazy reader.
Since I'm pretty darn shy and hardly ever post, and since most of you have
never heard of me, never seen my work (I've got an O Book and a chapbook from
Pasquale Verdicchio's The Parenthesis Writing Series), I'll post for you here
one of these occasional poems to which I'm referring, so you can see what I
mean.  (Forgive me for tooting my own horn here.)  Okay, here goes:

   Still and All

-for Marta, a valentine

Outside, the streaked kitchen window
beyond our wrought iron
grill work, detachable

in case of earthquake, fire
events, cataclysmic
by law required avenues of escape;

branchlets of willow confused and menacing
in winter seeming dead, crumpled
impossible even to imagine, ever

quickening; now
again, doused by early spring rain
against the torn and soggy pages

of some Sunday morning read-out
of the sky's hard fact littered with slate and steel

banks of cloud and breaths, drawn

anew, small
and tender

trembled, buds in gusts
pinking;

and I think of such mornings when empty pavement meant
a parking lot, the aroma of coffee and sweet jam
permeated the margins, emerging

from night's draped coma, the cold sheets
rose around your soft figure, if it please

you may, shouldering
the idea recorded of a late winter dawn-

that voice, mouth
and kisses

when you used to call me, baby.


As this poem demonstrates (I hope...), if I were to place myself and my work
on a poetics numberline, with -10 being stridently conventional and +10 being
wildly experimental, I think I'd say that my poetics are up at 10 but my
work, increasingly, hovers at around 5 or so (this poem, for example, is
quite lyrical, indulges in a romantic appostrophe, utilizes various phonic
techniques, treats the line in a fairly conventional manner and on and on).
But it's still experimental or avant garde or whatever, influenced by "L"
writing, right?

Now, I wonder, where would you all place yourselves on my -10 to +10
continuum? (I'm serious. I want to know.)  Is a discrepancy between one's
poetics and one's actual poems an unforgivable problem, a selling out of the
politics of the great "L" project?  Am I doing a Clinton and, evil critter
that I am, trying with my work to centralize the radical left?  Is there
something wrong if you, like me, find yourself interested in writing poems
that gramma can read and enjoy?  And what if you're a man and find yourself
interested in what Richard Silberg describes as "a feelingful poetic
experimenting"?  Does that mean that you're, as Mr. Prejsnar describes, going
"around" the theoretical insights of the 'language' writers  rather than
going "thru" them?  Or worse, "retreat[ing] back from them"?  What role does
gender play in all this anyway?  I look forward to your responses.

Thanks for your time,

Scott Bentley

From Maria & Steven:
">> > >What comedians do people find inspiring?

You should, if they ever run them anymore, check out the few episodes of a
program called "The State" which ran alternately on Comedy Central and MTV
over the last couple years - some of it is brilliant sketch comedy, the
first to truly move beyond both Monty Python & SNL in its conceptions - my
personal favorite: an idiotic piece called "Froggy Jamboree," where to
members come on screen and tell the story about how the rest of the
ensemble wouldn't let them air their sketch idea during the show but were
gracious enough to let them play it over the credits, at which point the
scene cuts to the two of them in full body frog suits splashing
spasmodically in a kiddy pool while playing banjos: that's it.

Subject:      Re: stein and gold
In-Reply-To:  <199707170403.VAA95984@f1n2.u.arizona.edu>

some related points to the gold piece:

gold strikes a similar pose to the one struck by various artists and
writers who published their rebuttals to stein's portrayal of them in the
*Autobiography*.  in a special supplement to *transition*, a little
magazine which often published stein's work in the 1920s, stein and her
*Autobiography of Alice B. Toklas* were the subject of derision,
chastisement, correction, and ridicule.  in one rant, the author (i can't
remember who) accused her of never really knowing what the
artistic/social/political ferment around her was really about it.  the
general feeling expressed was that stein had unfairly profited from her
association with them.

gold's accusations that stein is a "literary idiot" by the exploitation of
a so-called "primitive" or childlike language echoes, oddly enough, ts
eliot's review (among others) of stein's work.

what's also interesting about gold's presentation of stein is that he's
the only one i've ever encountered who claimed that stein was an
"excellent medical student" or "a brilliant psychologist."  a look at her
transcripts shows that she struggled after her first year in med school,
and the record of her career as a "psychologist" is, i believe, best shown
in the literary works gold eschews.  michael magee is right to note the
petulance of gold's complaint that her literary work falls short of the
promise that her scientific start hinted at.

despite my general disagreement with much of gold's article, i do think
he's on to something in terms of noting what is often missing in much
stein criticism.  to focus exclusively on the linguistic play of stein's
writing is, i think, to make of her work a bourgeois parlor game.  (jeremy
green has written of needing to recover the dialectic of her writing.)

jill mccartney

From:         "Bennett M. Sm [Dimpson" <bms5q@FARADAY.CLAS.VIRGINIA.EDU>
Subject:      Dennis Cooper
In-Reply-To:  <Pine.A32.3.93.970715114603.576918B-100000@faraday.clas.Virginia.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Dear Dodie Belamy + Kevin Killian, et al.

Okay, Dennis Cooper does deserve more than I gave him in another post. I
agree with Dodie that his ability to cull influence from the "everyday" is
pretty great. Rock bands, specific porn titles, carpet burns --all are
used fluidly, an abject object world parallel to metaphysics (not allegory
though, in that objecta and idea both merit equal over-exposure). I think
my reluctance to Cooper comes from the aura of "transgressiveness" foisted
on him by publishing/media machines. Need to get through the hype. On
their own (is there such a thing as "on their own" with material like
this?), passages like the following *are* fairly powerful if the reader is
willing to dance around a mess of cultural baggage and false difficulties:

"In Chris' fantasy, he's a ten year-old lost in some forest. He sees a
cabin with sweetly lit windows, and knocks. A monster of some sort invites
him inside. As soon as the door shuts, the monster tears Chris's clothes
off, ties him down on a bed, and tortures him for hours and hours. Then
they fuck, and as the monster comes, he brings out a machete and hacks
Chris's head off. That's making a long story short." (_Guide_ 41-42)

Or maybe passages like this are powerful exactly becasue of messy cultural
baggage and false difficulties. Cooper is a great acrobat, regardless of
how his writing makes the reader feel ("nauseated," put-out,
de-sexualized, over-mediated). I don't want to think aobut Cooper's
"intent" or if "shock" is purposed specifically by him. That's a rut to
get in.

un-seem-ly,

Bennett

bms5q@virginia.edu   &c.
                     &c.
&c.&c.&c.&c.&c.&c.&c.&c.

my eye. How does a piece really catch your eye, you ask, without a bloody
result?  Observe the following: I admire much of Stein's writing. On the
other hand, much of it I find innovatively dull. This is my opinion for
which I carry an entitlement in my breast pocket.

artist who is not towing the line for the Revolution. At first, anyway. I
wonder what people make of his comment on "idle art."

Subject:      New LVNG Supplemental
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

LVNG's third supplemental (to the magazine, which is free)
is a lovely and affordable gem by one Marton Koppany, a Hungarian concrete
poet. The title:

        "It is the Same"

Mr. Koppany has created a serial poem, which we here laboring
in the belly of the LVNG industrial machine have produced in a
pristine edition of postcards. The result produced many rounds
of hearty back-clapping: is in not glorious the manner in which
black ink appears on white stock?

Mr Koppany's "It is the Same" will not fail to produce a smile
no matter how often it is flipped and read.  I find myself
thumbing thru it with the rapidity of a jaded 10 year-old snapping
thru a pack of baseball cards looking for all-stars.  Such
rapidity with Mr Koppany's text may be said to evoke east-european
animation of the soviet era. But that is a matter for the exegisists.

Marton Koppany
"It is the Same"
serial concrete poem on postcards, edition of 250
US $5

We are
LVNG PO Box 3865
Chicago IL 60654-0865

Blocks to be Arranged ina Pyramid"

$10

"a run thru the dictionary"

Here's from the introductory page:


Welcome to the second stage of the *CybpherAnthology of Discontiguous
Literature*. This project is spurred by the recognition that a number
of online experimental lit zines seem to draw from an overlapping
community of contributors, and praps aesthetics: Jake Berry's *The
Experioddicist*; *Juxta Online* edited by Ken Harris & Jim Leftwich;
and Tom Taylor's *Anabasis* for a start. During the first stage, we
collected and indexed these publications. So far, the following
indexes have been completed:

     * Juxta Electronic, issues #1 thru #21;
     * Experioddi(cyber)cist, issues #1 thru 16,
       plus a number of online chapbooks;
     * Anabasis/Vision Project;
     * an Authors Index; all works in the above zines, alphabetically by
author.
          ^^^^^^^^^^^^^

These indexes (and the archives that they link to) are now online,
enabling quick access to individual works searchable by author or
publication. Additional indices are under construction (for instance,
to all the single-author chapbooks, and to the collaborations);
suggestions for additional indexing are welcome.

You're Invited to contribute to the second stage of this project. The goal
is to generate a body of critical work, based on this corpus of texts
(and related), using the linkages made available in this format for
hypercitations. That work, in the form or essays, close readings, commentary
and critique, will be presented as an online issue of TapRoot Reviews,
tentatively scheduled for the end of 1997. The overall aim is to put this
body of work into a context of community and discussion, and ultimately to
help readers find a way in to that community of writers/texts.

Creative Uses of the media and message are encouraged. I'd particularly
encourage folks to push the bounds of traditional critical "norms", as befits
the non-traditional nature of many of these texts. Additionally, significant
print-only zines such as Ficus Strangulensis' *Transmog* and John M.
Bennett's *Lost and Found Times* seem relevant; energies that would enable
us to engage those (and others) online would be helpful. Any feedback at
this stage is most appreciated. Email me:

     au462@cleveland.freenet.edu.

luigi-bob drake, ed.
TRR/Burning Press/etc...

Date:         Thu, 17 Jul 1997 13:58:52 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Mark Wallace <mdw@GWIS2.CIRC.GWU.EDU>
Subject:      What comes next?
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

        I want to take up Jacques Debrot's important question, from about
a week ago now, about the question of "what comes next" after language
poetry.

        The first thing to say, I think, is that language poetry is in no
sense "over." While the initial impact of much of the work associated with
this term now certainly has a history, many language poets are continuing
to write wonderful poetry and criticism, with greater or lesser relation
to what might be seen as the originary impulses of their context. So in
speaking of "what comes next," I don't think one is talking about what
will REPLACE language poetry. This is especially true as one of the things
I love about poetry generally is that it cannot be "replaced"--history
continues to roll, yes, and Emily Dickinson's world is not so simply our
own, yet in what significant sense is her work "replaceable"?

        So the question, if not what will replace language poetry, seems
to me more what contexts, approaches, and concerns will be the crucial
ones for a generation of poets influenced (to various degrees, and with
various levels of antagonism) but not delimited by the concerns of
language poetry?

        I think, in response to Jacques' question, that a great deal of
work has already been done on this subject, both in terms of poetry and
poetics. I can't provide a complete list of writers here, but they include
poets, poet-critics, and critical writers like Lee Ann Brown, Juliana
Spahr, Harryette Mullen, Rod Smith, Jefferson Hansen, Tan Lin, Rodrigo
Toscano, Charles Borkhuis and many many more.

        Nor can I, here, summarize a very complex area of activity.
Certainly one of the main things that I see among these writers, is that,
perhaps to a greater degree than language poetry (if only, at the very
least, because there are so many more of these younger writers), there is
no simple consensus about what concerns are important--the area involves
as much lack of agreement as it does a shared sense of what matters. Even
the two people that Jacques mentions, Mark Ducharme and myself, have
different significances in focus, although we share a great deal. If I
understand properly an article by
Mark forthcoming in the next (I think) issue of TALISMAN, he wants to
characterize these writers as being marked by a kind of DIVERSITY of
poetic approaches, and Mark urges an openness to diversity. While his
description has some truth, my own concerns in essays like "Towards A Free
Multiplicity of Form" have perhaps been more polemical. I'm not in favor
so much in some generalized diversity of forms ("any way you do it, that's
okay with me!") as I have been calling for a CONSCIOUS exploration of
multiple formal approaches, even in the case of a single writer. Not
"acceptance of diversity" so much as "consciousness of the implications of
choices of form" and an attempt to NOT settle for singular traditions or
approaches. "Diversity" in poetry seems to me fine ONLY as long it
contains awareness about the implications of form, and conscious attempts
to find those forms which might reveal untapped potentials in given areas.
A more generalized "diversity" that suggests "we're all individuals, and
we're all okay" runs to my mind the risk of avoiding the key question of
the relation between forms of poetry and forms of culture--if you're not
paying attention to how the forms you choose to use tie into the context
of the world around you, then I think that's probably NOT okay. But mine,
of course, as Mark rightly points out, is only one take of many.

        Interesting to me also, on the subject of how one's thoughts about
form tie into the world beyond, is the dynamics revealed in a question
like Jacques' important one "What comes next?," a question key to the
whole
history of modernism. Steve Evans' essay THE DYNAMICS OF LITERARY CHANGE
does
a profound job of putting the question "what comes next?" into context.
For haunting that question is the question of the NEW, and Jacques might
easily have said "What's NEW?" What Evans has done, I think (as have some
others like Jefferson Hansen), among much else, is to problematize the
very notion of looking for the NEW. This is not the same as accepting
"tradition" unproblematically. Rather, I think this particular generation
of poets find themselves at a moment when one must be as ironic about the
NEW as one must about the "tradition," without giving up on the
possibility of innovation, integrity, and concern with what has been left
unexplored.

        The irony of the NEW I think may best be expressed by a closing
quotation here. Thankfully, this quotation does NOT sum up the value of
the new in the work of those poets who have begun appearing in the 90s.
But it does express how EASILY that value might be missed, and why irony
is necessary these days whenever you or I ask "what's next?". I hope
you'll read this closing quote closely, because it's BRILLIANT, it really
is, especially considering what it is.

        It's from the book BEER BLAST; TWENTY YEARS OF FADS AND FOLLIES IN
THE BATTLE OF THE BREWS, written by Phillip Van Munching, whose company
handled the international distribution of Heineken until being forced out
several years ago:

        "I recently asked the public relations guy at Heineken USA why
Amstel Light's packaging had been changed so dramatically BEFORE any
decisions had been made about the direction of the brand's marketing. 'You
know how people like to look busy,' he replied. I relate that story for
two reasons... The second reason is that it gives insight into WHY new
marketers change everything; marketers feel the overwhelming need to
criticize what has come before them, so they can make a name for
themselves by spearheading some NEW direction. This is because there seems
to be less and less job longevity among marketers; the guy selling soda
pop this year might be selling beer next year and feminine hygiene
products the year after that. I suspect that the marketer of today is
afraid to go to an interview for the next job and say, 'Well, I've spent
the last few years as a caretaker for a brand image created before I
arrived on the scene.'"

        Mark Wallace

James Tate is the only poet I've ever heard read who laughed extensively
(*extensively*, I mean like over & over) at the jokes in his poems.
Surprisingly, it was kind of endearing.  My favorite joke: the end of his
poem "I Left My Couch in Tatamagouche": "I left my couch in Tatamagouche,
/ and that has made a big difference."

-m.

I'd written,

> >What poets do poets think would make excellent comedians? . . .
> possibly James Tate (in an exceedingly deadpan manner)?
> likely Rod Smith (under some circumstances) . . .

And Michael McGee remarked:

<< James Tate is the only poet I've ever heard read who laughed
extensively (*extensively*, I mean like over & over) at the jokes in his
poems.  Surprisingly, it was kind of endearing.  My favorite joke: the end
of his poem "I Left My Couch in Tatamagouche": "I left my couch in
Tatamagouche, / and that has made a big difference." >>

thanks for that -- maybe Tate-as-comic's not so deadpan after all
(laughing uproariously at his own wit) . . .

as for "and that has made a big difference," -- I hear the original line ("and
that has made all the difference") echoing in memory, but quite can't seem
to place it.  Can somebody help? (Robert Frost or something?) -- a
"wisdom" poem as 'twere . . . ??

I saw Tate read in NYC (circa 90) -- he shared the bill (Academy of Am.
Poets) with Michael Palmer.

Aboard subway after the reading, my late friend Lynne Beyer remarked
she liked Tate's humor & wasn't as wild abt. Palmer's seriousness.  (How
would Palmer do as a comedian?  Surely he could pull it off -- if he
wanted . . .)

/ / / /

Mark Twain found mention in the humor thread.  I just picked up a copy
of *Mark Twain on Writing and Publishing* (remaindered, from Book of
the Month Club, New York, imprint 1994) -- it includes an essay entitled
"Post-Mortem Poetry."  The latter is hereby reproduced (in large part) --
in interst of historical poetics or suchlike:


Mark Twain:
"Post Mortem Poetry"

IN Philadelphia they have a custom which it would be pleasant to see
adopted throughout the land.  It is that of appending to published
death-notices a little verse or two of comforting poetry.  Any one who is
in the habit of reading the daily Philadelphia *Ledger* must frequently be
touched by these plaintive tributes to extinguished worth.  In
Philadelphia, the departure of a child is a circumstance which is not more
surely followed by a burial than by the accustomed solacing poesy in the
*Public Ledger*.  In that city death loses half its terror because the
knowledge of its presence comes thus disguised in the sweet drapery of
verse.  For instance, in a late *Ledger* I find the following (I change the
surname):

                      DIED
  HAWKS.--On the 17th inst., Clara, the daughter of Ephraim and Laura
  Hawks, aged 21 months and 2 days.

    That merry shout no more I hear
        No laughing child I see,
    No little arms are round my neck,
        No feet upon my knee;

    No kisses drop upon my cheek,
        These lips are sealed to me.
    Dear Lord, how could I give Clara up
        To any but to Thee?

  A child thus mourned could not die wholly discontented.  From the
*Ledger* of the same date I make the following extract, merely changing
the surname, as before:

  BECKET.--On Sunday morning, 19th inst., John P., infant son of
  George and John Becket, aged 1 year 6 months, and 15 days.

    That merry shout no more I hear
        No laughing child I see,
    No little arms are round my neck,
        No feet upon my knee;

    No kisses drop upon my cheek,
        These lips are sealed to me.
    Dear Lord, how could I give Johnnie up
        To any but to Thee?

  The similarity of the emotions as produced in the mourners in these two
instances is remarkably evidenced by the singular similarity of thought
which they experienced, and the surprising coincidence of language used
by them to give it expression.
  In the same journal, of the same date, I find the following (surname
suppressed, as before):

  WAGNER.--On the 10th inst., Ferguson G., the son of William L. and
  Martha Theresa Wagner, aged 4 weeks and 1 day.

    That merry shout no more I hear
        No laughing child I see,
    No little arms are round my neck,
        No feet upon my knee;

    No kisses drop upon my cheek,
        These lips are sealed to me.
    Dear Lord, how could I give Ferguson up
        To any but to Thee?

  It is strange what power the reiteration of an essentially poetical
thought has upon one's feelings.  When we take up the *Ledger* and read
the poetry about little Clara, we feel an unaccountable depression of the
spirits.  When we drift further down the column and read the poetry
about little Johnnie, the depression of spirits acquires an added emphasis,
and we experience tangible suffering.  When we saunter along down the
column further still and read the poetry about little Ferguson, the word
torture but vaguely suggests the anguish that rends us.
  In the *Ledger* (same copy referred to above) I find the following (I
alter surname, as usual):

  WELCH.--on the 5th inst., Mary C. Welch, wife of William B. Welch,
  and daughter of Catherine and George W. Markland, in the 29th year of
  her age.

       A mother dear, a mother kind,
       Has gone and left us all behind:
       Cease to weep for tears are vain,
       Mother dear is out of pain.

       Farewell, husband, children dear,
       Serve thy God with filial fear,
       And meet me in the land above,
       Where all is peace, and joy, and love.

  What could be sweeter than that?  No collection of salient facts
(without reduction to tabular form) could be more succinctly stated than
is done in the first stanza by the surviving relatives, and no more concise
and comprehensive program of farewells, post-mortuary general orders,
etc., could be framed in any form than is done in verse by deceased in the
last stanza.  These things inestimably make us wiser and tenderer, and
better.  Another extract:

  BALL.--On the morning of the 15th inst., Mary E., daughter of John
  and Sarah F. Ball.

    'Tis sweet to rest in lively hope
        That when my change shall come
    Angels will hover round my bed,
        To waft my spirit home.

  The following is apparently the customary form for heads of families:

  BURNS.--On the 20th inst., Michael Burns, aged 40 years.

    Dearest father, thou has left us,
        Here thy loss we deeply feel;
    But 'tis God that has bereft us,
        He can all our sorrows heal.

  Funeral at 2 o'clock sharp.

  There is something very simple and pleasant about the following,
which, in Philadelphia, seems to be the usual form for consumptives of
long standing.  (It deplores four distint cases in the single copy of the
*Ledger* which lies on the Memoranda editorial table):

  BROMLEY.--On the 29th inst., of consumption, Phillip Bromley, in
  the 50th year of his age.

    Affliction sore long time he bore,
        Physicians were in vain --
    Till God at last did hear him mourn,
        And eased him of his pain.

    The friend whom death from us has torn,
        We did not think so soon to part;
    An anxious care now sinks the thorn
        Still deeper in our bleeding heart.

  This beautiful creation loses nothing by repetition.  On the contrary, the
oftener one sees it in the *Ledger*, the more grand and awe-inspiring it
seems.  With one more extract I will close:

  DOBLE.--On the 4th inst., Samuel Peveril Worthington Doble, aged
 4 days.

    Our little Sammy's gone,
        His tiny spirit's fled;
    Out little boy we loved so dear
        Lies sleeping with the dead.

    A tear within a father's eye,
        A mother's aching heart,
    Can only tell the agony
        How hard it is to part.

 Could anything be more plaintive than that, without requiring further
concessions of grammar?  Could anything be likely to do more toward
reconciling the deceased to circumstances, and making him willing to go?
Perhaps not.  The power of song can hardly be estimated.  There is an
element about some poetry which is able to make even physical suffering
and death cheerful things to contemplate and consummations to be
desired.  The element is present in the mortuary poetry of Philadelphia
[in a high] degree of development.
  The custom I have been treating of is one that should be adopted in all
the cities of this land.

/ / / / /

[the above is abt. 2/3 of Twain's rap, which is dated 1870.]
Thanks, Rod Smith, for selling me the book.

d.i.

From:         Ward Tietz <100723.3166@COMPUSERVE.COM>
Subject:      Re: What comes next?

On Thursday, July 17, Mark Wallace wrote,

"...my own concerns in essays like "Towards A Free Multiplicity of Form" have
perhaps been more polemical. I'm not in favor so much in some generalized
diversity of forms ("any way you do it, that's okay with me!") as I have been
calling for a CONSCIOUS exploration of multiple formal approaches, even in the
case of a single writer.  Not "acceptance of diversity" so much as
"consciousness of the implications of choices of form" and an attempt to NOT
settle for singular traditions or approaches. "Diversity" in poetry seems to me
fine ONLY as long it contains awareness about the implications of form, and
conscious attempts to find those forms which might reveal untapped potentials in
given areas."


Mark,

It seems to me you're only really talking about multiplicities of "discursive"
form here.  Literary forms that are more presentational in character, hypertexts
and other electronic forms, performance and sound poetry, visual poetry, etc.
don't offer themselves up to consciousness in the ways you describe.  If a "Free
Multiplicity of Form" is the goal these forms would probably have to be
considered too, unless of course some categorical reason were used to exclude
them.


Ward Tietz

Just a couple of early-morning squibs attached to Mark Wallace's post.

re: the new - wasn't it Pound who wrote, Poetry is news that stays new?
In this sense, as Mark said, E. Dickinson is "the new" or irreplaceable.
This relates to something one of those german guys (Schelling? Adorno?)
said:  the modern is a relational term which has to do with what
infiltrates our present concerns.  I.e. the ancients still have
"modern" impact in many ways - as well as remaining the antithetical
"ancient".

Nothing will replace language poetry or exactly "come after" it.  But
the whole event of langpo has created sort of a model for counter-counter-
poetics.  & some of those counter-counters might counter language
poetry on the level of a "poetics".  This shouldn't detract from the value
of any of it...(at least "in theory"...)

I don't like the "generational" approach that MW has repeatedly used, mainly
cause I'm an old guy starting a young.po movement - if you want to join,
see Jack Spandrift's website at www.deadend.wyo.edu (not really).

If you look at US poetry as a kind of closed, solipsistic system, langpo
came along and disrupted the "echo effect" (the narcissus effect) of
the stylized "discourse" of mainstream semi-academicized poetry.  But it
did so by means of a different closed system - see Ron Silliman's startling
equation of New Criticism & langpo in the Perelman conference thing
(Impercipient) - equated except on the level of politics.  Now seems to
me the new crits & langpo together - along with people like Zukofsky - did
invaluable service to poetry by concentrating on the MICROSTRUCTURE - the
architecture on a micro level of syllable & word.  But in a way, everything
turns on mathematics - on the one & the many - on solipsism & reference -
on the relation of word & thing. To me the langpos haven't gone FAR ENOUGH
in the direction of the microstructure, and an interesting development
in the future will be toward Saussure's ideas about anagrams & paranomasia.
Hart Crane was into this: "anagrammatize your Name", etc.  Saussure
found a pervasive subtext underneath a lot of classic latin poetry -
the whole poem would be the scattered (Osiris) fragments of a thematic
single WORD.  Thematic - & referential.  Build on it.   The poem as
architecture.  Mandelstam again.  & Yeats, too.  heck yeah.  - Henry Gould

p.s. another interesting thing about Saussure was that the anagrams were
sets of phonemes.  He wasn't interested in shuffling around written letters.
a phoneme-syllable was always a double-letter unity usually linked to a
THIRD letter.  Individual letters were irrelevant.  It was the sound effect
of the syllables he was listening to.  See Starobinski's little book
WORDS UPON WORDS about what Saussure was doing.
