this is a helpful note; thanks. after much consideration, i think, in fact,
that stein *was* politically naive, tho to my mind that doesn't mitigate
her significance; in fact, i think that her sidestepping some of the
crucial politics of her time enabled her to have certain insights about
language and experience that may end up being more radical than the
politically progressive thinkers of her time. in a way it makes her very
interesting. i remember being similarly touched on reading that james brown
supported nixon; when someone said, later, "that wasn't very smart,", he
retorted, "I didn't do it to be smart."

At 5:24 AM -0700 7/17/97, Jill A Mccartney wrote:
>some related points to the gold piece:
>
>gold strikes a similar pose to the one struck by various artists and
>writers who published their rebuttals to stein's portrayal of them in the
>*Autobiography*.  in a special supplement to *transition*, a little
>magazine which often published stein's work in the 1920s, stein and her
>*Autobiography of Alice B. Toklas* were the subject of derision,
>chastisement, correction, and ridicule.  in one rant, the author (i can't
>remember who) accused her of never really knowing what the
>artistic/social/political ferment around her was really about it.  the
>general feeling expressed was that stein had unfairly profited from her
>association with them.
>
>gold's accusations that stein is a "literary idiot" by the exploitation of
>a so-called "primitive" or childlike language echoes, oddly enough, ts
>eliot's review (among others) of stein's work.
>
>what's also interesting about gold's presentation of stein is that he's
>the only one i've ever encountered who claimed that stein was an
>"excellent medical student" or "a brilliant psychologist."  a look at her
>transcripts shows that she struggled after her first year in med school,
>and the record of her career as a "psychologist" is, i believe, best shown
>in the literary works gold eschews.  michael magee is right to note the
>petulance of gold's complaint that her literary work falls short of the
>promise that her scientific start hinted at.
>
>despite my general disagreement with much of gold's article, i do think
>he's on to something in terms of noting what is often missing in much
>stein criticism.  to focus exclusively on the linguistic play of stein's
>writing is, i think, to make of her work a bourgeois parlor game.  (jeremy
>green has written of needing to recover the dialectic of her writing.)
>
>jill mccartney

from David: "as for "and that has made a big difference," -- I hear the
original line ("and
that has made all the difference") echoing in memory, but quite can't seem
to place it.  Can somebody help? (Robert Frost or something?) -- a
"wisdom" poem as 'twere . . . ??"

It's playing off of Frost's "A Road Not Taken."
"I took the road less traveled by / And that has made all the difference."
I actually like Frost quite a bit but this is one of his worst, a
too-simple homage to going your own way, made worse by the fact that its
become greeting card fodder.  I'm sure it's been lampooned before but
something about the way Tate does it - I mean, the word "big," just
hilarious.  -m.

Date:         Fri, 18 Jul 1997 09:57:27 -0500
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         GrahamD <GrahamD@MAC.RIPON.EDU>
Subject:      Re: Frost

I'm surprised to hear Frost's "Road Not Taken" described as "a too-simple
homage to going your own way."  In my reading everything in the poem, from
the title's negative to the deliberate ambiguity of "all the difference"
(good?  bad?  bit of both?) works against seeing in it any such simple
homage.  Also check out the verb tenses:  speaker's ringing declaration of
nonconformity, if that's what it is, is projected into the future.  In the
present tense of the poem, he admits that both roads look about the same.

The biography tells us that Frost wrote the poem as a satiric jab at his
friend Edward Thomas, who could never make a decision.

This poem is persistently misread, I believe, through the lens of Frost's
folksy public persona. Frost wrote many truly bad poems, I'd say, but this
isn't one of them.

David Graham
grahamd@mac.ripon.edu

Date:         Fri, 18 Jul 1997 11:03:20 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Eliza McGrand- CVA Guest <elliza@AI.MIT.EDU>
Subject:      twain -- first deconstructionist?

does anyone remember twain's peice on james fennimore cooper?  twain takes
apart, bit by bit, the feats of derring do and forest cunning in the natty
bumpo/leatherstocking series, as well as anything cooper writes having to
do with rivers.  bit by bit, the innaccuracies pile up, the hyperbole, the
exagerations, till i was laughing out loud.

but after that, i was never able to read j.f. cooper with the attention and
suspension of disbelief necessary (for me anyway) to really disappear into
the book...

now, twain on the old masters ... fortunately, i had been looking at old
paintings before i read twain, not that i didn't enjoy it every bit as much.
and twain on the infamous "chamois" of switzerland (which he translates
as "flea," leading to all kinds of speculation on the nature of chamois
gloves, bags, etc.) as well as the wild "chamois" exchange at the opera!!!
now THAT is a sendup of high culture!

the delightful obituary poem send up excerpted (thanks david i!) ws so
typical of twain -- in its vein does anyone remember his series of stories
(which seem slightly autiobiographical) on the young married couple -- whose
baby is sick, and who weather a thunderstorm?

i was given a complete set of twain when i was nine or so, after i'd been
borrowing the books from the neighbors for months (they were moving).  my
mother got rid of all of my books (w/o forewarning or permission) and i still
have dreams of that wall of mark twain books waiting to be cracked.  speaking
of sci fi, philip jose farmer, in his riverworld series, reset twain into
a future "experimental" world where all of humanity has been resurrected.
i'm not sure i'm crazy about the series, but it was an interesting
interpretation of twain.

how do you all feel about writers who take on the task of "extending" the
series of another writer?  has anyone read the sequel to "gone with the
wind"?  and there is, of course, jean rhys' _Wide Sargasso Sea_ meant to
extend bronte's _Jane Eyre_.  there have been a couple of others on jane
eyre, and on bronte books...

i've generally found sequels unreadable, with the exception of sargasso,
which is problematic in its own way (rhys is an extraordinary writer, but
i can only take so much of her bleakness and painful vision before i am
about ready to lie down under a truck).  one feels, painfully, the differences
in skill between the original and the copy.  i think, as technical point,
that perhaps when one subdues one's own internal writing rhythms and clocks
for that long to another person's the muting flattens the prose and breaks
it down.  parodies work (as we know from our resident parodists, but then,
bromige is everyone, bromige is all-scrivent, so he doesn't really count)
perhaps as a sort of pentimento?  one sees the original, and the parody
at the same time?  but more extended serious endeavors, where one writer
tries to disappear into another, don't seem to come off usually.  maybe
sargasso works because rhys writes AS rhys, with her own rhythms and viewpoints.

the first continuation of nancy drew worked i thought, but the later
carolyn keene imitators began slipping into a sort of computer simulation.
i picked up one of the latest ones, adn it reminded me of barbara cartland
books, where characters are given slightly different physical characteristics,
times and scenarios are switched, but the basic dance remains the same.  they
say she has a master-plot/book on disk, and just plugs in slightly different
details...

e

At 9:56 AM -0400 7/18/97, Michael Magee wrote:
>from David: "as for "and that has made a big difference," -- I hear the
>original line ("and
>that has made all the difference") echoing in memory, but quite can't seem
>to place it.  Can somebody help? (Robert Frost or something?) -- a
>"wisdom" poem as 'twere . . . ??"
>
>It's playing off of Frost's "A Road Not Taken."
>"I took the road less traveled by / And that has made all the difference."
>I actually like Frost quite a bit but this is one of his worst, a
>too-simple homage to going your own way, made worse by the fact that its
>become greeting card fodder.  I'm sure it's been lampooned before but
>something about the way Tate does it - I mean, the word "big," just
>hilarious.  -m.

actually, this used to be one of my favorite "let's make fun of frost"
poems, until i reread it and realized that what it says is: two roads were
exactly the same, i don't know why i picked one over the other, but in the
future, when i tell the story, i'll *say* that it was because one was less
traveled by, and that has made all the difference. that makes the poem
quite a bit more interesting --it's about narrative and
self-aggrandizement, and the retroactive assignation of meaning to a random
act.

From:         GROBERTS@BINAH.CC.BRANDEIS.EDU
Subject:      morbid thoughts
MIME-version: 1.0
Content-type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII

Twain's piece on mourning poems (all-bads?) sounds like a send up of
Wordsworth's essays on epitaphs, but it could also be a response to the cult of
sentimental death washing over middle-class Americans in the nineteenth
century.
This trend produced its greatest monument in the world's first cemetery park,
Mt. Auburn Cemetery in Cambridge, Mass.  Intended as a place of comfort and
leisure, the cemetery today is shared by bird watchers and roller bladers.  It
also has a truly spectacular collection of trees, which shade sundry
Longfellows
and Lowells.  I haven't memorized any of the verse on the grave markers, but
it's closer to Twain's quotations than anything by Robert Lowell.  My
great-grandfather, Benjamin Franklin Roberts, a Tennessee farmer and Union vet,
has on the back of his grave marker a list of the battles he fought in and on
the front a different kind of cliche, which is lineated strangley:

        Remember when passing
        By you have to die and
        Lay as low as I

He now lies in the middle of the Oak Ridge atomic compound, and his grave
cannot
be visited without a special escort.

***

Last year I started reading Beckett's Watt, for me his funniest, on an
airplane,
and I had to stifle myself so as not to disturb fellow passengers. I got a kind
of morbid thrill from imagining myself, in the minds of people around me, as a
slightly demented giggler who also snorted and sighed now and then.  Laughing
to
oneself in a public place is a fun and harmless enough form of abjection.  I
followed Watt with Flann O'Brien's At Two-Swim-Birds, also pretty damn funny,
though in places a little too like the catechism chapter in Ulysses.  The first
sentece gives you a taste:

Having placed in my mouth sufficient bread for three minutes' chewing, I
withdrew my powers of sensual perception and retired into the privacy of my
mind, my eyes and face assuming a vacant and preoccupied expression.

Gary Roberts

This quote is from Robert Benchley: "There are two kinds of people in this
world:  Those who divide the world into two kinds of people and those who
don't."  He was also the author of the immortal line:  there are two kinds of
travel, first class and with children.

Sadly, Benchley's been pretty much forgotten, except for Woody Allen, who in
his written pieces poaches from him liberally.

At 11:03 AM -0400 7/18/97, Eliza McGrand- CVA Guest wrote:

>how do you all feel about writers who take on the task of "extending" the
>series of another writer?  has anyone read the sequel to "gone with the
>wind"?  and there is, of course, jean rhys' _Wide Sargasso Sea_ meant to
>extend bronte's _Jane Eyre_.  there have been a couple of others on jane
>eyre, and on bronte books...
>
>i've generally found sequels unreadable, with the exception of sargasso,
>which is problematic in its own way (rhys is an extraordinary writer, but
>i can only take so much of her bleakness and painful vision before i am
>about ready to lie down under a truck).

Eliza, I know what you mean about Rhys, one can't hate her but there is
definitely that ickiness to her.  I think you might make a clearer
distinction between sequels and retellings, Rhys' book being a retelling
and those Nancy Drew books being sequels.  In the retelling you're
basically following the original, but putting in "secret" origins,
perspectives, motives.  There's this element of cleverness that is
seductive.  Sequels are much more create-your-own-thing from these elements.

In reading your post I thought of Mary Reilly, which is so much better than
the Julia Roberts movie based on the book.  This retelling of Dr. Jekyl and
Mr. Hyde went way beyond the schlock that I was expecting--particularly in
the author's dealings with issues of class, which is an important subtext
to the original.

Even though my own book is, in a broad sense, a sequel to Dracula, I'm not
so hot on them as a form.  Sequels to me are like clones in Sci-Fi movies,
there's always something just not right about them.

Dodie

I have had similar responses to John Yau. I couldn't even mouth the words
to some of the poems in _Forbidden Entries_ they were so funny,
unexpected, exacting, incisive. Yau's humor is sometimes like Tate's,
completely deadpan, even slapstick, but the explicit political elements in
Yau's poems supercharge things beyond cleverness or irony. Is something
any less funny for its criticality? Or any less critical for its jokes?

Bennett

From:         Christopher Alexander <calexand@ALEX.LIB.UTAH.EDU>
Organization: U of U Marriott Library
Subject:      Re: twain -- first deconstructionist?
In-Reply-To:  <199707181503.LAA19657@waffle.ai.mit.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-transfer-encoding: Quoted-printable

Eliza M CVA-guest (!??) wroth:
> how do you all feel about writers who take on the task of "extending" th=
e
> series of another writer?  has anyone read the sequel to "gone with the
> wind"?  and there is, of course, jean rhys' _Wide Sargasso Sea_ meant to
> extend bronte's _Jane Eyre_.  there have been a couple of others on jane
> eyre, and on bronte books...

well, of course these things are often mass-market fiction, &
so much the worse. "one feels, painfully, the differences
in skill between the original & the copy"=97something like movie
sequels shot by successively less talented directors, that degrade
as one moves down the line. ["& how"]. reliance on "special effects":
"one subdues one's own internal writing rhythms...to another
person's". I think the problem can be just that=97trying to extend the
work seamlessly, an impossible labor (& to what end?). other
people are=97well, we won't go there again so soon. whereas I find a
more liberal ["forgive me"] interpretation of "extend", something
more on the order of "treat" ["mmmmm"] or "treatment of" the extant
work a considerably more interesting proposition. (wondering
about the announced relation of Kevin Killian's Santa to the=97
oh, forgive me, dammit, I've just forgotten his name=97to a story
called "Satan", by another writer). highly visible, unwitting,
unwilling (?) collaboration (not necessarily an appropriation)=97on the
order, really, of the commonest use of language=97with the exception
that, in this case, the rhizomatic aspect is deliberate=97not so much
planned, as willful. de-liberated: not "subdues one's own" so much as
the stricture (structure) imposed by the extant work. or "liberated":
working at the seams, re-situation, re-evaluation=97on the order of
production, & not reverence. (of course, I've left out liber-ated:
text arrested in the moment as book, which, yes, can be at least as
much production as commodity. cf. Blake, Drucker, others).
sometimes we forget, whatever theoretical lip-service we might pay
to intertextuality, that there are no sacred ["discreet"] texts (or
is it that all texts are sacred? nah...). all insertion ["immersion"]
in the text is necessarily a re-writing from a new subject-position.
(of course to say this here is an instance of what, in my loosely
protestant up-bringing, was termed "preaching to the choir").
"influence" =3D confluence. it's physical. love it.

Chris=97ah, but will parody work as a *pimento*?
..

Date:         Fri, 18 Jul 1997 12:38:26 -0700

From:         Mark Weiss <junction@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Humorist/poets
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Nobody'd mentioned Kenneth Koch: his baseball epic "Ko: A Season on Earth,"
and small pieces like "Mending Sump," which sends up Frost and contains the
line "Something there is that does not hump a sump."

Nor a word about Ed Dorn--despite last Winter's flap, one of our best and
funniest poets (and the incredible cadences of the opening of Gunslinger I
took up permanent residence in this poet's body the first time I read it aloud).

Here's one that no one will take me up on. Dryden coauthored a revised
version of the Tempest which abjures all profundity but becomes great
slapstick sex comedy. He added a female Caliban and a male Miranda, who
somehow had never met their counterparts, and some female castaways. So,
four horny virgins and a bunch of lecherous sailors and aristocrats trapped
on an island. Hilarious in itself, plus the subversive pleasure of
snickering at a parody of Shakespeare (albeit intended respectfully!).

As long as we're in the Restoration, the poet and playwright Thomas Otway,
best known as a tragedian, wrote two great forgotten comedies, Friendship in
Fashion and The Atheist, which bills itself as a sequel to the former. F in
F: the last three acts are an endless society party. The Atheist: a lovelorn
woman dresses as a man to seduce her rival for her beau's affections. You
hadda be there. Great. And the women change the rules of the game and win.

Comments: To: Mark Wallace <mdw@GWIS2.CIRC.GWU.EDU>

Great post, Mark Wallace. And thanks to Jacques Debrot for first posting
this very intriguing question. The quote Mark uses at the end sums up the
issue very succinctly, namely, that the concern with the New is basically
the expression of an _anxiety_ about what's come before - the acute anxiety
every writer feels, in some sense, whenver he or she "sets down to write" (I
don't mean this lasy literally...). I'm still reading Steve Evans' essay, so
can't add anything gleaned from there. I would just say though that the
issue of literary change vis-a-vis LangPo seems to me not so much a question
of "replacement" but of mutation.

Aldon Nielsen recently mentioned to me in passing the "manifestos" on
post-Language Poetry by John Noto and perhaps others that have appeared
recently in Talisman. Can anyone comment on what is meant by the idea of
post-Language poetry? Judging by the name alone, it doesn't seem to be
oppositional to LangPo, but operating in more or less "friendly" relation to
it.

But this desire to classify and sum up ideas about the New is also an
expression of the anxiety we feel about change, i.e. the urge to name and
identify what appears presently to be amorphous, to pin it down somehow.

Patrick Pritchett
 ----------
From: Mark Wallace
To: POETICS
Subject: What comes next?
Date: Thursday, July 17, 1997 7:55PM

        The irony of the NEW I think may best be expressed by a closing
quotation here. Thankfully, this quotation does NOT sum up the value of
the new in the work of those poets who have begun appearing in the 90s.
But it does express how EASILY that value might be missed, and why irony
is necessary these days whenever you or I ask "what's next?". I hope
you'll read this closing quote closely, because it's BRILLIANT, it really
is, especially considering what it is.

        It's from the book BEER BLAST; TWENTY YEARS OF FADS AND FOLLIES IN
THE BATTLE OF THE BREWS, written by Phillip Van Munching, whose company
handled the international distribution of Heineken until being forced out
several years ago:

        "I recently asked the public relations guy at Heineken USA why
Amstel Light's packaging had been changed so dramatically BEFORE any
decisions had been made about the direction of the brand's marketing. 'You
know how people like to look busy,' he replied. I relate that story for
two reasons... The second reason is that it gives insight into WHY new
marketers change everything; marketers feel the overwhelming need to
criticize what has come before them, so they can make a name for
themselves by spearheading some NEW direction. This is because there seems
to be less and less job longevity among marketers; the guy selling soda
pop this year might be selling beer next year and feminine hygiene
products the year after that. I suspect that the marketer of today is
afraid to go to an interview for the next job and say, 'Well, I've spent
the last few years as a caretaker for a brand image created before I
arrived on the scene.'"

        Mark Wallace

From:         Robert Hale <hale@ETAK.COM>
Subject:      Re: What comes next?
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Calling attention to the means of production makes sense. However, terms
such as "diversity" and "multiplicity" are only useful for politicizing the
matter.

Poetries that are non-discursive (more "presentational) are often
market-driven, entertainment economies and are processed that way by the
spectator. Performance poetry is usually (and quite literally) "judged" or
measured according to its entertainment value. These poetries are rendered
economic by virtue of the fact that they are perceived to be more material
in some sense -- they are framed in some kind of context that is not
concerned with consciousness of form. They are thought to take up the space
and time of the individual as other forms of entertainment do and are
effected by fluctuating rules of consumption that are essentially
market-driven. Though there is no recognizable market for, let's say,
"hypertexts," readers/spectators who seek-out such non-discursive forms
often do so for the same reasons that they would seek out a particular product.



At 07:22 AM 7/18/97 EDT, you wrote:
>On Thursday, July 17, Mark Wallace wrote,
>
>"...my own concerns in essays like "Towards A Free Multiplicity of Form" have
>perhaps been more polemical. I'm not in favor so much in some generalized
>diversity of forms ("any way you do it, that's okay with me!") as I have been
>calling for a CONSCIOUS exploration of multiple formal approaches, even in the
>case of a single writer.  Not "acceptance of diversity" so much as
>"consciousness of the implications of choices of form" and an attempt to NOT
>settle for singular traditions or approaches. "Diversity" in poetry seems to me
>fine ONLY as long it contains awareness about the implications of form, and
>conscious attempts to find those forms which might reveal untapped
potentials in
>given areas."
>
>
>Mark,
>
>It seems to me you're only really talking about multiplicities of "discursive"
>form here.  Literary forms that are more presentational in character,
hypertexts
>and other electronic forms, performance and sound poetry, visual poetry, etc.
>don't offer themselves up to consciousness in the ways you describe.  If a
"Free
>Multiplicity of Form" is the goal these forms would probably have to be
>considered too, unless of course some categorical reason were used to exclude
>them.
>
>
>Ward Tietz
>

Wasn't anyone going to remark on what I thought was the truly exemplary
behavior of Adrienne Rich last week in refusing whatever poetry prize
it was she was awarded? I only saw a brief newspaper column about it, but
she made some highly critical remarks about Clinton's policies and said
she couldn't accept such an award given that context.

I mean, the last book of poems of hers I remember liking is at least 20
years old, maybe 25 ( *The Will to Change*, from the Olson lin), and I'm
fairly sure I wouldn't be able to appreciate her recent work, but this
is a political gesture I can applaud.

But given the anxiety expressed by many about being locked out of the
prize circuit a few months back, perhaps not many share this view.

Yes, Joe, glad you mentioned it. Though as I recall, in the article from the
NY Times - very small, prob. the one you read - Rich not only objected to
Clinton but to the general state of politics as such in the country.

It would be nice if the Poet Laureate made the same gesture - either by
using the appointment, for instance, to bring to broader attention the
disgraceful way language is used by politicians to dress up their lies
(seems like a not unreasonable way for a poet to marshall his or her
expertise) - or by simply resigning. Instead the post functions as a mere
diadem in the king's crown, flattering the official state culture's image of
itself as "standing for the good things in life" - the poet rendering
sensitive observations of nature (or Frost's charming little paean for
imperialism, "The Gift Outright") from the stage of the Kennedy Center while
white papers are drafted for the subversion of this foreign country or that
social welfare program. Strange bedfellows indeed - but who's getting
screwed?

Patrick Pritchett

Mallarme [say] = {the emotion of intellect}

Ashbery = the intellectual emotion of

Bukowski = the emotion

a jigger-ful of thought -- to finesse the brew?)

I think this is a limited view of "performance poetry." It may be true of
many slam scenes, but I don't think it's true of the performance works of
bpNichol, Jackson Mac Low, Charlie Morrow, and others. Such works and
performers are acutely conscious of form. Still, depending on how you
define product and market, all of our poetries function as part of an
economy.

charles

chax press  &  alexander writing/design/publishing
handmade books and hand crafted web sites
http://personal.riverusers.com/~chax/

----------

> Poetries that are non-discursive (more "presentational) are often
> market-driven, entertainment economies and are processed that way by the
> spectator. Performance poetry is usually (and quite literally) "judged" or
> measured according to its entertainment value. These poetries are rendered
> economic by virtue of the fact that they are perceived to be more material
> in some sense -- they are framed in some kind of context that is not
> concerned with consciousness of form. They are thought to take up the
space
> and time of the individual as other forms of entertainment do and are
> effected by fluctuating rules of consumption that are essentially
> market-driven. Though there is no recognizable market for, let's say,
> "hypertexts," readers/spectators who seek-out such non-discursive forms
> often do so for the same reasons that they would seek out a particular
> product.

I remember reading in the height anti-similism their complete dismissal via
the single sentence "Comparisons are odious".  I don=92t really like=
 dismissal
and was unhappy at the summary nature of their dispatch.  However =85

Perhaps one step towards their rehabilitation is to start very small with,
say, animal similes.  As strong as an ox doesn=92t mean much to those who
don=92t often rub shoulders with said bovines. Better stick to native=
 species.
On a recent radio quiz program the contestant was asked to complete the
sentence "as happy as" which he obliged with "as happy as a pig in shit".
Astonishingly, the presenter refused to concede the point,  failing to win
my  confidence since the only Larry I know suffers from depression.  Back to
the animals. One comparison conspicuous by its absence concerns the common
rat.  Its testicle/penis ratio is of such an extraordinary dimension that,
well if human proportions were on anything like the same scale the
wheelbarrow would have been invented much earlier in history.  Hung like a
rat.  You never hear it.

Oh on another radio quiz the contestant was asked "What rock is so light
that it can float?"  His answer, "the moon", while beating pumice any day,
fell on stony soil.

another answer:  Jefferson Airplane?

However, as for similies, another trope of comparable antiquity is
the collocation of an image with implied metaphorical correlate(s) --
without connecting the dots, just suggesting 'em.  Speaking of rock,
here's a very fine example:

   Bright are the stars that shine
   Dark is the sky
   I know this love of mine
   Will never die

A kazillion times more effective & affective than something like "my
love is as long-lasting as the bright stars . . " or any such.  Just the
image, and the mind can draw that implied subtext or not -- because
anyway there's more to it than that.

Of course, those Beatles lines mirror the same method in the Shih
Ching ("Book of Songs* -- or Odes I think Pound called 'em?) of
Chinese antiquity.

d.i.

Subject:      Re: Prizes
In-Reply-To:  <Pine.HPP.3.96.970718143433.29520B-100000@seaccd.sccd.ctc.edu>

At 2:44 PM -0700 7/18/97, Joe Safdie wrote:
>Wasn't anyone going to remark on what I thought was the truly exemplary
>behavior of Adrienne Rich last week in refusing whatever poetry prize
>it was she was awarded? I only saw a brief newspaper column about it, but
>she made some highly critical remarks about Clinton's policies and said
>she couldn't accept such an award given that context.

Hi, it's Kevin Killian.  In an interview here in San Francisco, Adrienne
Rich spoke more fully and linked her decision to decline this award (the
National Medal for the Arts, not specifically for poetry) to a number of
previous examples.  Leonard Bernstein  declined the award, refusing to go
to the White House while nothing was being done about AIDS.  Stephen
Sondheim ditto, while Wallace Stegner declined to protest "political
censorship."  Rich is an extraordinary woman with an extraordinary career,
tho Dodie (Bellamy) tells me that Gigi Bradford and Donald Hall, both of
whom apparently lobbied for years and years to get this recognition for
Rich, are both a bit hurt about her decision.  Must have been some wires
crossed somewhere, for Rich said in the interview that she was surprised by
her selection. ``Given the kind of work I do, the kind of poetry I write,
it never seemed a likelihood that I would be proposed for it."

``I have a strong belief in the inseparability of art from society as a
whole," Rich said July 10th. ``Where growing numbers of people are being
marginalized, impoverished, scapegoated and beleaguered, I don't feel I can
accept an award from the government that is pursuing these policies.''
She wrote to Clinton, ``The radical disparities of wealth and power in
America are widening at a devastating rate.  A president cannot
meaningfully honor certain token artists while the people at large are so
dishonored.''

From:         Bob Grumman <BobGrumman@NUT-N-BUT.NET>
Subject:      The Juxtaphor
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Dear David:

Because you seem to be interested in EVERYTHING, I thought you might
like to know that I have a name for that trope you mention that "is the
collocation of an image with implied metaphorical correlate(s) --
without connecting the dots, just suggesting 'em": "juxtaphor."  It's an
especially useful term for describing those visual poems where one is
supposed to understand but is not told that the visual appearance of the
text acts as a metaphor for the denotation of the text.  I wonder if the
term has a standard name (besides "implicit metaphor").  Does anyone
know?

                                                      --Bob G.

                  when i am stable i am like a table
                 with four legs down and no questions
                and when i am down like now, the maple
                outside the window rings its bastions
       o-----     with brancherly concerns, and when     -----o
                like now i think of suicide and hills
         because sadness stems from treacherous fern and fen
            then i hunt for something stronger than pills
              to kill memories and mocking-birds singing
              each to each something different like snow
            flakes covering this corpse high and winging-o
               flaking your cunt from me as if a throw
           winged it higher until the throat's loud course
              crossed the trajectory of horse and hearse
           where nothing treds across the hedge and gorse,
            no lines of song and dead you fuck me, cursed

What's going on here? Heat stroke?
Look, I use this list as a convenient meeting place to exchange ideas,
words, wit. It helps fertilize this cultural semi-desert. Provocation for
its own sake merely disrupts that process. It also doesn't say much for the
cojones of the perpetrator--I mean, what bad thing do you risk in this
venue. I suggest, instead, if you really want to provoke reactions, that you
have your post printed on a t-shirt and walk into a leather bar. Or maybe
just go up to a cop, or your boss, or your parents, and shout it.

Lawrence Upton wrote:
> performance poetry and performance poetry

well, yes -- and are you in Britain, Lawrence?  And are you familiar
with (for instance) the performance poets mentioned by Charles
Alexander (i.e., bpNichol, Jackson Mac Low, Charlie Morrow)?  Or with
David Antin?  Or others to be heard here in the States?

To speak broadbrush about a genre or medium or school of work, or
whatever, involves some risks of misunderstanding -- particularly if
one is using the term based on what's seen/heard in one part of the
globe, when the term / phenomenon may be a different kettle of fish
by some in some other city or area or (so to say) culture . . .

Date:         Sat, 19 Jul 1997 16:56:54 -0600

From:         Hugh Steinberg <hsteinberg@GRIN.NET>
Subject:      Re: What comes next?
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

I think it's grossly oversimplifying performance poetry, especially the
slam/spoken word variety, as primarily market driven and formless.  Many of
the slam poets I know are quite concerned with form, particularly as to how
form and sound interrelate.  Bland free verse or simple, obvious rhymes and
meters don't cut it in performance poetry (at the Green Mill one of the
favorite audience heckling tactics is "guess the rhyme" in which audience
members will end the poet's lines before he or she does:  it's quite
rattling).  The work that is performed in these venues can be quite
political and/or experimental.

The thing to keep in mind is that this genre pretty much evolved
independently from the performance poetry that emerged in the sixties and
seventies (such as Nichol or Mac Low).  Most have never heard of, let alone
been influenced by, these people, even though occasionally there are some
remarkable parallels going on.

I agree with Charles on all poetry being affected by and taking part in the
market economy.  As for market economies and entertainment values, I'd like
to point out that the institutions of this poetry are much better situated
to thrive in the coming grant-free world than much of the mainstream.  And
I think it's ludicrous, if not downright hypocritical, to single out this
poetry as being driven strictly by entertainment.  What poetry (discursive
or not) isn't entertaining (and do you -- be honest -- want to spend your
limited time resources on the kind that isn't)?

Slam poetics are quite explicit in the connection between poetry, pleasure
and the presence of audience:  their emergence was in reaction to the
perceived notion that poetry was a dull, dutiful thing (like truly bad
church), to be attended to by people in college.  It is populist and
popular.  It is not, however, strictly hedonistic.  One development worth
looking at is the split that occured last summer in the Chicago slam team,
where several more explicitly political writers (Daniel Ferri, Monica
Copeland, Reggie Gibbons, and a fourth who's name I can't remember to save
my life) splintered off from the Green Mill to participate in the national
slam as Team Berwyn.  I think they took third.

Hugh Steinberg

Went to another arts administration symposium--this one on the state of
poetry in the West (meaning western U.S.).  The keynote speaker was Kim
Stafford, Bill's son, so that will give you all a sense of the
tone/aesthetic.  He didn't mention any dead deers but he did recite by
heart (and with *much* feeling) a poem a woman wrote for the occasion of
scattering the ashes of her friend's dead seeing-eye dog.  This was an
example of the riches that were out there if we arts administrators would
only look.

Another speaker was the director of Poets House in New York.  She was
likeable, and like Kim Stafford, was a fan of cowboy poetry.  I'm curious
that I've never heard any of my NYC friends mention Poets House.  What's
the word on the street about it?  Backchannel if what you have to say is
too juicy for public consumption.

Dodie

Dodie, you say & ask --

> Another speaker was the director of Poets House in New York.  She
> was likeable, and like Kim Stafford, was a fan of cowboy poetry.
> I'm curious that I've never heard any of my NYC friends mention

I don't have anything juicy -- & prob. am not in touch w/ the real
word on the street -- but do have a few brief impressions, for what
worth.  A late NYC poet-friend used to mention the place favorably,
saying she'd taken some sort of workshops or seminars there -- Poet's
House, as you likely know, was established by Stanley Kunitz (using
money he'd gotten from some big poetry prize, I think) -- they have
an *amazing* library (books & periodicals) which I've not yet taken
time to really take advantage of, but the place is open regular hours
and is well worth a visit, if one is in New York, on that ground
alone; -- once a year, they have a sort of festival for new po books
& publications, and I think they display many hundreds of such -- but
I've never made that event --

one thing I did get to, though, was a little several-hour seminar
thing (in a series of such); -- the one I managed to attend (timing a
visit to NYC so as to be able to do this) was led by our list's own
Michael Heller, on topic of the poetry of Wallace Stevens.  Slightly
pricy ($25) by some standards, but I much enjoyed the combination of
Heller's lecturing (more or less) combined w/ some discussion from
the group of half-a-dozen-or-so seminarians . . .

I know the xerox-zine *Talisman* is / was regularly dropped off at
Poet's House for their library (someone there seemingly knew my
almost-unknowable name from that, seemed) -- & many, many other
little (or otherwise) periodicals are likewise assembled.  I haven't
paid a lot of attention to their reading series (I think they have
one), but the folks have always seemed non-stuffy & friendly . . .

those are my own scant impressions, for what worth . . . I'll leave
it to the real cognoscenti to give you more serious low-down ...

d.i.

From:         Dan Raphael Dlugonski <raphael@ARACNET.COM>
Subject:      performance poetries
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

theres a differnce between poetry written for performance and poetry that is
(or can be) performed.
you can write something with the intent of a live performance either along
the lines of theatre (which itself has several lines, from brechtian to
realistic transport, with several places in between), all of which imply
some intent for aesthetic experience. then there are less artistic/literary
intent, such as to win a slam or to be a successful stand-up perfomer.
there's also the realm of performance art, but im going to limit this to
performance poetry. i think a good poem can exist at several levels,
including when heard and when read on a page. and that some of the elements
and imporessions communciated ont he page or in a reading/performance are
different, and that several levels of experience may be needed to find the
full richness of a work.
sound is part of the words and part of the poem. the visual images evoked by
the words, the individual memories evoked by the words are also part of the
experience of the poem. what you see in the poems arrangment, visual puns in
spelling, other elements that can only be communicated on the page,a re also
part of the experience.
some poets write more for/from the intellect, some more for/from the
emotions, and other realms/channels that are reached to various extents.
add to this the poedts themselves, their comfort in audiences, in public.
their voices. their relatioships with their bodies.
a poet who is comofrtable performing will usually write work more conducive
to live presentation; other poets may have work that can be presented by others.
my feeling is that the sond, teh communciaton should be there; that if the
poem is too reliant on the page, on solitary cogitation, then it is not a
fully realized work.
my first exposures to poetry (other than grade and high school) were at a
coffeehouse where people read ferlinghetti, ginsberg, patchem, yevtushenko &
others. people with limited experience with contemporary poetry often find
it easier to read my poems on the page once theyve heard me perform it.

dan raphael

Re. Dodie's query.  Everyone on the list ought to be looking into and
joining Poets House (which with fund cutting everywhere badly needs
support).  Beautiful space, one of the largest poetry libraries in NYC,
resource center and many presentations, seminars and panels (by many members
on this list) on everyone and everything including--and of special interest
in terms of recently dicussed topics-- HD, Neidecker, Oppen, Zukofsky,
buddhist influence on Amer. poetry, performance and sound poetries, the
enumerations go on and on.  Their annual showcase display of newly published
books is by itself worth the price of your support.

I know Poets House tries to acquire every poetry book published in each
year since the house's inception -- tries to acquire via donation from the
publishers, that is. I visited there and will attest to its rather
comprehensive library, particularly of books published in the last few years.

If anyone goes to the building, try to visit Pace Edition's Spring Street
Workshop, also in the same building (I don't remember the floor). Great
printmaking studios, other arts assembly studios. Once I got out of the
elevator on one floor and was right in the middle of Jim Dine working on a
new show. I don't know if the Spring Street Workshop is officially open to
the public, but the people there are usually very friendly.

charles

From:         Julie Marie Schmid <jschmid@BLUE.WEEG.UIOWA.EDU>
Subject:      Re: What comes next?
In-Reply-To:  <l0310280000c79ddba051@[160.94.60.226]>
MIME-Version: 1.0

Amen, Maria and Hugh!  I get frustrated with the kind of approach to
poetry that needs to maintain this page/stage dichotomy and cannot, for
the life of me, figure out why this list keeps having this discussion over
and over again. I've been working on a dissertation on community poetics
(slam, words-n-music, etc.)  for a good while now.  What drew me to the
project was both my own experience with performing poetry and the fact
that many of the poets I heard at the Green Mill and at the Guild Complex
and other venues around Chicago were explicitly political.  However, poets
like Patricia Smith, Michael Brown, or Reggie Gibson (on of my favorites!)
also have very good ears and work that slippery intersection of sound and
meaning very deftly.  I would also like to go on record as saying that
much of this work IS incredibly powerful on the page as well.  The way
that a poet like Smith works with alliteration, assonance, internal rhyme,
as well as voice is truly remarkable, both on the page and in performance.

 As far as commericalism goes--give me a break! I know of very few
performance poets who have big contracts with major publishing houses or
recording labels.  Nor do I know of any teaching in academic workshops or
doing the University reading circuit.  I have problem with the idea that
ANY commercialism is somehow a sellout or that it cheapens ones work.
Personally, I find that as an academic in this
publish-or-perish-Routledge-book-of-the-month environment, I am much more
driven by commercialism than most slam poets and to argue otherwise would
be disingenuous.

back from europe and watching the words whiz by, lagging... good to be
sleeping in my own bed...

yeah, the performance vs. _____ poetry thread is annoying... but hey, it's
a tv culture in the u.s. of a. and it's difficult sometimes to know how to
conduct a criteek of (any aspect of) same while avoiding the old high vs.
low culture distinctions... yeah, sure, i've had a good time at slams, seen
some stuff performed that was as bad as anything gurgling through the
hallowed halls of academe... which is to say, one can be as bad as the
other...

on the academic front, i lament the sheer sobriety of technique...

on the slam front, i lament the public relations strategies i've seen
employed to secure audience rapport, if not support...

ok, so my french is killing me... the peaches in paris were as sweet as my
childhood... most of the time, i mean... hey, humor-wise, how bout anybody
remember

STEAL THIS BOOK

?... hope so!...

anyway... not so good in some ways, but as to poetix, good to be back!///

best,

joe

From:         David Bromige <dcmb@METRO.NET>
Subject:      the tale of a toilet paper roll
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

At first I thought little of it, being some one thing and no other in life
appearing the natural course of events. But as time passed & I became
imbued, godknows how, with knowledge of other ways, & I learned that my
ancestors were trees, I felt a great yearning to be a tree in a forest.
Well, this was not to be. But I couldn't help but bewail my lot, that I had
not at least been made into a tallboy, or a set of diningroom furniture, or
the headboard of a bed, where the activities open to my view should have
proven more various.

I even upbraided myself, that there had been at some point a choice open to
me, and that i had, godknows how, stayed unaware of this choice. And that
now, affixed to the wall of a lavatory, it was too late. Still, I am
nothing if not consistent, and continued to have regrets even while proving
adjustable to my present circumstance. Perhaps this says nothing more than
that I had a mind of my own, and at least the choice to speak out or to
stay quiet about the conditions society had imposed upon me at the very
moment of my creation. My cry may well be a muffled one, but if you listen
hard enough, you will hear it.

Monotony,apprehensiveness, surprise & shock, you will suppose, make up my
lot -- the waiting & then the sudden ripping off from the whole, the
violent application to an asshole, then the rejection, dropped into water
to drown in a maelstrom. But I am more than the sum of my parts. I remember
those pieces of myself now apparently lost to me; aye, and I recall every
ass I've ever cleaned. And for some, although the acquaintance was brief, I
treasure to this day, tender feelings. Not all assholes are alike. Some
through their mere appearance aroused a passion in me, a longing that I
still feel, although the moment of physical intimacy was so brief. And even
today, hanging here, I hope that the next hole I see close up, will stir
this tender passion in me.

My regrets for the "roads not taken" (to quote one of my peers) have lately
yielded to a more pressing concern, however.  I observe that I am growing
thinner every day, and fear that shortly nothing shall be left of me but
the cardboard tube that is my heart, and that this shall be quickly
despatched into the garbage, just as so much of me has already been
flushed, in what condition I leave to the reader's imagination. Therefore
through a great effort of will I am self-perforating my tissue to leave
this message behind--some trace that I lived where people moved and had
their being. Please examine me carefully sheet by sheet so that my cri de
coeur not go unremarked. Like Kilroy, I was here, & like Kilroy, I had no
real means to be other than what I am. Do not send to see for whom the bowl
flushes. It flushes for thee.    T.P.

Carl Lynden Peters wrote:

> i didn't even think there was an audience for concrete and sound
> poetry (but i'm reading those into the word _performance_). xcept
> for the poet. but that doesn't count. i'm not so sure there is such
> a thing as a public art. or maybe i don't believe in one. and maybe
> i'm over - interpreting a gain.

For what it's worth, when I was performing in Dallas with the sound
poetry group "Question Authority, the", we got a good-sized audience,
primarily of people who probably had never hear the term "sound poetry".
They just knew that the people onstage were doing something that
appeared to be fun.

                       Mira Beloved of the Lord

          Mira I will wash the feet of my Lord and Will Sit
            Mira at this Washing of the Feet and they will
     Mira make of This a Shrine of a Pool of Water and They will
          Mira Make of this a Goal of Pilgrimage and I Mira
               Mira Will be Your Slave, and I will Tend
            Mira the Lines of Men and Women, and I will Be
Mira the tears from Your Eyes, And I will Wipe your Eyes Dry of These
 Mira Yours Tears, and I will Wipe the Sweat from your Brow and Oh So
   Mira Careful I will Dust by thy Footprints on the Road and Oh So
 Mira careful They will be Hide from You Know Who which is of My Name
Mira of Mira will be for you Of That Darshan and You Will Know Him and
Mira You Will Know Her and There is a Red Thread Across the River and
Mira There is A Red Path of Red Dust by the Thread and I will be Your
 Mira Guide by This River and I will Walk along the Red Thread by the
  Mira Red Path in the Red Dust and I will Wash your Feet and I will
                         Mira Wash your Feet

On Sat, 19 Jul 1997, Mark Weiss wrote:

Provocation for its own sake

First of all, Mark, I didn't think of what I wrote as being provocative
to the people here, regardless of wether it was "for it's own sake" or
not.  I've been here a while, Ive been watching.  I don't think of the
people on the list as the kind to be "provoked" by words like whore or
faggot.  It certainly was not intended in that spirit.  Secondly, I am
truly sick to death of having my own work and the work of others
criticised in those terms.  Frankly, I think it's a stupid fruitless
criticism that comes out of a pricle of discomfort conceptualised as
irritation for the sake of ease.  Thirdly, I feel hurt that the first
public response I get to a post is this kind of attack.  The bottom line
is I AM a whore and I AM in live with a Faggot and I AM, for obvious
reasons, deeply concerned with the mechanisms in place to make me feel
like shit about both of those things.  I thought that the people on this
list would be responsive or interested in the way language operates as
such a mechanism.  So whatever, buddy.  You made me feel really shitty so
I feel like saying fuck you.  But I won't.

From:         Eliza McGrand- CVA Guest <elliza@AI.MIT.EDU>
Subject:      Re: Words which make People Garbage.

why, of course i knew there were only the two irregular verbs in japanese,
and such delicious words, too!  to conjugate any more, irregularly, in
performance, would be indelicate, don't you think simon?

ah yes, as i sit nibbling tiny crunchy ortolans, the orotund phrases
of bukowski trembling like taught fawns in my mind, i tatter myself
back to memories of my days as a courtesan.  no bibelot was i, but a
myriad, aquifer, flows of words as body as text tumbling body to body,
text to text.  irregular verbs clash like swords and the sound reverberates
in the shatterable waterford halls of my sole -- heel my sole poetry,
be as wings to the tender dove, hands to the ticking clock, fowl to
the english hunter in pursuit of the inedible.  tremble oh faint heart
as i drew myself up and said "raoul, it must end now!  you must fight,
as a man, and i... i must love, as a woman."

but unfortunately my mother purchased several bottles of vicks cough
syrup over the coming several weeks and though i meant to cultivate my
cough, delicately, the odour of camphor and cherry overcame me.  packing
my grandfather's carpet bag, i went out into the world in search of the
romance so terribly worn, fatiguee, in the tiny northern town of my
birth.  i ended up, as do we all, on the Beaconed Vistas of Broadway,
bought a leather jacket, listened to the ineluctable Patty Smith, and
now, worn, disillusioned, Fatima hanging from the corner of my mouth,
i pursue the only things that can rouse me, occasionally, from my
ennui -- "Tasha, Old Thing, do Rouse Yourself" my friends say, but
the Muse, the Muse, the languid droop of her thin coughing fingers...

And now for something completely different...

(spot the Chaplin reference in the subject line)

Has anybody seen the new Isaac Julien - Franz Fanon doco?

I saw it last night - realising during that yesterday was his birthday - &
other numerological epiphanies

Anyway this isn't really poetics but it is nicer than all this bickering as
Fanon never said (But Mr Burn's did on the Mulder/Scully Simpsons) "Can't we
just all get along."

Anyway this was a fascinating & resonant if slightly overblown study of
Fanon which attempted all sorts of psychoanalytical quote-y visual tricks
(or maybe the director just liked the actor playing Fanon's body). Not
really a discussion of the poetics of poetry - but the poetics of cinema -
sure. And the poetics of documentary - absolutely.
The Fanon readings themselves were delivered poetically - a device strangley
appropriate considering the didactics of his writings (and there is a
hate-mongerer for you - other peoples words not mine - don't think he is so
much when you really read him). Interviewees included Homi Bhabha, Stuart
Hall  & other 'cultural theorists'. Whether people's cups of tea/coffee or
not - bloody nice to see something so thoughtful in this age of popular
thoughtlessness.

Wasn't sure about directorial efforts to represent 'unveiling etc' but any
criticism is a complement to a film attempting something so ambitious.
Anyway - a whole lot further on from Julien's homphobia and reggae doco of a
couple of years ago.

Anyway that's enough for now - anyone else?

Look Fanon is simply more relevant to a poetics discussion than a lot of
these bickerings. Flirtings and teasings... keep em up - there are no good
soaps on telly at the moment.

So lets get this train (of thought) back on track, and start pushing my
barrow cos these slivered linings of your cumulo-nimbus are dragging their
ol' butts hereabouts.

POoH-etics anybody?

Dan Salmon.

Subject:      What's in a poem? Cross-posting 2
In-Reply-To:  <E0wq9rW-0003pk-00@black.csi.cam.ac.uk>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Dematerializing The Poisoned Pastoral



With the time-lapse, the upturned echidna writhes,
        ants and maggots consuming its sponge-like
        flesh beneath the spreading International Klein Blue sky--
just a component part of an heroic Blaues Schwammrelief--
the residue of its life flashing by, as sun-eaten locals
        stare uncomprehendingly at the skins of their

finest sheep strung out over rusty fences, all veined
        and varicosed with ordnance despite
        tableaux of monochromatic sameness,
as if each were a small centre, a source of density--
the sky, the dam water, the raddled paddocks and graded roads,
        those soft diggings around fallen trees multiplying

each night, writ in mystical latin: Tachyglossus aculeatus.
        Beneath the picture subterranean streams overflow,
        underwriting patches of poison bush that'd see
the whole flock stone dead on the spread, blue as blue venus
in a deeply blue light, blue as the International Klein Blue sea
        beside which the locals spend their holidays.

<<i didn't even think there was an audience for concrete and sound
poetry (but i'm reading those into the word _performance_). xcept
for the poet. but that doesn't count. i'm not so sure there is such
a thing as a public art. or maybe i don't believe in one. and maybe
i'm over - interpreting a gain.>> Carl Lynden Peters =


in Britain, there tends to be quite a good audience for sound poetry -
relatively

there isn't all that much truly concrete poetry around but there is a lot=

of visual poetry, over here; and there is every reason for taking concret=
e
poems as scores or jumping off points for performance - sound poetry by
definition surely means performance

one of the problems of working in those areas is the prejudice of those w=
ho
have their hands on distribution channels - people respond very positivel=
y
when they get to experience it

with both visual and sound work there is in some a tendency to treat both=

as odd, perhaps funny, and quirky, not to be taken that seriously - sugge=
st
that only the poet herself is interested for instance - recently I asked
Bob Cobbing for visual texts for front and back covers for an issue of a
magazine - Sub Voicive Poetry 1997 # 12 - featuring the work of two other=

poets - Anthony Rudolf UK and Ifigenija Simonovic Slovenia and UK... I pu=
t
all three names on the cover because all three were contributing poetry.
Bob said that is very rare - his work is often treated effectively as
illustration

Lawrence Upton

A very provisional reply to parts of Scott Bentley's post---

(..maybe belated: have been ill and away from my day-job, where I can
access the list..)

..What the heck is a poet of power??

If the implication is of (a kind of Bloomian) will-to-power thru one's
writing, I'd say this is about equally accurate a claim regarding
mainstreamers...For the most part, the tendency associated with Stein and
the LangPotes (..I consider that the label is best used only for the
members of that loose circle, not to characterized the work of others
that's in the mod/pomo stream), that tendency is very largely about
**relinquishing** control, inviting the collaboration of the reader..

Mark P.

Date:         Mon, 21 Jul 1997 09:36:12 -0400

Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         James Finnegan <JforJames@AOL.COM>
Subject:      Re: Poets House w/Address

Poets House
72 Spring St.
NY NY 10012
212-431-7920

I'm not a New Yorker, but travel there often on
business and for me its great sanctuary: quiet,
well lit, a few comfortable chairs, chockful of
poetry books and litmags. In the afternoons
after my appointments are over I like to sit there
and read. (Located on Spring St., it's a stone's
throw from the SoHo galleries.)

I've been to some of the Poet House programs;
mostly the panel discussions, symposia & lectures.
These events by & large have been very worthwhile.

The Poetry Publication Showcase is an annual event
displaying most, if not all, of the new poetry titles
released during the past year. In conjunction with this
project, they publish an annual catalog that I've
found useful in terms of keeping track of new poetry
titles, and useful for ordering books directly from the
presses. I'm sure this catalog would be helpful to
acquisition librarians as well.

Basic tax-deductible membership is $40. Membership
benefits include discounts on the fees charged for their
special programs/events and a copy of the above-mentioned
catalog. One can avail oneself of the Poets House without
being a member--it's free & open to the public as they say.

Finnegan

From:         Douglas Barbour <doug.barbour@UALBERTA.CA>
Subject:      Re: performance poetry?
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Interesting this talk on 'performance poetry.' Paul Dutton, one of the
finest sound poets i know, & once a member of The Four Horsemen, performed
at eyerhymes & after wards (along with the great Bob Cobbing) at some other
venues in Alberta. We were talking at one point & he discussed his
difficulties in writing an encylopedia entry on "Sound Poetry/Performance
Poetry": since we (that is stephen Scobie & I as Re:Sounding) were
performing with a 'performance poet the next evening, we were interested.
He had decided to define sound poetry in terms of what he & Bob & some of
the others mentioned already on the list (Charles Morrow, Jackson Maclow) &
to leave out the kind of performance poetry we heard the next evening: a
good bit of comedy, too many obvious rhymes (& all hit hard by the voie for
some reason), & always a strong narrative (at least from this performer0,
yet done with he flair of a standup comic. I would, for the moment, tend to
agree with him. His amazing "Stereo Head" is certainly an awesome
'performance' but it is so within extremely strict & demanding *formal*
limits, as were the varied pieces of the horsemen. And Cobbing's chants are
too. Or any of the others i've already named & many others.

On the other hand, I have to think a lot of poets can't read too well if
perforance poets are supposed to be so much better or more 'entertaining'
than they are, because this performance poet wasn't really doing anything
much beyond what I've heard good readers of their own work do in terms of
'expression': well a George Bowering for example (when not cowering under a
lampshade [it's bowering not cowering he opined]), certainly Charles
Bernstein, definitely Robert Creeley the one time i was lucky enough to
hear him . . . you probabaly get the idea...

What intrigued me most about that Gold rant, as you accurately describe it,
is that Gold himself got the inverse treatment in the forward of the edition
of Jews without Money (still sounds like a description of my friendship
network) when Michael Harrington basically said, this dude can't write, but
he has something to say. In fact, Gold was a precise and even delicate
stylist. But his official position of "anti-style" gets taken at face value
too often.

Unpacking the Stein comment would take a whole history of the relation of
the CP's stalinized politics vis a vis modernism and in particular its
attraction to the Trots, first, and then to Stein's very obvious gender
transgressiveness as a secondary text. Frankly, no American writers other
than Sherwood Anderson and Hemingway seem to have had any idea what she was
doing until well after her death. She did better with musicians and visual
artists, who were generally less anxious about figuring out how to fit her
into any model of what writing "should be."

Consider the difficulty that modernist writers of a stalinist nature had:
specifically the objectivists. The Trots reviled them because of their CP
leaning politics (Zukofsky's college roommate was Whitaker Chambers, Oppen
took off for Mexico the minute that the Rosenbergs were arrested, Carl
Rakosi was "around" the CP for years and in fact his name is a nom de plume
from the real Calman Rawley partly for that reason), other modernists
thought they were nuts, poltically speaking, and the CP thought they were
nuts aesthetically. Consider, how an intelligent but "well-placed" red like
Gold had to negotiate social space. Add misogyny and homophobia to the mix
and I think you get what he wrote.

No?

All best,

Ron

Ron Silliman

You don't understand.  Which is a little hard to swallow, this shit about
you telling me to raise my conciousness and what, maybe my self esteem?
After you, Ms. Dodie, chose to A) not communicate with me privately, then
B) Make the news of your your brief and somewhat dismissive private
correspondance with me as a testimony to your, what was it, Radicalism?
Non bourgeoisness?  Or was it Avante Gardeism?  I can't remember.
But here, let me try to clarify:  I am using"The Personal Voice" (you're
familliar, I'm sure)  to write about a Public Institution (language) and
the damage it does--yes, to me, to my heart, to me!  But obviously I am
not submerged.  Jesus Christ, there's bad.  There's bad and good feelings
and there's poison and oppression and no, for fuck's sake, it's not "cool"
to be a prostitute.  Its lucrative!  It affords dignity to me, but I'm a
middle class college kid.  The word whore hasn't ruined me.  But it has
power, it corrupts all of our sexual/political/romantic landscapes.  It
is not cool.  The word faggot hasn't ruined the man I love, but it has
given him pause.  If you don't want to talk about this, fine.  There are
people who do, and I thank god for them, cause I am a lonely type.  Fuck,
why are you, Mark Weiss, and you Dodie Bellamy, so nasty about it?  I
will happily say it again, and please, this time listen to, or speculate on,
the inflection:

I am a whore and I am in love with a faggot.

See, no self loathing.  Just an acknowledgement of suffering.
Just a tear shed against injustice.  Just a poem, a short one.

From:         Mark Wallace <mdw@GWIS2.CIRC.GWU.EDU>
Subject:      a new book by Allen Ginsberg
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

I've just read this past week, with pleasure and obvious sadness, a book
just out from Zasterle Press, Allen Ginsberg's LUMINOUS DREAMS, a
collection of prose dream sequences written over a number of years.
They're all very intriguing; my favorite was the first, a dream sequence
called "History of the Jewish Socialist Party in America":

"... in fact we are completely unconcerned with the US Govt, and far from
spying on it we welcome spies in our midst in the hope they be converted
and learn something about us."

        It was both amazing and strange to hear, even in these relatively
casual pieces, the voice of Ginsberg come alive again in new work; reading
it I felt how powerful and present his work and life remain.

        Mark Wallace
