Date:         Mon, 21 Jul 1997 20:46:26 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Joel Kuszai <kuszai@ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Subject:      Dredging the Harbor for a Sinking Ship
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Performance of the spectacle of belligerent, principled,
truculent insistence at "being heard" at whatever cost to the
community at large, must end!

Having been off-line for a period greater than a month but less
than two, I've been lagging behind in my poetics reading, by
about a week or so, following up on the digests only as I am
able to get them on disk and then back home from my telnet
station on this foreign campus. Yesterday or the day before, I
returned to regular mail delivery from the poetics listserv back
on my home planet of Buffalo New York. If it is not too late,
and if there has not been too much written about this, please let
me jump in on a couple items that have been going on here.

It is astonishing to me the way that certain discussions, events,
or situations are repeated on this list, seemingly every few
months. The list itself isn't that old--wuzzit Charles B. said? --
went public Dec 1993?--and so perhaps the high volume of
verbiage and the nature of the way listservs "conduct
themselves" has led to a kind of chronocompression that, when
viewed against historical "reality" seems absurd. I'm not
personally opposing the repetition of any of the topics
discussed, from the criticism vs. poetry debates, to the
performance discussions to the continual struggle of the
"emerging writers" to define themselves in relation to
language poetry. Often, however, it seems that the same
problems are discovered and repeated anew without any
consideration for the fact that many "in the audience" have
seen much better actors in the very same roles.

I read somewhere that if nothing else, the "lumpen-slackers" of
the C.O. movement showed that the "system" was fallible in
that it wasn't able to garner the allegiance of "subjects."

Just as in the "subjective irrelevant" (an inverse of Eliot's
"objective correlative") real world, the lack of historical
awareness on the list is due to the huge volume of material to
read and comprehend and the unlikely prospect that someone
would read the whole list from beginning to current. How
many words is that? How many posts? On the other hand, if
I'm going to write to the Mammals List about my love and
knowledge of Otters, I certainly would do a search on "Otters"
first to stake out the field. I might even learn something about
Otters that I didn't know. But hey, I'm into Otters.

I'm not arguing that everyone should read everything before
participating, but I am thinking of the nebulous netiquette
unwritten rule of thumb, that one should read and see what's
happening on the list before starting any bonfires. I hadn't felt
that way before, but after my storm of reading of the last week
or so, I am convinced of it.

I'm not sure how many have been around since January 1994,
but us old-timers will tell you that the "identity-evasion" issues
of recent spam-artists and their often attendant personal
attacks have happened before, and is not the first time such a
drama has been perpetrated on this list. Obviously "y'all can do
wuchawant." It doesn't, finally, matter much to me. Like Maria
Damon, the diminishing returns have alarmed me and often I
have thought of unsubbing. But then it seems like things pick
up. More often than not it happens that on one of the other
poetics channels there is something meaningful in the
exchanges (and I like to think of this list as a kind of satellite
receiver with a delete-key filter, facilitating many
conversations on a wide-open spectrum, some of which, yes,
are dumb, boring, or painful to read).

Despite the valiant attempts of many to make something of
this space, this list, perhaps like many in cyberspace, is a list
where the glorious and ephemeral nature of the discussion is
matched only by the participants who keep up with it; or if not,
keep changing seats to give the impression of a cohesive set of
performers and a stable, if not cotten-eared audience. The
shifting nature of the list is now counter-balanced by a firm set
of people who've been on the list for more than a couple
months and who've stuck it out to have the conversation. List
Elders will remember that most of the instigators of Listserv
Drama have all moved on to more exciting internet venues,
I'm sure.

Any how, I am not sure why I am speaking out on this set of
issues except that I was disturbed by the tenor of the list when I
hooked back into it and the apparent bad faith by some of the
people writing here. I was disappointed by the unbridled
yelling, the fingers plugging the ears, the "I cant hear you I cant
hear you" of "you're not reading me your're not reading me,"
that god-awful mantra of the moment.

Much of the complaint surrounding the list is this careless
involvement of the public sphere in the quotidian exchanges by
exhibitionists seemingly lonely for any other kind of real life.
Why do we want to introduce anger and petit bourgeois
violence into the mix? It isn't so much to ask that people
consider their posts before sending them; keep private chatter
backchannel; reduce the amount of "noise," which finally
inhibits the intended function of this list.

On that note, on the matter of the literary chalice of poetic
inheritance, anxiety, and its attendant mores, I would argue it
isn't the value of any particular device that is the point, but the
relation of that device to our action and practice in the world.
There isn't anything inherently intrinsicly radical about
language poetry; isn't it the commonest thing in the world? But
the language movement was not *a* response but a series of
responses to a set of perceived institutional perceptions. I
confuses me, therefore that *naive* language poetry,
denouced on this list recently, would be held in disrepute, when
it alone can offer a critique from the vacuum of ignorance, the
place in which those literary devices of "advanced" poetic
technologies have a "value" that isn't "polluted" or
"committed" either. I'm being somewhat facetious here, but
really, I want to know what are the "committed" "ideological"
values of different formal practices. I asked my peers in Buffalo
last Fall what the inherent or tactical value was of doing work
in "homophonic translation." This led to a debate on our local
listserv there, and yet, I was never satisfied with the answers
which ranged in the vicinity of "homophonic translation
disrupts normative reading methods," as if such disruption
were somehow self-evident. I'm not saying that such work is
not valuable, but I want to know what is the significance (or
value) of doing this work *now.*

Insofar as there has been explanation of some of the rhetorical
devices used in recent list behavior, let us have a look at one of
them. The evasion of identity, the evacuation of specificity and
even the emptying of pronouns to malleable shifters--are these
really characteristics representative of the *current*
generation?  Why is identity play a valuable device in writing? I
can imagine a number of reasons myself, but wonder what
people "out there" think, as it has been something that has been
said of much of the current writing out there. It seems that the
cynical doubt of the possibility of sincerity (in some kind of
absolutist way?) has returned to us with a sort of sinister
vengeance. Why not follow out the natural results of some of
our theories? Tom Metzger was tried in Portland on charges
that he "suggested" the skinhead boys kill Mr. Seraw. A close
reading of Mr. Metzger would have one believe that he was
not responsible for his death, as he did not kill nor did he give
the explicit instruction to kill. I am not saying that we should
suspend Mr. Metzger's civil liberties, far from it. However,
close reading of the text often doesn't work in conspiracy cases.
When people say to those offended by the attacks on this list,
"lighten up," I am reminded of the woman at U-Mich in Ann
Arbor who was terrorized by a violent story published on the
internet in which the victim was *named* after her. While
there are crucial free speech issues every day, is the defense of
such a violent realization of these rhetorical technologies the
best way to use our energies? What is there to prove? Seriously,
I want to know? What *is* at stake here?

The danger lies, I think, mostly in the desire for anonymity as a
cover, or in the desire for an effaced or "slippery" identity, by
which one is allowed to conduct violent attacks. What is to be
gained from remaining anonymous? Certainly we're not
Weather Underground people, are we? (I wish we were
meeting in a warehouse and not in ineffectual cyberspace) The
rationalizing of this behavior among "friendly peers" (is that a
fair assumption, that the list should be a safe place to converse
without being attacked?) demeans other uses these devices can
have, and often those uses are revolutionary or subversive in
nature. Certainly, subversion and revolution are often valued
methods of valuing rhetorical technics.

All of this reminds me the "missent letter" (which we still see
occasionally, as the sender apologizes for having transgressed
their own--if no other--social order) in that being "attacks"
both the "spam" and the missent letter are often accompanied
by a kind of plausible deniability. Often missent letters are
marked only by this apology, with much of the discourse list
"missent"--in the sense that it has been reduced to a kind of
"could've been sent privately." Or, "should have been." Missent
letters are usually innocent; a few times they are embarrassing.
Once in a while they have been given an almost device-like
flavor of the intentional (and anyone who has been through the
logs knows what Im referring to).

The "misguided" spam on the other hand, offers deniability
through a misty cloud of half-baked "postmodernism" (for lack
of a better term). Utilizing the space of "plausible deniability"
may serve certain functional ideological purposes; a kind of
ends-meets-means endgame. But that space, of "willful"
misconduct seems dangerous, especially when transmissions of
violence posing as linguistic play are often linked to deniability
with concern to "identity" while at the same time serving to
advance the "cultural capital" of the speaker--and here Im
thinking how much of the capital generated by the AHP a
couple years ago was still connected to the never-revealed-
but-all-too-obvious writer-editors. The violence done to Jay
Schwartz, for instance, wasn't so much an actual nipple-
clipping real fear so much as it was a kind of jousting-like
aggressive verbal antagonism conducted on the public stage. I
personally don't see the point in that. The refusal to engage,
then, and defend one's actions, seems to me representative of a
kind of cowardice. I think of recent literary magazines which
offered up critique in manifesto-editorials but never allowed
even one letter to the editor to be published in response--so
much for the tradition of wrangling debate, as evidenced on
the left in the 30s, for instance. The fact that such an affair as
recently witnessed could lead to then a kind of community
melt-down and breaking into "sides" or positions, seemed
linked to the issue that there is "something to lose." What is it?
And if there is something to lose, why aren't we talking about
*that*?

Let me say that I really don't think were going to solve any
world or personal problems on this list. And while I certainly
don't think that there is so much at stake on this list that we
should take ourselves so seriously, finally, I do think that we
should take this space seriously. Obviously there is tons of
symbolic value to everything that is said. I guess it is better to
speak uninhibitedly and without reflection if reflection is going
to inhibit your speech.

Kind of like talking to people in a bar. Do you mean to be
saying that to me, or are you just acting out?

I have more things to post, so until next time--



Ellen-Ricardo

Poetics Janitor






"Sweeping up around the poetics playground
is what we aim to do."
                                Leon Grotsky
                                President
                                Poetics Workers of the World
                                Local 2.99

Subject:      Poetics Flashback: Deep Image c.1962
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Rachel Loden's posting of the Michael Gold piece on Stein was a useful
demonstration of some positive vibes on the poetics channel. As part of an
ongoing attempt to spur debate and educate the masses, here is an
installment of POETICS FLASHBACKS. Because poetic yammering didn't begin
with the internet, with the literary magazine there is a long tradition of
partisan debate and creative juices flowing, POETICS FLASHBACKS (brought
to you by the Poetics Workers of the World) would like to present
tonight's pogrom, I mean program, the exchange between Robert Kelly and
Jerry Rothenberg in the pages of Trobar, which Kelly edited in the early
60s. The following is the initial piece by Kelly, which as he mentions, is
a response to Rothenberg's idea of the Deep Image (a concept which is now
an unrestricted free agent).

Note: POETICS FLASHBACKS are not copyrighted but belong to the spirit of
poetics which is nowhere available but everywhere apparent. Please feel
free to upload any POETICS FLASHBACKS that might be recovered from the
forgotten world.

                        [note: POETICS FLASHBACKS
                        does not necessarily endorse
                        the opinions expressed below]



Robert Kelly

NOTES ON THE POETRY OF DEEP IMAGE

...the movement of images is rhythm.
- Nicolas Calas

These notes represent my attempt to understand and use this statement. The
climate of the notes is the atmosphere of excitement and confrontation I
am aware of in Jerome Rothenberg's working in what he calls 'deep image'.
In the second issue of his Poems from the Floating World he writes: "the
deep image rises from the shoreless gulf: here the poet reaches down among
the lost branches, till a moment of seeing: the poem." Working with deep
image is the development of a 'basic imagination.' I read FLOATING WORLD
as an attempt to plot a series of points, the poems & translations
printed, to surround an implicit definition of the powers of the deep
image. Rothenberg's first volume, WHITE SUN BLACK SUN (Hawk's Well Press)
has just been published. The poems in it are very good, very moving, very
much alive: demonstrations of the fruitfulness of the approach to the poem
via deep image. And the collection is, beyond the matter of the poems
themselves (what shall be said of them?), a happening in itself: the
appearance of a demand for a new set of concerns in poetry, the appearance
of a cogent movement in a new direction. The notes that follow are offered
as pertinent perhaps to the climate I've spoken of.

The present and necessary function of poetry is the transformation of the
perceived world. This transformation orders the known world into an
effective and coherent universe. The eye, seeing a concrete pavement for
the thousandth time but the flakes of mica embedded in it, glowing &
fiery, for the first time, sees a transformation and so is illuminated.
But poetry cannot stop with that enlightenment. Epiphany is meaningless
display outside the context of incarnation. Poetry is concerned with
things transforming and transforming things, with the whole picture in
mind. We are given: 1 world to transform, 1 language to transform it with.
        Transformation is process, involves truth as emergent from process
and not distinct from it, involves knowledge which alone redeems us from
innocence, the deadly innocence of not knowing where and what things are.
Poetry answers the questions  w h a t   w h e r e   w h e n.
        Nothing can be known unless it is known in situ, in the context of
its world. Transformation aims at the continuum of all perceptions. Poetry
is this continuum. Poetry establishes the mutual relevance of every
percept to every other percept.
        Percepts are from dreams or from waking, rise from the unconscious
or from the retina of the awakened eye. Poetry, like dream reality, is the
juncture of the experienced with the never-experienced. Like waking
reality, it is the fulfillment of the imagined and the unimagined. The
percepts, in order to be communicated, are fleshed in language. Poetry
cannot exhibit naked perception. The clothed percept is the image.
        Poetry is not the art of relating word to word, but the ACT of
relating word to percept, image to image until the continuum is achieved.

The Line:
        If the poem takes its departure from speech, a relationship of
some kind must exist between the rhythm supplied by the images and the
rhythm of the breath. What is the relationship of image to line?
        One easy answer is to say that one image equals one line. This
denies the independent existence of line, and is a quasi-solution that
produces poetry of blandness, no matter how great the initial force of the
images: the images are not being articulated, urgency is lost.
        Projective verse (for which see Charles Olson, Projective Verse)
offers a method of resolving breath and line, and my concern with it here
seeks to substitute the centrality of image for the centrality of syllable
& line as a way of access to the happening of a poem. The line as set down
on paper is an indication of the breath period, with visual & rhythmic
considerations determining the visual notation.
        The projective line ending in open juncture allows tremendous
stress on the last verbal unit in the line, a stress exploited not for key
words but for key silences, stretching out to vital & peripheral words.
'Systematic derangement' of standard speech rhythms, of the
inflexibilities of our analytic grammar, is a sharp exploratory tool, and
a means of locking images.
        When the image, prima materia, is lacking, the verbal gesture is
quickly emptied: the poem elapses instead of happening.
        The fundamental rhythm of the breath. One line represents one
breath period. The line rhythm is a product of internal (stress, morphemic
pattern) and external (weight, length) factors, relating one line to
another and to all others. Each line is rhythmically related to another
line by those same elements that relate lines formally to one another,
i.e. formal similarities beget rhythmic relationships.
        Thus a poem involves the fundamental rhythm of the images
(fundamental because more complexly present), a rhythm which is at once
intellectual and sensuous, and also the structural, more directly sensual,
rhythm of the breath expressed in line. The counterpointing of these two
rhythms is a principal sources of fullness and complexity in the poem.

Deep Image:
        Plucking things from the street or from the unconscious is
comparable to the digging of ore. Images do not necessarily proceed
directly from the pitchblende. Verbalization is of prime importance, and
on its subtlety the success of the appearance of the image, and of the
rhythm of images, depends.
        The deep image must be transferred to the paper, BUILT into the
poem, in language which gives it its fullest spatial, temporal, sonic &
kinetic properties, as conditioned by its presence in a series & in a
structure. Supplying the image in its fullest force is thus partially a
function of language.
        Basically, the fullest force is possible only by means of the
successful employment of one image's position in a context of other
images; the image, after its first appearance as dark sound, still lingers
as a resonance. This resonance must be controlled, and the effective means
of control are the acoustics of the space intervening between one image &
the next. The subsequent image is conditioned, made to work, by the image
that precedes it, and conditions, as it is finally conditioned by, the
image that follows it: through the whole poem. The first image to appear
in an Andre Breton poem will normally dominate all subsequent images and
the poem as a whole, even when the reader seems to have forgotten it.
        The whole poem is more than the sum of its parts. Very important
for this superequivalence is the ORDER of images within a poem. The final
quantum will vary with the rearrangement of the images and of the images'
fields of force. Every image has its field of force, its shadow moving
darkly through the poem, with which the poet must contend.
        The rational progression of images is only trope, whether or not
the middle terms are excluded: metaphor with a stale taste of truism. Only
the superior rationality of the dream is an effective impetus for the
movements of the deep image.
        The image is the measure of the line. The line is cut with image
in mind.

Language:
        The verbalization of the image comes out of the linguistic
patterns of the poet's native language.
        In the poem built from the deep image, the image itself bears an
enormous weight, for through it and its connection with the rhythmic
sequence of images, the flow of the image-conditioned word and music, the
meaning of the poem exists, all communication takes place.
        The American language of today provides the only reliable
linguistic patterns for the poet of images. Verbal expression of the image
demands an urgency and directness that only the spoken language of poet
and reader can supply, the language of here and now. The language of the
image must come across vividly and urgently, without cuteness or
distraction.
        Only in the native linguistic PATTERNS can the deep image
communicate at full strength.
        In the image and in the line, the poet is using a language
superficially akin to that of everyday. Atop the familiar linguistic
patterns, the images mold their own expressions. The poet charges these
expressions using the full arsenal of poetics, so that the image works in
all its urgency, at its maximal communicative force. The need for urgency,
for tension in the work itself, cannot be exaggerated. The language of
deep images restores the poetry of desperation.
                October , 1960                              [Trobar 2]




Jerome Rothenberg

WHY *DEEP* IMAGE?

When we speak about "deep image," we renew a demand that poets get at the
reality of things by turning inward: that the process of self-perception
be united as far as possible with our means for perceiving the world
around us. This sort of concern leads naturally to a reconsideration of
whether a "poem" is something other than the structure of its words, even
while being integrally connected to that structure, which gives it a shape
and name.

The question which presented itself at the start, before image in any
sense had clearly entered the picture, was where the poem took root (what
its source was) -- or, as it later developed, whether certain elements in
what, by the cut of the lines, we distinguished as a "poem," were "poetic"
in their very nature: in short, if there existed a special kind of poetic
activity. I was by then convinced that there was a long-standing confusion
between the structure of words we call a poem and the
event-of-a-poem's-happening: all more elusive because structure and event
could coincide in the same space -- and probably should, as likely in the
nature of things. But I did feel too that not all events that occur in a
poem -- and certainly not in most poems written today -- are in this sense
the happening-of-a-poem.

The event that seemed to me most clearly central to the
happening-of-a-poem was what we came to call "deep image." The word *deep*
wasn't intended to convey a sense of profundity, pseudo or otherwise, but
to show that the direction of seeing in this kind of image is into a man
rather than outside him: not a habit of the eye so much as a penetration
of the self to refocus on the world through the eyes-of-feeling. This
means that we have to try to see the world in all its natural and
contemporary detail as if no differences existed between the seer and the
things he sees. To see in this way -- through the self (emotively) --
results in certain necessary changes on the material emerging in the poem:

a heightened sense of the emotional contours of objects
(their dark qualities, or shadows);

their free re-association in a manner that would be impossible to
descriptive or logical thought, but is here almost unavoidable;

the sense of these objects (and the poem itself) being informed with a
heightened relevance, a quickened sense of life;

the recognition of the poem as a natural structure
arising at once from the act of emotive vision.

The power of the deep image is its ability to convey a sense of
two-words-in-one: directly: with no concept to come between the inner
experience and its meaning. With this comes a new attack on the mystery of
the real, in which all our habitual perceptions are continually being put
in question. The poet discovers the unknown by creating it from the vast
resources of his inner life, the savings of an experienced world still
rich in meaning: he delivers, as deep image, the life-giving vision that
he could in no other way explain.

In spite of this essential directness of communication, the recasting of
the world in the self's image will seem to some a distortion of whatever
world they habitually take for "the real one." Some such discomfort has
accompanied the introduction of deep image by other modern poets. But any
disruption of a bad habit should be welcome. The deep image brings with it
a demand for new visions of the world for new creations into thought: in
short for poetry in its *creative* aspect, in which, as Baudelaire first
had it, the poem "will contain, at one and the same time, the object and
the subject, the external world and the artist himself."
                                                [Trobar 3]

i sometimes share th impatience w/ rehashing what, to me, is
old hash...  but i think it's a mistake to see the conversations
as "only" about their ostenstible "topic"--th recurrent themes
recur because they're (still) issues that are still in process...
and the ongoing conversation often enuf isnt actually part ov
"solving" th "problem", but a public marker that it's still an
unresolved collective issue (even tho most ov the discussants
probably have resolved it individually & for themselves--probably
before the conversation begins...).
                as an example (sorry fr the rehash), my memory
of the criticism/poetry remergence: bob g. posted his taxonomy,
which contained his neologism "acadominant" to refer to LangPo;
several folks objected to the term on various grounds & w/
seemingly different interpretations of "acadominant"; i ventured
a guess as to the connection bob saw between th acadamy & LangPo
(i hypothesized it was because of the importance of critical
discourse to both); and that triggered th rehash--seemingly
just using th 2 terms in the same sentance provoked.  seemed
misplaced to me at the time, but i read it to mean that it's
still a point ov (con)tension w/in the list.  i admit i stopped
reading the individ posts; but the fact ov the recurring
event still seems notworthy...

[&&, i equally have no use fr the various cat&dog fights etc...
pretty quick w/ the delete key, tho, rather than unsubing--& while
not reading the posts hard, still noting the event, which then
colors other less flammable posts by those authors... ]

The very postmodern reason I will be in Seattle is that the US Dept of
Energy wants to see if my thyroid glows in the dark and is paying to fly me
all the way there to a hospital known colloquially as The Hutch, instead of
having me check at a local clinic here. The reason that they want to see if
it glows in the dark (that is not a technical term) is that I was born in
the immediate vicinity of the Hanford nuclear facility at the far end of
the state, which is where they built "Little Man," the bomb dropped on
Nagasaki. During said same period, the good scientists at Hanford also
dumped radioactive iodine into the ground and eventually into the Columbia
River (Roll on...). So, 50 years hence the DOE is checking on 3,200 children
born over the next ten years within X number of miles of the facility. In my
case, X is literally a Roman numeral.

So I guess I will go do my Tyrone Slothrop imitation. Or maybe my Araki
Yasusada one.

But it would be nice to get something positive out of the experience. So
give me a shout if you're there,

Ron

Jordon Davis wrote --

>Maria --
>
>What's the earliest usage of "men who squint at the moon"? Do you
have
>other breathtaking euphemisms?

And Maria Damon wrote:

<< judy grahn suggests a few nice ones: men who walk backwards is one
i remember. i was hoping someone out there cd let loose with a more
flamboyant and insiderish list >>

While neither flamboyant nor insiderish, I was reminded of a passage in
Vladimir Nabokov's THE EYE (1965, written originally in Russina),
which I lately read for 1st time --

the expression there is "sexual leftie" -- don't know the Russina, but I
think it's safe to assume (notwithstanding some paradox of such
assumption) that here, "leftie" is meant as a slangy form of "left-handed
person" (rather than a slangy form of "left-winger"; this notwithstanding
the novel's set among expatriate Russians in Berlin in the 1920s) --

the narrator is fascinated with the a character known as Smurov; & more
particularly, he's obsessed with trying to form a clear idea of how various
persons in their social surround regard Smurov -- for he has come to
understand that each seems to view Smurov differently.  To further his
research, he intercepts a letter penned by the prolix (& literarily
conceited) Roman Bogdanovich (who has made it be known that he
writes regular dispatches to a distant friend w/ details of all & sundry).
Sure enough, Bagdonovich expresses a view -- and none too generous (in
context) -- anent the mysterious Smurov.

Nabokov's prose reads thus:

<< . . . I skipped several pages and suddenly, like a familiar face amid a
hazy crowd, there saw Smurov's name.  What amazing luck!
    "I propose, my dear Fyodor Robertovich, to return briefly to that
rascal.  I fear it may bore you, but in the words of the Swan of Weimar --
I refer to the illustrious Goethe -- (there followed a German phrase).
Therefore allow me to dwell on Mr. Smurov again and treat you to a little
psychological study . . ."  <snip>
    "I have the impression, dear friend, that I have already written to you
of the fact that Smurov belongs to that curious class of people I once
called 'sexual lefties.'  Smurov's entire appearance, his frailness, his
decadence, his mincing gestures, his fondness for Eu de Cologne, and, in
particular, those furtive, passionate glances that he constantly directs
toward your humble servant -- all this has long since confirmed this
conjecture of mine.  It is remarkable that these sexually unfortunate
individuals, while yearning physically for some handsome specimen of
mature virility, often choose for object of thier (perfectly platonic)
admiration -- a woman -- a woman they know well, slightly, or not at all.
And so Smurov, notwithstanding his perversion, has chosen Varvara as
his ideal. . . . " [etc.] >>

(Coincidentally, the narrator was madly in love with this same Varvara.
But much more curiously, at the very end of the novel, the narrator is
astounded to discover that evidently -- albeit quite inexplicably -- he is,
in fact, himself none other than Smurov -- the bloke whose publicly
conceived character he's been so firecely trying to figure out.)

[ this: a long tangent, or a brief diversion . . . ? ]

d.i.

Enjoy Seattle Ron.  My sister worked in Hanford in the late 80's or early
90's.  The place became the world's biggest requirer of scientists overnight
when a new research facility was opened to try to find out why a crust had
formed over the nuclear material in the reactors.  The occasional burp of
gases through said crust, I think Fiona, my sister, said every 15 mins,
increased the risk of the things exploding by surely it wasn't 50%?  She now
works in Italy after a minor hiccup one Thursday afternoon.  T-shirts were
on sale in Hanford bearing the mushroom cloud image under which was written:
Made in America, Tested in Japan.  It still shocks me.

From:         Jordan Davis <jdavis@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      L-Dopa
In-Reply-To:  <MAPI.Id.0016.00686178202020203030303430303034@MAPI.to.RFC822>

> I get frustrated with the kind of approach to poetry that needs to maintain
> this page/stage dichotomy and cannot,

I see "dichotomy and carrot", as in, if you accept the dichotomy, you can
have the carrot. Bob Hale's post (he used the word "often" when he made the
interesting if general statements about performance poetry) proposed the
idea that poetry need not be produced in the same time-economy as comedy.
Is Bob wrong to say that slam poetry (which is a distinct category of
performance poetry? no, but only some performance poets participated in
slams -- pace Charles Alexander) shares many trappings with stand-up
comedy.

The audience has a clearer contract with the stand up comedian, though --
you go (or you change the channel) and within say a minute, you laugh, or
you can start talking to your date (or change the channel again). What is
the audience's contract with the performance poet? Give me some crazy
words, give me a narrative describing how you had a strong and easily
identifiable emotion, talk too fast -- what?

Implicit in Bob's description of performance poetry is the idea that a poet
is better off where the contract is clearer -- i.e. where the audience
knows that they don't know the rules. (Viz Rod Smith's post -- inspiration
comes from listening to Bird -- bop ((like abstract expression)) being a
systematization of surprise ((or maybe just a few simultaneous incarnations
of Shiva in the world?)) -- the jazz audience contracting to have their
minds blown -- to know that they werent' going to know -- to be ok with
that -- the parallels between bop and serialism?)

Julie's (was it Hugh's?) account of heckling by guessing the rhyme jibes
with this -- the poet has a harder job when the audience knows the rules --
when they can collaborate. This ties back into Mark Presjnar's post about
reader-response.

At 9:01 AM -0400 7/21/97, Mark Prejsnar wrote:
>that's in the mod/pomo stream), that tendency is very largely about
>**relinquishing** control, inviting the collaboration of the reader..

I know this is the jargon -- but is it the case? Even the jargon seems a
little like _states' rights_, if you ask the individual with this reply
address. But assuming that the jargon describes something about the
relationships between writer work and reader, what would that collaboration
be? (No fair citing O'Hara's Lucky Pierre -- not all of us went to
adventurous schools) Filling in the blank spaces on the page (in a work
like Bruce Andrews' _Tizzy Boost_)? Coming up with one's own brutal
one-liners (in a work like Bruce Andrews' _I Don't Have Any Paper So Shut
Up, (or, Social Romanticism)_)?

I'm assuming, Joel Kuszai, that when you ask what the meaning is of doing
homophonic translation *now*, you're referring to a couple of things *in
the air* (or rather, in magazines and books) lately. One is Marjorie
Perloff's idea (quoted in David Kellogg's Diacritics article; thanks for
the offprint, David) that one must figure out what language game is the one
to be playing *now*. Another might be Andrews' gonzo homophonic translation
of the entirety of Dante's Paradiso.

To ask the meaning is to assume there is one, or that there's a process
going on and what set it off is interesting and what will follow it is
interesting. Maybe the meaning going on is sluggish? Maybe the critical
will to proscribe (to place bets on?) what goes on *now* is off? But if
it's not, then I'm placing my bets on what Henry's mentioned, the phonemic
shuffle -- but with this corollary -- the paraphrasable meaning has to be
as unfamiliar and overdetermined as the sound combinations are -- viz the
recent work of Ben Friedlander, the lunch poems of Tim Davis, "Eon" by Kim
Lyons, practically anything by Ange Mlinko. But I wouldn't bet
_everything_, my printing press goes too slowly for that.

Anyway, to echo Mark Wallace's call for a CONSCIOUS exploration of multiple
approaches (as opposed to what Mark characterizes as a naive "anything
goes" polymorphousness -- more about that dichotomy, Mark?) I'm more
comfortable looking at Andrews' work as a reductio ad infinitum of
Pound/Olson's idea that each poem must take its own form. Alice Notley's
work has a similar impulse -- do a different thing. Those might be some
interesting trajectories to track -- any grad schools out there with cash?
Can an exploration of multiple approaches be separated out from its
ordinary literary-historical complement, the biographical/chronological? I
do this _then_ I do that? Or does influence work backwards, in the form of
_fame_.

Ahh, who knows,
Neologism or Typo

Mark and Jordan conversing:
">that's in the mod/pomo stream), that tendency is very largely about
>**relinquishing** control, inviting the collaboration of the reader..

I know this is the jargon -- but is it the case? Even the jargon seems a
little like _states' rights_, if you ask the individual with this reply
address. But assuming that the jargon describes something about the
relationships between writer work and reader, what would that
collaboration
be? (No fair citing O'Hara's Lucky Pierre -- not all of us went to
adventurous schools) Filling in the blank spaces on the page (in a work
like Bruce Andrews' _Tizzy Boost_)? Coming up with one's own brutal
one-liners (in a work like Bruce Andrews' _I Don't Have Any Paper So Shut
Up, (or, Social Romanticism)_)?"

I think the idea of filling in the blank spaces on the page is only the
simplest expression of a readers collaboration and a writers willingness
towards such collaboration.  More interesting to me at least are those
instances when a writer's willingness to collaborate with her readers is
somehow inscribed in the language itself.  Nate Mackey talks about how
Creeley "registers the impact upon the rhythms of those thoughts of his
apprehension of the other inhabitants of the field or space in which this
articulation takes place.  The allowance he makes for the sensibilities of
his audience exemplifies a decentralizing impulse, a field approach, his
admission  that not only other things but also other minds exist."  So,
that's a kind of writer/reader collaboration, one which has been very
important to me, one which I see coming down from people like Creeley, and
even O'Hara, to the present moment.

-m.

Dear List,

I'm missing a word I used to know, and would greatly appreciate getting at
least its phone number, if any of you can help.

The word is a theoretical/critical term. The words closest to it in sound
and meaning that I can think of are disjunctive, dissociative, disruptive,
but none of those is it. The missing word essentially describes the act,
in poetics, of jumping from A to Z without traversing points B, C, D, et
cetera along the way. An instantaneous flash, if you will.

I used to feel really smart when I used it, and it actually came in handy
a lot for describing some of the things I am trying to do. A handsome
reward (unless you would prefer an ugly reward) is offered for its safe
return.

Thanks
Gwyn McVay

Date:         Tue, 22 Jul 1997 10:37:12 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         George Thompson <thompson@JLC.NET>
Subject:      Re: What comes next? Martian poetics
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

A tardy response to Henry Gould's interesting post, in particular to:

"To me the langpos haven't gone FAR ENOUGH
in the direction of the microstructure, and an interesting development
in the future will be toward Saussure's ideas about anagrams & paranomasia.
Hart Crane was into this: "anagrammatize your Name", etc.  Saussure
found a pervasive subtext underneath a lot of classic latin poetry -
the whole poem would be the scattered (Osiris) fragments of a thematic
single WORD.  Thematic - & referential.  Build on it.   The poem as
architecture.  Mandelstam again.  & Yeats, too.  heck yeah."

Saussure is a VERY interesting linguist, one who, like Jakobson, should be
of great interest to poets in general. Of course he is best known for his
"Course in General Linguistics" which triggered that language revolution
which I'm sure you're all familiar with [structuralism, semiology, etc].
But as Henry points out he did very interesting work on poetic
"microstructure" too [on an earlier thread there was discussion of
sub-lexical, sub-morphemic, and even sub-phonemic analysis: Saussure worked
very fruitfully on such things].

Although he triggered a revolution, Saussure was also a master of the
old-style  comparative linguistics [etymology, reconstruction, etc.].
Non-specialists often don't realize that Saussure pulled off one of the
most impressive stunts in the history of linguistics. In his doctoral
dissertation [he was 21 yrs old!], using the comparative method, he posited
the existence of "sonant coefficients" that *must have existed* in the
parent language, Proto-Indo-European, long-dead. This series of sounds did
not survive in any known language, but accd to S's analysis, they must once
have existed, way back in pre-history. Well, a generation or two later,
well after S's death, Hittite was discovered, and when it was deciphered,
guess what was found? The Hittite language, very archaic, preserved these
very "sonant coefficients" exactly where S predicted they would be [they
are now known as 'laryngeals']! This is an astonishing demonstration of the
fact that the theoretical constructs of historical linguistics had a
verifiable basis in reality [in real languages].

Saussure was also interesting for other, less mainstream, interests, such
as the notebooks on anagrams that Henry cites. If it is feasible to write a
book on Vedic poetics now, as I am trying to do, it is largely because
Saussure and Jakobson have opened the eyes of Vedicists to things in
"their"texts that they had not seen, in spite of 200 yrs of looking.

Then there is the matter of Martian poetics, which Saussure explored when
he was invited to examine the glossolalia of a Mdme. Helene Smith, "famous
clairvoyante". His researches are treated in Th. Flournoy's _From India to
the Planet Mars_, recently reprinted somewhere.

When I teach Jakobson in a course on linguistics & literature, I suggest
that J's conception of the poem is that it is a Rube Goldberg machine [=
Henry's 'poem as architecture'].

Try to imagine Emily Vey Duke's recent poem as a Rube Goldberg machine ["a
small one"].

George T

just a coupla comments on the always-always posts of JD & his aliases.
I have trouble relating the poet/listener contract described(?) here with
be-bop.  Other extensions of jazz, maybe (O. Coleman? Sun-Ra?) - but in
bop I hear a lot of form, control, expectations.  Not that I'm an expert.
>
>
>I'm assuming, Joel Kuszai, that when you ask what the meaning is of doing
>homophonic translation *now*, you're referring to a couple of things *in
>the air* (or rather, in magazines and books) lately. One is Marjorie
>Perloff's idea (quoted in David Kellogg's Diacritics article; thanks for
>the offprint, David) that one must figure out what language game is the one
>to be playing *now*. Another might be Andrews' gonzo homophonic translation
>of the entirety of Dante's Paradiso.

Re: homophonicism, check out as I mentioned before Starobinski's book
on Saussure's never-published years-long investigations into what he
calls "hypograms" (extended vowel-sound anagrams of a key word or words
spread THROUGH other words across the poem like a kind of thematic bass-note).
I dug this up following an essay about, yes, again, sorry, Mandelstam,
which investigated the AMAZING anagrammatic fireworks in M's 1st poem
from his 1st bk ("I am given a body - what to do with it?").  Saussure
is aware of the danger of research solipsism, given the small # of vowel
sounds, a line's undertone can be read in myriad ways - but he discovers
some remarkable symmetries.  Hart Crane was a master of this kind of thing.

>
>To ask the meaning is to assume there is one, or that there's a process
>going on and what set it off is interesting and what will follow it is
>interesting. Maybe the meaning going on is sluggish? Maybe the critical
>will to proscribe (to place bets on?) what goes on *now* is off? But if
>it's not, then I'm placing my bets on what Henry's mentioned, the phonemic
>shuffle -- but with this corollary -- the paraphrasable meaning has to be
>as unfamiliar and overdetermined as the sound combinations are -- viz the
>recent work of Ben Friedlander, the lunch poems of Tim Davis, "Eon" by Kim
>Lyons, practically anything by Ange Mlinko. But I wouldn't bet
>_everything_, my printing press goes too slowly for that.
>
>Anyway, to echo Mark Wallace's call for a CONSCIOUS exploration of multiple
>approaches (as opposed to what Mark characterizes as a naive "anything
>goes" polymorphousness -- more about that dichotomy, Mark?) I'm more
>comfortable looking at Andrews' work as a reductio ad infinitum of
>Pound/Olson's idea that each poem must take its own form. Alice Notley's
>work has a similar impulse -- do a different thing. Those might be some
>interesting trajectories to track -- any grad schools out there with cash?

The key word up there is "overdetermined".  As Jordan & Mark is saying,
multiple approaches should be looked for not only in the generational
"scene" but within individual writers' works & individual WORKS. There's
no simple formula for styles & schools.  The phonemic shuffle, for example,
can be understood not only as a "subtext" or undertone but as a method
of producing poetry (see OM's "Conversation abt Dante" on the malleability
of "poetic instruments") - which clearly is related to jazz improvization
& glossolalia too.  Words themselves become amazingly malleable under
pressure (did anyone see the article in Times science section today about
quantum "tunneling" through walls etc.?) - really very much like CLAY -
and can be molded to "mean" literally dozens of things simultaneously
(I'm mouthing the obvious for many of you out there).
- Henry G.

On Tue, 22 Jul 1997, George Thompson wrote:

> A tardy response to Henry Gould's interesting post, in particular to:
>
> "To me the langpos haven't gone FAR ENOUGH
> in the direction of the microstructure, and an interesting development
> in the future will be toward Saussure's ideas about anagrams & paranomasia.
> Hart Crane was into this: "anagrammatize your Name", etc.  Saussure
> found a pervasive subtext underneath a lot of classic latin poetry -
> the whole poem would be the scattered (Osiris) fragments of a thematic
> single WORD.  Thematic - & referential.  Build on it.   The poem as
> architecture.  Mandelstam again.  & Yeats, too.  heck yeah."
>
> Saussure is a VERY interesting linguist, one who, like Jakobson, should be
> of great interest to poets in general. Of course he is best known for his
> "Course in General Linguistics" which triggered that language revolution
> which I'm sure you're all familiar with [structuralism, semiology, etc].
> But as Henry points out he did very interesting work on poetic
> "microstructure" too [on an earlier thread there was discussion of
> sub-lexical, sub-morphemic, and even sub-phonemic analysis: Saussure worked
> very fruitfully on such things].
>
> Although he triggered a revolution, Saussure was also a master of the
> old-style  comparative linguistics [etymology, reconstruction, etc.].
> Non-specialists often don't realize that Saussure pulled off one of the
> most impressive stunts in the history of linguistics. In his doctoral
> dissertation [he was 21 yrs old!], using the comparative method, he posited
> the existence of "sonant coefficients" that *must have existed* in the
> parent language, Proto-Indo-European, long-dead. This series of sounds did
> not survive in any known language, but accd to S's analysis, they must once
> have existed, way back in pre-history. Well, a generation or two later,
> well after S's death, Hittite was discovered, and when it was deciphered,
> guess what was found? The Hittite language, very archaic, preserved these
> very "sonant coefficients" exactly where S predicted they would be [they
> are now known as 'laryngeals']! This is an astonishing demonstration of the
> fact that the theoretical constructs of historical linguistics had a
> verifiable basis in reality [in real languages].
>
> Saussure was also interesting for other, less mainstream, interests, such
> as the notebooks on anagrams that Henry cites. If it is feasible to write a
> book on Vedic poetics now, as I am trying to do, it is largely because
> Saussure and Jakobson have opened the eyes of Vedicists to things in
> "their"texts that they had not seen, in spite of 200 yrs of looking.
>
> Then there is the matter of Martian poetics, which Saussure explored when
> he was invited to examine the glossolalia of a Mdme. Helene Smith, "famous
> clairvoyante". His researches are treated in Th. Flournoy's _From India to
> the Planet Mars_, recently reprinted somewhere.
>
> When I teach Jakobson in a course on linguistics & literature, I suggest
> that J's conception of the poem is that it is a Rube Goldberg machine [=
> Henry's 'poem as architecture'].
>
> Try to imagine Emily Vey Duke's recent poem as a Rube Goldberg machine ["a
> small one"].
>
> George T
>

actually, Gwyn, i have that problem too (missing words). except the words i
forget are simple words which makes me very frustrated ("it's a simple,
fucking word!... hand! that's it! HAND me the hammer!"). i have a similar
problem with directions, with trying to visual directions in my head from
memory. most times i can't do it at all. my mind will actually go blank --
nothing there -- like my mind is saying "don't EVEN go there!"

There's a billboard ad for Honda cars that i see every day that i drive
home from work and it shows a Honda car and above it are the words:

Slam! Slam! Slam! Slam!

but my mind at first, second and third pass tells me:

Slap! Slarn! Slam! Slarn!

I thought everyone read well. I was struck by the _physicality_ of the
readers--two dancers, an ice-skater-turned-long-distance cyclist, a
maseuse,a long-distance runner : and was wondering whether the learned
ability to objectify one's body doesnt bleed over into an awareness of the
poem as an autonomous object--an awareness so often missing in your
would-be poet, an awareness that understands poetry is something else than
"i open my mouth and the words stream out, bound for poetry!" Layne
Russell, Catherine Bowers, Cydney Chadwick, Jayne MacPherson, Karen
Eberhardt--thanks to you all.

The radio i'view Layne Russell alludes to was in fact a talk on Beckett I
gave because no-one around here reads him any more as far as I can
discover.

On another matter, I am not so much "witty and charming" as indifferent and
bewildered, by turns. WWhen I am not getting on someone's case, at which
point, nothing is too small for me. I advance these disclaimer because I
shall be traveling back east this fall, & want to avoid disappointing
people looking for noel coward. I'm a grumpy old fart, but you can still be
my friend. David B

OED--as for 1883, I would have thought it to be the reverse


parataxis pæratæ;ksis. Gram. [mod.a. Gr. paratacij a placing side by
side, f.
paratass-ein to place side by side, f. para- para-1 1 + tassein to
arrange, tacij
arrangement.] The placing of propositions or clauses one after another,
without indicating by
connecting words the relation (of co-ordination or subordination)
between them.

     1842 in Brande Dict. Sci. etc.

     1883 B. L. Gildersleeve in Amer. Jrnl. Philol. IV. 420 Now to make
hypotaxis out
     of parataxis we must have a joint.

     1888 W. Leaf Iliad II. 414 A good instance of primitive parataxis,
two clauses being
     merely set side by side.
--
Bob Grotjohn

A Martian poem for the list's delectation [n.b. diacritic marks go with the
preceding letter]:

mode' tanine'e ce' ke' mache radzire' ze' tarvini
va nini nini trime'ne^ni ii adzi
ce' ze' sei=A8mire' ve'tiche
i mode' ine'e ke'vi be'rimir m hed
machiri ce' di trine' ti e'stotine' ni baze'e animina
i mode' ce' me'i=A8 adzi iline'e
i mode' ine'e ce' ke' le' naze`re ani --
mira^ mode' itatine'e
mira^ mira^ mira^

Translation:

My dearest, I cannot pronounce the language
in which we understood each other so well!
I understand it, however!
Oh! adored mother, when will it return?
When shall I be able to speak to thee of my last and short existence?
Oh! mother, I have well recognized thee
Oh! mother, I am not mistaken!
=46arewell, dearest mother,
farewell, farewell, farewell!

N.B. Being no Martiologist myself, I give this in Flournoy's rather florid
translation [itself translated from the florid French].

Henry, do you smell any Alexandrian rotten eggs here? Or Martian marigolds?

George T

p.s. Yes, Russian poets and critics have been there [I mean Mir] for quite
some time.

>parataxis pfratf;ksis. Gram. [mod.a. Gr. paratacij a placing side by
>side, f.
>paratass-ein to place side by side, f. para- para-1 1 + tassein to
>arrange, tacij
>arrangement.] The placing of propositions or clauses one after another,
>without indicating by
>connecting words the relation (of co-ordination or subordination)
>between them.
>
>     1842 in Brande Dict. Sci. etc.
>
>     1883 B. L. Gildersleeve in Amer. Jrnl. Philol. IV. 420 Now to make
>hypotaxis out
>     of parataxis we must have a joint.
>
>     1888 W. Leaf Iliad II. 414 A good instance of primitive parataxis,
>two clauses being
>     merely set side by side.

>Bob Grotjohn

I like the original.  Reminds me of a dialect I learned as a wee lad in
the scandinavian wilds of upstate MN : Unfinnish.
Though the civic ambience is not easy to detect on the surface, the poem
does have a public side.  Can you find it?  Down around the 4th hypogrammatic
level, there's a key theme-word there: EUREKA.  & if you scan for anagram-
vowels in the TRANSLATION, you get the following:
GREETINGS, EARTHLINGS.  BOW DOWN BEFORE YOUR MASTERS, THE RULERS OF MARS.
(As everyone knows, the poem was recited from the pod door back in the 30s
when they landed in New Jersey.)

"Aporia" is one of those words that makes me feel queasy.  Maybe because
it is faintly recursive [is that word "dictionary" in the dictionary?].
When EA Poe was wooing SH Whitman in Providence, he wrote out a
copy of his poem "To Helen" & then FOLDED IT LIKE AN ENVELOPE & sent it
to her (pearl-lined) in the mail. They thought they were twins.  SH's
father's name was Power; one version of Poe's family name was Poer.
They weren't really related.
- Eric Blarnes

Subject:      repetitions
In-Reply-To:  <1997721221855241@ix.netcom.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

I agree with Joel that repetitions of topics within short time frames can
be frustrating. But I think web behavior is such that there's not much to
do about this. People do come onto lists all the time and have concerns
that have come up before. And if anyone did a statistical study I would
hazard a prediction that a tiny percentage of people ever go back through
archives, rather than try to get answers or conversation going immediately.
Personally, if this list was always at such a level of new ideas that it
was consistently compelling for me, then it would be nearly too much and I
wouldn't have enough time for it at all. As is, I can go through periods
where I don't participate much at all, skimming for the most part, yet
joining in again when something moves me to do so.

Compared with another list I'm on, concerned with design for the web, the
repetition on poetics is slight. But on the webdesign list, it's usually a
question of someone who needs to know some java trick, and asking for help.
Then a couple of weeks later, someone else needs to know basically the same
thing, and asks for it. Often I'm glad for the repetition, in case I failed
to note the code in the first place.

And here, I do find that the repetitions aren't usually exact, and it's
good to hear new voices.

I think there's a web-sociology list out there somewhere which discusses
how people behave on the web & why, how lists tend to work and be
repetitive, etc. I don't have the address handy, but perhaps someone else
does.

Still, for the most part I have to agree with Joel's post, and say that
it's always good to hear from you, Joel.

charles

Charles,

On Alta Vista I looked up "hot;dog and origin;of"

I found the following under the wordwizard site:
http://wordwizard.com/club/askww/

It has the orgins of lots of fun words.

---------------------------------------------------

                                                                     Ask
The Word Wizard

hot dog - the American version for frankfurter

Question:

What is the derivation of "hot dog" I have several students (ESL) that I am
tutoring and I con't explain this term to them.

Frederick Gilmore (Traverse City - U.S.A.)
Mar 16, 1997

Answer:

This is the enrty from my forthcoming Casell's Dictionary of Slang (pub. 1998)

hot dog n. [late 19C+] (orig. US) a spiced, heated sausage, served on a
split roll and garnished, traditionally, with 'rags and paint': sauerkraut
and mustard;

2. the penis (cf. HIDE THE HOT DOG).

Ety:

[SE since c. 1939, when it was served under that name by the Coney Island
Chamber of Commerce to President Franklin D. Roosevelt and his guests, King
George VI and Queen Elizabeth of England, the hot dog started life as
slang. It probably comes from heavy-handed mid-19C humour focussing on the
supposed use of horse- and dog-meat as sausage filling, a concept that was
accentuated by the 1843 scandal concerning the use of dog-meat for human
consumption. The image was intensified by the use c. 1860 by German
immigrants of hundewurst: dog sausage to mean smoked frankfurter sausages
(larger sausages were pferdwurst: horse baloney); the dachshund, of course
was a `sausage dog']

---------------------------------------------------

Sorry to bring up definition #2!

Dodie

At 08:45 PM 7/22/97 -0700, you wrote:
>and in many parts of the country, including Detroit (which I just
>visited), those things are still called "Coney Islands" --
>
>anybody know when "hot dog" got to mean "top gun"?
>

1976 OED Supplement:
1.a. -N. Amer. slang_ ...1896 W.C. Gore in _Inlander_, _Hot Dog_, good,
superior. "He has made some hot-dog drawings for---.'
1900 _Dialect Notes_ II. 1. One very proficient in certain things. 2. A hot
sausage. 3. A hard student. 4. A conceited person. (followed by several
examples of 1.)
2. A hot sausage enclosed as a sandwich in a bread roll. orig. _U.S._

Examples that follow, from O.Henry in 1908, Sinclair Lewis (Main Street, no
less) in 1920, and three others in the twenties and early thirties, suggest
that it was firmly established in its present senses by then. The guess as
to origin in Dodie's communication is as good as any; could also be that the
"hot dog" was the leader of the pack, or a good dog in the dog-fight ring,
and got applied to the sausage as an approbation.
Aldon--more on "Coney Islands?" I've never heard the usage. I would guess
that it comes from the brand-name "Coney Island Franks" from the '70s, I think.

        Yesterday re paronomasia i noted the use of this in some
contemporary Russian poetry.  not having the reference to hand was not
specific (i.e. not poetic practice which is specific) so here is an
excellent reference that may be of much use to those interested:

        Vsevolod Nekrasov, Master Paronymist

by Gerald Janecek
         in Slavic and East European Journal Volume 33 Number 2
         Summer 1989 275-292


        From Professor Janecek i understand the essay will be included as
well in a forthcoming collection of his essays.
        I would also very highly recommened to anyone interested in
Russian Futurism his most recent book from San Diego State UP
        Zaum  The Transrational Poetry of Russian Futurism
        The book is for most part focused on this writer's exemplar
Kruchonykh.  Examples of Kruchonykh's work and excerpts from Professor
Janecek's book may be found at Light and Dust Mobile Anthology of Poetry at
        http://www.thing.net/~grist/homekarl.htm

        Henry Gould noted re anagram a book by John Irwin on Borges and
Poe to which add a very high recommendation for another book of Irwin's
American Hieroglyphs which is concerned with the influence of the then
recently translated Egyptian hieroglyphs on the writers of the "American
Renaissance"--esp. Melville and Poe's Narrative of Arthur Gordon Pym.
        Robert Smithson in his great essay (concerns art as well as
poetry and poets writing art criticism) "A Sedimentation of the Mind:
Earth Projects" recommends Poe's book as excellent art criticism and
presentation of "proto-earthwords".
--davebaptistechirography

Gywn:

Hypotaxis--which refers to subordination, arranging under, etc.
as opposed to parataxis which refers to arranging side by side or
juxtaposing.  A lot on these distinctions in various studies on Pound.

From:         Herb Levy <herb@ESKIMO.COM>
Subject:      Re: L-Dopa
In-Reply-To:  <POETICS%97072210372904@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

>On Tue, 22 Jul 1997 09:57:50 -0400 Jordan Davis said:
>>
>>Implicit in Bob's description of performance poetry is the idea that a poet
>>is better off where the contract is clearer -- i.e. where the audience
>>knows that they don't know the rules. (Viz Rod Smith's post -- inspiration
>>comes from listening to Bird -- bop ((like abstract expression)) being a
>>systematization of surprise ((or maybe just a few simultaneous incarnations
>>of Shiva in the world?)) -- the jazz audience contracting to have their
>>minds blown -- to know that they werent' going to know -- to be ok with
>>that -- the parallels between bop and serialism?)
>
>just a coupla comments on the always-always posts of JD & his aliases.
>I have trouble relating the poet/listener contract described(?) here with
>be-bop.  Other extensions of jazz, maybe (O. Coleman? Sun-Ra?) - but in
>bop I hear a lot of form, control, expectations.  Not that I'm an expert.

Jordan & Henry,

You're both right about be-bop, you're just writing about two different
moments in its life cycle.  I'll continue with the musical analogy, despite
clear differences in how things work in the performing arts, I think the
potential parallels are also clear.

There was a time when bop was the very essence of the sound of surprise (to
swipe a phrase from Whitney Bailliett), though now it's rare (though
certainly not impossible) for an improvisor to play bop with the kind of
freshness of the folks who developed the form.  More often someone playing
be-bop nowadays is someone who learned it as a set of rules, possibly in an
accredited degree program, rather than someone who's using it as a language
system to create within.  Over time, innovation calcifies into form which
in turn calcifies further into cliche. (Late SunRa performances, for
instance, were mostly sloppy versions of swing-era tunes, hardly the Magic
City or HeliocentricWorlds). Interesting sometimes, but not always inspired
or inspiring.

While I'm not advocating that more musicians (whether they play jazz or
grunge) becoming junkies, there is something dis-concerting about hearing a
bunch of very clean & very straight high school kids who have learned the
rules of playing be-bop "correctly" - in most, though not all, cases, I'd
rather hear their rock bands.

This is probably true for most (again, though, not all) post-bop forms of
improvisation, or for that matter, most performing arts.   To bring it
around (I think) to Jordan's point, though this is my take on it, not his:
one can learn the formal structures of a style at any time, but there's a
point after which one can not partake of the community of peer out of which
the style developed.

To use a non-musical example, is it possible to imagine an emerging poet
using some of the formal procedures of, say, Language poetry, to write a
work that was non-ironically supportive of, say, the views of the Christian
Right?

I'm not (just) arguing for a simple form of "authenticity" here, there are
(shudder) those who'll say one shouldn't play "free improv" unless it's
clear that one can "really" play other kinds of music, but there's often
less room for irony, sarcasm, irreverence, etc. among artists who don't
have some kind of stylistic ownership.

(On the other hand, considering Jordan's use of a parallel with serialism,
perhaps he's thinking of listeners who know the rules as a language, as the
musicians do which happens before the calcification of the forms, but after
the initial development by the originating community of artists.

(For that matter, one of the most effective definitions of new music I know
of is simply "music you haven't heard before."  So maybe you should just
forget all of the above, especially to whatever extent it may pertain to
any possible parallels with poetry or other art forms.)

Bests,

Herb


Herb Levy
herb@eskimo.com

From:         Mark Wallace <mdw@GWIS2.CIRC.GWU.EDU>
Subject:      Mike Gold
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Anyone wanting an interesting take on Mike Gold might want to look at
Richard Hofstaetler's (sorry about the spelling, but I don't have the book
here) great book from the 60s, ANTI-INTELLECTUALISM IN AMERICA. There's a
fascinating section on the Communist Party and Gold, reading it in the
larger context of how intellectuality and anti-intellectuality have been
at odds in American labor movements. If I remember correctly, RH quotes
from one individual at the time (who was later described by people in the
party as "terminally Bohemian," or something like that) talking about Gold
as the intellectual who had MOST absorbed a sense of guilt about being
intellectual, and therefore as the MOST ready to idealize the working man
and deny his own non-working class roots. I think Ron Silliman is right to
call him a "delicate stylist," but Gold was paranoid enough about his lack
of "working class masculinity" that he probably would have been tempted to
slug anyone who called him "delicate" about anything.

Mark Wallace

Date:         Wed, 23 Jul 1997 15:37:04 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Mark Wallace <mdw@GWIS2.CIRC.GWU.EDU>
Subject:      elaborating multiples
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Thanks very much, Jordan, for suggesting that I might say more! What could
be more fun than elaborating!

        I think, in this case, that Henry Gould's comment is almost
exactly what I mean--a conscious multiplicity of form in a writer might
seek a radical alteration of formal perspective from book to book, from
poem to poem, or even within a single poem. It's one of the things my own
poetry has been about, frankly. My first book was very much about
shifts in perspective from line to line; I've done very lyrical work like
in my Standing Stones chapbook and in things like the Oblek anthology; I
published a book of Sonnets last year (not quite traditional ones); I've
worked with chance and "deterministic" techniques in an issue of Abacus;
and my soon to be available Edge Book might be taken for Ron Silliman-like
parataxis if I
didn't so consistently lack his intelligence. Some books I've done have
been more or less in a single structure which I then don't use again;
other things I've done shift structure within the work. I published in
AVEC, "The Necessity of Feet" a 12-page poem in which the
form of each page was consciously different, and I've done that several
other times as well. I've been pushing this structural shift within works
lately; I've got a piece I think of as a long (about 50 page) poem in
which I try to call up as many different structural shifts as I can think
of, although certain structures do repeat (I'm not so interested in
complete differences of structure as I am in the tension between
similarity and difference in structure).

So that's where I'm at. What this attempt has to do with the work of other
writers of my generation is not clear. Certainly my attempt is NOT new or
particular to this moment in time, but I'm less interested in whether it's
new as in whether it feels worthwhile at this moment, and I think it does.
By no means do I think of my own attempt as characterizing the work of
other writers of my generation--it clearly does NOT characterize them, or
at least more than some of them. But while I am sympathetic to Henry's
assertion that the matter CAN'T be considered from merely a generational
perspective, what I DO think is true is that many writers of my own
generation (which is more or less yours, Jordan, I guess, maybe) have a
different relation to the history of the poetries we've
read. And I think the difference is THIS; that because of historical
circumstances, many of us have learned about more differing traditions of
poetry than any previous generation of writers, which gives us both
increasing options as well as increasing irony about the idea that some
"new" direction in poetry is going to save or make anybody. Some of my
langauge poetry friends describe coming up in a time where repression of
poetic possibilities seemed the rule, but equally a time in which they
seem to have felt that their poetic revolution would be heard, someplace
or other. My own sense is more like I can do anything I want in poetry,
with little chance of it being heard anywhere. This is a bit of an
exaggeration, of course, but it's like what they say about freedom of
speech in the U.S.--you can say what you want because nobody's
listening. I don't, for the most part, encounter students or even
professors who are "resistant" to formally experimental poetry, or who
desire formally traditional verse. I encounter students and professors who
usually don't read any contemporary poetry at all. There are obviously a
few exceptions, but I do mean a FEW. And certainly it's true that more
formally conservative approaches still get most of whatever CASH there is
in poetry.

Non-poetry people are probably not the point, of course, so I'll get
back to the subject. In his forthcoming article, Mark Ducharme is right
that my arguments don't DESCRIBE the writers of my generation. But I never
meant them to. Still, what IS at stake in a description of such writers?
And I think there are some pretty interesting answers here. If these
writers are characterized by "diversity," then we're describing a kind of
free-for-all smorgasborg of writers borrowing from various traditions all
of which are okay. But we're not NECESSARILY describing writers with
consciousness about form, or writers working out of any more than singular
traditions. IN the worst case scenario, for my money, we all end up
seeming borrowers of earlier and more vital traditions--Jordan Davis and
Lee Ann Brown are latter-day New York School, Rod Smith and Jefferson
Hansen are latter-day language poets, Jennifer Moxley likes traditional
lyrics, Lisa Jarnot is just imitating Bernadette Mayer. And I've heard
enough arguments LIKE that to know that the risk that things will be taken
that way is real. But it would also, of course, be wrong.

So I see a number of reasons for polemically asserting the value NOT of a
free smorgasborg of traditions but of a conscious shifting, rearranging,
and perhaps violating of the various poetic frameworks which existed
before we did and which became part of our education. I'm not sure whether
Joel's post indicated some annoyance with ME that these issues keep coming
up, but as long as people keeping asking questions like "What's
next?" I see a value in trying to answer them, even if part of that answer
must be a deconstruction of the question. And the issue is NOT simply
about anxiety regarding language poetry--it's about finding poetic
structures that make SENSE as a response to the world in which we find
ourselves. And I don't think that's a question that any poet can really
avoid. My saying that, of course, won't make it so--I think where Mark D's
point about diversity has the drop on me is that MY conviction about what
matters will never be everybody else's. Thankfully, I guess, and not, I
guess.

Mark Wallace

About Sun Ra: there's an interesting new biography of him [I forget the
details]. Unfortunately, one of his sisters is quoted as saying, her eyes
rolling upward in exasperation, that he was born and raised right here on
earth.... But maybe she's missed something, or has an axe to grind.

Other members of the Martian poetics lineage might include St. Paul [yes,
that's right]. He was a glossolalist too, though for some reason he
attributed his inspiration to the Holy Ghost rather than to Mars.

The Jakobson-Khlebnikov connection is very clear. I wonder if K. was
familiar with Saussure's work on Martian, published in Flournoy's book in
1900?

Many others could be mentioned, but I think esp. of Borges. Apparently he
had something to to with the following homophonic translation of Saussure's
Martian text:

>mode' tanine'e ce' ke' mache radzire' ze' tarvini
>va nini nini trime'ne^ni ii adzi
>ce' ze' sei=A8mire' ve'tiche
>i mode' ine'e ke'vi be'rimir m hed
>machiri ce' di trine' ti e'stotine' ni baze'e animina
>i mode' ce' me'i=A8 adzi iline'e
>i mode' ine'e ce' ke' le' naze`re ani --
>mira^ mode' itatine'e
>mira^ mira^ mira^
>
Homophonic Translation:

mode' tanine'e ce' ke' mache radzire' ze' tarvini
va nini nini trime'ne^ni ii adzi
ce' ze' sei=A8mire' ve'tiche
i mode' ine'e ke'vi be'rimir m hed
machiri ce' di trine' ti e'stotine' ni baze'e animina
i mode' ce' me'i=A8 adzi iline'e
i mode' ine'e ce' ke' le' naze`re ani --
mira^ mode' itatine'e
mira^ mira^ mira^

It strikes me as being both *very* literal and *very* accurate, more so
than Zukofsky's Catullus, though perhaps less lyrical and not as funny.

GT.

[no sign of activity on the Sanskrit front]

>anybody know when "hot dog" got to mean "top gun"?

In most sports and activities modelled on sports, a hot dog is a show off
who makes the play look tougher than it was, or who uses more flair than
Joe DiMaggio would. You always shout something like this at him: "Hey! You
want mustard with that?"

Thank you, George, for transversing us the Borgesian "wedge extractum"
as it's called in 4th planet lingo.  While I agree that this is by far
the most accurate homophonicism of the text we have, I do hear a very
faint temblor in Borges' rendition here of "nini nini trime'ne-ni"
(transcribing his transposition, if I mighty be so bold) - the 2nd "nini"
- a repetition in miniature of an initial non-repetitive repetition -
seems drenched in a red-planet pampas atmosphere that only Borges (or
JLB, as his nemesis LBJ used to taunt him) could corral. E verde?
- Enrique Los Bastolos-Michaelski da Entrada dos Corralles

        one last Martian before i go/to the valley below to paraphrase
bob dylan
        Roky Erikson leadsinger/songwriter/vocalist with the legendary
Thirteenth Floor Elevators and later with his various Aliens bands in
interviews often speaks of his inspiration coming from Mars.  on a
double lp collection of work by musicians on the old International
Artists label out of Houston (run by Kenny Rogers' cousin Leland, the
label included besides the Elevators the original Red Krayola, Bubble
Puppy and Lightnin' Hopkins) Roky tells an interviewer that
the Punk classic (see Nuggets vol. one from Rhino or the old double LP on
Sire) "You're Gonna Miss Me" is about the creature from the Black Lagoon
and messages from Mars
        There are two volumes out now of Roky's writings. (Can't recall
the publisher.) He has moved from Houston to Austin--maybe too much
competition from the NASA crowd in Houston for Martian messages?
        There is a tribute CD/double cassette out for Roky and many great
covers of his work.  For "You're Gonna Miss Me" see DMZ--the lp and
various live recordings and the Nomads Stagger in the Snow collection.
Also one by Doug Sahm on Border Wave lp.
        Then there was "Flying Saucers Rock and Roll" by Billy Lee Riley
and His Little Green Men" . . .  which you can get on most Sun rockabilly
collections . . .
dbchiromancy

I believe this is a project whose home for a long time, and perhaps still,
was at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. It was under the direction of
Fred Cassady for years, perhaps decades, and the research was so thorough
that it seemed everyone knew this was a project that volumes might be
issued years apart from one another. But that was about as much as I knew
about its status about 16 or so years ago. Now? I don't know -- any
Wisconsin folk on this list who know about it?

hole."

It tastes better than it sounds. But then again, it is English fare.

In the midwest and in California, the two dialects I'm most familiar with,
hot dogs in a corn batter are called corn dogs.

spoke of pigs in the blanket, we meant stuffed cabbages.
