Subject:      Words Worth (fwd)
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

-


Words Worth


I would love to lie with Julu, unfold
Her flap of skin from where it joins
This perineum, or Jennifer, unstitched
In that vast region between one nipple
And the other's vacancy and stare;
Still, somewhere bleak I recognize
These impulses as extra-current voices
Ceasing precisely at a certain temperature,
Beginning once again as world and room fall quiet
And my too comfortable bed holds all at once.
O Julu, I would cry, O Jennifer, and turning
Then from one unto the other, homeward-bound,
I'd once again be whole and hole identical,
The perfect rose within the perfect vase,
Or perfect home within a perfect vale.
But now, I wake, another scar appears
Across my bleak pleateaus of sheltered skins,
And it will take until my death reigns down
For such writing to complete, to cease -
Then, and only then, will others come
And read my body, what I could not, across
The corpse of Alan, Julu, Jennifer.
I write myself for you, and you, I think;
I cannot read these letters that I write -
They were not meant for me, what may contain
The vast appeal of great uncertain worlds,
Which I could be but vessel, channel, woman,
Of Julu, Jennifer, Alan, tribe of woman,
Not that a story would not have started forth
From half-dead lips, breath, pale exhalation;
The flap of skin, the surgery, is all
The fuel I have left, as well as memory
Of fuel, triad, scar, and conflagration.


____________________________________________________________________

From:         Hugh Steinberg <hsteinberg@GRIN.NET>
Subject:      Re: What came before?a Martian poetics 1986
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Jordan writes:
>
>PS what about a contrarian poetics of consensus ... the difference between
>parliamentary debate and collaboration is .. what?

Actually, they're the same thing, in that they both operate under an agreed
upon set of rules.  In parliamentary debate you have a loyal opposition,
who hopefully is just that:  they disagree with you, but they're not going
to overthrow the state either, and they have as much an investment in the
structures and institutions in the society as the ruling party.

I think this is a valuable concept to understand when thinking about poetry
and poetics, specifically when considering the way we all interact with
each other, and the way in which people outside of our communities interact
with us.

There's a lot of poetry I like, and there's a lot I don't, but at a
fundamental level there is just poetry and the forces trying to silence it.

To illustrate my point: a short while ago there was much discussion about
APR, both good and ill, particularly towards the type of writing it
published.  Would we be better off if it ceased publication?  How about
Poetryflash (which nearly did cease publication) or any other journal,
reading series, publisher?  Would we be better off if the Green Mill or the
Nuyorican Cafe got out of the poetry business?  If a goodly number of MFA
programs went defunct?  How 'bout this list?

From an institutional level, I don't really care about what people write
about or how well they write.  All I care about is that there will be
places where these people (and that includes us) can be heard.

Hugh Steinberg

At 6:01 PM -0700 7/23/97, dbkk@SIRIUS.COM wrote:
>At 10:43 AM +1200 7/24/97, DS wrote:
>>In NZ a hot dog is a sausage in batter - distinct from a sausage in sandwich
>>- whcih we call an american hot dog
>
>In the midwest and in California, the two dialects I'm most familiar with,
>hot dogs in a corn batter are called corn dogs.
>

yes, corndogs! and at the MN State Fair, it is de rigueur to eat them "on a
stick" --that is, impaled on a disposable, slender wooden wand.  this
obviates the need for a protective bun of dough to hold while mustard,
ketchup, sauerkraut and juice from punctured dog splatters the face and
potentially the hands.  that is, the corn dog has none of the above, just a
husk of corn batter and a stick.  other Fair food includes "wisconsin
cheese curds" (plastic bags of inch-long/wide bits of cheese),
"mini-donuts" (or "minnedonuts," heavily sugared and made right in front of
you!  and all the milk you can drink for $.25.  one of the hilites of the
fair is the array of butter sculptures of Miss Dairy 1997. (i always thot
dylan was making up the butter sculpture concept in Tarantula).

At 9:15 PM -0400 7/23/97, Alan J Sondheim wrote:
>-
>
>
>Words Worth
>
>
>I would love to lie with Julu, unfold
>Her flap of skin from where it joins
>This perineum, or Jennifer, unstitched
>In that vast region between one nipple
>And the other's vacancy and stare;
>Still, somewhere bleak I recognize
>These impulses as extra-current voices
>Ceasing precisely at a certain temperature,
>Beginning once again as world and room fall quiet
>And my too comfortable bed holds all at once.
>O Julu, I would cry, O Jennifer, and turning
>Then from one unto the other, homeward-bound,
>I'd once again be whole and hole identical,
>The perfect rose within the perfect vase,
>Or perfect home within a perfect vale.
>But now, I wake, another scar appears
>Across my bleak pleateaus of sheltered skins,
>And it will take until my death reigns down
>For such writing to complete, to cease -
>Then, and only then, will others come
>And read my body, what I could not, across
>The corpse of Alan, Julu, Jennifer.
>I write myself for you, and you, I think;
>I cannot read these letters that I write -
>They were not meant for me, what may contain
>The vast appeal of great uncertain worlds,
>Which I could be but vessel, channel, woman,
>Of Julu, Jennifer, Alan, tribe of woman,
>Not that a story would not have started forth
>>From half-dead lips, breath, pale exhalation;
>The flap of skin, the surgery, is all
>The fuel I have left, as well as memory
>Of fuel, triad, scar, and conflagration.
>
>
>____________________________________________________________________
wowie kazowie alan jj

Well, my Scottish mother used to cut a hole in a piece of bread and fry an
egg in it - that's what a toad in the hole must be on the Partick side of
Glasgow...but it's a good name for your band...In Sydney at the Royal Easter
Show they used to call the NZ version of a hot dog - saveloys in batter -
"Pluto Pups" or "Dagwood Dogs" - they were on little plywood sticks and
covered in tomato sauce...urk

From:         Susan Wheeler <wheeler@IS.NYU.EDU>
Subject:      Re: POETICS Digest - 22 Jul 1997 to 23 Jul 1997
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Re various threads:  DARE is now 3 volumes, from Harvard UP.  Random House
has a comparable project, a Historical Dictionary of American Slang, but
DARE is the standard.  Volume 3 is through O, so too early for pigs in a
blanket, but I remember clearly the picture of these items from my Betty
Crocker Boys & Girls cookbook and they were full-size dogs in biscuit dough.
Of course Chicago has red hots too.  And isn't the Sun Ra bio by John Swed?

Apropos of DARE, there is a great journal out of the University of Alabama
Press (editorial at Duke) published for the American Dialect Society,
American Speech: A Quarterly of Linguistic Usage.  At $20/year it is a slang
maven's dream for its "Among the New Words" feature at the back of the book.
Its papers are often amazing too: the winter 1996 includes "Transmission
Languages and Source Languages of Chinese Borrowings in English," "Cultural
Sensitivity and Political Correctness: The Linguistic Problem of Naming,"
and "The Development of the Strong Obligation System in American English."
Although I admit I first tracked it down for an article on regional
differences in current teenagers' slang for penis, the gamut keeps me in its
debt.

Susan Wheeler
wheeler@is.nyu.edu
voice/fax (212) 254-3984

I first came upon corndogs, so yclept, as an adult at New England county
fairs. Be interesting to know what the geographic vector was. Little
cocktail franks wrapped in dough and deep-fried were a standard at Bar
Mitzvahs. I don't remember what we called them, certainly not pigs in a
blanket, a term I learned only when my world became more cosmopolitan.
My first wife used to reminisce about the round of competitive Bar Mitzvah
receptions that she went to, each more elaborate than the last. At the
penultimate one there were huge swans carved out of ice. The final Bar
Mitzvah featured a life-size sculpture of the Bar Mitzvah boy in full
regalia. He was the presumptive heir to the Joyva Halvah fortune, and that
was the medium in which the sculptor worked.
What's the phrase, "no flies on him?"

From:         Rachel Loden <rloden@CONCENTRIC.NET>
Subject:      Re: Mike Gold
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Thanks, Mark, for the tip on the Hofstadter book.  Fascinating what he
says about Gold's class roots--Michael Harrington is spinning quite a
different (could it be mythologized?) tale in the afterword to _Jews
Without Money_:

"He [Gold] was born Irwin Granich in 1893 on the Lower East Side of New
York.  The child of a Roumanian immigrant family, he went to work at the
age of twelve like the character in _Jews Without Money_ (the book is as
much autobiography as it is fiction).  As he later told it, he had 'no
politics. . .except hunger' until he was nineteen..."

Very odd.  Found this, from Katherine Anne Porter, which seems to
support the Hofstadter:

"Once on the picket line, I took a good look at the crowd moving slowly
forward. I wouldn't have expected to see some of them on the same
street, much less the same picket line and in the same jail. I knew very
few people in that first picket line, but I remember Lola Ridge, John
Dos Passos, Paxton Hibben, Michael Gold, Helen O'Lochlain Crowe, James
Rorty, Edna St. Vincent Millay, Willie Gropper, Grace Lumpkin, all very
well known then and mostly favorably--most of them have vanished, and I
wonder who but me is alive to remember them now? I have a strangely
tender memory of them all, as well as the faces of strangers who were
being led away by the police.

We were as miscellaneous, improbable, almost entirely unassorted a
gathering of people to one place in one cause as ever happened in this
country. I say almost because among the pickets I did not see anyone
identifiably a workingman, or 'proletarian,' as our Marxist
'dialecticians' insisted on calling everybody who worked for his living
in a factory, or as they said, 'sweatshop,' or 'slave mill,' or 'salt
mine.' It is true that these were workdays and maybe all the workingmen
were at their jobs. Suppose one of them said to his boss, 'I want a day
off, with pay, to picket for Sacco and Vanzetti.' He would be free to
picket at his leisure from then on, no doubt. There were plenty of
people of the working class there, but they had risen in the world and
had become professional paid proletarians, recruits to the
intelligentsia, dabbling in ideas as editors, lawyers, agitators,
writers who dressed and behaved and looked quite a lot like the
bourgeoisie they were out to annihilate. What a vocabulary--proletarian,
intelligentsia, bourgeoisie, dialectic--pure exotics transplanted from
the never-never-land of the theoretically classless society which could
not take root and finally withered on the stalk. Yet, they had three
classes of their own and were drawing the lines shrewdly. During that
time I went to a meeting of radicals of all kinds and shades, most of
them workers, but not all by any means; and Michael Gold made a speech
and kept repeating: 'Stick to your class, damn it, stick to your class.'
It struck me as being such good advice that I decided to take it and
tiptoed out the way one leaves church before the end."

I would guess that an internalized anti-Semitism played some role in the
Stein rant (along with the misogyny and homophobia already mentioned by
Maria D. and Ron S.), since Gold seems particularly unglued by the
notion of a Jew _with_ money.

Rachel L.

Mark Wallace wrote:
>
> Anyone wanting an interesting take on Mike Gold might want to look at
> Richard Hofstaetler's (sorry about the spelling, but I don't have the book
> here) great book from the 60s, ANTI-INTELLECTUALISM IN AMERICA. There's a
> fascinating section on the Communist Party and Gold, reading it in the
> larger context of how intellectuality and anti-intellectuality have been
> at odds in American labor movements. If I remember correctly, RH quotes
> from one individual at the time (who was later described by people in the
> party as "terminally Bohemian," or something like that) talking about Gold
> as the intellectual who had MOST absorbed a sense of guilt about being
> intellectual, and therefore as the MOST ready to idealize the working man
> and deny his own non-working class roots. I think Ron Silliman is right to
> call him a "delicate stylist," but Gold was paranoid enough about his lack
> of "working class masculinity" that he probably would have been tempted to
> slug anyone who called him "delicate" about anything.
>
> Mark Wallace

From:         Henry Gould <AP201070@BROWNVM.BROWN.EDU>
Subject:      Re: elaborating multiples
In-Reply-To:  Message of Wed, 23 Jul 1997 15:37:04 -0400 from
              <mdw@GWIS2.CIRC.GWU.EDU>

On Wed, 23 Jul 1997 15:37:04 -0400 Mark Wallace said:
--a conscious multiplicity of form in a writer might
>seek a radical alteration of formal perspective from book to book, from
>poem to poem, or even within a single poem. It's one of the things my own
>poetry has been about, frankly. My first book was very much about
>shifts in perspective from line to line; I've done very lyrical work like
>in my Standing Stones chapbook and in things like the Oblek anthology; I
>published a book of Sonnets last year (not quite traditional ones); I've
>worked with chance and "deterministic" techniques in an issue of Abacus;
>and my soon to be available Edge Book might be taken for Ron Silliman-like
>parataxis if I
>didn't so consistently lack his intelligence. Some books I've done have
>been more or less in a single structure which I then don't use again;
>other things I've done shift structure within the work. I published in

This approach reminds me of Isaiah Berlin's(?) bit about the hedgehog
and the fox - every writer is one or the other - the fox knows a little
bit about everything, the hedgehog knows a lot about one big thing.
Eventually, I suppose, by sniffing in circles for long enough,
the fox turns into a hedgehog - and after a long while, the hedgehog
begins to think she's a lot like a fox (knowing one thing is knowing
everything).  The situation Mark describes - of a complex multiverse
of differing approaches to what poetry is - seems optimal for the poet
with the confidence to absorb it & spin it around - for the one who
isn't looking for the right group but how to reflect it all back in
the "right" way - but to avoid too much pastiche & imitation would seem
to require I say again an awareness of microstructure - I am continually
amazed by some of the ancient & renaissance poets who can make a 12-line
poem - because of the minute architectonics - comparable to a large
building or ornamental tent - architectonics of both sound & multiple
meaning - classicism is voluble lotion -oo lalala goo goo gong - Henry Geewhiz

is there a heart in the goldberg machine?

>AVEC, "The Necessity of Feet" a 12-page poem in which the
>form of each page was consciously different, and I've done that several
>other times as well. I've been pushing this structural shift within works
>lately; I've got a piece I think of as a long (about 50 page) poem in
>which I try to call up as many different structural shifts as I can think
>of, although certain structures do repeat (I'm not so interested in
>complete differences of structure as I am in the tension between
>similarity and difference in structure).
>
>So that's where I'm at. What this attempt has to do with the work of other
>writers of my generation is not clear. Certainly my attempt is NOT new or
>particular to this moment in time, but I'm less interested in whether it's
>new as in whether it feels worthwhile at this moment, and I think it does.
>By no means do I think of my own attempt as characterizing the work of
>other writers of my generation--it clearly does NOT characterize them, or
>at least more than some of them. But while I am sympathetic to Henry's
>assertion that the matter CAN'T be considered from merely a generational
>perspective, what I DO think is true is that many writers of my own
>generation (which is more or less yours, Jordan, I guess, maybe) have a
>different relation to the history of the poetries we've
>read. And I think the difference is THIS; that because of historical
>circumstances, many of us have learned about more differing traditions of
>poetry than any previous generation of writers, which gives us both
>increasing options as well as increasing irony about the idea that some
>"new" direction in poetry is going to save or make anybody. Some of my
>langauge poetry friends describe coming up in a time where repression of
>poetic possibilities seemed the rule, but equally a time in which they
>seem to have felt that their poetic revolution would be heard, someplace
>or other. My own sense is more like I can do anything I want in poetry,
>with little chance of it being heard anywhere. This is a bit of an
>exaggeration, of course, but it's like what they say about freedom of
>speech in the U.S.--you can say what you want because nobody's
>listening. I don't, for the most part, encounter students or even
>professors who are "resistant" to formally experimental poetry, or who
>desire formally traditional verse. I encounter students and professors who
>usually don't read any contemporary poetry at all. There are obviously a
>few exceptions, but I do mean a FEW. And certainly it's true that more
>formally conservative approaches still get most of whatever CASH there is
>in poetry.
>
>Non-poetry people are probably not the point, of course, so I'll get
>back to the subject. In his forthcoming article, Mark Ducharme is right
>that my arguments don't DESCRIBE the writers of my generation. But I never
>meant them to. Still, what IS at stake in a description of such writers?
>And I think there are some pretty interesting answers here. If these
>writers are characterized by "diversity," then we're describing a kind of
>free-for-all smorgasborg of writers borrowing from various traditions all
>of which are okay. But we're not NECESSARILY describing writers with
>consciousness about form, or writers working out of any more than singular
>traditions. IN the worst case scenario, for my money, we all end up
>seeming borrowers of earlier and more vital traditions--Jordan Davis and
>Lee Ann Brown are latter-day New York School, Rod Smith and Jefferson
>Hansen are latter-day language poets, Jennifer Moxley likes traditional
>lyrics, Lisa Jarnot is just imitating Bernadette Mayer. And I've heard
>enough arguments LIKE that to know that the risk that things will be taken
>that way is real. But it would also, of course, be wrong.
>
>So I see a number of reasons for polemically asserting the value NOT of a
>free smorgasborg of traditions but of a conscious shifting, rearranging,
>and perhaps violating of the various poetic frameworks which existed
>before we did and which became part of our education. I'm not sure whether
>Joel's post indicated some annoyance with ME that these issues keep coming
>up, but as long as people keeping asking questions like "What's
>next?" I see a value in trying to answer them, even if part of that answer
>must be a deconstruction of the question. And the issue is NOT simply
>about anxiety regarding language poetry--it's about finding poetic
>structures that make SENSE as a response to the world in which we find
>ourselves. And I don't think that's a question that any poet can really
>avoid. My saying that, of course, won't make it so--I think where Mark D's
>point about diversity has the drop on me is that MY conviction about what
>matters will never be everybody else's. Thankfully, I guess, and not, I
>guess.
>
>Mark Wallace
>

Calling hot dogs 'Coney Islands' or, better yet, 'Coneys,' predates by
several decades the 70's brand name--they were served on the boardwalk long
before.  I think that the excellent book -Roadfood- (a state-by-state guide
to the niceties of local vernacular cuisine) sheds some light on this.
Can't recall the authors' names, I'm afraid.  Actually, now that I think of
it, the technical term is 'Coney Island Red Hots,' I think because of the
pepper flakes within.
And let's not even start on the regional variants on hot dog condiments--the
Chicago dog with its celery salt, the slimy red relish indigenous to New York,
Pink's chili (loved by Howard Hughes and also rumored to be horsemeat--see
James Ellroy's 'Hollywood Nocturnes') here in L.A.

On an equally 'pop' note--an excellent versions of You're Gonna Miss Me (R.
Erickson) have also been recorded by The Lazy Cowgirls.  But I don't believe
for a minute it's about Martians.  Now, The Rezillos' "Flying Saucer
Attack," or Twinkeez' amazing single "Aliens In Our Midst"...and that old
novelty hit "Martian Hop," there's some homophonic translation for you.

Which reminds me--is Andrews' ongoing -Paradise- really a homophonic
translation of Dante?  From what I read of his working method it -Paradise
and Praxis- it would seem otherwise.

diggity,
fjb

Charles Alexander wrote --

> I agree with Joel that repetitions of topics within short time
> frames can be frustrating. But I think web behavior is such that
> there's not much to do about this. People do come onto lists all the
> time and have concerns that have come up before.  . . .

I've been reading ~85-95% of the poetics posts since Feb. of this
year, and haven't seen the repetitions that Joel mentioned -- so I
guess these exceed a strech of 6 months anyway.  Also to note, if (as
Joel did) one sits down and pores over everything from a period of
several weeks, that's a different relationship with a listserv than
if one reads & participates on a day-to-day basis.  The way
discussion emerges *in situ* and develops, suggests the organic life
of discourse in a way that a retrospective read (transcript) of the
proceedings won't necessarily serve to illuminate.  What folks talk
about over coffee may also exhibit thematic repetition & incremental
variation, but to what extent is that a useful critique of the
discussion practice?  Also (finally) to note, Joel did seemingly get
some of the controversial / controverted facts a bit wrong, anent the
KD diatribe dialogue . . . but I think I'll let a sleeping dog lie . . .

hot (dog) today / cold (dog) tamale,
d.i.

dog to cat:
pig in the blanket reminds me of pig in the poke (they used to sell
pigs in sacks, or "pokes"), but there was a scam in which
 a cat would be substituted for the pig--unbeknownst to the buyer.
Hence "letting the cat out of the bag."

Personally, I would not eat a hot cat.

Regional hors d'oevres:   I grew up in a vaguely Jewish household in
one of the whiter sections of Washington, D.C., so I  missed out on a
 local dialect  (*).  Anyway, we did not have  pigs in blankets--just
 chopped liver and those little pieces of dense, cocktail
pumpernickel.  It isn't too hard to figure out where the term
"chopped liver" comes from; but had we HAD pigs in the blanket, I
would have been preoccupied. Think I associated "hot dog" with puppy dog
tails--purely visual, slightly you know what.  Then, the proximity of
"buns."

*much speculation/justification here

--rreynolds

> spoke of pigs in the blanket, we meant stuffed cabbages.

and in Italy, if the meat was over 75 years old, it was called "attsa KAPUTSA".
That is, until around 1912, when they started the Milan Chuwowzi Pup races,
which involved literally thousands of lil weenie dogs from Venice running
their buns off around Piazza della Spliatza.  4 sectors of the city would
compete ferociously year after year, & this, according to Dr. Simonetta
Frankcesca-Giuliani of Torno Ospedale, was instrumental in preserving
them links for at least another ten years of active bird-doggin'.

- Jack Spandrift

From:         Herb Levy <herb@ESKIMO.COM>
Subject:      Re: L-Dopa
In-Reply-To:  <POETICS%97072317375945@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

I want to respond to this on the list, cause I think some of the issues
raised by Henry are relevant. I'll make a few more poetical analogies to
show this, though some of them will be no more accurate than any analogy is
likely to be.  I do think that generally, though there's a parallel
reception dynamic for advanced work in virtually any creative field &
comparing how these mechanisms work in a variety of genres and styles can
be useful.

Now of course bop is little more than the music used to cue a detective on
television, or some other culturally specific referent, but early on it was
often perceived as being as weird as "free jazz" or punk rock.  Think, for
example of the early responses to Beat work in comparison to the overall
influence of this kind of writing today.

In a lot of ways, Be-bop was very different from the jazz that came before
it - the time feel & the use of greatly extended harmonies made it seem
extremely foreign to many swing-era listeners used to Glenn Miller and Duke
Ellington. & the obscure slang & costumes of post-war hipsters further
distanced the music from the general pop audience that had followed big
band jazz in the '30s. There were long-standing, well argued fights between
traditional jazzers (called moldy figs) & champions of the new music
(called boppers, etc.) that you can read in magazines like Downbeat and
Melody Maker.  This situation parallels the raw v. cooked anthology wars of
the 1960s poetry world, or, say, the more recent articles focusing on
distinctions between new formalism, language poetry, & workshop poetry.  &
there are remarkable quotes from musicians like Louis Armstrong that the
new music (bop) was no more comprehensible than Chinese music, etc., just
as, later, Miles Davis would often sound off against the late works of
Coltrane, anything by Cecil Taylor, etc.

The work of folks like Ornette Coleman or Sun Ra seemed chaotic in the
context of either the swinging groove or more formalist be-bop, but has
many parallels with the collective improvisations of early New Orleans
jazz.  Also, though its not fun (& probably not worth the time, unless
you're looking for a musicological dissertation topic in modern jazz
theory), the music of Coleman, Taylor, etc. can be analyzed in terms of
traditional harmonic structures, though the most interesting in the way the
players avoid cycles of repetitive chordal patterns (the key, so to speak,
to bop's riches & its seemingly dull repetitive structure) while moving
within a shared harmonic realm.

The analogies of the collective improvisations of Coleman, Ra, et al to the
earlier New Orleans styles seems to me to be a strong parallel to the
claims of various avant garde writers (Pound, Olson, Sanders, etc.) that
they are reclaiming formal and/or social functions of poetry lost since
ancient times, while the possibility of looking at Coleman's work as
advanced harmonic structures recalls the frequent later reception of work,
poetic or otherwise, that seems totally crazy when it first comes out, but
later turns out to be as overdetermined, if not moreso, as the more
traditional works of the time.  Remember when writers as different as
Stein, Joyce, Zukofsky, etc. were criticized as "not being about anything?"
even though, to varying degrrees they're now readable with much less, uh,
training than previously required.

If I had more time today, this could all be brought to bear on the issues
Mark Wallace raises in his "elaborating multiples" thread, but this will be
a day from hell so I'll leave it at this for now.


>I'm gonna display my ignortance (good word - use it) once again, Herb -
>I thought bebop was invented by Monk, Bird, Dizzy and them - & was
>speeded-up offbeat un-scripted, yes - but what comes out is so deeply
>musical in terms of controlled harmonics - whereas what Coleman &
>Sun-Ra (yes, 2 very different) sound like to me is also deeply musical
>of course but it's CHAOTIC in a lot of ways - so I think of the surprise
>JD referred to as the chaos in the music - which I don't hear so much
>in the other above-mentioned -
>this is just dilettantism, I realize, & if you want to backchannel that's
>probably a good idea.
>
>- Henry the harmonica



Herb Levy
herb@eskimo.com

This is the 3rd or 4th message like this today.  No need.  All that "mail
failure" means is that Poetics  is maxed out and your message will get sent
after a (short or medium) wait, almost always within a day.

So by resending mail failure messages you're just increasing the likelihood
of someone else getting a mail failure message, and sending your message
twice.

Not that AMS/CLLBMCS/POSTMASTER makes this very clear.

just a little techno note here -- I believe the message generated under the
circumstance you refer to (i.e., where the listserv has maxed out) has a
different subject heading than "mail failure."

This mail failure is a different situation -- it indicates that one particular
subscriber's address is no longer active (or something like that) -- ergo,
that particular subscriber didn't get reached, and their server is letter you
know that said server isn't serving them.

You're quite correct, though, in your observation that the REST of the
listserv population HAS successfully rec'd the particular item in
question.  I'm sure our good list-master will clear up the failure mailee
(i.e., remove a non-working address from the list -- or whatever
procedure is appropriate for such situation) --

and meanwhile, it's quite correct that there's no need to re-post in such a
situation (but this simply provides a somewhat different explicatory
background for that same general conclusion) . . .

/ / /

anyway, that's how I reads it.

Date:         Thu, 24 Jul 1997 17:47:36 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Charles Bernstein <bernstei@BWAY.NET>
Subject:      The 50 Limit
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

>A number of these multiple postings held my interest. The problem is the
>50-per-day limit, as I see it. Can't it be changed? It sounds so arbitrary
>(why not 49 or 51?) What's the reason for it? Do more than 50 messages a day
>cost the listmaster more?
asks David Bromige

50 is the default on the listserve program we use, but yes this can be
reset to 49 or 51. There is no limit to the size of individual messages,
however, so in general it is better to send one message that responds to
several threads, if so inclined.

This issue recurs every six months or so. A few years back I posted this
comment:

All of this reminds me of my commitment to keep the scale of this list on the
smaller side, not only because I am committed to small-scale exchanges but
also because this particular list is not set up -- _I'm not set up!_ -- to
handle more volume than we've now got.  The paradox is that in an attempt
to be open and nonexcluding one can end up excluding those who are unable
to handle the volume: people are drowned out rather than kept out -- until
Dreamworks Interactive, Inc., guides us and we asphyxiate. My hope is that
we have set-up some basic alternative sites: EPC and Poetics are two
models, firmly in place. But I certainly don't have the answers and see
Poetics as only one of many possible formats for listserve poetry
discussion groups.

***
by the way, the "failed mail" messages some of you report as getting are
likely just bounced mailed from individual subscribers who did not get your
individual post. These only occasionally go out to an individual poster,
but they come by the scores to our Poetics account and this is the rather
monotonous maintenance task that Joel Kuszai has generously been doing for
the past year. When a subscriber's address stops working, we have to
manually delete them from the subscription roles. In any case, suffice it
so say, we do prefer those list "defaults" that minimize extra maintenance.
        You get a different message when the 50 limit is reached. The Buffalo
listserve generates a message to say that your message is being held until
the list is released by the list owner.
=========================================================================

At 08:29 AM 7/24/97 -0700, you wrote:
>Calling hot dogs 'Coney Islands' or, better yet, 'Coneys,' predates by
>several decades the 70's brand name--they were served on the boardwalk long
>before.  I think that the excellent book -Roadfood- (a state-by-state guide
>to the niceties of local vernacular cuisine) sheds some light on this.
>Can't recall the authors' names, I'm afraid.  Actually, now that I think of
>it, the technical term is 'Coney Island Red Hots,' I think because of the
>pepper flakes within.
>

I, too, predate the brand name by several decades, a couple of which I spent
(weather permitting) getting sunburned and eating hot dogs, garnished with
mustard and sand, at Coney Island. They weren't, to the best of my
knowledge, served on that boardwalk. "Red hots" was used in some
neighborhoods of my youth, and especially at ballparks, as a synonym for an
ordinary hot dog. Could this usage pre-brand name, have been attached to the
hot dog in the provinces so that it would bask in the reflected glory of the
place? Just as there were hot dogs at Yankee Stadium long before "Yankee
Franks?"
The quintessential Coney Island hot dog was, and is, the "kosher style"
all-beef (or so it's claimed) served since before modern sanitation and
franchises a block from the boardwalk at Nathan's. The default New York hot
dogs have always been, unlike those of other places, primarily beef--witness
the Sabrett's wagons.
"Le hot dog" is now fairly common in France, but it hasn't displaced another
exotic, the far-superior merguez, a Tunisian lamb sausage served with
harissa, a red pepper concoction, and/or dijon mustard.
To those with English stomachs--this for me is more about language usage
than about food (I've already eaten lunch). There are yet mysteries to plumb
here. To add another--why is the frankfurter sometimes a wiener?
I don't see how a cummulative (aglutinative?) exchange like this could do
anything but eat up message units. The democratic spread of webtime is
preserved, it seemeth me, by the frequent descents into lurk-mode of even
the most active communicator.
=========================================================================

in my family the preference is for "street dogs"--any kind of sausage in a
bun served by street vendors.  for example, when i liven in boston and my
dad came out to visit and i took him to a red sox game, we eschewed
anything thay might be selling inside fenway for whatever they were
selling on the street.  That night we ended up w/ polish sausage w/
peppers and onions in a sour-dough roll--awesome!

another thing my family (well: dad, bro, and i) are big fans of are Top
Dogs.  Top Dog is a sausage joint in Berkeley and truly one of a kind.
tiny, tiny place and all they serve is sausage (polish, keilbasa, brats,
etc.) (sometimes cleverly titled: a turkey dog there is a "bird dog") and
whenever we are in berkeley we have to make a pilgrimage to Top Dog.  been
there since the '50s, looks like it, and tastes like it--awesome (again)!

--shaunanne

From:         cris cheek <cris@SLANG.DEMON.CO.UK>
Subject:      Re: performance poetry?
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Hi, sorry if this crosses other recent posts, have been off-line for two
days and might have missed discussion: but

Doug Barbour's report on Paul Dutton's attempt at a form of purist
cleansing within the ranks of 'performance poets' point up a vain folly.
There are likely to be as diverse appraoches to the performance of
poetries, as to the writings of them. Dutton's deliberations mark out a
protectionist approach to parameter formation that does us all a
dis-service. I write as someone who considers performance an integral
aspect of my 'writing' practice and whose work fits neither comfortably
into the slam / rap / epiphanic identikit skools, nor is 'sound' poetry as
such conventions might be referred to in short-hand. The binary, on which
Dutton is reported to be deliberating, is appallingly false and crude. It
also bears more than a hint of old creaky 'high' 'low' blather. It's the
corrupt rump of modernist angst. No thanks.

>He had decided to define sound poetry in terms of what he & Bob & some of
>the others mentioned already on the list (Charles Morrow, Jackson Maclow) &
>to leave out the kind of performance poetry we heard the next evening: a
>good bit of comedy, too many obvious rhymes (& all hit hard by the voie for
>some reason), & always a strong narrative (at least from this performer0,
>yet done with he flair of a standup comic. I would, for the moment, tend to
>agree with him. His amazing "Stereo Head" is certainly an awesome
>'performance' but it is so within extremely strict & demanding *formal*
>limits, as were the varied pieces of the horsemen. And Cobbing's chants are
>too. Or any of the others i've already named & many others.

love and love
cris

Hi Cris - my emails to you have been bouncing so I am happy to converse v=
ia
Buffalo. I don't think I have seen / heard what Paul has said and would
rather hear what he is saying before saying things like _vain folly_... i=

did delete a couple of messages by accident but i dont think that was one=


Having said that I agree with the undertow... there are not only diverse
approaches but also changing perhaps evolving approaches so that the
diversity patterns themselves change - by evolving I dont necessarily mea=
n
getting better of course... and as with evolution approaches will come in=
to
being again and again

and as with evolution if you are doing it then you exist / it exists and =
it
deserves attention even if you dont =


all texts are created free and are everywhere in anthologies

almost any binary is likely to be wrong... the answer whatever the questi=
on
is more than likely to look as though it should be _maybe_ but with a bit=

more processing power the answer is nearly always seen to be _wrong
question_

asking the wrong question isnt a cue to ask the right question - it is an=

alarm that you have misapprehended the context

terminologies are short hand and therefore unreliable - you enlarge the
picture they appear to give and all you get is a page of dots - you have =
to
keep saying at least to yourself what you mean by each term or you start
thinking it is real

sound poetry - i _grew up_ with the term but it worries me - it isnt so
much that i dont know what _sound poetry_ is - i dont know what _poetry_ =
is

i think i know it when i hear it

but then I think i am sane

terminologies are useful to help me think and talk about i t - poetry -
they are counter productive if the terminologies take over
the work always comes first

From:         Steve Shoemaker <shoemakers@COFC.EDU>
Subject:      Re: hot dogs I have known
In-Reply-To:  <Pine.OSF.3.96.970724161808.12989H-100000@pogonip.scs.unr.edu>

Mmmmmm, sounds good.  I just had a Wholesome and Hearty Foods, Inc.
Garden Vegan burger myself, but when i'm back in Maryland i still
sometimes go for an Anne's Footlong.  It's a tiny, white diner-style
place w/ a long counter, an open grill, fry baskets, and those
stools you can spin around on.  It can be found in Glen Burnie, a
suburb in the vicinity of Baltimore (or Balmer, as we like to say) known
for its high redneck quotient, and it's been there "forever," even as a
giant mall has devoured the entire surrounding area.  But if
you sit on one those stools you'll have a three-deep crowd breathing down
your neck as they shout their orders.  The piece de resistance is the
"footlong with everything," everything meaning onions, mustard, and
a delightful chili-style sauce.  When i was a kid i wld always "wash
it down" (picture a rather *slo* process) with one of those really
sticky-sweet milkshakes
in one of *the* three flavors--chocolate, vanilla, or strawberry (you
know the *really* pink kinda strawberry where you're never in danger
of encountering a stray seed).  But the best thing about the place is
the waitress/cooks (and tho Anne is retired, her daughters are rumored
to still work there).  They're amazing.  They're gruff, brisk and friendly
all at the same time, and no one *ever* writes down an order, no matter
how byzantine its requirements.

just a veggie drooling for meat, steve

The authors of Roadfood are Jane and Michael Stern.  Their new book is
called "Eat Your Way across the USA," and I cannot recommend it highly
enough, especially if you're on a roadtrip.  Along with scads of reviews of
great regional restaurants, there are fascinating sidebars exploring the
different types of regional cuisine, such as the different varieties of
barbecue, hot dogs, meal and threes, etc.

Having recently left Chicago, my stomach still periodically yearns for
Italian beef sandwiches, which are sort of like an especially sloppy french
dip (and if you're especially interested in clogging your arteries, you can
get a combo Italian beef/Polish sausage, complete with grilled onions and
peppers).

Hugh Steinberg

My hunch is that they were picketing over the Sacco-Vanzetti case (two
anarchists railroaded over an alledged murder of a paymaster and his guard
in 1920.  They were armed when arrested, gave contraditory evidence, and
feared deportation.  They were found guilty in 1921, and executed in 1927.
The most notorious political execution in this country prior to the
Rosenbergs).

Hugh Steinberg

From:         Alan J Sondheim <sondheim@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      First User's Guide to the Net, Ever:
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

First Internet Guide:


The following is the first user's guide to the Internet, ever, dated Har-
vard 30-Apr-71 ; the indenting is slightly changed, and underlining is
given as _x_.

----------------------------------------------------




        PRELIMINARY USER'S GUIDE TO THE ARPA NETWORK


1       _Overview_

The socket connection is viewed as a device and setting up a connection is
analogous to mounting a disk pack or, in the 10/50 system, to assigning a
logical name to a device. The user establishes a connection (via the UUO
given below) and performs normal I/O, including file manipulations (initi-
ally not implemented). The connection is permanent for the life of the
user's job (unless it is explicitely closed). The user interface to the
network is a pseudo-device labelled an "IMP". Each IMP is capable of a
transmit and/or a receive socket connection. The IMP has been constructed
to resemble as much as possible the device types on the PDP-10 timesharing
system. Thus existing programs can be expected to work over the network.

2       _Implementation_

2A      NCP Interface

2A1     The user interfaces with the NCP via a single UUO. The calling se-
        quence is:

        MOVE AC,[ (<FLAGS>B8) + <CODE> ,, E]
        CALLI AC,-5   OR CALL AC,[SIXBIT -IMPUUO-]
          ERROR RETURN...       ERROR CODE PLACED IN E+1
        OK RETURN...            FUNCTION COMPLETED

                ...

        E:      SIXBIT /NAME/   ;DEVICE LOGICAL NAME
                O               ;RETURN ARGUMENTS
                <SOCKET>        ;LOCAL (8 BIT) SOCKET NUMBER
                <STATE>,,<HOST> ;INITIAL STATE(BYTE SIZE,
                                ;   ETC.), REMOTE HOST
                <REMOTE SOCKET> ;REMOTE(32 BIT) SOCKET

2A2     Operation

Upon execution of the IMPUUO, the exec first identifies the requested
function and verifies that the user is privileged to use the facility. The
device identified in location E is then found and assigned by console to
the user. If the device cannot be found and the function is of the
connection type, then a free IMP is given to the user. If the specified
name is null or "IMP", then the physical name of the device (IMP1,  IMP2,
IMP3,  etc.) is written over it. Otherwise, the supplied name is given to
the IMP as a logical name.

The NCP(Network Control Program) is called to generate the proper control
messages and the current socket state (see section 2A5) is updated, as ap-
propriate. If the function is one of those that wait for a reply from the
remote host, the user's job is placed in I/O wait until that reply arrives
or a timeout occurs (timeout occurs) timeout not yet implemented). When
the operation has been completed, the skip return is taken. Whenever an
error is detected, the proper code is deposited in E+1 and the non-skip
return is taken.

2A3 Function Codes

The function codes are not yet fixed and are subject to immediate altera-
tion. The current set is:
0       Return the status of transmit socket in left half of E+1 and the
        receive socket in the right half of E+1. See 2A5 for an explana-
        tion of the state codes.
1       Start making the connection specified.
2       Start closing the connection specified.
3       Same as (1), but wait for completion.
4       Same as (2), but wait for completion.
5       Listen for external requests for connection.
6       Flush all requests.
7       Get the next external request.
8       Accept the latest request.
9       Reject the latest request.
10      Connect the user's teletype to the specified socket pair. Both
        must be open.
11      Specify a translation code. (unimplemented)
12      Send an interrupt on link.
13      Trap to specified address on receipt of an interrupt on link.
        Address is in E+!.
14      Return the version numbers of the IMP service and the NCP in the
        left and right halves of E+1, respectively.

64      Send a "RST"
65      Send an "ALL". Arguments in E+1 and E+5.
66      Send a "GVB".
67      Send a "RET".
68      Send an "ECO".
69      Send an "ERP".

2A4     Error Codes

        When the non-skip return is taken, an error code is deposited in
        E+1 as follows:

0       The function is not available (illegal or not implemented).
1       There is no such device (IMPn with n too big).
2       The device is not available.
3       The device is not an IMP.
4       The socket must be closed for this operation.
5       System error -- socket wouldn't open.
6       Socket must be open for this operation.
7       System error -- socket wouldn't close.
8       Socket must be listening for this operation.

2A5 Socket States
0       S.CLOS  Closed
1       S.LSTN  Socket is listening for incoming requests.
2       S.RFCN  An RFC has arrived on a listening socket
3       S.ABRT  A CLS was received for a socket in S.RFCN state.
                        (aborted request)
4       S.RFCW  A RFC was sent. An answer is expected.
5       S.OPEN  Open for data transfer.
6       S.CLSW  A CLS was sent. A reply is expected.
7       S.RFMW  Waiting for a RFNM before issuing a CLS.
8       S.CLRC  Awaiting a CLS for the logger
9       S.RMLW  Awaiting a RFNM for the logger.


------------------------------------------------------------------------
[This constitutes the first 3 pages. Punctuation has been preserved. The
fourth page is handwritten and contains a diagram, Module interaction for
a Telnet-logger Connection. The date on this is 12-May-71; both are from
Harvard. The diagram demonstrates the central role of the IMP, NCP, Data
Control, and Logger modules, as well as Server and User Processes.

Thanks to Peter H. Salus for the xerox. It's unclear whether the diagram
is part of the Guide. Salus states that Guide is "four pages long," but
the diagram is dated later, and is not necessary for access. The third
page ends half-way down.

I recommend Salus' Casting the Net; he is also producing two larger vol-
umes on the early history of the Net, which will include various repro-
duced documents.

        Re Paul Dutton:
                Making a "high"/"low" distinction --I don't think from
conversations with him and his essays that Paul Dutton does this.  After
all, his work has long drawn on blues forms, doo wop, early rock and roll
and Free Jazz.  Paul has written esays in Musicworks on Doo wop and as
well an excellent essay on bpNichol in which Free Jazz and country and
western are discussed. I won't pretend to speak for Paul Dutton in re the
ways in whcih he may make distinctions among performances. I can only
offer my impressions--and one  is that he is open to listening to anything and everything as
material.  From his interest in blues, doo wop and Free Jazz I gathered
that he has more of a sense of what Lorca called Duende in his response
to a work's "immediacy and force" to use Larry Eigner's criteria. That
is--Paul has a sense of what used to be called Soul involved in his
listening.  As well he did note a sense of some artists being such by
vocation and others by professionalism.  But these are not hard
"modernist" distinctions.  They are ones that may be found in any area of
work and performance.  I have heard more than my share of interviews with
baseball and football and basketball players in which such distinctions
are made.  Sometimes the two are intertwined--as they are in Paul's work
in which scholarship and discipline are used as materials in the
presentation of a work which opens up the materials as in the disciplined
exchanges involved in the spontaneity of Free Jazz.
        Bob Cobbing said he had one criteria for a work to be of interest
and use:  "robustiousness".  That may be more akin to Paul's sense than
the intellectual dialectics being imputed to him.
-dbchirot

                             Loose Lips

        Dear Franklin
        when it comes to BA's method I'm a duffer
        you're better off asking a pro
        but each time I hear him read it he says
        this is the first song off our new album
        no
        this is from my sound translation of Dante's Paradiso
        is what he says (I say)
        the poem's called "Lip Service" and parts of it
        were in Brian Kim Stefans' excellent magazine, _Arras_
        anyway what ever happened to Dale Herd?
        To Curtis Faville?
        To Charlie Vermont?
        To Dee-dee Susan Dubelyew?
        walking through Union Square last night
        heard Ed Sanders and Eileen Myles read
        Eileen got to say Fuck You to the Barnes & Noble marquee
        it was a very pleasant evening
        they both read very well I thought to a loosely assembled crowd
        of young thugs in the breeze
        afterwards Lisa Jarnot reintroduced me to Ed which was cool
        Anselm Berrigan was there
        so was Simon Pettet reclining on the pavement
        Ed Friedman was a sort of cohost
        Ed Sanders had read from 1968 Eileen read from School of Fish
        Anyway
        How are things out there?

I liked the democratic trappings of the Dictionary of American Regional
English, too, and I loved the bird-book quotient of the use-maps. Why am I
piping up? All this discussion of sausage has me thinking of Athenaeus's
The Philosophers at Dinner which admittedly is at times an entertaining
read, but am I glorifying an imaginary past when I say it's perhaps less
_on topic_ than that other collection of table talk, the Symposium?

What are poems about? Or rather, what are _other people's poems_ about,
what do they do, since it seems likely that are many complications
involved in speaking reasonably about what one's own poems do. Probably a
writer can say useful things about the architecture of a poem, and the
working method, and also probable is the will of the writer to confirm or
deny rumors of influence. What then are other people's poems about?

Jordan

Hi Lawrence,

re: I don't think I have seen / heard what Paul has said and would
>rather hear what he is saying before saying things like _vain folly_...

I would agree. Wish (perhaps he is) he were here to put my slander right.
I've great respect for his skill as a performer.

I wanted to encourage this thread to unravel further since as through the
extension of the subject heading i feel this is part of the discussion
under 'what comes next?'.

Without any intention to priveledge performance, it is that work which
explores an inter-disciplinarity between 'page' and 'stage' with some
integrity and sharp attention to detail, that excites my curiosity. Even to
the points of blur.

I'm particularly struck by the work of TRG (bp nicol and Steve McCaffery),
as documented in 'Rational Geomancy' in this respect. Also Steve Benson's
'Blue Book' and 'Reverse Order'; Fiona Templeton's 'Recognition'; the work
that you yourself are doing with Bob Cobbing in the 'Domestic Ambient
Noise' series; Caroline Bergvall's 'Eclat'; Carla Harryman's 'Memory Play';
Bernard Heidsieck's 'Poems - Partitions'; Joan Retallack's 'Errata Suite';
Antin's 'Talking at the Boundaries'; Jackson MacLow's 'The Pronouns' and
many more

>almost any binary is likely to be wrong... the answer whatever the question
>is more than likely to look as though it should be _maybe_ but with a bit
>more processing power the answer is nearly always seen to be _wrong
>question_

Indeed binaries, more often than not, reveal the oversimplistic results of
dull application.

>asking the wrong question isnt a cue to ask the right question - it is an
>alarm that you have misapprehended the context

Apprehension is that context. It often results in a reading for comforts of
'home'. Perhaps it's time for more strategically exploratory approaches to
'discomfort'.

Placing of the work into contexts which offer less obvious securities  -
engagements with issues of site (and 'non-site', not to forget Smithson's
hugely useful dialectics) and audience  -  that become dialogic with the
work itself, in ways that ask direct (very often positive) questions of it.

love and love
cris

Volume III of the DARE just came out this year. The "launch"
was at the end of May, part of the Dictionary Society of North
America meeting in Madison.
Volume I A-D
Volume II E-H
Volume III I-N
Volume IV (which we began working on 4 yrs ago while
finishing Vol. III) O-T.
Vol. V U-Z plus a list of al the people who contributed quotes,
and other addenda.

It was initially projected as a 5-year project--and still does
offer the only synchronic pciture of (U.S.) American speech.
Data collection 1965-70.

DARE's part of the English dept. at UW-madison.

More than you wanted to know, perhaps.

From:         David Bromige <dcmb@METRO.NET>
Subject:      mark wallace/mark weiss/held list?
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

I would like to second, with great appreciation, Mark Wallace's expositions
of multi-variable poetry. Such an approach to the art was certainly given
by the poetics of the New American Poetry, & also by the poetics of Langpo.
Yet it is not often found, & it is an interesting question as to why?
Perhaps it has something to do with it being the thing, & espec. the
american thing, to build a better mousetrap & then go on using it. As
marketable product, which poetry at one point in its social life has to be,
it needs to be readily identifiable, & the kind of work Mark would advance,
does not lend itself readily to this "trademark" or "brandname" practice.

Such practice, btw, is intimately bound up with an authentic (though not
nec. intrinsic) aspect of poetry, to wit, that, just as in the sciences,
there are _problems_ & can be _solutions_ , (or better, with poetry, (non)
problems & (non) solutions), & that these often bear a "stamp" or "typos".
Diminishing returns, esthetically, arise, however, when last time's
solution becomes this time's goal. Increasing returns, though, may be
anticipated in terms of product recognition. The poet becomes to
her/him/self the poetry already written, with consequent loss of sharpness.
(Rae Armantrout writes in her poetry : "At first we loved because we
startled." For present purposes of clarification, I would add to this.,
"And then we love because we dont.")

Actually, for those who _really_ want a poetry that bears the authentic
imprint of an author, Mark's is the way to follow. The greater the variety
of practice by one author, the greater the chance that what consistencies
_can_ be traced throughout the oeuvre, are unavoidable to that poet, the
real blind spots that everybody know it or not wants to love. But that is
difficult work, locating such, & more superficial signs of identity prove
more generally welcome.  Mark has chosen a hard row to hoe, but his books
to date demonstrate he does it brilliantly, and his essAys & postings show
that he argues for it very well.

**********

Another Mark, surnamed Weiss, writes me via this list that the hotdog
thread isnt abt food, it's abt language.. Sure, I get that, but for me,
words are mixed up with the objects they name. When I read about hot dogs,
the taste & texture of a hot dog comes into my mouth. This is why I cant
discuss Hedy Lamarr's book _Ecstasy & Me_ , except with increasing
incoherence.

**********

Is this another list-held day? Perhaps we should all send ten bucks to the
listmaster so that he can hire extra help. (No, Charles didnt put me up to
this back channel. But it must cost _something_ to run this operation. How
come we're getting it for free? If we paid something, we could feel more
justified in wishing to control the means of production, & able to do
something about things that don't please us.)

David

Mark Weiss wrote:
>"Le hot dog" is now fairly common in France, but it hasn't displaced another
>exotic, the far-superior merguez, a Tunisian lamb sausage served with
>harissa, a red pepper concoction, and/or dijon mustard.

Thanks, Mark, now I know how to spell 'merguez,' which I'd never heard them
until man-of-much-travel-and-many-talents Guy Bennett (whose Seeing Eye
Books series I hope you've all subscribed to) served them at a dinner a few
months back.  They reminded me a bit of a gamy Italian meat-product called
(I'm transliterating from my family) 'gimarede,' which isn't really a
sausage, having no casing. You know, this list, especially in the digest(ed)
form I receive it, is a bit like a string of sausages itself--a long
receptacle of undifferentiated matter pinched and twisted into separable
units.  To that extent, I'm with those who have recently suggested that
people stuff more rather than less into their casings (i.e. comment on
several threads in a single post).  Since, as CB comments, there's no limit
on the length of each of the arbitrary 50 messages, this might help avoid
more rejected messages.  Dodger Dogs, not Lil' Smokies, people.

Actually, I don't feel that strongly about this, but the strained metaphor
was too much for me to resist.

fjb

i was thingking abt th recent discuss of Paul Dutton's sound/performance
poetry distinctions, thot to go back to _Sound Poetry: A Catalogue_ (ed.
by mccaffery/nichol) & see what dutton was saying then, and low & beholden,
INSTEAD found another martian ref, our own Lwrence Upton's graphic "from Poems
in Polar Martian", which very much reminds me ov an anglosax riddle...

one ov the things most interesting to me about that Catalogue, btw, is
the extent to which sound poetry is represented by scores that are more
visual poetry than most vispo i see lately...  which tends, fr me, to
argue against th kind of neat separation into neat catagories that is th
oversimplification of pauls arguement.  contrarywize, i'm sympathetic to
th impulse to try to distinguish among directions...  i've performed some
sound poetry at slams, and the results aint pretty...

From:         Mark Weiss <junction@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      American food
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

While we're on the subject, I've always been curious about the yuck factor
in American eating habits--the voluntary restriction of dietary choices.
Even in cultures with strict food taboos the range of what's considered
edible is usually fairly wide: traditional Jews, for instance, keep kosher,
but they eat intestines, tongue and liver. English, Germans, Italians,
French, Chinese, eat almost anything, regardless of the social class of the
eater. Americans, on the other hand, reduce their range as they get further
from their ethnic origins. Here's a short list of the often-considered
yucky: any innards, octopus, squid, eel, lamb or goat (at least in Anglo
Southern California--there are Greek restaurants here that don't serve
lamb), mutton, all game, duck, oysters and clams (particularly raw), all
other seafood except lobsters and shrimps. Veggies fair somewhat better,
altho okra commonly provokes a gag reaction. Actually, vegetables are more
tolerated for their healthfulness than loved--witness Bush's PR-
manufactured aversion to broccoli, which was supposed to make him seem
childlike and appealing, a regular guy or something.
The consequence--limited production of many of the offending comestibles and
a food industry that caters to food paranoia--hence the listing of
ingredients on restaurant menus and the proliferation of clone franchises
that protect one from the gustatory surprises of travel. Even cheeses are
affected by the general narrowing of taste--in the coutries of origins
hundreds of cheeses are produced. Here it's mostly cheddars and
near-relatives and one or two soft cheeses and unripe goat cheese among the
well-travelled: selection for blandness, as in the distaste for gamey meats.
I don't think that this progressive limiting of taste is a product of
agribusiness, altho it certainly makes its job easier--in industrialized
countries where the yuck factor doesn't exist or is less extreme demand has
successfully thwarted suppliers' homogenizing tendency.
Perhaps an anthro list would be more appropriate for this one. Any theories?
=========================================================================
Date:         Fri, 25 Jul 1997 17:11:11 -0400

From:         John_Lavagnino@BROWN.EDU
Subject:      Real food

Out near Worcester, Mass., is a great place called Hot Dog Annie's,
open every day of the year.  One of the largest displays of hot dogs
rolling in place that you'll see anywhere.  They also do hamburgers.
A few years back the Boston Globe ran an interview with Annie herself,
and she complained: you go to most burger places and order a burger,
and what do you get?  A plate of weeds.  When you order a burger at
Hot Dog Annie's, we don't put any weeds on it.

From:         cris cheek <cris@SLANG.DEMON.CO.UK>
Subject:      Re: performance poetry?
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Hi Dave, fair points all along  -  it seems crass on my part to use
Douglas' Dutton dilemma story:

>        Re Paul Dutton:
>                Making a "high"/"low" distinction --I don't think from
>conversations with him and his essays that Paul Dutton does this.  After
>all, his work has long drawn on blues forms, doo wop, early rock and roll
>and Free Jazz.  Paul has written esays in Musicworks on Doo wop and as
>well an excellent essay on bpNichol in which Free Jazz and country and
>western are discussed.

But what's curious then, is that when it comes to the performance poetries
which much align themselves to rap, dub, ragga and so on  -  surely the
blues, jazz, of our time  -  there is (and here i've only, as Lawrence
points out, got Douglas Barbour's report to go on) apparently a wish to
distance such influences in terms of poetic practice. That is to feel the
desire to define them outside of 'performance poetry'. Perhaps exactly the
point Dutton is making. That the verbal stylings and the vocal projection
have most impact when integrated. In other words that such things can be
discussed in terms of their vocal stylings but become more bothersome when
the linguistic content (we could go on gnawing over that one all night) is
offered without all of the contextualising sound.

My worry is of a priveledge being given to the Free Music trajectory as an
arrival on the trail of 'progress'  -  that idea that that's the stuff
that's really going down. It promotes what Fiona Templeton usefully
nick-names the 'ejacula-improv' approach to voice.

I suggest that is both old and too closed, reductive and sometimes even
essentialist (something McCaffery also pointed out). Not uninteresting, but
period.

I'm writing here as someone who values highly what Bob Cobbing is up to,
who has done and still does do voice-based performance work, who has in the
past played a lot of so-called Free Music.

Voice / orality / spoken rhetorics have far more to offer integrated and
inter-disciplinary poetics practices than such an advocacy, if that is what
is somehow surfacing, permits. It seems far too easy to consign 'that' to
'there' as not a part of. To say that's all slam poetry, that's stand-up
(Jeff Derkson can be hilarious and so on) or comedy poetry or whatever -
without looking at what can be learned and re-applied in other contexts to
other purposes.

Time to re-appraise, re-contextualise  -  move on (not in a teleological
sense but  - you know what i mean i think).

love and love
cris

What are poems about? Or rather, what are _other people's poems_ about,
what do they do, since it seems likely that are many complications
involved in speaking reasonably about what one's own poems do. Probably a
writer can say useful things about the architecture of a poem, and the
working method, and also probable is the will of the writer to confirm or
deny rumors of influence. What then are other people's poems about?

Jordan

Subject:      Re: dog days
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

In the interest of limiting the flow of electrons through space this post
will serve three distinct functions.

1. Perhaps this should be backchannel. Where and for how much can one
acquire Dare vols II-III?

2. This should be of more general interest. What is the boundary between
social dialect/nonstandard material and slang, and is it guarded by
permanent gun emplacements? For instance, my wife's family, from Charleston
SC (deebutante class) and Asheville NC (educated ministerial hillbillys
become professionals), use words like wapperjar and bumfuzzled. Which are these?

3. This one's just because I want to tell the story. It speaks to a social
dimension of the yuck factor. My  then inlaws-to-be, trying to be nice,
acceded to my requests for regional food by taking me to a wonderful
black-run soulfood restaurant (I forget the name, but it's apparently
well-known) in Chapel Hill (we were visiting relatives in Durham, which is
close by). I was delighted to find chitlins (alright, chitterlings) on the
menu. They are a favorite of mine, and hard to come by in my usual haunts.
When I ordered them the black waitress asked me if I was sure I knew what
they were, i.e, "white people don't eat this stuff." My future father-in-law
(we very quickly became great friends) had a peculiar look on his face which
I interpreted as approbation, as in, "this long-haired yankee jew knows how
to eat!" I later learned that what he really meant  was "this long-haired
yankee jew is even weirder than the last guy she brought home--he eats
servants' food." I was, of course, the only one who ordered chitlins.

>
>But, regarding DARE, we include regional and social dialect/
>nonstandard material, but not slang--although Vol I sticks with
>this distinction less than Vols. II & III. (above should be
>Vol. III 1st half).

no theories but yearning for many of the weird things you describe.  when i
was young my mother would serve cold tongue as a matter of course for
weekend lunches, until our little friends started coming over and having
strong reactions of revulsion.  we used to get cheese airmailed by her
danish-farmer father so strong that she'd get calls from the post office,
Mrs Damon, we think someone has mailed you a dead animal, please come get
it out of here right away.

Subject:      Advertisement, Virtual Love (fwd)
MIME-Version: 1.0

--



                            Advertisement



                 pay me five dollars and when i come,
                        i'll cry out your name
                  pay me five dollars, and, coming,
              i'll cry your name out, in the empty room

            pay me seven and i'll caress my naked breasts,
                whispering, I love you, and for eight,
                          i love you <name>

             your name my love, your name, and for nine,
             your name my love, your name, and for nine

          pay me ten and i'll grasp air, calling you softly
               i will wrap my arms around the empty air
                    and i will grasp the empty air

        for fifteen you'll be in all my dreams, and for twenty
              i'll promise anything, tossing and turning
       in the bed alone, tossing and turning in that empty bed

       and for twenty, you will have me, you will have my name,
                  for twenty, you will have my name

        and for thirty, when you come, i will write @hold you,
                         @hold you in my arms

         you need not fear escalating prices, i promise you,
         they remain the same for all time, and as for forty,
                        you dream of naked me,
                        you dream of naked me

      and now there are no higher prices, this empty air expands
             and covering your body, and penetrating you,
          in my dreams, and forever you will have your name
                             upon my lips
                you will have your name, upon my lips,
                               forever

Date:         Sat, 26 Jul 1997 01:19:05 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Shemurph@AOL.COM
Subject:      Sad News - Gerald Burns

A couple of hours ago, I received a telephone call from Scott Duddridge in
Portland, Oregon.  Scott let me know that Gerald Burns had passed away in his
sleep while at his parents' home in St. Clair Shores, Michigan.  Gerald was
staying with his parents to help care for his mother, who had suffered a
stroke.  Gerald's plan was to be there for approximately a couple of months,
assisting his mother in gaining back some of her functioning, and helping his
father handle the difficult situation.  It seems to me that Gerald had been
in Michigan for about a month when this occurred a couple of days ago.  As
many of you may know, Gerald had for the past couple of years made Portland
his home.

Scott Duddridge is planning to assemble reminiscences from people who were
friends of Gerald.  Anyone wishing to participate may contact me through
e-mail at shemurph@aol.com, and I will share contact information for Scott.
 For those who may want to write to Gerald's family, I can direct you on
that, as well.

The shock of this is great.  Suffice it to say that those of us who loved
Gerald will miss him greatly.  His contribution as a writer, critic, teacher,
and friend was exceptional.  You may remember Robert Creeley's having
selected Gerald's book SHORTER POEMS for the National Poetry Series book
selection that appeared from Dalkey Archive Press in 1993.  In Creeley's
words,

"These extraordinary poems are testament to their author's passionate
commitment to all that has entered his mind and heart.  He is our great
master of detail, of why it is and how it is that the things of our lives
constitute a primary index of place.  I love the pleasures he so invites, the
wit of his insistent response."

Gerald was born in Detroit in 1940, was educated at Harvard and Trinity
College (Dublin).  He taught at Southern Methodist University and New York
University, and in 1985 was awarded an NEW Creative Writing Fellowship for
poetry.  His volume of verse theory, A THING ABOUT LANGUAGE, was published by
Southern Illinois University Press in 1989.

These were among the things Gerald was proud of having done.

Sometimes we come to believe it is our right to have someone with us forever.
 In fact, each moment of time we have is a privilege.  Gerald's life and his
infinite generosity of spirit will continue to give those of us who loved him
courage.
=========================================================================

From:         rsillima@IX.NETCOM.COM
Subject:      Doggie Diner, Curtis Faville
Comments: To: poetics@UBVM.cc.buffalo.edu
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Doggie Diner, with its trademark (literally) 20 foot tall smiling dachsund
head in a chef's hat, was a regional fast food chain with HQ in Oakland
during the 1950s and '60s (maybe even the '40s, a period I partook of only
partly and then only in a preliterate fashion, so I lack notes). I'll wager
that the one Charles is recalling was the one at the southwest corner of
Mission & Army streets in SF, immediately next to what was then Sears and
was, last time I needed it, the Employment Development Department (with some
pretty generic loft space upstairs). Doggie Diner's specialty was the foot
long hot dog, though as I recall any resemblance between that processed
thing and meat was too abstract for me to make the connection. My favorite
high school teacher, Charles C. Clarke, aka Chico Charlie to us at Albany
High, used to deliver supplies from the central DD warehouse to the 10-20
doggies.

We call pups in a blanket "pigs in a blanket" in our house.

Curtis Faville, last I heard (a couple of years back) was still living in
Kensington and still working at Social Security in SF (right next to UN
Plaza, known locally as Urine Plaza). His son Randy was living out near SF
State. Curtis "gave up" poetry with a vengeance. He studied architecture for
awhile (which led to his last book, Wittgenstein's Door, which Lyn published
as Tuumba 29) and spent some time in Japan thanks to a job that his wife got
with one of the armed services. While there, he got into photography. But
other than those ventures, he's been at Social Security for 20+ years.
Stanzas for an Evening Out remains one of the great books of the 1970s, up
there with Bending the Bow, Sentences, Space and a precious few others. I
don't think I ever met anyone who'd known Curtis who didn't learn something
useful about writing from him, but he will let you know that he doesn't want
to discuss it, Period (capital P), the instant you bring it up.

All the years I knew Curtis, I don't think we ever ate at Doggie Diner
together. Last meal we had was a breakfast at Mama Royal's Cafe on San Pablo
in Albany.

Ron

I never got to meet Gerald Burns, but I got to know him well through a
constant stream of mail from him, an experience many others will
recognize.  When I started _lower   limit   speech_, I got a few poems
from him.  Wrote back to tell him this was just the sort of response I had
hoped for -- I'd read Gerald's small pamphlets years ago and found his
work a refreshing departure from nearly everything else I was reading at
the time -- Gerlad also sent me a number of whimsical drawings (has anyone
ever collected his drawings for publication) --

There is a delightful interview with Gerald recorded for a Portland (I
think it was) radio program -- I hope they will air it again in
remembrance --

Has anyone mentioned that he used to work in the circus?

Date:         Sat, 26 Jul 1997 17:07:55 +0700
