Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Rebecca Weldon <rcweldon@LOXINFO.CO.TH>
Subject:      Re: Thai influences
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Sorry for the mix-up, Alan, and, as to why this took so long, I've been way
up in northern Laos on the China border.

>
>Did you not want to send this to the Poetics list? And if you do, could
>you perhaps talk about the first three writers, who I am unfamiliar with?
>
>Alan

On Tue, 15 Jul 1997, Rebecca Weldon wrote:

> Rong Wongsawan, Sila Komchai, Sunthorn Plu, Mehta, Mishima, Eco, Fuentes, Okri
> and the writers of southeast asian epics who gave their names in private
> offering to their gods.


Rong Wongsawan is perhaps the master of the Thai satirical novel and has
not, to my knowlege, been translated into English.  His career has brought
him fame, but perhaps because of his highly creative use of language, not a
very wide readership.  One of a generation educated outside the country, he
returned to become an important and much beloved social critic (perhaps
because he was of the hedonistic rather than the ascetic variety). He was
named National Artist last year and those of us who know him were relieved
that he would at least receive 8,000 Baht (approx $300) per month from the
government from the rest of his days. Until this time, his main income was
from the mass-distributed newspaper Daily News, for which he writes a
regular column under increasingly difficult circumstances since his health
is failing.

Sila Komchai's novel "the path of the tiger" has been recently translated
into English.  He is best known, though, for his short stories, having won
the SEA Write award in 1993 for his second collection.  He was among the
thousands of the best and the brightest of young Thai who were forced into
the jungles following the 1976 massacre.  Nature is an important metaphor
for his socio-political observations.

Sunthorn Plu composed in verse,over 200 years ago.  His favorite form was
"klone paet" (eight lined klone), double quatrains with both internal and
final, linking rhymes, to which he added a rhyming innovation of his own.
His many works include epic tales, plays and "nirat" or jouney poems(a form
much honored by Thai poets, even today, a personal interpretation of a
voyage).  His work illustrates how tonal languages expand plays on words and
make for a particularly rich poetic expression.  The following quatrain
(khlong form):

Khao khiao khote khoum khuen   khieng khieng
Rom ruen rouk rang rieng       riep roy
Hom hak hing hai hieng         hua haad haing he
Yaang yai yode yuen yoy        yoke yo yone yen

may be translated thus:

Emerald facades twist             merge forever
Perfect, coolly clothed           dark green forest
Nude trunks and broken branches   the riverbed
Huge trees shoot the sky          swaying canopy

although the translation cannot even approximate the original, since each
word has both rhyming and tonal values, the equivalents of which do not
exist in English.

Of course, Thai literature is as rich as any other, I simply happen to
admire these three more than others.

Rebecca

> understand it, basically followed on the heels of her (long-since
> past) days of dance/choreography.  I think I only saw one such film,
> (including Valda Sutterfield among the cast (and wish such things
> were to be seen more readily elsewhere than such film meccas as
> Anthology Film Archive in NYC . . . )

summer of '74.

From:         cris cheek <cris@SLANG.DEMON.CO.UK>
Subject:      Re: Yvonne Rainer . . .
Comments: To: Multiple recipients of list POETICS <POETICS@UBVM.cc.buffalo.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Thanks Layne, Yvonne's work is surely overdue a major reappraisal

>talk about the merging of poetry and dance....

i hope you'll forgive me being a bit autobiographical, it might spark some
bases for discussions  -  Working on a boundary between dance and poetry is
something i used to do more. To be brutally honest i found working in old
tea warehouses and veneer factories with dancers preferable to propping up
the bar with poets and musicians for quite a few years.

                    When 'jgjgjgjgjgjgjgj . . . (as long as you can say it
that's our name)  -  a trio with Lawrence Upton and Clive Fencott  -  was
performing 3 (sometimes more) voice writing, much along the lines of the
Four Horsemen, we began, individually and or collectively i can't remember
which, to lose interest in holding a 'score' (the page in the hand
approach). That necessitated memorised materials and memory strategies,
themselves particularising editorial performance tools. Of course gesture
became more consious as part of the performance. I'm reminded of David
Bromige's hilarious presentation on 'podium behaviour' at last year's
Assembling Alternatives Conference in New Hampshire. How a poet presents
themselves, how they stand, what they do with their hands, what is readable
and revealed  -  Bourdieu's 'habitus'?

                    We did some work incorporating deliberate gesture, then
drifted onto seperate paths. I'd got very interested in the interaction
between vocalising and movement. In fact i always had been. One of my first
things was a sonnet of invented signs, several of which repeated, which
necessitated variations on vocal gesture and physical mark-making (drawing
with the hand in space, body wriggle, constriction and release  -  simple
stuff, related to writing).

                    I was in Baltimore, working with CoAccident throughout
much of 1979/80, with Kirby Malone, Chris Mason, Marshall Reese, Nora
Ligora, Patty Karl, Svexner Labs and Lisa Land. We did a lot of work that
incorporated what i'd now refer to as physical theatre.

                    Back in London the prospect of supporting myself
through my poetry seemed slim. I had however seen a couple of independent
choreographers, from X6 Dance Collective, performing at the ICA  -  Fergus
Early and Jacky Lansley. My line of interest jumped across from Judson. I
got invoved with the emergence of what was called New Dance in the UK.
'Dance' was becoming porous to quotidian movement, sports and so on and i
thought "i could do that". There was a lot of Contact Jamming happening (i
danced with Nancy Stark-Smith, Mark Tompkins and Julyen Hamilton and so
on). I auditioned for a company Jacky and Fergus were putting together. As
i remember, it's one of only 2 auditions i've ever been to, i knew i had to
have a piece. So i prepared something during which I improvised a talk and
then threw 5 balls of different sizes and colors up into the air (like
going to juggle which is a pet no-no -  as my friend Sianed Jones says,
when i see someone starting to juggle, i goes to sleep) opened my arms in a
grand dramatic gesture and saying something like a bunch of non-sequitors
let them all simply fall to the floor without making an effort to catch
any. I got the job and was in a dance company performing regularly and
earning ok (for about the next year).

                    That experience brought me into contact with many
choreographers for whom i was commissioned to write. They opted for a
spoken text instead of music. These were some of the most satisfying
performance experiences i can remember. Michael Clark, Mary Prestidge,
Miranda Tufnell, Lisa Nelson, Kistie Simpson, Sue MacLennan and Patricia
Bardi were all collaborators at this time. I'd always be 'on stage', always
be working from memorised materials devised with the movement, frequently
move myself at times.

                    A few years back i got together a bunch of younger
choreographers and re-created Jackson MacLow's 'The Pronouns' with
shinkansen on London's South Bank. That worked really well. Initially they
looked at the writing and couldn't find ways into it. When however, they
began to actually try to work out, in a space, how to DO them, everything
rocked.

                    It's this DO thing that interests me. Basil Bunting
declared that 'Poetry must be read aloud'. How many do that. And when they
do, how aware are they of the subtle particularities of what Steve Paxton
calls the small dance , taking place in their bodies?

Any thoughts? I'm keen to hear on this

love and love
cris

Subject:      execution/myth and poetry
Mime-Version: 1.0

I know a Rexroth poem titled (I think) "August 23, 1939" which is the
anniversary date of the execution of Sacco and Vanzetti. It begins with a
lengthy extract of a letter Sacco wrote to his son Dante while
incarcerated. The poem has wonderful energy, I think, memorable lines ('if
they line the cellars with cork it is not to still the pistol shots but to
silence the last words of  . . . ' -- an approximation, I don't have the
book before me either, which doesn't make it less memorable).  It's a poem
about exile and execution, a long list, not confining itself to US history
but Europe and Asia also.

As notorious as the Sacco/Vanzetti case was (is), I think it falls under
the larger notoriety of the Haymarket "martyrs, in--what?, 1886? 1888?
Indeed the context of the movements Sacco and Vanzetti were much active in
retained a heavy grasp on the memory of 8 (8?) anarchists executed in
Chicago. (Rexroth, in another longer poem--"The Dragon and the Unicorn," I
think-- answers when some young men ask him in Europe (in the late 40s),
"Is THE GRAPES OF WRATH true?" "Most of it's true. In the book one man is
killed, but really it was eight men."  (Or something like that.)

Paul Avrich's book SACCO & VANZETTI: THE ANARCHIST BACKGROUND is a
wonderfully informative book. His conclusion is that the cobbler and fish
peddlar WERE innocent of killing the paymaster and guard, but of
bomb-throwing activity they were not.

In fact, it's interesting to learn about how many bombs were thrown in the
years following WWI especially since many seem to be going off recently. Of
the group S & V were part of--disciples of an Italian anarchist who
published a paper in the US and was deported after many years living in the
country--can't remember his name-- the bombing attempt on Attorney General
Mitchell Palmer's house in Washington DC is linked to it. The bomb went off
on Palmer's front step. Some think the man carrying the bomb tripped going
up the steps.  Whatever happened, the authorities found his scalp on the
Chief Justice's lawn and other parts of him on the house of then-Navy
Sec'ty FDRoosevelt.

It takes so long to write posts like these, with the citations questionable
but not the essence of the material and work piling up before me, etc. -- I
think I lost my intended point.  Read the Rexroth poem, it's quite good.
And the Avrich book too, especially considering how often Sacco & Vanzetti
appear in 20th literature.


daniel_bouchard@hmco.com

See Rexroth poem re: the execution. Sorry, my books are unavailable. The
executions are one of the key events in US leftist history/myth.

        Today is 75th Anniversary of death of Khlebnikov.
        A moment of respect & sound for him!
        "The King of Time" . . .

        Kogda umirayut koni--dyshat,
        Kogda umirayut travy--sokhnut,
        Kogda umirayut solntsa--oni gasnut,
        Kogda umirayut lyudi--poyut pesni.

        When horses are dying--they wheeze,
        When grasses are dying--they wither,
        When suns are dying--they wane,
        When people are dying--they sing songs.

        NEZHNYI YAZYK

        Segodnya veshchi,
        Nezhny i veshchi;
        Nezhenki-bezhenki
        V nebe plyvut.

        SOFT TALK

        All things today
        Have all things to say;
        Softly and swiftly
        They swim through the sky.



        (from Snake Train  Ann Arbor:  Ardis, 1976  pp. 35 & 44.
                Edited by Gary Kern.  Translations Kern, Richard Sheldon,
                Edward J. Brown, Neil Cornwell, Lily Feiler.)

        the world as we see it is passing
        before our very eyes turns dark
        yet the brilliance of its sounding
        makes one turn back

        for one last look at the horizon

        where the rough grass lies
        silhouetted by a blue so sharp
        it cuts the eyes with its memories
        cuts it sharp as any stone in field
        as any tongue in mouth
        crying to the ear
         . . . crying to the a-i-r


                my beloved
                                i have

                                          found you

--dbKiro

The Rexroth poem to which I referred is "Climbing Milestone Mountain, August
22, 1937," pp. 89-90 in _The Collected Shorter Poems_.

It's a constant source of dismay to me that the decade 1965-1975 has become,
with astonishing speed, a subject for university courses, almost a
discipline, as aging college profs try to rewrite their youths, while the
once-subversive and seductive passions of almost everything that came before
gather dust and are lost to memory.
Important to remember that the greatest grassroots movement of the
post-Vietnam period thus-far has been the struggle to restore classic coke.

Don Cheney adds this demotic note --

<< Carl's Jr. fast food out here in California has a new ad campaign that
centers around the phrase "eat meat." as funny as that is, the funnier (is
"funnier" a word, seems kind of, well, funny) thing is that they are
handing out bumperstickers portraying a yellow star with a smiling face on
it and next to it the phrase:

EAT MEAT

who comes up with these ideas . . . ? . . . >>

what I'm wondering is: does this suggest a commercial attempt to capitalize on
(& consolidate in language-in-circulation) a sort of contra-PC-ish-ness w.r.t.
meat eating? -- i.e., the idea of an "in your face" gesture: the bumper sticker as a
sign of identity ("I am what I like to eat") -- so that, in a highly
bumpersticker-sensitive society, contrarian responses could be anticipated:

  NOTHIN' BUT TOFU

or

  BROWN RICE! (19 years & counting)

or even a retro

  EAT YOUR VEGETABLES!

in short: a war of the comestibles?

What I'm trying to get at here, is the observation that, evidently, the fast-fooders
are feealing conceptually cornered by science facts & culture trends, and are
trying to lash out / take a stand / make a statement / gather a following / or
something . . .  (??) -- Carl Jr. as the avant garde in a culinary campaign of
carnivore reaction? . . . (just as other companies position themselves as proxies
of hipness nostalgia etc.)

the language of advertising at the Carl Jr. level lacks the finesse one gets used to
in pages of Vanity Fair or The New Yorker -- but then, perhaps the target
audience is believed not quite as accustomed to subtlety & irony, &c.  . . .

d.i.

Subject:      Re: deipno / diotima
Comments: To: "Pritchett,Pat @Silverplume" <pritchpa@silverplume.iix.com>

Things is going to infinity all around us and all you can say is hell is
other people? Poems remain. I notice that a lot of my friends are what you
might term celebrating (so some of them are pouring caustics down pipes
while they do it). Is this a different world-historical phoneme from the
one that preceded it, or are we in the middle of one big diphthong. (So
that differing becomes necessary, the raison d' from whom we are all trying
to get a table? -- in that making meaning takes on a macroscopic ((greil
marcus --> brioschi)) meaning of its own .. to differ _and_ survive is the
job. Differing the long range surviving the short range tho as the priest
at st marks liked to say a group in survival mode is not an attractive
group).

Date:         Tue, 29 Jul 1997 12:45:15 +0100
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         "L.MacMahon and T.R.Healy" <Suantrai@IOL.IE>
Subject:      body dance
Comments: To: british-poets@mailbase.ac.uk
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

cris wrote:

>>>Basil Bunting
declared that 'Poetry must be read aloud'. How many do that. And when they
do, how aware are they of the subtle particularities of what Steve Paxton
calls the small dance , taking place in their bodies?

Any thoughts? I'm keen to hear on this<<<

This is something which has interested me for some time.  The entire body is
continually mapping and consulting with what becomes constructed at various
levels as realities.  In one model it absorbs/seeks out about one hundred
billion bits per second, the mind/perception at the same time swimming in a
data space many many times this size.  This raises all sorts of interesting
questions.  Clearly not all of this activity is conscious.  However, by
subconscious I do not mean the gizmo laden productions of Freud et al.  Not
that I am necessarily against, or for, them.  I simply mean to refer to a
well of far from raw data/experience which is not always available at will.


Memories can seem to lodge in the body, one can see people fall into
coherent posture-dialects as they talk about particular things.  I am
interested in seeing how this might relate to the creative process.  By
focusing in a meditative way on particular parts of the body, e.g. the feet,
subtler and subtler sensations arise which may then transform into images or
sounds.  There are also breathing techniques which stimulate "dead" parts by
altering the oxygen/carbon dioxide balance.  (This can lead to a full body
orgasm.  You have been warned.)  Temperature is another medium.  I tried
things like somatic meditations in a sauna longer and longer times (drink
lots of water before and after).  And texture:  walking incredibly slowly in
bare feet and noticing every sensation.  When doing any of these exercises,
I would avoid having any desire to come out of it bearing a hot little poem
in my hand.  Rather the idea is to open out in general, to enjoy doing
nothing, to notice the subconscious (I have an idea that it can get quite
crotchety if ignored constantly or indeed if it feels one is exploiting it
for creative software),  to remember that I have a body.

Yes and yes to reading aloud.  And to noticing.

Randolph Healy

Date:         Tue, 29 Jul 1997 08:12:17 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Robert Hale <hale@ETAK.COM>
Subject:      Re: elaborating multiples
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

The characterization of various poets as later-day practioners of various
schools could apply to anyone, anytime, anyplace, and threatens to spark
another banal influence/originality thread. The issue is how and why do
these poets use these influences time and again to write. As far as changing
forms constantly -- that's a good thing, but as a reading of your own work,
it takes on characteristics of progress, evolution and technology.
Critiquing one's own work is a bit like the transference in psychoanalysis.
This would eclipse the idea that you can "do whatever you want in poetry,"
also the historical determinism you outline is still a specter to us all.
I'm sure you would agree that history is still dialectical (despite the
power of the irony you describe), and its tensions give rise to the choices
poets make in how and what they write.

At 03:37 PM 7/23/97 -0400, you wrote:
>Thanks very much, Jordan, for suggesting that I might say more! What could
>be more fun than elaborating!
>
>        I think, in this case, that Henry Gould's comment is almost
>exactly what I mean--a conscious multiplicity of form in a writer might
>seek a radical alteration of formal perspective from book to book, from
>poem to poem, or even within a single poem. It's one of the things my own
>poetry has been about, frankly. My first book was very much about
>shifts in perspective from line to line; I've done very lyrical work like
>in my Standing Stones chapbook and in things like the Oblek anthology; I
>published a book of Sonnets last year (not quite traditional ones); I've
>worked with chance and "deterministic" techniques in an issue of Abacus;
>and my soon to be available Edge Book might be taken for Ron Silliman-like
>parataxis if I
>didn't so consistently lack his intelligence. Some books I've done have
>been more or less in a single structure which I then don't use again;
>other things I've done shift structure within the work. I published in
>AVEC, "The Necessity of Feet" a 12-page poem in which the
>form of each page was consciously different, and I've done that several
>other times as well. I've been pushing this structural shift within works
>lately; I've got a piece I think of as a long (about 50 page) poem in
>which I try to call up as many different structural shifts as I can think
>of, although certain structures do repeat (I'm not so interested in
>complete differences of structure as I am in the tension between
>similarity and difference in structure).
>
>So that's where I'm at. What this attempt has to do with the work of other
>writers of my generation is not clear. Certainly my attempt is NOT new or
>particular to this moment in time, but I'm less interested in whether it's
>new as in whether it feels worthwhile at this moment, and I think it does.
>By no means do I think of my own attempt as characterizing the work of
>other writers of my generation--it clearly does NOT characterize them, or
>at least more than some of them. But while I am sympathetic to Henry's
>assertion that the matter CAN'T be considered from merely a generational
>perspective, what I DO think is true is that many writers of my own
>generation (which is more or less yours, Jordan, I guess, maybe) have a
>different relation to the history of the poetries we've
>read. And I think the difference is THIS; that because of historical
>circumstances, many of us have learned about more differing traditions of
>poetry than any previous generation of writers, which gives us both
>increasing options as well as increasing irony about the idea that some
>"new" direction in poetry is going to save or make anybody. Some of my
>langauge poetry friends describe coming up in a time where repression of
>poetic possibilities seemed the rule, but equally a time in which they
>seem to have felt that their poetic revolution would be heard, someplace
>or other. My own sense is more like I can do anything I want in poetry,
>with little chance of it being heard anywhere. This is a bit of an
>exaggeration, of course, but it's like what they say about freedom of
>speech in the U.S.--you can say what you want because nobody's
>listening. I don't, for the most part, encounter students or even
>professors who are "resistant" to formally experimental poetry, or who
>desire formally traditional verse. I encounter students and professors who
>usually don't read any contemporary poetry at all. There are obviously a
>few exceptions, but I do mean a FEW. And certainly it's true that more
>formally conservative approaches still get most of whatever CASH there is
>in poetry.
>
>Non-poetry people are probably not the point, of course, so I'll get
>back to the subject. In his forthcoming article, Mark Ducharme is right
>that my arguments don't DESCRIBE the writers of my generation. But I never
>meant them to. Still, what IS at stake in a description of such writers?
>And I think there are some pretty interesting answers here. If these
>writers are characterized by "diversity," then we're describing a kind of
>free-for-all smorgasborg of writers borrowing from various traditions all
>of which are okay. But we're not NECESSARILY describing writers with
>consciousness about form, or writers working out of any more than singular
>traditions. IN the worst case scenario, for my money, we all end up
>seeming borrowers of earlier and more vital traditions--Jordan Davis and
>Lee Ann Brown are latter-day New York School, Rod Smith and Jefferson
>Hansen are latter-day language poets, Jennifer Moxley likes traditional
>lyrics, Lisa Jarnot is just imitating Bernadette Mayer. And I've heard
>enough arguments LIKE that to know that the risk that things will be taken
>that way is real. But it would also, of course, be wrong.
>
>So I see a number of reasons for polemically asserting the value NOT of a
>free smorgasborg of traditions but of a conscious shifting, rearranging,
>and perhaps violating of the various poetic frameworks which existed
>before we did and which became part of our education. I'm not sure whether
>Joel's post indicated some annoyance with ME that these issues keep coming
>up, but as long as people keeping asking questions like "What's
>next?" I see a value in trying to answer them, even if part of that answer
>must be a deconstruction of the question. And the issue is NOT simply
>about anxiety regarding language poetry--it's about finding poetic
>structures that make SENSE as a response to the world in which we find
>ourselves. And I don't think that's a question that any poet can really
>avoid. My saying that, of course, won't make it so--I think where Mark D's
>point about diversity has the drop on me is that MY conviction about what
>matters will never be everybody else's. Thankfully, I guess, and not, I
>guess.
>
>Mark Wallace
>

On Tue, 29 Jul 1997 08:12:17 -0700 Robert Hale said:
>The characterization of various poets as later-day practioners of various
>schools could apply to anyone, anytime, anyplace, and threatens to spark
>another banal influence/originality thread. The issue is how and why do
>these poets use these influences time and again to write. As far as changing
>forms constantly -- that's a good thing, but as a reading of your own work,
>it takes on characteristics of progress, evolution and technology.
>Critiquing one's own work is a bit like the transference in psychoanalysis.
>This would eclipse the idea that you can "do whatever you want in poetry,"
>also the historical determinism you outline is still a specter to us all.
>I'm sure you would agree that history is still dialectical (despite the
>power of the irony you describe), and its tensions give rise to the choices
>poets make in how and what they write.

"Critiquing one's own work" does bring up the problem of recursive
logic or the endless hall of mirrors effect (if it's not just conflict of
interest).  Is it possible that in the real world poetry and criticism
work in tandem - the critics reading back into the work of the past in
the context of history & the clash of world-views in order to
discover authentic - deep sense - what redeems the time - & poets
meanwhile implanting "how to read" directions in their poems based on their
own prior critique/borrowings of past endeavors...
but then recursiveness is built into nature, & poets should be able to
talk about what they're doing, even if it's to lead astray -
& who are these poets & critics?  & what is authentic poetry?
do individuals exist in writing - or is there an impersonal standard
& an impersonal memory & a tradition implanted in languages we
are trying to re-enact?  (or overturn?)  Say what, Socrates?
Can you dance to it?  Repent to it?   ? = ?[?]
- Henry g.

Henry G [avuncular sideman / pseudonymous alterego / parallel-universe avatar:
the Double Life of Kenny G? -- pardon, just noting the letters] writes

<< "Critiquing one's own work" does bring up the problem of recursive
logic or the endless hall of mirrors effect . . . Is it possible that in the real world .
. . poets . . .implant... "how to read" directions in their poems . . . but then
recursiveness is built into nature, & poets should be able to talk about what
they're doing, even if it's to lead astray - & who are these poets & critics?  ....>>

that "recursiveness is built into nature" is one to ponder -- well said.

This discussion calls to mind (you'll pardon a putative mainstreamism?)
ex-laureate Mark Strand's little vol *The Monument*, which has (if memory
serves) an explicit conceit w.r.t. how it's intended to be read, to wit:

in translation.

The book claims (as I recall) that it's really written for purpose of being read
(centuries -- or so -- later) in translation.  I didn't happen to reach the  end of the
poem (but no matter, I was reading the English original, & so wouldn't "get it"
anyway).  Ergo can't elaborate on this authorial conceit; -- but perhaps this book
does address (or skirt around, or circumambulate, or carry to market, or . . . ) a
few of the issues that might be at issue here. ...

d.i.

In-Reply-To:  <E0wtQUX-0001rp-00@black.csi.cam.ac.uk>

Interested in hearing what people have to say about "quality
and quantity". That familiar "s/he's too prolific" can be pretty
irksome for poets at times. It is most frequently levelled at those
poets who are "experimenting" with language - one digression per
financial year being more than enough... Fiction writers tend
not to get it as much, and for "genre" writers it's usually seen
as a plus!

Best
JK

Subject:      Stentar Caeruleus (fwd)
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

--


Stentar Caeruleus


Breath leaves a carpse, carrying anly
Final banes af wards always, and anly
Skein af blaad and entrails, anly
Wards ance wet with mauth's tangue, anly

Palisades crest apen, merely
Carry crests af signs, sa merely
Spaken by the dead mauths, merely
Mauth wards wet and distraught, merely

Anly carpse blanks death's trap, breath
Anly banes and wards are ever final,
Anly entrails snare life's skein,
Anly tangues mauth dead wet wards,

Merely crassing palisades,
Merely farming crests that carry,
Merely what was never spaken,
Merely tangue sharn fram the mauth,

Merry, lanely, brat's skin af swards
Tarry fusillades, gare braken shauts.


_______________________________________________________________________

<<Interested in hearing what people have to say about "quality and
quantity". That familiar "s/he's too prolific" can be pretty
irksome for poets at times. It is most frequently levelled at those poets=

who are "experimenting" with language - one digression per financial year=

being more than enough... Fiction writers tend not to get it as much, and=

for "genre" writers it's usually seen as a plus!>>

i am never forget an ancient tv image of robert graves tough and wiry and=

game playing and bossy showing how he put together a poem line by line
draft by draft - there was more than an element of someone saying _This i=
s
how you must deal with bills of lading_

and then he summed up the page count per year, whatever it was, and said
_It's not very much, is it?_ with considerable satisfaction

it's a strange idea and in UK at least seems to be associated with the me=
an
spirited everything has gone down hill since we were romans nonsense,
culling bits of beauty from the wastes of time, the lonely poet strugglin=
g
for perfection

Some people produce more than others for sure but I can't see any
relationship between quantity and quality as such - there are certainly
those who might publish more interesting work if they looked at their
typescripts before issuing them - but being careless isnt the same thing =
as
being prolific

Subject:      Campus by night
MIME-Version: 1.0

GRIMEY OLIVE

Do emote.  Try.  Freesweet sugar.
In sheer night of sea-imitation
        Insistence of ground loop.
        Joint justification of the couplet.
    Awful good, pack your tick, cruel
    Bicker, bewilder thick, pointed
                Vilification of the luckwit.
                Another affecting trammel.
          A standing lunch rush.  In-
          Iquitously prep chef hopes
        Into leaf bed.  Must be moral
        Function, no peregrine langor.


HIRSUTE PEACH

        So-called edens of commodified melancholy
        To become uncritically devoted, disinherited
           Of lunch smite.  That's a bad bunch out to
           Accoutre the fields beyond your chill green lawn.
   Awful good bewilder, standing rush to freesweet
   Sugar in luckwit.  No peregrine langor, no nymph.
Joint justification of fore.  Low relief as
Grimey olives, hirsute peach, resistence at
              The core.  Intermittance is after all not
              Perturbed constance.  Do emotry.


                I[I]I   pdurgin@blue.weeg.uiowa.edu    I[I]I

(She had a grave loss.  You wouldn't know about this kind.)

She is alone.  He was so slight, and so precious, and she loved him
inhumanly.  The way you won't let her say, cause of the
stains
But he loved the stains and would smell them with his mouth open
(they have a special gland or receptor for smelling in the mouth, in the
memorymouth)and then lick 'em.  And he's dead,
Get it! Dead, like the ballerina I mentioned, dead of hunger and
struggle, but Him he died from a crushing force.  He's the lucky one, cause
She bears the weight now for ever.  A ten ton truck.
He was only the wieght of a snake.  He was only the size of her head and
he slept there and suckled and she should get
Prizes and Bills and Boyfriends galore for her strength in this matter, just
crying.  And soothing and sniffing and being herself which is wickedly
special.  But you don't care cause it's a drag to see sadness and hope
nonetheless.

From:         Christopher Alexander <calexand@ALEX.LIB.UTAH.EDU>

Subject:      Tax Bill Details
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT

I thought this might be of interest to some list members
(I hope so, anyway). it was forwarded to me from a local
(to me, that is) member of the National Association of
Graduate & Professional Students (I like that bit about
"professional students"), who are preparing to meet with
our local Representative, Merrill Cook, over some of the
issues raised below. best, Chris


------- Forwarded Message Follows -------

For all who have been in suspense of how the chips are
falling -- here's an update


7/24/97

NAGPS Update
Conference Report on Tax Bill Released
Kevin Boyer, NAGPS Executive Director


** Thanks to NAICU, CGS and the Chronicle of Higher Ed for help in
accessing this information **


The Republican agreement on the Tax Bill has been made public via a
report from the Joint Committee on Taxation titled "Summary of Conference
Agreeement Relating to the Major Revenue Provisions of HR 2014 "The
Revenue Reconciliation Act of 1987."  NAGPS is still attempting to get
clarification on some of the provisions of interest to grad students.
This update will focus just on graduation/professional students - a
future update may broaden the information to include various tax
proposals of interest to undergraduates.

1.      117d - WE WIN!

        As promised over the last 3 weeks, section 117d of the Internal
Revenue Code was not eliminated from the tax code in the conference bill.
Though language does not appear in the summary, this is being interpreted
as an indication that the conferees chose to leave Section 117d of the
Internal Revenue Code alone.  NAGPS was promised by conferees' staff that
graduate teaching and research assistants would be protected ("we get the
message," they said).  The tax exemption of undergraduate tuition benefits
for faculty, staff and dependents of university employees appears to have
also survived.  Many have suggested to us that the work of the grad
students on the tuition waiver tax issue may have pulled the faculty/staff
benefits with it in the minds of the conferees.  We are thrilled that the
Senate position prevailed, and appreciate the hard work of the House
members (both Republican and Democratic) who worked to ensure 117d
remained part of the tax code.

2.      127 - WE LOSE!

        Section 127 of the Internal Revenue Code allows for employer
provided educational assistance to be given to an employee without that
benefit accruing tax on the first $5,250 of the benefit.  Present law
expired for undergraduate tuition on 5/31/97, and for graduate tuition on
6/30/96.  The Senate position was to make Section 127 permanent for
undergrads and grads.  The House position was to extend Section 127 for
undergrads only through 12/31/97.  The conferees chose to extend Section
127 for undergrads only through 6/30/00 (3 years).

        We are disappointed in this development and we urge students and
their families to contact the White House to ask that the president push
for the original Senate position in this legislation.  The Senate
position has broad bipartisan support in both the House and the Senate.

3.      Student Loan Interest Deduction - WE WIN!

        If this legislation becomes law, student loan interest will be tax
deductible for the first time since 1986!  This has been at the top of the
NAGPS legislation agenda for 10 years and we are ecstatic that the Senate
provision survived the conference.  President Clinton has indicated
strong support for this provision, as well. Thanks should go to the
Senators on the Finance committee, particularly Senators Grassley,
Moynihan and Roth, for their support of this provision.

        The win is not completely untainted, however.  The original Senate
provision allowed for an up to $2,500 deduction for interest payments for
the first five years of repayment.  This provision would have been
phased out for single taxpayers earning between $40K and $50K.  Married
taxpayers would have had the phase out between $80K and $100K if filing
jointly.  The conference position increases the phaseout for single
taxpayers, phasing out between $40K and $50K.  The married phase out,
however, was dropped to from between $60 and $75K.  This reduction
essentially punishes married couples if both work.

        The idea behind the $2,500 deduction is to help graduate students
manage their post-graduation debt.  This debt for some professional
students exceeds $100,000.  NAGPS supports a return to the original Senate
position on the married couples phase out and we will urge the President
to stand firm to avoid this marriage penalty.

4.      Tuition Tax Credit - UNCLEAR

        The conference position on tuition tax credits is not yet clear
to us.  The conferees accepted the Senate position of a $1,500 credit for
the first two years of college (Hope scholarship).  However, the tuition
tax credit beyond the first two years is only 5% of up to $5,000 in
expenses.  (This translates to a $250 reduction in tax liability for
those paying $5,000 or more in tuition).  The Joint Conference Committee
report says "5% credit for up to $5,000 of expenses for education after
second year of college."  On the surface, this would seem to imply that
graduate education would qualify for the tuition tax credit, as well.
However, today's Wall Street Journal says that the tax credit is
available for students in their 3rd and 4th years of college.  The WSJ
article doesn't suggest that the credit will NOT be available for
graduate education - indeed, the WSJ reporter may not have even thought
of graduate education.

        NAGPS has phone calls into the tax staffers to gain clarification
on this issue.

        If graduate education qualifies for a tuition tax credit, we will
be pleased to have something in this part of the bill.  However, this is
a far cry from the President's proposal of a 20% tax credit on up to
$5,000 in tuition through the year 2000 and 20% tax credit on up to
$10,000 in tuition  afterward.  The President's proposal is 4 times
better over the next 3 years and 8 times better after that.  While a $250
credit would be welcome, NAGPS continues to strongly favor the
President's proposal.  We will be asking the President to clarify the tax
credit to ensure that it goes for graduate education, and ask him to
negotiate for a higher tax credit than 5%.

5.      IRA withdrawals - WE WIN!

        The proposal to allow for penalty-free withdrawals from all IRAs
for undergraduate, post-secondary vocational, and graduate education
expenses was included in the compromise bill.

6.      Education IRAs - WE WIN!

        The Senate proposal to allow for Education IRAs that could be
used, tax-free, for undergraduate and graduate education was included in
the compromise bill (the House version would have extended many of the
benefits to undergraduate tuition only).

####

In summary, the Conference Agreement provides some real tangible tax
relief to graduate/professional students.  We are relieved that in many
cases, the Senate negotiators prevailed on the Senate position, since the
House bill had little or nothing in it that focused on graduate education.

NAGPS is disappointed that some of the provisions in the Senate bill were
apparently lost in conference.  We are particularly concerned about
Section 127, the married income phase-out for the Student Loan Interest
Deduction, and the decision to lower the tuition tax credit beyond the
first two years of school (and the lack of clarity on this issue as it
applies to graduate education).

Interested graduate/professional students should communicate a strong
pro-education message to the White House, asking that the President
continue to strongly negotiate for the provisions that were in his
original proposals and which will benefit graduate education.  We
appreciate the President's support of graduate/professional education and
encourage him to keep this vital segment of our nation's post-secondary
educational system at the top of his list when negotiating with the Congress.

Specific details on the message we will recommend, and to whom you should
direct your comments will be forthcoming in the next several hours.  In
the meantime, you may direct email messages to the President at
president@whitehouse.gov, and to the Vice President at
vice-president@whitehouse.gov.  Watch our web site for sample text,
additional contact names, numbers and email addresses, and more updates.

In summary, NAGPS is very proud of the role we have played in preserving
tax benefits for the nation's graduate TAs and RAs.  But we are even
prouder of the strong citizen advocacy of our nation's
graduate/professional students.  Those of you who exercised your
democratic right to participate in the political process are really the
reason we saved 117d, and your voices were definitely heard.  Please
don't stop now - negotiations on the tax bill continue, and
appropriations legislation and higher education reauthorization
legislation now take center stage.  Without your voices, NAGPS is not as
strong in Washington, DC.



..
Christopher W. Alexander etc.
nominative press collective

calexand@library.utah.edu
P.O. Box 522402 / Salt Lake City UT 84152-2402

http://choengmon.lib.utah.edu/~calexand/nonce

From:         Hugh Steinberg <hsteinberg@GRIN.NET>
Subject:      Re: Quantity & Quality
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

John Kinsella writes:

>Interested in hearing what people have to say about "quality
>and quantity". That familiar "s/he's too prolific" can be pretty
>irksome for poets at times. It is most frequently levelled at those
>poets who are "experimenting" with language - one digression per
>financial year being more than enough... Fiction writers tend
>not to get it as much, and for "genre" writers it's usually seen
>as a plus!

Actually, I've heard mention of the "Joyce Carol Oates" effect, where the
prolificacy of the writer overwhelms the reader, leading to a sort of
ho-hum response irregardless of the quality of the book at hand.

Also, speaking more specifically of poets here, there is often a huge gap
between what is written and what is published.  Even when I keep all my
poems in the mail for consideration, my success rate is usually only one in
ten. It takes months to get a response, and if I'm lucky enough to get
accepted, six months or more will pass before the poem actually is in
print. Sometimes it will apppear as if I'm being prolific because several
publications will occur at roughly the same time, but those poems may have
been written over the course of years (I just got a poem accepted that's
seven years old).

I don't think quantity vs. quality is a particularly useful way of looking
at writing or writers.  Is George Oppen or Elizabeth Bishop good or bad
poets because they didn't write that many poems?  Is Allen Ginsberg a good
or bad poet because he did write a lot of poems?  Do all the lousy poems a
writer cranks out make the good poems less good?  Do long periods of
silence drown out good writing?  Some writers churn out lots of work,
others don't.  Some are vegetarians, others like really greasy
cheeseburgers.  I'd like to think poems are judged irregardless of any
writer's work (or eating) habits.

Hugh Steinberg

Subject:      Re: Quantity & Quality

Hugh Steinberg wrote:

>John Kinsella writes:
>
>>Interested in hearing what people have to say about "quality
>>and quantity". That familiar "s/he's too prolific" can be pretty
>>irksome for poets at times. It is most frequently levelled at those
>>poets who are "experimenting" with language - one digression per
>>financial year being more than enough... Fiction writers tend
>>not to get it as much, and for "genre" writers it's usually seen
>>as a plus!
>
>Actually, I've heard mention of the "Joyce Carol Oates" effect, where the
>prolificacy of the writer overwhelms the reader, leading to a sort of
>ho-hum response irregardless of the quality of the book at hand.

This is Kevin Killian and this is so true!

I was reading this book "Robert Penn Warren" by Joseph Blotner and
thinking, if Robert Penn Warren writes one more book of poetry and wins one
more Pulitzer Prize I'm going to break down in tears!  Finally, he dies
(oops, should have used some spoiler space).  Anyway I knew very little
about Robert Penn Warren before reading this book and now I feel I know too
much.

How about the Janet Dailey scandal?  (She is the US romance writer who,
confronted with charges that she plagiarized a few of her books from the
work of Nora Roberts, confessed to her fans that in 1990 and 1991 she was
suffering from a psychological disturbance she did not, until now, even
know she had!)  I say, if one could write 200 books oneself, why steal 1 or
2 from one's rival . . . the Eve Harrington to one's own Margo Channing.

>I don't think quantity vs. quality is a particularly useful way of looking
>at writing or writers.

I do.  Maybe not at writing but at writers.  There's a psychological
disturbance in writing in any case.  "Are George Oppen or Elizabeth Bishop
good or bad poets because they didn't write that many poems?"  In Oppen's
case the poems he wrote in later life suggest to me a desperation about
catching up after 25 years of silence, guilt about Stalinism, guilt about
bowing to whoever or whatever it was told him to stop writing, etc.  In
Bishop's case there was the alcoholism and the tension about keeping her
sexual life a secret.  Yet these two actually managed to write quite a bit.
I'm sure both of them had days when they sat there trying to remember in
which book did I have the image of the fish, etc.

We all know writers who have written way too much, though we do not speak
their names, perhaps due to an obscure reaction to our own feeling of
living in a glass house!  In the Penn Warren book he is often quoted as
complaining that X or Y have "written themselves out," a kind of
self-erasure like a Max Fleischer cartoon of the eraser working its way
backwards around the outlined figure.

In San Francisco I go to a lot of poetry readings and am constantly trying
to maintain my composure when someone gets up to the stage and says, this
poem is in fifty numbered sections each with seven parts and an epigraph
from Levinas and I wrote it in response to, then they look out at the
audience and sigh, oh, I should just read the poem.  And I'm there
mumbling, no, what you should do is read for about eleven minutes and use
the rest of the time to go home and do the laundry.

 PS, John Kinsella, have these charges (or "writing too much") been
levelled at you?

Thanks.
--A querulous San Francisco crank.

From:         Gwyn McVay <gmcvay1@OSF1.GMU.EDU>
Subject:      Overglossing a reading--was Re: Quantity & Quality
In-Reply-To:  <l03102800b005e1beed9e@[205.134.245.104]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

The over-glossing thing can turn a reading into self-parody before
syllable one of the poem has been spoken. I was at a reading in New York
State this summer where the poet confessed charmingly that she was making her
"very own Zen rock garden" in her back yard by lugging around rocks--and
then offered a dark aside, with a little laugh, that she spent so much
time back of the house out lugging around rocks that her husband (whom she
glanced at) probably thought she was having an affair. This was rather
more than I wanted to know, and I don't remember the poem nearly so well
as its intro.

o well. Your mileage may vary.
Gwyn

>In San Francisco I go to a lot of poetry readings and am constantly trying

>poem is in fifty numbered sections each with seven parts and an epigraph
>from Levinas and I wrote it in response to, then they look out at the
>audience and sigh, oh, I should just read the poem.  And I'm there
>mumbling, no, what you should do is read for about eleven minutes and use
>the rest of the time to go home and do the laundry.

Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>

From:         Rachel Kubie <rkubie@EROLS.COM>
Subject:      Quality & Quantity
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

also think arrogance toward quantity has to do with the set form of print
& the idea of history, where a poem is "something made" & done &
(following Lawrence) a little example of perfection--therefore we can be
suspicious of quantity cuz it smacks of the contiuous present.  In  more
living circumstances--for example a bar or cafe group that meets on a
regular basis for open mics, where participants may feel compelled to do
something their friends haven't heard before, or the poetry in Emily
Dickinson's letters-- the poet seems to feel the need to meet each new
occasion with creative force. Experimental poetry also seems very much to
be acting on present, immediate needs. It's maybe a question of whether
the poetry is *meant* to be a single object that stands against time or a
continuous act of invention which is also engaged in the flow of it?

At 10:49 AM -0400 7/31/97, Gwyn McVay wrote:
>The over-glossing thing can turn a reading into self-parody before
>syllable one of the poem has been spoken. I was at a reading in New York
>State this summer where the poet confessed charmingly that she was making her
>"very own Zen rock garden" in her back yard by lugging around rocks--and
>then offered a dark aside, with a little laugh, that she spent so much
>time back of the house out lugging around rocks that her husband (whom she
>glanced at) probably thought she was having an affair. This was rather
>more than I wanted to know, and I don't remember the poem nearly so well
>as its intro.
>
>o well. Your mileage may vary.
>Gwyn

i myself have been guilty of such excessive self-disclosure. at one panel,
i was surrounded by other panelists, in very adanced states of pregnancy
and with large diamond studded rings announcing their matrimonial
respectability. they even made comments about it during their talks, which
brimmed over w/ feminine/feminist-theological imagery of the old school.
this put me over the edge so when i got up to do my thing i crankily
announced that i was not pregnant, not married, not christian and probably
not really a woman.  they felt terrible of course and i felt some remorse.
on another occasion, the queer beats conference in fact, i don't really
know what i said, but at the party afterward, robert gluck was describing
some text or other to me as an "abject narrative," then said, "well, you've
probably written some of those yourself."

>In San Francisco I go to a lot of poetry readings and am constantly trying
>to maintain my composure when someone gets up to the stage and says, this
>poem is in fifty numbered sections each with seven parts and an epigraph
>from Levinas and I wrote it in response to, then they look out at the

>mumbling, no, what you should do is read for about eleven minutes and use
>the rest of the time to go home and do the laundry.

On the other hand, I remember hearing Thom Gunn read when I was an
undergraduate, I think even a bare freshman. Thom was/is pretty amazing,
but his long introduction to his poem Moly (I believe this was the one)
included a full reading of a Robert Duncan poem which had occasioned Gunn
to write his poem. It was the first I had heard of Duncan, and it seemed
that the Duncan poem was so marvelous and rich that it overshadowed Gunn's
poem. Still, I owe it to Gunn that I began from that point to read Duncan's
work. And Gunn is still a poet I greatly respect as well. So, although it's
rare, very good things can happen in those long overtures to reading.

Judy Roitman wrrt:
> Let me only add that it is getting harder and harder for me to think of
> each piece in isolation from the life's work, both in my own work and in
> contemplating others' work.

"there are no individual poems" [almost writes"indivictual"]:
utterance (to the phoneme) as the intersection of proliferating
& un-/recoverable fields of relations (poetic, political, Literary,
& commercial radio all news all the time...). nothing stands against
time, only in it (whatever is/was the intention...)(whatever that
means). it's getting hard to separate my own wrtg from anybody
else's. (even foresworn the scare quotes). "evening swarms over
the" possibly a conflation of production & reception, or just an
awareness of process (every act inflects/inflected by...).

but I'm familiar with the feeling Kevin describes, that sort of
"enough, already" near-dread that's really just boredom. "yes,
go ahead, write one more" but I'm not driving you home. (as
opposed to "talk all you want, baby, but then..."). not sure
what it wld mean to evaluate a wrter on this basis, though=97
I've always taken it to have more to do with my own limits (if
not limitations). of course, I'm not terribly prolific myself...
"not to make them too too evident". can someone elaborate?
("maybe not such a careful reader after all"). the ones in
parenthesis are whispers.

Subject:      Re: Quality & Quantity
In-Reply-To:  Message of Thu, 31 Jul 1997 13:00:43 -0500 from

>>also think arrogance toward quantity has to do with the set form of print
>>& the idea of history, where a poem is "something made" & done &
>>(following Lawrence) a little example of perfection--therefore we can be
>>suspicious of quantity cuz it smacks of the contiuous present.  In  more
>>living circumstances--for example a bar or cafe group that meets on a
>>regular basis for open mics, where participants may feel compelled to do
>>something their friends haven't heard before, or the poetry in Emily
>>Dickinson's letters-- the poet seems to feel the need to meet each new
>>occasion with creative force. Experimental poetry also seems very much to
>>be acting on present, immediate needs. It's maybe a question of whether
>>the poetry is *meant* to be a single object that stands against time or a
>>continuous act of invention which is also engaged in the flow of it?

Does there need to be a polarity between print & performance?
Of course there ARE differences.  But what if you looked
at a written/printed poem as a musical score.  Then writing might
be an aid to composition (in quantity large or small).  & writing might
make POSSIBLE multi-dimensional performances, as opposed to one-time
"unrecorded" hits (or one-time recorded hits).
   I like the idea of a further integration of print & performance.  On
every level.  Real poems never stand against time - they re-express time
& enrich time.  Why are present needs IMMEDIATE?  Because they are impoverished
- they lack the meta-time represented in poetry & memory.  Does so-called
experimental poetry renounce memory & history in order to mimic (& therefore
"play a role" in) so-called "present needs"?  Somebody (Stevens) said the
purpose of poetry is to help people live their lives (do I have that right?).
We know what impoverishment is & that it asks for a response.  Is mimicry
& participation the only response?  Maybe it's a better response than
the offer of elite traditions & values.  But it might not be the only
response.  Ignoring history & what's been done (in print, in performance)
is an experiment in conformity (the flip side of uncritical imitation).
- Henry Gould

Date:         Thu, 31 Jul 1997 16:07:41 -0400

From:         James Finnegan <JforJames@AOL.COM>
Subject:      Re: Crankiness: Quantity & Quality

The quantity v. quality argument can get tiresome.
But when I see a writer who seems to spill out
page after page after page with little regard to
what's there, what's been written, it often seems
to me that the writer's ignoring an implied contract
between writer & reader: "your (the reader's) time
will not be wasted by engaging this material, because
of the effort I (the writer) put into the product." What
we too often get is ego-driven wordspew--I wrote it,
so it must be wonderful, profound, entertaining...
Often I don't see any labor in the writing--I know Ginsberg's
dictum of "first thought, best thought," but I don't
like to think of that as an easy excuse for not
weighing one's words on the page, for not making hard
decisions: "this is better, than that--this is worth
publishing, this should be dropped in a bottom drawer
or the recycle bin."

There are some writers who need to lift their heads up
from the page/screen and look around--to check to see
if anybody's really reading those reams of brilliance
their unreeling. Actually the internet is a perfect great
black hole waiting for such writing--it can be laid out
there in cyberspace and the writer can pretend thousands
of interested readers are partaking of his/her bounty. "If you
build it (my own personal webpage), they will come." Atleast
the trees won't suffer from the profligacy of a too-prolific poet.

Finnegan
